site_title: Punchlines: May 1, 2017
summary: ST's Punchlines is a Singaporean newspaper section. The article, dated May 1, 2017, likely featured a collection of humorous one-liners or jokes. However, no specific content is provided.

site_title: Eleven killed in Pakistan van plunge: Officials
summary: At least 11 people, including women and children, were killed in a van plunge into a ravine in Pakistan's mountainous north-west on April 30. The van, carrying over capacity, lost control on a slippery road and fell into a 46m deep ravine, killing everyone on board. Nine others were wounded, four critically. The accident highlights Pakistan's poor road safety record due to poorly maintained vehicles and reckless driving.

site_title: Qatar upholds rare death sentence in UK teacher's murder
summary: A Qatari court has upheld the death penalty for a man convicted of murdering a 24-year-old British teacher, Lauren Patterson, in 2013. Badr Hashim Khamis Abdallah al-Jabr was found guilty of stabbing Patterson and burning her body in the desert. The original verdict was quashed, but a retrial resulted in the death penalty being reinstated. The rare use of capital punishment in Qatar, last carried out in 2003, was upheld by the court, with the judge dismissing all aspects of Jabr's defence and citing "several consequential strands of evidence" pointing to his guilt.

site_title: Tennis: Red-hot Rafael Nadal wins 'dream' 10th Barcelona Open
summary: Rafael Nadal won his 10th Barcelona Open with a 6-4, 6-1 victory over Dominic Thiem. The win marks a "dream start" to his clay court season, following his 10th title at the Monte Carlo Masters last week. Nadal, 14-time Grand Slam champion, praised the club for naming a court after him and credited his win as a confidence booster ahead of the French Open. Nadal has now won 19 straight sets, with Thiem being the toughest opponent he's faced on clay this year.

site_title: Japan warship to escort US supply vessel in Pacific: Reports
summary: Japan will dispatch its helicopter carrier Izumo to escort a US supply ship in the Pacific on May 1, 2017, amid rising tensions over North Korea. The move is the first outside of troop exercises to protect the US fleet, following Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's expansion of Japan's military capabilities in 2015. The US supply ship will support the naval fleet, including the aircraft carrier USS Carl Vinson, on high alert over North Korea's ballistic missile firings. The deployment aims to counter North Korea's threats, with US President Donald Trump warning of a "major conflict" with the regime.

site_title: Two motorcycles catch fire in Jurong West carpark
summary: Two motorcycles caught fire in an open carpark in Jurong West, Singapore, on April 30 at around noon. No injuries were reported. The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) responded to the incident and extinguished the fire using compressed air foam and a waterjet. The cause of the fire is currently under investigation by the SCDF.

site_title: Malay/Muslim community leaders call on community to fight drug scourge
summary: Malay/Muslim community leaders in Singapore are launching an anti-drug campaign, "Dadah itu Haram" (Drugs are Forbidden), to combat the growing issue of drug abuse among the community. Figures show that Malays account for more than half of drug abusers arrested in 2016, with 1,700 arrests in 2016 alone. The campaign aims to spread awareness and encourage community members to take responsibility in shielding their friends and family from drug abuse, emphasizing that drugs are forbidden in Islam.

site_title: Persian satellite TV channel owner 'shot dead in Istanbul'
summary: Turkish authorities confirmed the shooting death of British-Iranian satellite TV channel owner Said Karimian in Istanbul on Saturday. Karimian, owner of GEM TV Group, was gunned down along with a Kuwaiti business partner in the upscale Maslak district. The assailants escaped in a burned-out vehicle, and police are still searching for them. Karimian was a British citizen of Iranian origin and had faced disdain from Iran over his channel's Western programming, which was seen as culturally infiltrating the population and Westernizing their lifestyle.

site_title: Football: Newly elected FAS president Lim Kia Tong sends letter of thanks to all 44 affiliates
summary: Lim Kia Tong, the newly elected FAS president, sent a letter to 44 affiliates on April 29 expressing gratitude for their participation in the historic elections. Team LKT secured a two-thirds majority with 30 votes, defeating the Game Changers 30-13. Despite a close competition, both teams showed sportsmanship, with Hougang United's Bill Ng accepting the result and supporting the new council. Lim vowed to work with anyone with generous ideas to take Singapore football forward, and urged all affiliates to support the FAS in its efforts to bring glory to the game.

site_title: Asean presses peaceful resolution of territorial conflicts
summary: Southeast Asian leaders issued a statement reiterating the need for a peaceful resolution of disputes in the South China Sea, avoiding direct references to China's island-building and military deployment. The statement, released by Asean chair Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte, emphasized the importance of mutual trust and confidence, and called for the pursuit of peaceful resolutions without resorting to force. The softer stance was seen as a compromise with China, but may create frustration among some Asean member states, including those that previously took a more robust stance on the issue.

site_title: 4 men injured after taxi explodes on Commonwealth Avenue
summary: A taxi exploded on Commonwealth Avenue in Singapore on April 30, 2017, injuring four men, including a Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) officer, who suffered minor burns. The likely cause of the explosion was a road traffic accident that occurred several minutes prior to the explosion. The injured individuals were taken to the National University Hospital, with one of the SCDF officers later discharged and recovering. Eyewitnesses reported a loud explosion, smoke, and a burnt smell at the scene, and investigations by the Police, SCDF, and LTA are ongoing.

site_title: Tennis: WTA partners Porsche in year-ender Finals' Race to Singapore campaign
summary: The Women's Tennis Association (WTA) has partnered Porsche in a multi-year deal to be the title sponsor for the "Porsche Race to Singapore" qualification campaign to the BNP Paribas WTA Finals Singapore presented by SC Global. The partnership, which strengthens the WTA's long-standing relationship with Porsche, will feature a Porsche 911 GTS Cabriolet as the grand prize for the player finishing the season as No. 1 on the leaderboard. The campaign will culminate in the 2017 WTA Finals in Singapore from October 22-29.

site_title: Football: Moyes unsure about future after Sunderland drop
summary: Sunderland manager David Moyes expressed uncertainty about his future after the team's relegation from the Premier League. Moyes stated that he would not confirm whether he would remain as manager next season, saying it's too early to think about it. He emphasized that the team's relegation is a collective issue, not just an individual problem. Moyes' future is expected to be reassessed during the close season, with Sunderland captain John O'Shea suggesting potential changes to help the team bounce back and achieve Premier League football.

site_title: Football: Bayern on verge of fifth straight title after Leipzig held
summary: Bayern Munich is on the verge of securing its fifth consecutive Bundesliga title after a 22nd league win this season, leaving the team seven points clear of second-placed RB Leipzig with four games remaining. Leipzig's goalless draw against Ingolstadt and Bayern's upcoming win over Wolfsburg will likely confirm the Bavarians as champions. Dortmund holds onto third place, which would secure a direct Champions League spot next season, while Hoffenheim can leapfrog Dortmund if they beat Eintracht Frankfurt on Sunday.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, May 1 edition
summary: US President Donald Trump invited Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to the White House to strengthen ties between Singapore and the US. Trump called Lee for their second conversation since his presidency and expressed satisfaction over their existing relationship. Meanwhile, tensions with North Korea remain high, with Trump praising leader Kim Jong Un as "a pretty smart cookie." Chelsea secured a 3-0 win over Everton, cutting the gap to four points in the Premier League title hunt. The Fate of the Furious continued to dominate the box office, passing the $1 billion mark worldwide.

site_title: US Marines back in Helmand as Afghanistan 'stalemate' continues
summary: US Marines have returned to Helmand province in southern Afghanistan to train Afghan forces amid a "stalemate" in the conflict. The deployment comes as the Afghan army struggles to contain the Taliban insurgency, which has pushed back forces in the province and controls large stretches of land. The Marines' mission is to train and assist Afghan forces, but the deployment occurs at a challenging time, following a devastating attack on the Afghan army in the northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif and a recent "green on blue" incident at Camp Shorab.

site_title: Chicken rice boss calls taxi driver to say sorry, will give 200 packets of chicken rice to cabbies
summary: Mr Gary Lim, 37, the boss of The Yang's Traditional Hainanese Chicken Rice, has apologized to a taxi driver, Sun, after a viral video showed him blocking the cabby's way and mocking him. Lim has promised to give 200 packets of chicken rice to taxi drivers as a gesture of goodwill, to be distributed on May 2. Lim had initially apologized to Sun over the phone, acknowledging he was drunk and made senseless comments, and Sun accepted the apology, advising Lim to treat others with respect and move forward.

site_title: NBA: Rudy 'The Stifle Tower' Gobert crucial to Utah Jazz's play-off hopes
summary: Utah Jazz center Rudy Gobert is crucial to the team's playoff hopes, but his shaky health has raised concerns. Gobert twisted his left ankle in Game Six, his second injury in the series, and is expected to be ready for Game Seven but may not be at full strength. The 24-year-old's absence has exposed the team's vulnerability without him, particularly in the paint, where DeAndre Jordan has thrived. Gobert's importance was highlighted in the regular season, where he led the NBA in blocks and was a key factor in the team's turnaround.

site_title: Donald Trump invites Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte to White House in phone call
summary: US President Donald Trump invited Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte to the White House in a phone call, discussing regional security concerns and the North Korean threat. The meeting, likely to take place in November, will be part of Trump's summits with Asian nations. The conversation also touched on the Philippine government's efforts to combat the country's opioid crisis. No specific date or details for the White House meeting were provided.

site_title: Pope calls for end to violence, respect for human rights, in Venezuela
summary: Pope Francis called for an end to violence and respect for human rights in Venezuela, where nearly 30 people were killed in unrest this month. The Pope decried a grave humanitarian crisis and appealed to the government and opposition to avoid violence and seek a negotiated solution. Venezuela's opposition demands elections, autonomy, humanitarian aid, and freedom for jailed activists. The Vatican-led talks have broken down, with the Pope stating "very clear conditions" are necessary for their resumption.

site_title: Tennis: Gutsy Mladenovic ends Sharapova comeback at Stuttgart
summary: Maria Sharapova lost to Kristina Mladenovic in the semi-finals of the Stuttgart tournament, her comeback from a 15-month doping ban ending in defeat. Sharapova, a five-time Grand Slam winner, lost 3-6, 7-5, 6-4, after Mladenovic rallied to take the second set and the match. Mladenovic, a vocal critic of Sharapova's return, said she was "very happy" with her victory, while Sharapova praised Mladenovic's play, saying she needed match practice after her enforced break.

site_title: Egypt urges US to play 'active' Middle East peace role
summary: Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi urged the US to play an active role in restarting Middle East peace negotiations between Israel and Palestinians, stating the two-state solution is key to regional stability. Sisi's call comes after a meeting with Palestinian President Mahmud Abbas, who will meet US President Donald Trump on Wednesday. The US should base its solution on the 2002 Arab peace initiative, which offers normalized relations with Israel in exchange for resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

site_title: Hollywood star Leonardo DiCaprio joins thousands marching in Washington to protest Trump climate policies
summary: US actor Leonardo DiCaprio joined thousands of protesters in Washington to show support for climate-change science and oppose President Donald Trump's rollbacks of environmental protections. The People's Climate March, held on the 100th day of Trump's presidency, drew tens of thousands of people, many carrying signs and banners criticizing the president's climate scepticism and environmental policies. The march called for greater emphasis on renewable energy sources and warned against the danger of inaction by the Trump administration, which has pulled out of the Paris climate accord.

site_title: Football: Jose Gimenez may miss Atletico's Champions League semi-final clash at Real
summary: Atletico Madrid defender Jose Gimenez may miss the Champions League semi-final first leg against Real Madrid due to a groin injury. Gimenez, who has deputised at right-back, suffered a muscular injury in his left adductor during Saturday's 5-0 win over Las Palmas. The injury will be further tested in the coming hours. Atletico, who have been beaten by Real in the past three Champions League finals, will travel to the Santiago Bernabeu in good form after a dominant win, moving three points clear of Sevilla in LaLiga.

site_title: With clear mandate, all eyes are on new FAS leaders to improve local football
summary: The Football Association of Singapore (FAS) has elected Team LKT as its new council with a clear mandate to improve local football. The team, comprising many members from the previous council, won the election with a resounding victory, receiving a two-thirds majority in less than 30 minutes. The new council must address organizational issues, including transparency and governance, and put stronger checks and balances in place. Team LKT's deputy president, Bernard Tan, has vowed to be consultative and abide by the team's campaign promise. The new leaders face significant challenges to transform Singapore football, which has been criticized for its decline.

site_title: Hassan Rouhani warns voters to prevent 'extremism' returning to Iran
summary: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani warned voters in a May 19 election that if he loses to a hardline rival, they could face greater authoritarianism. Rouhani, who has been criticized by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei for his economic record, faces competition from hardliners such as Ebrahim Raisi and Mohammad Baqer Qalibaf. Rouhani's challengers have ties to Khamenei and have experience in the judiciary and military. Rouhani maintains support among young, urban voters who value social freedoms, but human rights activists say his administration has not achieved significant progress on personal freedoms or freeing political prisoners.

site_title: Golf: Jonas Blixt and Cameron Smith pull away at Zurich Classic
summary: Jonas Blixt and Cameron Smith maintained their four-stroke lead at the Zurich Classic of New Orleans after a bogey-free 68 on Saturday. The Swedish and Australian duo has played 54 holes without a bogey, outperforming all other teams. They will face Kevin Kisner and Scott Brown, and Charley Hoffman and Nick Watney in the final round, which will be played in a better ball format. The tournament is expected to be completed early due to forecasted storms on Sunday.

site_title: Golf: Ko out of LPGA Texas Shootout with eye infection
summary: Lydia Ko withdrew from the LPGA Texas Shootout due to an eye infection, potentially jeopardizing her world number one ranking. Ko was one over par through two rounds, trailing Ariya Jutanugarn by one shot. If Jutanugarn wins the tournament, Ko could lose her top spot. The infection, likely caused by pollen, forced Ko to stop wearing contact lenses.

site_title: Football: Ronaldo passes Greaves as Europe's top scorer
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo surpassed Jimmy Greaves as Europe's top scorer with 367 goals in top leagues, surpassing his 366 goals in 528 appearances. Ronaldo achieved this milestone with a goal against Valencia, while also holding Real Madrid's all-time record with 367 goals. Greaves, a 1966 World Cup winner, had previously held the record. Lionel Messi is close to overtaking Greaves with 345 La Liga goals.

site_title: Formula One: Mercedes' Valtteri Bottas wins his maiden F1 race at Russian Grand Prix
summary: Finland's Valtteri Bottas won his maiden Formula One race at the Russian Grand Prix on April 30, 2017, after jumping both Ferraris at the start and holding his nerve in the closing laps. Bottas finished 0.6 seconds behind Sebastian Vettel, who secured second place. This victory marked Bottas' first F1 win after 81 starts, replacing Nico Rosberg at Mercedes in January.

site_title: British PM Theresa May ‘not in a different galaxy’ over Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May denied being "in a different galaxy" after European Union leaders expressed dismay over her Brexit negotiating demands, saying she stood by her stance that "no deal was better than a bad deal". May rejected claims that her negotiating stance was unreasonable, stating she wants to ensure a trade deal and withdrawal arrangements are agreed upon. EU leaders have estimated the Brexit bill to be 40-60 billion euros, and the EU has called for a "serious response" from Britain on the rights of European citizens.

site_title: Tennis: Thiem beats Murray to make Barcelona final
summary: Dominic Thiem of Austria defeated world number one Andy Murray 6-2, 3-6, 6-4 to secure a spot in the Barcelona Open final. Thiem dominated the first set with three breaks of serve, while Murray struggled with form and fitness after an elbow injury. Thiem fought back from a break down in the third set to seal his win and set up a final against either Rafael Nadal or Horacio Zeballos.

site_title: Football: Kylian Mbappe's hot streak goes on as Monaco come from behind to go top of Ligue 1
summary: Monaco secured a 3-1 victory over Toulouse, moving three points clear at the top of Ligue 1 with 83 points from 34 games. Kylian Mbappe scored a stunning second goal, tormenting the Toulouse defense, and also set up teammate Thomas Lemar for the third goal. Monaco faces Juventus in the Champions League semi-final first leg on Wednesday, while Paris Saint-Germain trails by nine points. The win cements Monaco's position as the league leaders, ahead of PSG and Nice.

site_title: PM's May Day message: Singapore economy picking up, but unemployment also creeping up
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to pick up this year, with total employment expanding, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's May Day message. However, unemployment is also rising, reaching 2.3% in March, with some sectors struggling with structural changes. The PM urged a tripartite effort between workers, businesses, and the Government to ensure jobs for all, highlighting the need for adaptability, reskilling, and support for workers and businesses.

site_title: Selling imperfect food items a perfect way to reduce waste
summary: FairPrice, a Singaporean supermarket chain, has successfully reduced food waste by selling imperfect fruits and vegetables at a discount and donating unsold canned food. This approach can encourage others to adopt similar practices, such as reducing home food waste and ordering only portions that can be finished. Spreading awareness of the issue in schools and workplaces is also crucial. Several schools are already piloting a food-waste recycling system, which may soon be fully implemented across Singapore, setting an example for other supermarkets to follow.

site_title: Football: Monaco's Tiemoue Bakayoko a doubt for Champions League semi-final against Juve
summary: Monaco midfielder Tiemoue Bakayoko may miss the first leg of their Champions League semi-final against Juventus due to a broken nose sustained in training. Bakayoko broke his nose in a collision with Kamil Glik on Friday and sat out Monaco's 3-1 win over Toulouse on Saturday. Monaco coach Leonardo Jardim plans to wait two or three days to assess Bakayoko's condition, who will wear a mask and potentially delay surgery until the end of the season.

site_title: China manufacturing growth slows faster than expected in April
summary: China's manufacturing sector growth slowed to a six-month low of 51.2 in April, down from 51.8 in March, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. The slowdown was driven by weakening demand, with input prices declining sharply. Analysts attribute the decline to the de-leveraging efforts by the Chinese authorities, which have led to a decrease in iron ore and steel prices. The country's economy grew 6.9% in the first quarter, but growth is expected to slow as authorities step up efforts to cool the property sector and contain financial risks.

site_title: Formula One: Vettel on pole for Russian GP in Ferrari one-two
summary: Sebastian Vettel secured pole position for the Russian Grand Prix, leading Ferrari to their first front row lockout in nine years. Vettel outpaced teammate Kimi Raikkonen by 0.059 seconds, while Valtteri Bottas of Mercedes took third place. The result marked the end of Mercedes' 18-straight pole positions, and Ferrari's first front row lockout since 2008. Vettel's pole position also gave him his first of the year and his 47th of his career.

site_title: Car-Free Sunday back for April edition
summary: Car-Free Sunday returned on April 30, 2017, in Singapore's Central Business District and Civic District areas. The event featured various activities, including a treasure hunt, Share the Road Cycling Carnival, and a Personal Mobility Roadshow. Participants also enjoyed free trishaw rides and a bike train. The event promoted cycling and personal mobility as recreational activities, aiming to encourage a more sustainable and inclusive lifestyle.

site_title: Football: Patrice Evra fires broadside at compatriot Christophe Duggary
summary: French football defender Patrice Evra has fired a broadside at compatriot Christophe Dugarry, criticizing his remarks about Evra's performances. In response, Evra mocked Dugarry's relationship with Real Madrid coach Zinedine Zidane, calling him "the only person on earth" who knows about Zidane's personal life. Evra also stated that Dugarry can criticize him in person, challenging him to come to Marseille. Evra maintains that there is no issue between them, despite Dugarry's initial criticism.

site_title: Football: Chelsea take giant step towards Premier League title with impressive win at Everton
summary: Chelsea secured a 3-0 win over Everton at Goodison Park, moving closer to the Premier League title. Pedro scored the opening goal, and goals from Gary Cahill and Willian sealed the victory. Chelsea's next four fixtures appear straightforward, making a title win highly likely. Manager Antonio Conte's side showed "belief and quality" against Everton, according to Ronald Koeman, who acknowledged his team's superiority.

site_title: China-built amphibious aircraft takes maiden flight: Xinhua
summary: China's AG600, the world's largest amphibious aircraft, successfully completed its maiden flight ahead of schedule on April 29 from Zhuhai. Designed for firefighting, rescue, and ocean monitoring, the aircraft is part of China's military modernization efforts. The flight comes as China asserts its claims in the South China Sea, raising concerns in the Asia-Pacific region and the US. The AG600's maiden flight marks a significant milestone in China's military development, which includes anti-satellite missiles, stealth fighters, and a new indigenous aircraft carrier.

site_title: Italy's Renzi likely to win Democratic Party election
summary: Matteo Renzi, former Italian prime minister, is likely to regain the leadership of Italy's ruling Democratic Party (PD) with an overwhelming lead in a primary election. Renzi won about 75% of the vote, ahead of Justice Minister Andrea Orlando and Michele Emiliano, the governor of Puglia region. His current approval rating is about half of his previous 50% rating. Renzi's comeback may be crucial to fending off the anti-establishment 5-Star Movement, which questions Italy's euro membership. However, the party's chances of winning the most seats in parliament are uncertain due to Italy's proportional representation voting system.

site_title: South Korea says US reaffirms it will pay Thaad costs; joint drills wrap up
summary: The US has reaffirmed its commitment to deploying the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) system in South Korea, despite President Donald Trump's previous comments suggesting Seoul should pay for the $1 billion battery. In a phone call, US National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster assured South Korean officials that the US alliance with South Korea is its top priority and that the cost of the THAAD deployment is for Washington to bear. The deployment has drawn protests from China and local residents, while US-South Korean joint military drills have concluded. The US and South Korea say the THAAD system is designed to guard against North Korean missiles.

site_title: Win a chance to be a player escort at the Sultan of Selangor Cup
summary: The Sultan of Selangor Cup is hosting a contest for children aged 12 and below to become player escorts for the event. To participate, send an email with a 50-word explanation of why they deserve the opportunity, including name, NRIC, and contact number, to Contest@fas.org.sg by May 4, 12 noon. The best five submissions will be selected to walk out onto the National Stadium pitch with the Singapore Selection players. Winners will also get to watch the team train on Friday at the Sports Hub. Notification of winners will be sent by May 5.

site_title: Nine youths aged 14 to 16 arrested for rioting at void deck in Woodlands
summary: Nine youths aged 14-16 were arrested for rioting at a void deck in Woodlands, Singapore on April 27. An eyewitness alerted authorities after seeing police and students at the scene, describing a fight among the youths. The incident occurred at around 5:37pm and the police are still investigating. The youths were arrested, but no further details on their charges or circumstances surrounding the incident have been released.

site_title: Golf: Poulter to keep PGA Tour card after points structure adjusted
summary: English golfer Ian Poulter will keep his PGA Tour card after the tour recalibrated its FedEx Cup playoff points structure for players on major medical exemptions. Poulter, who was on his 10th and final event under the exemption, was initially worried he would lose his playing status after missing the cut at the Texas Open. However, the tour acknowledged its new system made it difficult for players to retain their exempt status, providing Poulter with a reprieve and allowing him to maintain his playing schedule.

site_title: Football: Decimated Manchester United held by lowly Swansea as injury jinx strikes again
summary: Manchester United suffered a blow to their top-four finish hopes with a 1-1 draw against Swansea City at Old Trafford. The result left United in fifth place with 65 points, while Swansea moved two points clear of the relegation zone. Manchester United's injury woes continued, with defenders Luke Shaw and Eric Bailly being taken off, and manager Jose Mourinho expressed concerns about the team's tiredness and exhaustion. The draw was a rare point for United, who are now relying on the Europa League to make the Champions League.

site_title: Football: Pep Guardiola chuffed with 'special' Gabriel Jesus but bemoans injury-enforced absence
summary: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola expressed his satisfaction with "special" Gabriel Jesus, who made a lively return from injury in a 0-0 draw with Manchester United. Jesus, who missed three months of the season due to a broken foot, has rejoined the team's top-four chase rather than a Premier League title challenge. Guardiola praises Jesus' work ethic and instinct, but notes the team's reliance on him and his potential impact on Sergio Aguero's playing time. The team's Champions League qualifying slot remains secure, but Guardiola is focused on the upcoming match against Middlesbrough.

site_title: Furious 8 charges ahead to outpace 3 new releases
summary: Universal's "The Fate of the Furious" continued to dominate the North American box office, taking in an estimated $19.4 million for the weekend and passing the $1 billion worldwide mark. The eighth installment in the high-octane series, starring Vin Diesel and Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, has grossed $192.7 million domestically in its three weeks out. Three new releases, "How to be a Latin Lover," "Baahubali: The Conclusion," and "The Circle," took second, third, and fourth place, respectively. The film's success cements its position as the top-grossing film of the weekend.

site_title: Divers search for 10 missing people as 27 drown in India
summary: At least 27 people drowned in India in two separate incidents, with emergency workers searching for the bodies of 10 missing people. In one incident, 13 people died after a dinghy capsized in a lake in southern Andhra Pradesh state due to overcrowding. In another incident, dozens of people were swept away after a jetty collapsed in eastern India's West Bengal state, with scores of divers and speed boats searching for the bodies of eight missing people.

site_title: Football: Sunderland relegated from Premier League after Bournemouth defeat
summary: Sunderland was relegated from the Premier League after losing 1-0 to Bournemouth at home, leaving them 13 points adrift with four games remaining. The loss ended the 10-year stay of the team in the top division. A draw between Hull City and Southampton also ensured Sunderland's relegation, with the Tigers earning a vital point in their own battle against the drop. Manager David Moyes expressed disappointment, saying the team had not given their fans enough this season.

site_title: Football: S'pore U-22s and U-20s to face Vanuatu in three friendlies this week
summary: Singapore's under-22 and under-20 national teams will face Vanuatu in three friendlies from May 1 to May 7. Vanuatu is preparing for the 2017 Under-20 World Cup in South Korea, where they will compete in Group B alongside Venezuela, Mexico, and Germany. The friendlies will take place at Choa Chu Kang, Queenstown, and Bishan stadiums. These matches will provide valuable experience for the teams as they prepare for the upcoming tournament.

site_title: 20 die in Colombia building collapse
summary: A six-storey building in Cartagena, Colombia, collapsed on Thursday, killing 20 people and injuring 16. A two-day rescue operation resulted in the saving of 41 people, including 16 with severe injuries. The cause of the collapse is under investigation by the Red Cross. A mass has been held for the victims, with 12 of the deceased identified so far.

site_title: Formula One: Renault's Jolyon Palmer suffers a blow to both car and ego
summary: Renault driver Jolyon Palmer suffered a setback at the Russian Grand Prix, crashing his car into the tyre barriers during qualifying. The crash damaged his car and dented his ego, with Palmer attributing it to his own mistake. Despite Renault's efforts to rebuild and replace the power unit, Palmer qualified 16th and is under pressure. With his team-mate Nico Hulkenberg scoring Renault's first points, Palmer remains uncertain about his future, with media speculation about his potential replacement at the end of the season.

site_title: Football: Stoke's Butland stars in West Ham stalemate
summary: Stoke City goalkeeper Jack Butland made several crucial saves to secure a 0-0 draw with West Ham United in the Premier League. Despite a strong West Ham performance, Butland's impressive displays prevented the visitors from winning. The draw was a valuable point for Stoke, who were virtually safe from relegation, while West Ham manager Slaven Bilic will feel they should have won. Butland's heroics, including a brilliant bicycle kick save from Andre Ayew, earned him praise from England manager Gareth Southgate.

site_title: Football: Vardy on target as Leicester beat West Brom 1-0
summary: Leicester City secured a 1-0 win over West Bromwich Albion, with Jamie Vardy scoring the decisive goal in the 43rd minute. The victory lifts Leicester to 11th place in the Premier League, nine points ahead of Swansea City, and takes them closer to safety. Vardy's 12th league goal of the season sealed the win, despite West Brom's second-half efforts, which included the introduction of James McClean. The loss drops West Brom to eighth place, and they have now lost their last four league games.

site_title: Chee Hong Tat 'concerned' about recent reports of TCM clinics offering sexual services
summary: Singaporean Minister of State for Health and Communications, Chee Hong Tat, has expressed concern over reports of traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) clinics being used as massage parlours offering sexual services. A police enforcement blitz raided 15 establishments across the country, arresting nine women, including those found to be offering sex to customers. Chee criticized TCM practitioners who allow such practices, saying they tarnish the industry's reputation and standing. The incident highlights the need for a united stand against negative practices within the industry.

site_title: Dozens detained as Russian protesters say 'sick of Putin'
summary: Hundreds of Russian opposition supporters protested against President Vladimir Putin's expected candidacy in 2018, with police detaining dozens in Saint Petersburg. The Open Russia movement, founded by former oil magnate Mikhail Khodorkovsky, called for Putin to step down, citing his 17-year rule as too long. The protests, held in several cities, were peaceful in Moscow but turned violent in Saint Petersburg, with over 125 people detained. The movement aims to galvanize the opposition movement ahead of the 2018 presidential election.

site_title: Stagger lunch breaks to ease seat crunch at food centres
summary: Singapore is considering staggering lunch breaks to ease the "seat crunch" at food centers, particularly hawker centers. The problem is that most office workers take a 1pm lunch break, resulting in a crowded and competitive environment. By staggering breaks to 12pm, 1pm, and 1:30pm, lunchtime crowds can be dispersed, and available seats can be shared with others. This mindset shift is seen as key to eradicating the "choping" culture, which has led to disputes over seating.

site_title: Football: Keita Balde ruins Franceso Totti's final derby for Roma
summary: Keita Balde scored twice to lead Lazio to a 3-1 win over Roma in a thrilling Serie A match on April 30, 2017, spoiling Francesco Totti's final derby as a player. The match, played at the Stadio Olimpico, saw Lazio dominate despite Roma's strong start, with Edin Dzeko and Daniele De Rossi scoring for the hosts. Dusan Basta's deflected shot and Balde's second goal sealed the victory for Lazio, ending Totti's Italian top-flight career.

site_title: Malaysia boys drown in stream during leadership course for students
summary: Three Malaysian schoolboys, aged 16 and 17, drowned while trekking along a man-made stream at the Eco Lake Resort in Membakut, Kota Kinabalu, as part of a leadership programme. The incident occurred when the group, including teachers, went off the designated route and slipped into a deeper part of the stream. The boys were pronounced dead at the hospital, while a 16-year-old girl was rescued by fellow students. An investigation was launched, and the Beaufort Fire and Rescue Department advised resort operators and teachers to inform authorities before trips to prevent similar incidents.

site_title: Tennis: Wild card Laura Siegemund wins Stuttgart title
summary: Germany's Laura Siegemund won the Stuttgart WTA tournament, defeating Kristina Mladenovic 6-1, 2-6, 7-6 (7/5) in the final. Siegemund, a wild card entry ranked 49th, claimed her second WTA win after a nearly two-and-a-half hour match. She won the title, a Porsche sports car, and €107,036, after Mladenovic, the 19th-ranked player, broke Siegemund in the second set, but ultimately couldn't hold off the German's comeback.

site_title: Boxing: Joshua defeats Klitschko in world heavyweight epic
summary: Britain's Anthony Joshua defeated Ukrainian Wladimir Klitschko in a world heavyweight title fight, winning on an 11th round stoppage. Joshua added the WBA title to his IBF belt, taking his record to 19 wins in 19 fights. Klitschko, 41, was knocked to the canvas multiple times, including in the 11th round, before Joshua's victory. Joshua praised Klitschko's heart and sportsmanship, and both fighters received tributes from the boxing community after the intense match at Wembley Stadium in London.

site_title: Donald Trump touts first 100 days despite widespread criticism
summary: US President Donald Trump is celebrating his 100-day mark in office, despite widespread criticism over his administration's struggles to convert campaign promises into tangible achievements. Critics have lambasted his efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act and implement a border wall, while his supporters blame obstruction by Democrats. Trump has signed dozens of executive orders, but his policies have been met with significant opposition, including blocked court orders and rising global tensions. Trump claims his administration has been the most successful in US history, but polls show he is the least popular leader in modern times.

site_title: EU says united Ireland would be automatic full member
summary: European Union leaders have pledged to automatically accept Northern Ireland into the EU if it unites with the Republic of Ireland, following the 1998 Good Friday Agreement. This stance was made during an EU summit, with Irish Prime Minister Enda Kenny stating that the conditions for a referendum on uniting the island do not currently exist. The EU's declaration is seen as a recognition of the principle of territorial changes in international law, with some officials describing it as a "statement of the obvious."

site_title: Labour gains in British polls, but PM Theresa May's Conservatives party keeps strong lead
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative party maintains a strong lead in polls, with a gap between 11 and 17 points ahead of the opposition Labour party. Despite a slight narrowing of the gap, Labour's support has risen to 31%, down from 25% last weekend. May has called for an election on June 8 to secure a mandate for her Brexit plan, with the Conservative party maintaining a stable lead, and sterling rising on the prospect of an election.

site_title: Famed Swiss climber Ueli Steck falls to death, preparing for Mount Everest ascent
summary: Swiss mountaineer Ueli Steck, 40, died on April 30, 2017, after falling in the Everest region of Nepal while preparing to climb Mount Everest. Steck, an experienced climber, had planned to ascend the mountain via the West Ridge route and traverse to Lhotse. He fell 1,000 meters in the Western Cwm, near Camp Two, and his body was retrieved and brought to Kathmandu. Steck's death marks the first fatality in the current climbing season, following a previous incident in 2013.

site_title: Football: Granada relegated from LaLiga
summary: Granada CF has been relegated from LaLiga after a 2-1 loss to Real Sociedad. The defeat, their fourth in five games, sealed their fate as they finish the season. Despite a late goal from Adrian Ramos, Granada could not avoid relegation. The loss also boosted Sociedad's push for a Europa League spot, as they moved into sixth place. Granada will join Osasuna in the Segunda Division next season, while Sporting Gijon's defeat at Villarreal puts them almost certain to follow.

site_title: Britain gears up for negotiations of a 'lifetime' after EU outlines Brexit stance
summary: Britain is gearing up for complex Brexit negotiations after the EU outlined its tough stance. EU leaders endorsed stiff divorce terms, warning Britons of no swift access to EU markets. Brexit Minister David Davis described the talks as the most complex in UK history, stating they will be "tough and, at times, even confrontational." The UK is set for a national election on June 8, with Prime Minister Theresa May seeking to strengthen her hand domestically before negotiations begin. The two-year countdown for departure terms has started, with Davis warning of opposition from both within and outside Europe.

site_title: EU sets Britain tough divorce terms, slams budget veto
summary: EU leaders have agreed on tough divorce terms for Britain, which includes securing rights of 3 million EU expatriates, paying tens of billions of euros owed to Brussels, and avoiding a hard EU-UK border across Ireland. The guidelines, finalized by EU diplomats, were endorsed by leaders in a Brussels summit, with some warning that Britain must make significant progress on withdrawal terms before discussing a free trade deal. EU leaders also criticized Britain's decision to veto some EU spending, saying it could disrupt negotiations, and called for a "spirit of goodwill" in talks.

site_title: Bayern take fifth straight Bundesliga crown with 6-0 win at Wolfsburg
summary: Bayern Munich secured their record-extending fifth consecutive Bundesliga title with a 6-0 win over VfL Wolfsburg, opening a 10-point lead over second-placed RB Leipzig with three matches remaining. The Bavarians, led by Robert Lewandowski and Arturo Vidal, dominated the match, with Lewandowski scoring twice to take his league goal tally to 28. Bayern's coach Carlo Ancelotti expressed happiness and gratitude, while CEO Karl-Heinz Rummenigge praised the team's consistency, stating, "The league is the most honest of titles" and "we have done it five times in a row."

site_title: May Day: Unions are helping retrenched workers switch sectors, union leaders tell PM
summary: Singapore union leaders are helping retrenched workers switch sectors amid economic uncertainty. Retrenched workers from the offshore marine, oil and gas sector are being retrained for jobs in the aerospace sector, which remains hiring. Union leaders also expressed concerns over the ports sector, which has seen a turnaround, but still faces challenges. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for companies to be adaptable and flexible, and for workers to be open to new opportunities.

site_title: Football: Chelsea on course for the title as Spurs beat Arsenal
summary: Chelsea is on course for the Premier League title after a 3-0 win at Everton, leaving them four points clear of second-placed Tottenham Hotspur. Tottenham beat Arsenal 2-0, with Harry Kane scoring from the penalty spot, and can close the gap to one point if they win their next game. Chelsea has a chance to put pressure on Tottenham with a 10th straight league win, but will face Middlesbrough next. Tottenham's resilience in the league, led by England players Kane and Dele Alli, poses a challenge to Conte's Chelsea team in their pursuit of the title.

site_title: PM Lee accepts Donald Trump's invitation to White House; hopes to visit later this year
summary: US President Donald Trump invited Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to the White House to "further strengthen ties" between the two countries. Lee accepted the invitation and hopes to visit the White House later this year. The two leaders reaffirmed their countries' deep and longstanding relationship, which includes thriving trade, investment, and security cooperation. The invitation comes as Trump seeks to build a new foreign policy approach, marked by a shift towards pragmatism and cooperation with regional leaders.

site_title: Bus accident kills 11 in Indonesia
summary: At least 11 people were killed in a bus accident in Indonesia's West Java province on April 30, 2017, after a suspected brake failure. The bus collided with four cars and motorbikes, tumbling down a slope and killing the driver and several motorists. Nearly 50 people were injured in the accident. This incident highlights the common issue of transport accidents in Indonesia, where buses and trains are often old and poorly maintained.

site_title: Football: Suarez double keeps Barca level with Madrid
summary: Barcelona and Real Madrid remain tied for first place in La Liga with 81 points after the weekend's matches. Luis Suarez scored twice to lead Barcelona to a 3-0 win over Espanyol, while Marcelo scored in the 94th minute to give Real Madrid a 2-1 win over Valencia. Suarez said Barcelona needs to keep winning to put pressure on Real Madrid, and Real Madrid's Zinedine Zidane acknowledged that his team is not yet out of the season.

site_title: Tornadoes, storms kill nine in US South
summary: Tornadoes and storms swept through the US South, killing at least 9 people across four states. Three tornadoes were confirmed in East Texas, with at least four fatalities and 49 injured. Other states affected include Missouri, Oklahoma, Arkansas, and Mississippi, where floods and strong winds caused additional deaths. The storms also caused widespread destruction, with roads and power lines damaged. Texas Governor Greg Abbott deployed a search and rescue team, while governors of Missouri and Oklahoma declared states of emergency due to flooding.

site_title: Asean summit ends in uncertainty over South China Sea stance
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's Association of South East Asian Nations (Asean) summit ended without an agreement on addressing Beijing's assertiveness in the South China Sea. Despite a draft statement referencing "land reclamation and militarisation", China successfully lobbied to omit the term, sparking concerns over the region's uncertain ties with the US. The summit's outcome leaves the issue unresolved, with Duterte calling for a maritime code of conduct with Beijing to defuse tensions by the end of the year.

site_title: US President Donald Trump calls North Korea's Kim Jong Un 'a pretty smart cookie'
summary: US President Donald Trump has called North Korean leader Kim Jong Un "a pretty smart cookie" during a television interview. Trump made the comments while discussing North Korea's missile and nuclear programs, saying Kim's ability to take power at a young age was impressive. However, Trump emphasized that the US will not allow North Korea to develop a ballistic missile capable of hitting the US mainland. Trump also stated that China's help is crucial in reining in Kim's behavior, and he is willing to make concessions to achieve this goal.

site_title: Australia probes video showing ISIS fighter's son wearing suicide vest
summary: Australian police are investigating a video showing the 8-year-old son of an ISIS fighter, Khaled Sharrouf, wearing a suicide vest and threatening to kill Australians. The footage, allegedly filmed in Syria, was recently obtained by the media. Sharrouf, who was stripped of his Australian citizenship in February, left the country in 2013 with his family. Authorities say there is no specific threat, but the current national terrorism threat level remains at "probable." The investigation is ongoing, with the NSW Joint Counter Terrorism Team leading the inquiry.

site_title: Football: Gabriel Jesus header gives Manchester City 2-2 draw at Middlesbrough
summary: Manchester City drew 2-2 with Middlesbrough on Sunday, with Gabriel Jesus scoring the equalizing goal in the 86th minute. The match, played at Middlesbrough's Riverside stadium, was a comeback victory for City, who trailed 2-1 with 21 minutes remaining. Jesus' header, assisted by Sergio Aguero's chip, came after Aguero had converted a disputed penalty. The draw keeps City in fourth place, just ahead of Manchester United, and maintains their Champions League spot.

site_title: Iran's leader Khamenei rebuffs President Rouhani's detente policy ahead of vote
summary: Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has rebuffed President Hassan Rouhani's detente policy ahead of the May 19 vote, saying that Iranians should not thank Rouhani's efforts for reducing the threat of war. Khamenei criticized the nuclear deal, which lifted international sanctions, for failing to deliver promised economic benefits, and instead, attributed any improvement to Rouhani's presence in the political scene. Hardline candidates, including Ebrahim Raisi, have echoed Khamenei's views, emphasizing Iran's ability to defend itself without foreign help.

site_title: Football: Ancelotti hails 'fantastic' five-in-a-row Bayern
summary: Bayern Munich secured their fifth consecutive Bundesliga title with a 6-0 win over Wolfsburg, leaving them 10 points clear of RB Leipzig with three games to spare. Manager Carlo Ancelotti hailed the season as "fantastic" and praised his team's performance. This is Bayern's 27th league crown, 18 more than any other German club. Ancelotti, who won his 19th trophy as a manager, will celebrate the title with the team before preparing for the new season.

site_title: US President Donald Trump touts 100-day record, slams media
summary: US President Donald Trump marked his 100th day in office with a rally in Pennsylvania, touting his administration's record of job creation, reduced immigration, and economic growth. He cited 600,000 new jobs and a 73% reduction in southern border immigration. Trump also emphasized his plans to withdraw from the Paris Climate Accord, renegotiate NAFTA, and build a border wall. His approval rating remains low, but among his supporters, it remains over 90%. The President signed two executive orders, bringing the total to 32, and emphasized the need for deregulation and tax reform.

site_title: Difficult trade-offs necessary for RCEP to be worthwhile: PM Lee Hsien Loong
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized that a Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) must have substance to be worthwhile, requiring countries to make difficult trade-offs. He urged Asean leaders to conclude negotiations speedily but not set the bar too low, citing the need for balance benefits for all participants. Lee noted that the pact cannot be the equivalent of existing free trade agreements and must be substantial, meaningful, and have benefits for all. He is not optimistic about concluding negotiations this year, expecting a longer process.

site_title: Formula One: Mercedes face a big battle as domination disappears
summary: Mercedes, the dominant Formula One team, faces a significant challenge as Ferrari ended their 18-race winning streak in pole positions and led the pack for the first time in 31 races at the Russian Grand Prix. Ferrari's front-row lockout marked the team's first since 2008, with Sebastian Vettel on pole and Kimi Raikkonen in second. Mercedes boss Toto Wolff acknowledged the team's dominance was bound to end, stating they need to "out-develop" Ferrari to regain their lead.

site_title: Toned-down White House Correspondents' dinner carries on without Donald Trump
summary: The White House Correspondents' Association held its annual black-tie dinner on April 29, 2017, without President Donald Trump, who had previously attended the event. The dinner was toned down after Trump's administration skipped it in solidarity with him, who had repeatedly accused the press of mistreatment. Journalists and Washington insiders attended, and comedian Hasan Minhaj delivered jokes about Trump to honor the US constitutional protection of free speech. The event was seen as a celebration of press freedom, with WHCA President Jeff Mason defending the media against Trump's accusations of "fake news."

site_title: Football: Jakupovic heroics secure Hull draw at Southampton
summary: Hull City earned a crucial 0-0 draw at Southampton, securing their first point on the road in six games. Goalkeeper Eldin Jakupovic saved a late penalty from Dusan Tadic in the 91st minute, after Alfred N'Diaye committed a foul during a corner. Hull, in 17th place and three points clear of the drop zone, held on to the draw with a tight defensive display, moving them closer to safety. The result marked a significant boost for the relegation-threatened team.

site_title: Formula One: Sebastian Vettel keeps Ferrari on top in final Russian practice
summary: Sebastian Vettel led Ferrari to the top of the timesheets in final Russian Formula One practice, lapping the Sochi circuit with a fastest time of 1:34.001 seconds on ultrasoft tyres. Vettel is seven points clear of Mercedes's Lewis Hamilton after winning two of the first three races. Ferrari's Kimi Raikkonen was second, and Valtteri Bottas third for Mercedes. Mercedes have led every lap in Sochi since the circuit's debut, but Vettel's strong performance may end their 18-race qualifying pole streak.

site_title: Bigger changes to Cabinet ahead in 2018, says PM Lee Hsien Loong
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced plans for bigger changes to his Cabinet in 2018, with new ministers to be appointed to some ministries. Following recent promotions, Lee said he expects to make more changes and appoint new ministers next year, including Mrs. Josephine Teo and Mr. Desmond Lee, who were promoted to full ministers in the Prime Minister's Office. Four ministers of state will also be promoted to senior ministers of state, with Dr. Lam Pin Min appointed as Senior Minister of State for Transport.

site_title: Turkey blocks Wikipedia access, bans TV dating shows
summary: Turkey blocked access to Wikipedia and banned TV dating shows, amid fears of a crackdown after President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's victory in a referendum enhancing his powers. The ban was imposed due to alleged content promoting terror and cooperation with terror groups, with no indication of when it may be lifted. The government also dismissed nearly 4,000 public officials, including over 1,000 pilots and 500 academics, in the latest wave of purges under the nine-month state of emergency.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, April 30 edition
summary: Tens of thousands marched in Washington to protest Trump's environmental policies, with Leonardo DiCaprio joining the rally. Pope Francis urged mediation to end the North Korea crisis, warning of nuclear devastation. Asian leaders failed to agree on South China Sea stance, with no joint statement issued. Maria Sharapova lost in the semi-finals of the Stuttgart tennis tournament, ending her comeback from a doping ban. Bayern Munich secured their fifth consecutive Bundesliga title with a 6-0 win over Wolfsburg.

site_title: Thai family buries baby murdered on Facebook Live
summary: A Thai family has buried an 11-month-old girl, Natalie, who was murdered by her father in a live Facebook broadcast before he took his own life. The father, Wuttisan Wongtalay, hanged Natalie from an abandoned building and filmed the act, which was seen by hundreds of thousands of people. The incident has sparked debate over Facebook's handling of graphic content, with calls for the company to remove such videos more swiftly. Relatives held a Buddhist ceremony to bid farewell to Natalie, who was buried with her favorite toys and pillows, and her mother expressed forgiveness for her boyfriend.

site_title: Pope Francis tells Egypt mass that dialogue can battle extremism
summary: Pope Francis delivered a mass in Egypt, appealing for dialogue to combat extremism and promote reconciliation with Muslims. He told a crowd of 15,000 pilgrims that true faith moves the heart to love everyone and that fanaticism can only be of charity. The visit comes after a series of church bombings by ISIS, which killed dozens of worshippers. The Pope also met with the grand imam of Al-Azhar and Coptic Orthodox patriarch, signing a joint declaration pledging peaceful coexistence between Christians and Muslims.

site_title: Netball: Mission Mannas beat Tiger Sharks 57-37 in 2017 NSL final
summary: The Mission Mannas won the 2017 M1 Netball Super League finals, defeating the Tiger Sharks 57-37 at Toa Payoh Sports Hall. The Mannas dominated the first quarter, building a 15-6 lead, and maintained their advantage throughout the game. This victory capped off an unbeaten season for the Mannas, securing their second M1 NSL title in 2014.

site_title: North Korean missile launch a grave threat to Japan: PM Shinzo Abe
summary: North Korea's ballistic missile launch is a grave threat to Japan, according to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. He called on the US and China to maintain pressure on Pyongyang, warning that further provocation is "fully conceivable." Abe expressed concern over the potential for a major conflict and urged the international community to maintain a close coordination with the US to ensure safety for Japanese citizens. China's role in calming the situation is seen as crucial, with Abe expressing high expectations for China's response.

site_title: Football: Burnley bolster survival bid with 2-0 Palace win
summary: Burnley secured their first Premier League win in London at Selhurst Park, defeating Crystal Palace 2-0 on April 29. Goals from Ashley Barnes and Andre Gray gave the Clarets their first away league win of the season, moving them eight points clear of the relegation zone. The win left Burnley within touching distance of Premier League survival, while Palace and West Ham are still in danger of relegation despite both being leapfrogged by the Clarets.

site_title: Marine Le Pen to appoint right-winger Dupont-Aignan as PM if she wins French election
summary: Marine Le Pen has chosen far-right politician Nicolas Dupont-Aignan as her prime minister if she wins the French presidential election. Dupont-Aignan, a nationalist with protectionist economic policies, is seen as a bid to attract his voters and help Le Pen defeat centrist Emmanuel Macron. The alliance aims to form a "government of national unity" but risks alienating far-left support needed for Le Pen's victory. The choice sets the stage for a European choice between Le Pen's resurgent far-right and Macron's pro-EU and pro-business agenda.

site_title: 31-year-old man arrested for trying to snatch heavily pregnant woman's wallet
summary: A 31-year-old man was arrested on April 29 for attempting to snatch a wallet from a heavily pregnant woman at Bedok, Singapore. The woman reported the incident to the police on April 28, and officers identified the suspect using footage from police cameras. He was arrested at Tampines MRT on the same day and charged with attempted snatch theft. The suspect faces a possible jail sentence of at least a year and up to seven years, and may also be caned if convicted.

site_title: FAS election: Five things to know about new FAS president Lim Kia Tong
summary: Lim Kia Tong, a 64-year-old veteran lawyer, has been elected as the new president of the Football Association of Singapore (FAS) after defeating Bill Ng's slate by 30-13 votes. Lim has been involved with the FAS for 25 years, serving on the disciplinary committee, council, and as interim president. He is well-regarded in international football circles, having held leadership roles on FIFA and AFC committees. Lim's experience in law enforcement, including as a member of the Volunteer Special Constabulary, has also been highlighted.

site_title: Boxing: Wladimir Klitschko and Anthony Joshua do their weigh-ins as heavyweights prepare for bruising encounter
summary: Anthony Joshua weighed in at a career-high 113.4 kg for his fight against Wladimir Klitschko, 4.5kg heavier than the Ukrainian. Joshua, 27, is seeking to defend his IBF world heavyweight title and claim the vacant WBA belt. Klitschko, 41, aims to regain two of the three titles he lost to Tyson Fury and has described Joshua as "as big as Arnold Schwarzenegger at his best." Joshua remains focused on the fight, saying "it depends if I see an opportunity" for a knockout, while Klitschko believes his experience will give him the edge to win.

site_title: Climate protests to mark Trump's 100 days in office
summary: Tens of thousands of protesters are expected to gather in Washington, DC, on April 29 to mark the 100th day of Donald Trump's presidency, focusing on climate change and Trump's environmental policies. Organizers, including labor unions and environmental groups, aim to build momentum for the 2020 presidential race and midterm elections. The protest comes after a March for Science event last weekend, which also targeted Trump's administration's denial of evidence-based science. Environmental activists believe public opinion is on their side, with a recent Gallup poll showing 59% of Americans prioritizing environmental protection.

site_title: Golf: Jonas Blixt and Cameron Smith in one-stroke lead at Zurich Classic
summary: Jonas Blixt and Cameron Smith of Sweden and Australia, respectively, took the lead at the Zurich Classic team tournament with a 10-under par 62 in the second round, one stroke ahead of Patrick Reed and Patrick Cantlay. Blixt and Smith credited their trust in each other's games for their aggressive play. Retief Goosen and Tyrone van Aswegan of South Africa also made a strong move, posting a 12-under 60 to move up the leaderboard. The tournament is the first team event on the PGA Tour in 36 years.

site_title: 24 dead as Kyrgyz landslide engulfs village homes
summary: At least 24 people, including nine children, were killed when a landslide engulfed a village in Kyrgyzstan's Osh region, destroying 11 houses. The disaster occurred on April 29, 2017, and prompted an emergency response from authorities. A second landslide hit a neighboring village, but no casualties were reported. The government has announced a day of national mourning and pledged assistance to affected families, with Prime Minister Sooronbai Jeenbekov stating that the government will provide "all necessary assistance."

site_title: NBA: Celtics and Wizards advance to second round of play-offs, Clippers stave off elimination
summary: The Boston Celtics and Washington Wizards advanced to the second round of the NBA playoffs, with the Celtics defeating the Chicago Bulls 105-83 in Game 6 and the Wizards defeating the Atlanta Hawks 115-99. The Celtics' Avery Bradley led the way with 23 points, while the Wizards' John Wall and Bradley Beal combined for 73 points. The Celtics will face the Wizards in the next round, while the Los Angeles Clippers staved off elimination with a 98-93 win over the Utah Jazz in Game 7.

site_title: Formula One: Williams' Felipe Massa in no hurry to hang up his helmet again
summary: Brazilian Formula One driver Felipe Massa, 36, is in no hurry to retire from the sport despite being given a new lease on life at Williams. Massa, who has been racing since 2002, is currently scoring all of Williams' points and is confident he can continue to perform at a high level. He cites the example of MotoGP rider Valentino Rossi, who is leading the championship at 38, as proof that age is not a barrier to success. Massa feels fit and comfortable in his current role, helping his younger teammate Lance Stroll.

site_title: Sandwich Factory in Osaka has a quirky atmosphere, huge selection
summary: A quirky English tea room-meets-cafe, Sandwich Factory in Osaka offers a unique atmosphere and a vast selection of sandwiches. The restaurant boasts a range of Japanese classics, pita sandwiches, and international options, including a notable burdock root and tuna offering. With a grand piano and bells signaling customer readiness, the ambiance is pleasant and fun. Located in Utsubo Park, Sandwich Factory is open daily from 11am to 9pm, with a variety of options to suit different tastes. Its eclectic atmosphere makes it a standout destination in downtown Osaka.

site_title: Wireless@SG unveils automatic login for tablets and laptops at Tech Saturday fair
summary: The Wireless@SG service, a free national network for 180,000 tablet and laptop users, now offers automatic login after a one-time set-up process. This move follows the automatic login available on devices using SIM cards, building on the Smart Nation initiative's digital economy transformation. The change was announced at Tech Saturday, a two-day fair showcasing local tech products and services, as part of the Infocomm Media Development Authority's Smart Nation Innovations Week.

site_title: Golf: Haru Nomura takes one-shot lead at LPGA Texas Shootout
summary: Haru Nomura of Japan took a one-shot lead at the LPGA Texas Shootout, finishing the second round with a 65 and a nine-under-par 133. Ariya Jutanugarn of Thailand shot a 67 to take second place at 134, one stroke ahead of Suzann Pettersen of Norway. The halfway lead was secured after Nomura made six birdies in the final eight holes.

site_title: Philippine police chief backs secret cell detention of drug suspects
summary: Philippine police chief Ronald Dela Rosa defended the detention of a dozen people in a secret cell at a police station in Manila, despite allegations of torture and extortion. The detainees claimed they were held for a week after being arrested on drug-related charges and were released after national police chief Dela Rosa visited the station. The incident sparked outrage, with the government's human rights commission launching an inquiry and international rights groups calling for the release of all unlawfully detained suspects. The police chief rejected allegations, accusing the rights commission of plotting to embarrass President Duterte's government.

site_title: Career advancement opportunities for SCDF, SPS, ICA and CNB officers from July: Desmond Lee
summary: Singapore's Senior Minister of State for Home Affairs Desmond Lee announced a scheme to provide career advancement opportunities for officers from four Home Team agencies, starting July 2017. The unified rank structure, initially rolled out to the Singapore Police Force last year, aims to equalize career paths for diploma- and degree-holders. The new scheme will introduce expert tracks and programs to develop officers professionally, enhancing the Home Team's operational capabilities and preparedness. The move is part of Lee's promotion to Second Minister for Home Affairs, effective May 1.

site_title: Football: Marcelo rescues Madrid with late winner
summary: Real Madrid edged closer to the La Liga title with a 2-1 win over Valencia, thanks to a late goal from Marcelo. Cristiano Ronaldo opened the scoring, but Diego Alves saved his penalty attempt. Dani Parejo's free-kick seemed to hand Valencia an unlikely point, but Real Madrid responded with a late winner from Marcelo in the 39th minute. The win puts Real Madrid three points ahead of Barcelona with four games remaining, and sets up a crucial Catalan derby for Barcelona later in the week.

site_title: Tennis: Bookmakers install Maria Sharapova as joint-favourite at French Open
summary: Bookmakers have installed Maria Sharapova as the joint-favourite to win the French Open, listing her at 6/1 odds alongside Romania's Simona Halep. Despite a 15-month doping ban, Sharapova has made a strong comeback, reaching the semi-finals of the Stuttgart Open. She will learn on May 16 whether she will receive a wild card to the French Open, but many believe she will not only play in Paris but also win the title, as several top players, including Serena Williams and Petra Kvitova, are absent.

site_title: Football: David Moyes hints at exit as Sunderland face up to life in the Championship
summary: Sunderland manager David Moyes hints at potential exit at the end of the season, following the team's relegation to the Championship. Moyes was non-committal when asked if he would remain in charge in August, stating he would assess the situation at the end of the season. The team faces a crucial match against Bournemouth on Saturday, where a loss would seal relegation, with fans calling for his dismissal. Moyes emphasized that his decision would not be influenced by supporter opinions.

site_title: Football: Spurs to play all home games at Wembley next season
summary: Tottenham Hotspur has confirmed it will play all home games at Wembley Stadium next season while its new, £800 million stadium is being built on the site of White Hart Lane. The 90,000-capacity Wembley will be used from the 2017-18 season, with the new stadium expected to be ready for the 2018-19 season. Chairman Daniel Levy announced the decision after a board meeting, citing the need for certainty on the new stadium's delivery before decommissioning White Hart Lane. Tottenham's last match at White Hart Lane will be on May 14.

site_title: China 'putting pressure' on North Korea, says Donald Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that Chinese President Xi Jinping is "putting pressure" on North Korea, amid rising tensions over Pyongyang's nuclear and missile programs. Trump expressed concern over North Korea's potential nuclear test, saying he would not be happy with it. China, North Korea's top trade partner, has called for denuclearization talks but has been hesitant to use economic pressure that could destabilize North Korea. Trump criticized North Korea's missile launch as a show of disrespect toward China, but did not commit to military action.

site_title: Pope urges mediation to end North Korea crisis, avert devastating war
summary: Pope Francis urges mediation to resolve the escalating North Korea crisis, warning that a widespread war would "destroy a good part of humanity" and "everything." He suggests a third country, such as Norway, could mediate the dispute between North Korea and Washington to avert nuclear devastation. The Pope also emphasizes the need for the UN to reassert its leadership in world diplomacy, and calls on leaders to seek solutions through diplomacy.

site_title: Football: Rare defensive howler as Juventus drop points at Atalanta
summary: Juventus was held to a 2-2 draw at Atalanta in the Italian Serie A on April 28, 2017. The draw came after a rare defensive mix-up, with Juventus' Dani Alves heading them in front in the 83rd minute, only for Remo Freuler to equalize six minutes later. Juventus coach Massimiliano Allegri criticized his team for pouring forward to try to grab a late winner, rather than staying calm and defending. The draw keeps Juventus nine points clear of AS Roma and marks a rare defensive lapse for the team.

site_title: Duterte to tell Trump to exercise restraint, says North Korea's Kim 'just wants to end the world'
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte urged US President Donald Trump to exercise restraint in dealing with North Korea, warning that war would be a catastrophe. Duterte, who expects a call from Trump, advised the US to be "prudent and patient" and not play into the hands of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. He described Kim as someone who "just wants to end the world" and blamed both North Korea and the US for rising tensions on the Korean peninsula. Duterte urged America to use its "biggest stick" wisely to avoid a potential holocaust.

site_title: Nationwide litter-picking campaign extended to one month, up from a day
summary: A nationwide litter-picking campaign, Keep Clean, Singapore!, has been extended to one month, up from a single day, with over 260 organizations participating across 230 locations. The campaign aims to promote community involvement in keeping Singapore clean, with the goal of building a more caring and inclusive city. The initiative, which started in 2014 as Operation We Clean Up!, collected 120kg of litter in just one hour during its initial event.

site_title: Football: Dele Alli and Harry Kane earn Spurs stirring derby win
summary: Tottenham Hotspur defeated Arsenal 2-0 in a north London derby at White Hart Lane, cutting the gap to four points in the Premier League title hunt. Goals from Dele Alli and Harry Kane, who scored his 21st goal of the season, sealed the win for Spurs. The victory marked Spurs' first win above Arsenal in the league since 1995, ending a 22-year drought known as "St Totteringham's Day."

site_title: Indians throng temple to crack Trump's visa curbs
summary: Hundreds of Indians visit the 500-year-old Chilkur Balaji Temple in southern India, seeking US visas, particularly after US President Donald Trump signed an order to reform the "H-1B" work visa system. Devotees offer prayers and make 108 rounds of the sanctum, believing in the temple's supposed magical powers. Temple officials report a surge in visitors since Trump's election, with over 100,000 devotees visiting weekly. Many claim the temple's blessings have led to successful visa applications, with some attributing their success to "divine intervention".

site_title: Football: Two lucky S'porean fans won tickets to Manchester derby thanks to ST-Mundipharma contest
summary: Two Singaporean fans, Benjamin Wan and his son Kenzie Wan, won tickets to a Manchester derby through a contest run by The Straits Times and Mundipharma. The pair, both Manchester City fans, received economy-class airfare, a hotel stay, and a tour of the Etihad Stadium as part of their prize. Their trip included a photo opportunity with former Manchester City midfielder Frank Lampard, who was the Football Writers' Association Footballer of the Year in 2005. The contest was sponsored by Mundipharma, Manchester City's official healthcare partner.

site_title: New awards for emerging local pop artists
summary: Singapore launched a new series of awards to recognize emerging local pop acts as part of the Next initiative, a platform to help young artists break into the music scene. The awards, part of the Sing50 Fund, will be held in six categories and will feature $3,000 prizes for winners. The awards aim to promote and preserve Singapore's music heritage and provide opportunities for solo and group performers to showcase their talents. The winners will be decided by an advisory committee and nominations are now open to the public.

site_title: Tennis:  Nadal one win from 10th Barcelona title
summary: Rafael Nadal advanced to the Barcelona final with a 6-3, 6-4 win over Horacio Zeballos, moving within one win of a 10th title. Nadal will face Dominic Thiem in the final, with Thiem having beaten Andy Murray 6-2, 3-6, 6-4. The match will be Nadal's 106th career final, and he holds a 2-1 career record over Thiem.
