site_title: Singapore deeply concerned by North Korea's actions, says PM Lee Hsien Loong
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed deep concern over North Korea's nuclear and ballistic missile tests, calling for the country to cease all provocative actions and return to dialogue. He stated that Singapore is deeply concerned by the series of deliberate and provocative actions, including nuclear tests and ballistic missile launches, which violate UN Security Council Resolutions and pose a grave threat to regional peace and security. Lee emphasized the need for Asean to be strong and united in calling for North Korea's return to dialogue.

site_title: Motorcyclist and pillion rider severely injured after colliding with bus near Tuas Checkpoint
summary: A motorcyclist, 32, and his pillion rider, 31, were severely injured in an accident with a bus near the Tuas Checkpoint on April 28. The motorcyclist suffered spinal injuries, while the pillion rider had multiple fractures. Both were taken to the National University Hospital. The police and SCDF were alerted to the incident at 10:07pm on Friday and dispatched ambulances for treatment. Investigations into the accident are ongoing.

site_title: Singaporean woman raises over $239k to get comatose father home from Tokyo
summary: A Singaporean woman, Eileen Cheong, successfully raised over $239,000 through crowdfunding to help her comatose father, who had a heart attack in Tokyo, return home. Her father was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit on April 19, 2017, and was left with permanent brain damage. Cheong initially sought $250,000 but reached her target before the campaign ended. The Singapore Embassy in Tokyo is providing consular assistance to the family.

site_title: Golf: Nomura stretches lead at windy LPGA Texas Shootout
summary: Japan's Haru Nomura stretched her lead to two strokes at the LPGA Texas Shootout, firing a one-over par 72 at Las Colinas Country Club. Nomura's total of 205 for 54 holes put her two ahead of South Korean star Park In-Bee and Cristie Kerr. Despite gusting winds, Nomura's effort included two birdies and a bogey, while Park had a double-bogey at the par-three fourth. Stacy Lewis seized fifth place with a five-under par 66, and Ariya Jutanugarn struggled to master the conditions with six bogeys in a five-over 76.

site_title: Man filmed 'mocking' taxi driver identified as chicken rice stall owner, restaurant being 'harassed'
summary: A viral video shows a man, identified as 37-year-old Gary Lim, a chicken rice stall owner, harassing a taxi driver and mocking his profession after a ride. Lim, who appeared drunk, was filmed blocking the taxi driver's way and making derogatory comments. Lim claimed he was sorry for the incident and said he didn't mean to offend taxi drivers. The taxi driver, Mr Sun, filed a police report, and Lim's restaurant has also reported harassment due to the incident.

site_title: Threatening letter sent to DPM Tharman under the name of Sungei Road market's chairman
summary: A threatening letter was sent to Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, allegedly under the name of Sungei Road market's chairman, Koh Eng Khoon. The police are investigating and have raided Koh's home, where he denied any involvement. The letter, with two handwritten notes, expressed anger over the market's planned closure, despite the government's categorical refusal to relocate. Koh, 76, has gathered 4,000 signatures for a petition to allocate an alternative site, and his phone was confiscated during the police raid.

site_title: Football: SportSG CEO tells new FAS council that public funding will depend on maintenance of 'high standard of regulatory compliance'
summary: Sport Singapore's CEO Lim Teck Yin has urged the newly elected FAS council, led by Team LKT, to maintain a high standard of regulatory compliance and best practices. Public funding support will depend on this, as well as confidence in the FAS' strategies and actions to develop football in Singapore and national teams. Lim Kia Tong, the Team LKT leader, was elected to all 15 council positions, and SportSG looks forward to working with him on football ecosystem development in Singapore.

site_title: Asean nations face massive drug menace, says Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte warned Southeast Asian leaders that their region faces a "massive" illegal drug menace, urging a united response to combat it. He emphasized the need for non-interference in internal affairs, despite criticism from international rights groups. Duterte's own anti-drug campaign has been marred by thousands of deaths, with allegations of extrajudicial killings and "mass murder". Asean leaders are expected to avoid criticizing Duterte, with some expressing support for his efforts to combat the drug trade. A united response is seen as crucial to dismantling the illicit trade.

site_title: Football: MCCY Minister Grace Fu calls on fraternity to unite after FAS polls, urges new leaders to 'rebuild trust and confidence'
summary: Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Grace Fu has called on the Singapore football fraternity to unite after the end of FAS' first-ever election, where Team LKT won all 15 council positions. Fu urged the new leadership to rebuild trust and confidence with stakeholders and the public, addressing pressing issues such as local football development and governance. She also emphasized the need for a more robust governance system, stating that the new FAS leadership must prioritize its review. The call comes after a bitter election campaign marked by claims and counter-claims.

site_title: Vital for Asean to stay united and deepen economic integration: PM Lee Hsien Loong
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of Asean unity and economic integration amid anti-globalization and protectionism. He urged member countries to conclude a credible and high-quality Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), which includes 16 countries, to secure the region's future. Lee highlighted Asean's 50-year history of creating a peaceful environment, fostering dialogue and cooperation, and its growing economic potential. He urged the group to deepen integration, build resilience, and maintain relevance to ensure its continued influence on the global stage.

site_title: The Simpsons troll Donald Trump in episode on president's first 100 days
summary: The Simpsons released a viral video teaser for an upcoming episode, trolling President Donald Trump on his first 100 days in office. The 84-second trailer parodies Trump's accomplishments, including his Twitter following and golf handicap. It also satirizes his administration's actions, such as Ivanka replacing Ruth Bader Ginsburg on the Supreme Court. The episode, scheduled to air on April 30, marks a tradition of The Simpsons predicting future events, having famously predicted a Trump presidency in 2000. The show is nearing its 30th season and has a record for most primetime scripted episodes.

site_title: A timeline of North Korea's development of missiles and nuclear weapons
summary: North Korea has rapidly developed its missile and nuclear capabilities since 2017, with notable milestones including the successful test of an intermediate-range and submarine-launched missile, the launch of a long-range Unha-3 rocket, and the development of a hydrogen bomb. The country has also conducted numerous missile tests, including the firing of ballistic missiles into Japan's air defense zone and the launch of unidentified missiles that exploded shortly after launch. Despite international condemnation and sanctions, North Korea continues to pursue its nuclear ambitions, with leader Kim Jong Un announcing in 2015 that the country is "ready to detonate" a hydrogen bomb.

site_title: Philippine troops kill Abu Sayyaf leader behind kidnappings of Malaysians, Indonesians
summary: Philippine troops killed Alhabsy Misaya, a senior leader of the Abu Sayyaf group, in Sulu province. Misaya was behind the 2015 kidnappings of Malaysians Thien Nyuk Fun and engineer Bernard Then, and the 2014 abductions of Chinese citizen Gao Huayun and Filipino resort worker Marcy Dayawan. Misaya's death comes weeks after the killing of Abu Sayyaf spokesman Muamar Askali. The group remains active, holding at least 24 hostages, including 13 Vietnamese, seven Filipinos, and foreigners from the US, Japan, and Indonesia.

site_title: First direct Britain-China freight train completes 12,000-km run
summary: The first direct freight train linking Britain to China has completed a 12,000-km journey, arriving in Yiwu, eastern China, after a 20-day trip. The train, named the East Wind, departed London on April 10 and passed through 7 countries, carrying whisky, baby milk, pharmaceuticals, and machinery. The route is part of China's "One Belt, One Road" strategy, aiming to strengthen trade links with western Europe. The train's carrying capacity is limited to 88 shipping containers, and its economic viability has been questioned by experts, but it may offer a convenient and flexible alternative to air transport.

site_title: French amphibious carrier visits Japan ahead of Pacific show of power
summary: A French amphibious assault carrier, Mistral, arrived in Japan's Sasebo naval base on April 29 ahead of drills with US, Japanese, and British forces. The 700-troop exercise near Guam aims to practice amphibious landings, amid rising tensions on the Korean peninsula and China's expanding military presence. China recently launched its first domestically-built aircraft carrier, the Shandong, and has been increasing its influence in the South China Sea. The drills risk upsetting China, which faces US pressure to rein in North Korea's arms programs.

site_title: Muis, Mendaki looking into sprucing up mosque-based kindergartens
summary: Muis and self-help group Mendaki are exploring ways to professionalize mosque-based kindergartens in Singapore, aiming to address concerns about resources and uneven curricula. Minister Dr Yaacob Ibrahim announced plans to oversee the quality of such pre-schools and ensure they meet the requirements set by the Early Childhood Development Agency. The goal is to retain and improve the quality of the 71 mosque-based kindergartens, which would also enable them to obtain the Singapore Pre-school Accreditation Framework (Spark) quality mark.

site_title: Pipe bomb blast in Manila injures 14 as Asean leaders gather for talks
summary: A homemade pipe bomb exploded in Manila, injuring 14 people, on the eve of an Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) summit. The blast, 5km from the summit venue, was dismissed by authorities as a possible revenge assault. Police are investigating and found the device to be a low-grade explosive, similar to those used in firecrackers. No one has been arrested, and the incident is not linked to the summit. The Philippines is currently fighting Islamic militants in the south, who have been blamed for past bombings and kidnappings.

site_title: Malaysia's Islamist party leader avoids issue of PKR partnership in speech at party congress
summary: Malaysia's Islamist party leader, Datuk Seri Hadi Awang, avoided discussing the proposed dissolution of the party's partnership with opposition party Parti Keadilan Rakyat (PKR) in his hour-long speech at the PAS annual congress. Despite resolutions to sever ties with PKR, Hadi focused on Islamic teachings to address societal ills and corruption. The decision to sever ties would strengthen the ruling party Umno and split the Malay vote in Selangor. PAS delegates are expected to continue pushing for the dissolution, which will be decided by the party's top decision-making body in coming days.

site_title: EU nations must stay united in Brexit talks, says EU President Donald Tusk
summary: EU President Donald Tusk urged EU nations to stay united in Brexit talks, saying it's in Britain's interest to reach a deal. The EU 27 have toughened their guidelines, and leaders will discuss automatic membership for Northern Ireland and the relocation of EU agencies. Tusk emphasized the need for solid guarantees for citizens and their families affected by Brexit. The EU is set to back a united front despite a war of words between German Chancellor Angela Merkel and British Prime Minister Theresa May.

site_title: askST: Are revolvers a sufficient weapon for frontline officers in this age of armed terrorists?
summary: The Singapore police force is replacing its Taurus M85 revolvers with pistols, starting in April, in response to the heightened security threat. Frontline officers will be equipped with the CZ P-07 pistol, which has a capacity of 15 rounds, replacing the revolver's 10 rounds. Experts consider semi-automatic pistols safer and easier to use, but acknowledge revolvers' reliability. The switch aims to provide officers with more firepower and easier control during potential confrontations with armed terrorists.

site_title: askST: Are there differences in eggs from kampong chickens, free range chickens and black chickens?
summary: Egg producers claim that kampong, free-range, and black chicken eggs have unique nutritional values, but experts disagree. The Centre for Applied Nutrition Services found that egg size and nutrition are not directly related to breed or egg color. Egg sizes from kampong and black chickens are smaller, but nutritionally equivalent to generic eggs. The only difference lies in "designer eggs" that have added nutrients, making them more expensive. Experts emphasize that egg color and breed do not determine nutritional value, and all eggs contain the same essential vitamins and minerals.

site_title: Donald Trump on North Korea: Tactic? 'Madman Theory'? Or just mixed messages?
summary: US President Donald Trump has taken an extreme position on North Korea, warning of a "major, major conflict" and stating that the US could end up having a major conflict with the country. This comes despite the US Secretary of State's efforts to negotiate with North Korea, and contradicts the administration's message that no pre-emptive strikes are planned. Trump's strategy may be a "madman theory" tactic, but it risks miscalculation and escalation, with Democratic Senator Edward J. Markey expressing concern over rapid escalation.

site_title: Punchlines: April 29, 2017
summary: No article content provided.

site_title: Football: Counting underway as Singapore's football fraternity votes in FAS' first-ever election
summary: Singapore's Football Association of Singapore (FAS) holds its first-ever election, with affiliates voting for leaders for a four-year term. Two teams, Game Changers and Team LKT, contest the election, while 14 individuals run for six council member positions. The election comes after a drama-filled campaign period, marked by raids on FAS offices and allegations of misuse of club funds. The election marks a significant change, as previous office bearers were appointed by the government, which was found to contravene FIFA regulations.

site_title: Car bomb blast kills three in central Baghdad: Medics
summary: A car bomb attack in central Baghdad's Karrada neighborhood killed at least three people and wounded seven on April 28. The blast targeted a traffic police compound, with several policemen among the victims. This is one of the deadliest bombings to hit the area, following a July 2016 attack that killed over 320 people. The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria is suspected of being behind the attack, but it was unclear if it was a suicide blast.

site_title: MOU signed between Jurong-Clementi Town Council and bike-sharing firms to encourage responsible bicycle use
summary: Jurong-Clementi Town Council and three bike-share companies - Mobike, ofo Singapore, and oBike - signed a one-year MOU to pilot a bike-sharing scheme in the area. The program aims to promote responsible bicycle use, with incentives for users to park in designated areas. The companies will also provide cycling patterns to improve future cycling path planning. The scheme replaces the proposed National Bicycle Sharing Scheme, which was shelved due to private bike-share companies entering the market. The pilot scheme will monitor user behavior and introduce measures to minimize vandalism and ensure bike safety.

site_title: Brexit guidelines: What the EU wants from Britain
summary: EU leaders will formally meet on April 29 to rubberstamp guidelines for Brexit negotiations. The EU 27 want Britain to settle its divorce terms before discussing a future trade relationship, aiming for a phased approach by the end of 2017. Key issues include the fate of 3.2 million EU citizens in the UK and 1.2 million Britons on the continent, the UK's exit bill estimated at up to 60 billion euros, and the border between Ireland and Northern Ireland. The EU also proposes automatic membership for Northern Ireland after Brexit if it reunifies with Ireland.

site_title: Football: Team LKT wins FAS election, Lim Kia Tong is new chief of Singapore football
summary: Lim Kia Tong, a lawyer and deputy chairman of FIFA's disciplinary committee, has won the election as the new president of the Football Association of Singapore (FAS), leading his slate, Team LKT, to a 30-13 victory over the opposing team, Game Changers. Lim, along with six other members of Team LKT, will serve on the FAS council for a four-year term. The election marks a significant shift in governance, as the FAS was previously led by appointed officials. The new council is expected to focus on transparency, youth development, and improving the country's football programs.

site_title: Asean leaders to push for stop to South China Sea land reclamation, militarisation
summary: Southeast Asian leaders will express "serious concerns" over China's land reclamation and militarization in the South China Sea, pushing for a stop to these activities at the end of their talks. The draft Asean document avoids mentioning the international tribunal's ruling on the Philippines' case, instead focusing on avoiding actions that may further complicate the situation. The move is likely to frustrate Beijing, with the Philippines' President Duterte having set aside the ruling in favor of securing investments and loans from China.

site_title: Sun, sand, sea: Resort living in Pasir Ris under HDB rejuvenation plans
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has announced plans to rejuvenate Pasir Ris, a town in Singapore, under its Remaking Our Heartland (ROH) programme. The makeover will include an elevated "highway" and Central Greenway, a 1.2km-long walkway and cycling path, connecting Pasir Ris Park to the town centre and nearby Tampines Expressway. The project aims to improve accessibility to the park, enhance public facilities, and provide more opportunities for residents. The upgrades will also include new public housing units, upgraded neighbourhood centres, and a new town centre.

site_title: South Korean presidential frontrunner says North Korea's missile launch futile
summary: South Korean presidential frontrunner Moon Jae In has described North Korea's latest missile launch as "an exercise in futility." His spokesman, Park Kwang On, urged the Kim Jong Un regime to stop "reckless provocative acts" and cooperate with the international community by giving up its nuclear program. The launch, which saw a missile disintegrate after several minutes, has been met with criticism from US and South Korean officials. The South Korean presidential election is set to take place on May 9.

site_title: US stocks dip as North Korea anxiety hits sentiment
summary: US stocks declined on Friday, April 28, as investors' anxiety over North Korea and other geopolitical issues overshadowed positive corporate earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.2% to 20,940.51, while the S&P 500 fell 0.2% to 2,384.20. Despite strong earnings from Alphabet and ExxonMobil, Intel's disappointing results and concerns about North Korea's nuclear program contributed to the market's downturn. The Nasdaq Composite Index also retreated from a record, closing at 6,047.61.

site_title: North Korea unsuccessfully test-fires ballistic missile, Donald Trump says test shows disrespect to China
summary: North Korea test-fired a ballistic missile on April 29, but it appeared to have failed. The US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson warned that failure to curb Pyongyang's nuclear and ballistic missile programs could lead to "catastrophic consequences." US President Donald Trump called the test an affront to China, North Korea's sole main ally, and said it showed disrespect to the country. The failed test comes as the USS Carl Vinson aircraft carrier group arrived in waters near the Korean peninsula, and tensions remain high over North Korea's nuclear and missile development.

site_title: Football legend Zidane urges French to snub far-right Le Pen at polls
summary: French football star and Real Madrid coach Zinedine Zidane urged French citizens to vote against far-right presidential candidate Marine Le Pen, saying "extremes are never good." Zidane, whose parents immigrated from Algeria, referenced his parents' experience in 2002 when the far-right candidate Jean-Marie Le Pen reached the second round, prompting a united vote against him. Le Pen dismissed Zidane's statement, accusing him of being influenced by his wealth to support centrist candidate Emmanuel Macron.

site_title: #spwm17 Singaporeans showcase their inner poet
summary: The Singapore Poetry Writing Month (SPWM) is an annual event where over 4,500 people write a poem daily for 30 days. Organized by a group of poetry enthusiasts, the month features daily prompts and encourages community engagement through comments and critiques. This year's prompts reflect the local nature of Singapore, including favorite bus routes, markets, and regional art forms. The event culminates in a closing party with prizes, poetry readings, and a chance to meet participants. A print anthology of the month's best pieces is also in the works, available through a crowdfunding campaign.

site_title: NSA stops some warrantless surveillance of American messages
summary: The US National Security Agency (NSA) has halted a form of warrantless surveillance that collected digital communications of Americans mentioning a foreign intelligence target. The program, known as "about" collection, will now limit its collection to internet communications sent directly to or from a foreign target. The agency will also delete the majority of collected data to protect US person communications. The decision, confirmed by the NSA, comes as a surprise to privacy advocates and is seen as a significant change to US surveillance policy, with potential implications for the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act.

site_title: 6.8-magnitude quake strikes the Philippines
summary: A 6.8-magnitude earthquake struck off the southern Philippines, triggering a tsunami warning that was later lifted. The quake occurred at 4:23am local time, 700km south-east of Manila, at a depth of 41km. Philippine authorities reported no immediate casualties or damage, but the Pacific Tsunami Warning Centre initially advised of hazardous tsunami waves for the Philippines and Indonesia. The alert was lifted after two hours, but local authorities are checking for potential damage. The Philippines is located on the Ring of Fire, a region prone to earthquakes and volcanic eruptions.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, April 29 edition
summary: North Korea test-fired a ballistic missile on April 29, 2017, which appeared to have failed, defying pressure from the US and China. US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson warned of "catastrophic consequences" if North Korea's nuclear and ballistic missile programs are not curbed. Pope Francis denounced religious extremism during a visit to Egypt, urging Muslim leaders to unite against violence. A Taiwanese hiker was rescued in Nepal, marking his 21st birthday after surviving 30kg weight loss and losing his girlfriend. Maria Sharapova faced criticism for receiving "extra help" in her comeback from a doping ban, while Ilie Nastase apologized for derogatory comments about Serena Williams.

site_title: Japanese PM Shinzo Abe asks British PM Theresa May for ‘smooth Brexit’ for business
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe asked British Prime Minister Theresa May to ensure a smooth Brexit to allow Japanese companies to continue operating in the UK. Abe praised May's efforts to secure Brexit transparency and a transitional period, citing concerns from Japan about the impact of Brexit on UK investment. Japanese companies, including Nissan and Hitachi, have invested over $40 billion in the UK and employ 140,000 people, making a smooth Brexit crucial for their operations. Abe emphasized the importance of free trade and cooperation between Japan, the UK, and the US.

site_title: Changi shoppers stand to win $1 million and a brand new S90 Volvo in airport's biggest retail promotion
summary: Changi Airport has launched its 'Be a Changi Millionaire' retail promotion, offering a $1 million cash prize and a brand new Volvo S90 T5 luxury sedan. To qualify, shoppers must spend at least $50 in a single receipt between May 4 and Oct 31. Six monthly finalists will be selected to enter a draw for the sedan, with a seventh finalist chosen from iShopChangi and an eighth from Platinum members of the Changi Rewards loyalty program. Four new Volvo S90 sedans will be on display at the event sites, and all finalists will receive a three-night hotel stay and cash prizes.

site_title: US could speed up North Korea sanctions in response to missile test: US official
summary: The US may expedite sanctions against North Korea in response to its recent failed missile test, including measures against specific entities. A US official stated that the test was a "provocation" that could prompt China to take action against North Korea. New sanctions could target financial institutions and front companies, as well as China, potentially angering Beijing. The US is also considering naval drills and deploying more ships and aircraft in the region as a show of force, but pre-emptive strikes are ruled out due to the risk of massive retaliation.

site_title: Tennis: Sharapova 'extra help' blasted by Stuttgart opponent
summary: Maria Sharapova advanced to the Stuttgart semi-finals with a 6-3, 6-4 win over Anett Kontaveit, her third consecutive victory in her comeback from a 15-month doping ban. However, her opponent, Kristina Mladenovic, questioned the fairness of receiving a wild card, suggesting Sharapova might be receiving "extra help" due to her fame and the tournament's desire for attention. Sharapova dismissed Mladenovic's comments, stating her success on the court is the proof of her comeback.

summary: The US military is investigating whether two US special operations commandos, Army Rangers Joshua Rodgers and Cameron Thomas, were killed by friendly fire during a raid on an ISIS compound in eastern Afghanistan. The two soldiers died in a three-hour firefight, along with several high-level ISIS leaders and fighters. A formal probe is underway to determine the cause of their deaths, with the possibility that the bullets came from US, Afghan, or militant gunfire.

Murray credited his improved performance at the net, where he started to dictate more points, for the win. He will face Dominic Thiem in the semi-finals after Thiem defeated Yuichi Sugita earlier on Friday.

site_title: Donald Trump moves to lift bans on Arctic drilling
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order to lift bans on offshore Arctic and Atlantic drilling, aiming to generate "billions of dollars" and create jobs. The order reviews Obama-era bans, which prohibited new drilling in US waters, and seeks to allow "responsible development" of offshore areas. The move was met with no mention of environmental concerns, sparking criticism. Trump claimed the bans deprived the country of thousands of jobs and billions of dollars in wealth.

site_title: Pope Francis denounces barbarity during Egypt visit, preaches tolerance
summary: Pope Francis has denounced barbarity and promoted tolerance during his two-day visit to Egypt, urging Muslim leaders to unite against religious extremism. The Pope's trip comes after Islamic State bombings killed at least 45 people in Egyptian churches, targeting ancient Christian communities. Francis emphasized the importance of peace and unity, criticizing the notion of political Islam and calling for good education to counter hatred and violence. His visit aims to improve Christian-Muslim ties and bolster Egypt's international image, which has been rattled by attacks on Christians.

The NRA, which backed Trump's 2016 campaign, welcomed him with a triumphant welcome, praising his appointment of conservative judge Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court.

site_title: SpaceX to launch classified US government payload on Sunday
summary: SpaceX is set to launch a classified US government payload, known as NROL-76, on Sunday from Cape Canaveral, Florida. The mission, which marks SpaceX's first military launch, is part of the company's effort to make rocket parts recyclable. The Falcon 9 rocket will carry the payload into space and then make a controlled landing on solid ground, with the first stage powering its engines and flying back to Earth. The launch aims to challenge the US military's long-standing reliance on United Launch Alliance, a joint operation of Boeing and Lockheed Martin, for national security launches.

site_title: Conte out to contain threat of ex-Chelsea striker Lukaku
summary: Chelsea manager Antonio Conte confirmed paying close attention to Everton striker Romelu Lukaku to prevent scoring against the Blues, not to sign him in the summer. Lukaku is the league's top scorer, but Conte plans to find a solution to stop him and other players, not changing his current team. A win for Chelsea would secure Champions League qualification, with only one hurdle remaining to win the title.

site_title: Football: Wembley to become Spurs home in 2017/18
summary: Tottenham Hotspur will play all their home games at Wembley Stadium for the 2017/18 season due to the demolition of their existing White Hart Lane stadium. The 61,000-seater Wembley will be their temporary home while their new stadium is being completed. Tottenham chairman Daniel Levy described the decision as "a momentous day" and promised a fitting farewell to White Hart Lane with their final match against Manchester United on May 14. The team will return to their new stadium after the season, which will host NFL games and contribute to the club's future growth and success.

site_title: Japanese PM Shinzo Abe says will work with Britain's Theresa May on North Korea, South China Sea disputes
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledged to work with British Prime Minister Theresa May to address threats to international order from North Korea and the South China Sea. Abe stated that the UK and Japan will closely cooperate on global issues, including North Korea's nuclear and missile development and the South China Sea dispute. This agreement aims to counter destabilization and promote stability in the region, with Abe describing the partnership as "extremely significant."

site_title: Football: I'll be disappointed if Spurs miss out on title, says Pochettino
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Mauricio Pochettino expressed disappointment if his team fails to win the Premier League title, despite a four-point gap to Chelsea. Pochettino believes his squad has improved focus after last season's title loss to Leicester City. Spurs, unbeaten at home in 17 league games, face Arsenal in the North London derby at White Hart Lane, which could be its final local derby at the stadium. Pochettino emphasized the importance of preparation and playing well in the derby, with Spurs hoping to move to their new 61,000-seat stadium in the 2018/19 season.

site_title: Formula One: Vettel on top as Ferrari dominate
summary: Sebastian Vettel led the way in Friday's free practice for the Russian Grand Prix, clocking a best lap of 1:34.120 seconds. The Ferrari driver edged out teammate Kimi Raikkonen, while Valtteri Bottas took third place. Mercedes driver Lewis Hamilton, seven points behind Vettel in the title race, struggled to keep up, finishing third. Ferrari's dominant performance marked a bold statement of intent to end Mercedes' three-year dominance at the Sochi Autodrom.

site_title: China warns situation with North Korea at ‘critical point’
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi warned that the situation with North Korea is at a "critical point" and urged a peaceful settlement through dialogue and negotiations. China pledged to fully implement UN sanctions on North Korea and step up non-proliferation efforts. US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson pressed the Security Council to impose stronger sanctions in response to further provocations. The meeting comes as tensions escalate following North Korea's nuclear and missile development, with the US warning of a "major, major conflict" with Pyongyang.

site_title: Tennis: Nadal joins Murray in Barcelona semi-finals
summary: Rafael Nadal advanced to the semi-finals of the Barcelona Open, defeating Chung Hyeon in straight sets, 7-6(1) 6-2. Nadal, the 14-time Grand Slam champion, praised Chung's character and took to the court with respect. Meanwhile, Andy Murray also reached the semi-finals, overcoming Albert Ramos-Vinolas 2-6 6-4 7-6(4). Nadal will face either Karen Khachanov or Horacio Zeballos in the semi-finals on Saturday.

site_title: Make yeongeun bokkeum, Korean-style stir-fried lotus root with peppers and mushrooms
summary: Korean-style stir-fried lotus root, known as yeongeun bokkeum, is a simple and nutritious dish made with lotus root, peppers, and mushrooms. To prepare, peel and slice the lotus root, then soak it in vinegar water to remove impurities. The dish is quickly prepared by stir-frying the vegetables in a mixture of oil, soy sauce, and other seasonings. Yeongeun bokkeum can be enjoyed as a side dish or light meal, and is rich in fiber and essential nutrients like vitamin C and potassium. It is a quick and flavorful way to prepare this crunchy and starchy root.

site_title: Britain foils active terror plot after parliament arrest
summary: British police have arrested six people as part of an active terror plot, following a separate counter-terrorism operation that resulted in the arrest of a 27-year-old man near parliament on suspicion of terrorism offences and possession of knives. The man, believed to be a British national born overseas, was tracked by police and MI5 before his arrest. A woman in her twenties was shot during the raid on a property in north London, but remains in a stable condition. The arrests bring the total number of counter-terrorism operations in London to a near daily basis, with police saying they have contained the threats posed by the suspects.

site_title: Tennis: Sharapova into Stuttgart semis on doping ban return
summary: Maria Sharapova defeated Estonian qualifier Anett Kontaveit 6-3, 6-4 in the quarterfinals of the Stuttgart WTA tournament, advancing to the semifinals for her third consecutive win since returning from a 15-month doping ban. Sharapova, ranked 30, showcased her impressive skills, hitting four aces and 28 winners, while Kontaveit put up a fight but ultimately lost. Sharapova will face French player Kristina Mladenovic in the semifinals, and a win would propel her to a ranking of approximately 125th, allowing her to qualify for the French Open and Wimbledon.

site_title: The Straits Times' News In A Minute: April 28, 2017
summary: The Singapore government warned of a potential rise in unemployment due to the slowing economy and structural changes. The National University of Singapore was ordered to implement mandatory personal data protection training for student leaders within 120 days after a data breach. Meanwhile, Shanti Pereira won the 200m race at the Singapore Open Track & Field Championships.

site_title: Tennis: Nastase sorry for Serena 'chocolate with milk' remarks
summary: Romanian tennis great Ilie Nastase apologized for derogatory comments about Serena Williams, calling them "spontaneous" and "unforgivable." He also faced backlash for a foul-mouthed Fed Cup tirade, which led to his suspension by the International Tennis Federation. Nastase's comments, including a remark about Williams' baby being "chocolate with milk," sparked outrage and support from the tennis world and beyond. The incident has been a difficult few days for Nastase, who has dedicated his life to tennis and its audiences.

site_title: Boxing: Anthony Joshua v Wladimir Klitschko in heavyweight battle of the ages
summary: Anthony Joshua and Wladimir Klitschko are set to face off in a highly anticipated heavyweight battle at Wembley Stadium in London on April 29, 2017. Joshua, 27, is the young and seemingly invincible champion, while Klitschko, 41, is the aging and deposed former title-holder. The fight is expected to earn both fighters over £10 million and will be broadcast to over 140 countries. Joshua believes his youth and sharpness will give him an edge, while Klitschko relies on his experience to outlast his opponent.

site_title: Formula One: Mercedes still the team to beat in Russia, says Vettel
summary: Formula One champion Sebastian Vettel believes Mercedes remains the team to beat at the Russian Grand Prix, despite Ferrari's strong practice times. Vettel attributed the gap between Ferrari and Mercedes to "artificial" factors, suggesting Mercedes didn't show their full pace and didn't get a single lap together. Ferrari's Kimi Raikkonen was fastest in practice, with Vettel second, while Mercedes' Valtteri Bottas was third. The Russian Grand Prix is a circuit Mercedes have dominated in the past, and Vettel expects Ferrari to be strong but notes Mercedes' potential for improvement.

site_title: Formula One: McLaren's Stoffel Vandoorne faces Russian Grand Prix grid penalty
summary: McLaren driver Stoffel Vandoorne will start the Russian Formula One Grand Prix from the back of the grid due to engine problems, resulting in a 15-place penalty. Vandoorne's team, McLaren, is struggling in the season, currently last in the championship without a point. The team's poor performance has led to Fernando Alonso skipping the Monaco Grand Prix to compete in the Indianapolis 500, citing a fresh perspective to focus on.

site_title: Power women, ID cards for holy cows, Liar's Poker
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam was elected after a slate cherry-picked by Beijing. Australian Foreign Minister Julie Bishop and Indonesian Minister for Maritime Resources and Fisheries Susi Pudjiastuti are leading protests against Chinese Coast Guard intrusions. Women leaders are stepping up in Asia, with notable examples including Singapore's Josephine Teo, Malaysia's Rafidah Aziz, and India's Shashi Tharoor. US President Donald Trump has expressed admiration for Chinese President Xi Jinping, with possible influences from media mogul Rupert Murdoch, tycoon Carl Icahn, and billionaire Stephen Schwarzman. India has recommended unique ID numbers for its holy cows, while China stocks have experienced sharp falls despite better-than-expected economic growth.

site_title: US urges global community to isolate North Korea, pins hope on China
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson urges the global community to isolate North Korea, calling for sanctions and economic pressure to halt its nuclear and missile programs. He warns that the threat of a North Korean nuclear attack on major cities is real and that the US will not negotiate with North Korea unless it shows a good faith commitment to abide by UN resolutions. Tillerson also singles out China, citing its significant trade with North Korea and urging full compliance from all UN Security Council members.

site_title: Netflix remake of Journey To The West slammed for whitewashing
summary: A Netflix remake of Journey To The West, a classic Chinese tale, has been criticized for "whitewashing" after none of the main cast was revealed to be Chinese. The series, titled The Legend Of The Monkey, features Australian-Thai actor Chai Hansen and New Zealand actors in key roles. The move has sparked online outrage, with many Asian fans expressing disappointment and frustration, citing past examples of whitewashing in films like Ghost In The Shell and The Great Wall. The series is set to air with 10 half-hour episodes in 2018.

site_title: Tech firms race to spot video violence
summary: Tech companies, including Google and Facebook, are racing to develop artificial intelligence to automatically spot and block violent content on social media before it goes viral. A dozen or more companies are working on deep learning-based solutions, but none have cracked the problem completely. The AI systems use neural networks to learn from examples and identify violent scenes, but limitations include the software's reliance on training data and subjective interpretation of violence. Humans must still be involved to verify the authenticity of flagged content, and industry adoption is hindered by added expense.

site_title: NS officers have made crucial contributions to Singapore's nation-building: Desmond Lee
summary: Senior Minister of State Desmond Lee emphasized the crucial contributions of National Service (NS) officers to Singapore's nation-building. In a speech at the launch of the SCDF NS Gallery, Lee highlighted the commitment and shared responsibility of NS officers in keeping Singapore safe and secure. The gallery, which commemorates 50 years of national service, showcases the journey of the SCDF from the mid-1970s to present day, featuring equipment, uniforms, and stories of pioneer NSmen who served in critical roles such as firefighting and rescue operations.

site_title: Football: Team LKT issue closing statement ahead of FAS election
summary: Team LKT, led by lawyer Lim Kia Tong, issued a closing statement ahead of the FAS election, emphasizing the importance of restoring trust and confidence in the sport's leadership. They promised to be more inclusive and consultative, and unveiled a 10-point plan to bring football to a better place. The team has secured sponsorships and initiated discussions with government agencies to free up areas for play and improve youth development schemes. Team LKT is competing against Game Changers led by Hougang United chairman Bill Ng in the historic polls on April 29.

site_title: Formula One: Bernie Ecclestone made us 'look like idiots' - Sepang boss
summary: Bernie Ecclestone, 86, admitted to over-charging tracks to stage Formula One races in an interview. The move led to the cancellation of the Malaysian Grand Prix, which will no longer be held. The circuit's CEO, Razlan Razali, criticized Ecclestone's statement, saying it showed a lack of respect and made them look foolish. The decision to cancel the race was due to low attendances and high fees, which cost the government $67.6 million annually. Ecclestone's admission comes after he was ousted from his controlling position in Formula One.

site_title: Nasdaq heads for fourth record this week as investors shrug off weak US GDP data
summary: The Nasdaq Composite Index is on track for its fourth record high this week, driven by strong quarterly earnings reports from Amazon and Alphabet. The tech-heavy index rose 0.2% as investors shrugged off weak US GDP data, which showed a 0.7% annual growth rate in the first quarter. Despite this, the Nasdaq is on track to post gains for the sixth straight month, with corporate earnings season continuing to impress. The S&P 500 Index and Dow Jones Industrial Average were little changed, but all three benchmarks have advanced at least 1.7% this week.

site_title: Rescued Taiwanese hiker marks sombre birthday in Nepal
summary: A Taiwanese hiker, Liang Sheng-yueh, marked his 21st birthday in a Kathmandu hospital after being rescued from Nepal seven weeks after going missing. Liang, severely malnourished, survived on salt and water for 47 days after his girlfriend Liu Chen-chun, 18, died. He was airlifted from a remote region after being stuck near a waterfall. Liang expressed regret for the ordeal and vowed to be more careful in the future, but was still deeply troubled by Liu's death. He is slowly regaining strength and walking again.

site_title: US economy grew 0.7% in Q1, slowest pace in three years
summary: The US economy expanded at a 0.7% annualized rate in Q1, the slowest pace in three years, due to weak auto sales and lower home-heating bills. Consumer spending rose 0.3%, the worst performance since 2009, while investment in housing and oil drilling contributed to the growth. Despite forecasts of a rebound, the GDP slowdown may be due to transitory forces and could be influenced by policy support such as tax cuts. The Federal Reserve is unlikely to be dissuaded from raising interest rates in the coming months.

site_title: Trump's 100 days in office: 8 things he said in interviews about life as US president
summary: US President Donald Trump completed 100 days in office on April 29, 2017. In interviews, he discussed the challenges of his new job, including missing his old life and being surprised by the lack of privacy. He also clarified his stance on Taiwan, China, and NATO, stating he wouldn't want to cause problems for Chinese President Xi Jinping and that NATO is not obsolete. Trump also discussed his first address to Congress, calling it one of the best speeches in history, and revealed he had never heard of WikiLeaks prior to the 2016 campaign.

site_title: Man in Ang Mo Kio reversing tragedy wants to give up driving for good
summary: A 67-year-old Singaporean man, Mr Quek Chin Ling, has decided to give up driving after his wife, 64, died in a car accident in Ang Mo Kio on April 25. The couple was on their way to a briefing in China when Mr Quek allegedly reversed into his wife, who fell and hit her head on the ground. The couple had been married for over 35 years and had a close relationship. Mr Quek is struggling to cope with the loss and has expressed difficulty breaking the news to his two sons, who are still in shock.

site_title: US Congress passes short-term Bill to avert government shutdown
summary: The US Congress passed a short-term stopgap bill to avert a government shutdown at midnight, providing federal funding until May 5. The measure was approved by the House (382-30) and Senate (voice vote) and now awaits President Donald Trump's signature. The bill aims to give lawmakers another week to reach a deal on federal spending, with contentious issues remaining, including defence spending and healthcare programs. The stopgap measure is the third during the current fiscal year, and lawmakers are expected to negotiate a longer-term funding bill in the coming days.

site_title: Court finds Gallop Stable guilty of animal cruelty
summary: A Singapore court found Gallop Stable guilty of animal cruelty for neglecting a 17-year-old mare named Sharpy, who suffered from severe inflammation and infection of her right hind leg. The stable failed to provide adequate veterinary attention, despite knowing of her suffering. Judge Lim Keng Yeow convicted the stable, stating the omission to call a vet was "quite unconscionable". The stable faces a maximum $10,000 fine. The case was adjourned for mitigation and sentencing.

site_title: Pope Francis arrives in Egypt with message of peace
summary: Pope Francis arrived in Egypt on April 28, 2017, with a message of peace and reconciliation, amidst a time of heightened tension for the country's Christian community. Egypt's Copts face unprecedented pressure from ISIS militants, following twin church bombings that killed 45 people, and Pope Francis hopes his visit will help bring peace and encourage dialogue with the Islamic world. He will meet with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi, Grand Imam Sheikh Ahmed al-Tayeb, and head of the Coptic Orthodox Church Pope Tawadros II, in efforts to improve relations and condemn radical Islam.

site_title: Framework for code of conduct on South China Sea on track: Vivian Balakrishnan
summary: Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan expressed confidence that a framework for a code of conduct on the South China Sea will be completed by the middle of the year. A strong sense of common will among Asean member nations and China exists to reach an agreement, with a deadline set for June. The framework sets parameters for negotiating a legally-binding code of conduct, aiming to build confidence and reduce tensions in the disputed waters, where China claims territories claimed by the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia, and Brunei.

site_title: EU says Britain must settle key divorce issues first before talks on post-Brexit trade deal
summary: EU President Donald Tusk stated that Britain must settle key divorce issues, including the fate of EU citizens in Britain, Britain's exit bill, and the Ireland border, before discussing a post-Brexit trade deal. Tusk proposed phased talks, where Britain must make "sufficient progress" on these issues before talks on future relations. The EU emphasizes that progress on "people, money, and Ireland" must come first, as the bloc has limited time to conclude the talks.

site_title: Furore over Holocaust comments hits Marine Le Pen's French election bid
summary: Marine Le Pen's presidential bid in France faced a setback when Jean-Francois Jalkh, the interim head of her National Front party, stepped down amid charges that he shares Holocaust denial views, sparking a furore over the party's past associations with xenophobia and anti-Semitism. Jalkh's comments, made in 2005, were linked to a professor convicted of questioning the scale of Jewish extermination in Nazi gas chambers. Marine Le Pen, who expelled her father Jean-Marie Le Pen from the party two years ago, now faces a challenge in distancing herself from her father's past remarks and reviving her campaign against centrist Emmanuel Macron.

site_title: Bangladeshi girl with three legs can walk and run after successful Australia surgery
summary: A 3-year-old Bangladeshi girl, Choity Khatun, who was born with three legs due to a rare condition, has undergone successful surgery in Australia, enabling her to walk and run. The complex procedure, involving eight doctors and eight hours, was performed in November after months of planning and consultation with experts from Europe and the US. Choity, who was malnourished and incontinent, has made significant progress, including becoming continent, and can now play like other children. She is returning to Bangladesh after her mother's 22-year-old husband.

site_title: Korean girl band Twice are raring to impress Singapore fans
summary: K-pop girl band Twice is set to perform in Singapore at The Star Theatre on Saturday, marking their first concert in the city-state. The nine-piece group, known for hits like "Cheer Up" and "Like Ooh-Ahh," has gained immense popularity globally, with their songs dominating music charts in Korea and abroad. Despite a recent controversy surrounding Taiwanese member Tzuyu, the group remains in high spirits, citing their fans' energy as a major motivator. Tickets for the concert have sold out, with only limited seats available.

site_title: 2.4% hike in gas tariff for households from May 1 to July 31
summary: Singapore's City Gas will raise gas tariffs for households by 2.4% (0.43 cents per kilowatt hour) from May 1 to July 31, due to a 9.2% increase in fuel costs compared to the previous quarter. The revised tariffs have been approved by the Energy Market Authority. This increase affects households using City Gas, while commercial and industrial customers will continue to be supplied by the company.

site_title: 43-year-old man arrested for vandalising 5 buildings in Bugis
summary: A 43-year-old man was arrested for vandalising 5 buildings in Bugis, Singapore, after graffiti was found on various structures on April 24. The suspect, identified through CCTV images, was arrested along Hougang Avenue 8 on Thursday. He was charged with vandalism and faces a minimum fine of $2,000 or up to three years in jail, as well as up to eight strokes of the cane.

site_title: Mediacorp CEO Shaun Seow leaves to join parent Temasek Holdings
summary: Mediacorp CEO Shaun Seow is leaving the firm to join Temasek Holdings' Telecom, Media & Technology (TMT) investment team as a managing director. He will assist in the transition until September 30 and help find his successor. Seow, who has led Mediacorp since 2011, will oversee companies including Mediacorp, Singapore Technologies Telemedia, and stakes in Alibaba Group and Singtel, all within Temasek's portfolio.

site_title: Football: Game Changers issue closing statement ahead of FAS election
summary: The Game Changers, a team fielded by Hougang United chairman Bill Ng, released a closing statement ahead of the FAS election, urging affiliates to vote for them to lead Singapore football for the next four years. The team emphasizes the unifying power of football, stating it brings people together regardless of age, gender, or background. They outline plans to revamp Singapore football, including changes to administration, technical aspects, and commercializing the sport, with the goal of revitalizing the game and making it more accessible to all Singaporeans.

site_title: Philippines and Indonesia eye launch of coordinated maritime patrols against piracy, terrorists soon
summary: The Philippines and Indonesia have agreed to launch coordinated maritime patrols against piracy, terrorism, and drug trafficking. The move aims to address traditional and emerging threats in the region. President Rodrigo Duterte and Indonesian President Joko Widodo signed a joint declaration to step up cooperation, including a trilateral maritime patrol called Indomaphi. The two countries also plan to establish a hotline to combat piracy and kidnappings in their shared waters, particularly in the Sulu Sea.

site_title: Football: Thiago Alcantara extends Bayern Munich contract until 2021
summary: Bayern Munich has extended the contract of midfielder Thiago Alcantara until 2021, adding two years to his existing deal. The 26-year-old has been a key player for the team, making 20 appearances for Spain since 2011. Bayern's chairman Karl-Heinz Rummenigge praised Thiago as one of the best midfielders in Europe, while Thiago expressed his desire to win many titles with the team in the future. This extension comes after Bayern's German Cup semifinal defeat to Borussia Dortmund and their Champions League quarterfinal loss to Real Madrid.

site_title: Football: Dreaded vote of confidence for under-fire Bayern coach Carlo Ancelotti
summary: Bayern Munich chairman Karl-Heinz Rummenigge has defended head coach Carlo Ancelotti, saying he is backing Ancelotti despite the team's disappointing exits in the Champions League and German Cup. Bayern lost to Real Madrid and Borussia Dortmund, respectively, and are now winless in five games. Rummenigge attributed the losses to injuries and refereeing decisions, and said the team will focus on securing their fifth-straight Bundesliga title. Rummenigge has ruled out any panic and said the club will not rush to replace Ancelotti, with Julian Nagelsmann being a potential candidate if needed.

site_title: Athletics: Two national marks broken on final day of Singapore Open
summary: Two national marks were set on the final day of the Singapore Open Track & Field Championships. Wendy Enn broke Lynette Lim's 11.89m triple jump record with a leap of 12.05m, while Cheryl Chan set a new 3,000m steeplechase record with a time of 11:42.2, beating her previous national record of 11:45.16sec.

site_title: Teen who died while skateboarding ruled as tragic misadventure
summary: An 18-year-old Singaporean teen, Louis Chen Hong Ming, died from extensive liver laceration after falling while skateboarding at Pine Grove estate. Chen left his apartment at 9pm without telling his family and returned home 30 minutes later without his skateboard, wearing only one slipper. He suffered significant injuries, including a chest abrasion, and died three hours later. The coroner ruled his death a tragic misadventure, citing the importance of using safety equipment, proper footwear, and protective gear to prevent similar accidents. Chen's death highlights the risks of skateboarding, especially for inexperienced riders.

site_title: My wish for social science research
summary: The Social Science Research Council (SSRC) in Singapore has announced 12 grant recipients for research studies, giving researchers the freedom to publish their findings without government strings attached. This model of academic freedom is a shift from conventional practice in Singapore, where government funding often comes with restrictions. The SSRC has set aside $50 million for research grants, with a focus on topics such as financial decisions in retirement and the impact of digital technologies on society. The council's decision aims to promote social science research and provide a platform for researchers to share their findings with the public.

site_title: Football: ST looks at a starting XI of key issues new FAS leaders need to fix
summary: The new Football Association of Singapore (FAS) council will face 11 pressing issues upon taking office, including reconciling the fractured football community, implementing greater governance and accountability, and addressing the decline of the S-League. The new leaders must prioritize domestic issues, such as revitalizing the S-League and engaging with grassroots and amateur football. They must also adopt a consultative leadership approach and build a platform for continuity to ensure the organization's stability and success. The council's vision and leadership style will be crucial in restoring Singapore football to its former glory.

site_title: 27-year-old arrested for several cases of cheating involving discounted shopping vouchers
summary: A 27-year-old man in Singapore has been arrested for multiple cases of cheating involving discounted shopping vouchers. One victim reported being cheated after purchasing $380 worth of vouchers for $300 on Carousell, receiving only $30 worth of vouchers and unrelated documents. The suspect is believed to be involved in several similar cases. Anyone found guilty of cheating can face up to 10 years in jail and fines. The police advise the public to be cautious when making online purchases, verifying the vendor's reputation and location, and never sharing personal or financial information with unknown individuals.

site_title: Football: Dejan Lovren signs new long-term Liverpool deal
summary: Liverpool defender Dejan Lovren has signed a new long-term contract until 2021. The 27-year-old has made 105 appearances for the club since joining in 2014. Lovren credits manager Jurgen Klopp for his improvement this season, saying he changed his mentality and approach to the game. Despite a challenging season, Lovren remains confident that Liverpool can secure Champions League football next season, with four matches remaining. The contract extension is seen as a significant boost to the team's future prospects, with Klopp praising Lovren's commitment and potential for continued success.

site_title: Asean leaders gather in Manila for summit as grouping marks golden jubilee this year
summary: ASEAN leaders gathered in Manila for the 30th Asean Summit, celebrating the grouping's golden jubilee. The 10-member nations will discuss ways to strengthen Asean and ensure unity, focusing on the Asean Economic Community and regional cooperation. Key agenda items include the Korean peninsula, terrorism, and trade, with leaders aiming to conclude a region-wide trade pact by the end of the year. The summit marks a significant milestone for Asean, which has grown to become the world's fifth-largest economy.

site_title: Golf: Hur Mi Jung grabs early lead at Texas Shootout
summary: Hur Mi Jung of South Korea took the early lead at the Texas Shootout with a 65, four-under par, at the Las Colinas Country Club. Lexi Thompson shot a 69 and is two strokes back, trying to put her ANA Inspiration controversy behind her. Thailand's Ariya Jutanugarn and Australian Katherine Kirk are also two strokes back, along with Michelle Wie and others. Nine players are tied for ninth at 68, setting the stage for a competitive second round.

site_title: Three more arrested on third day of police raids on massage parlours
summary: Police in Singapore raided two massage parlours on April 28, arresting three women and a male customer. The third day of raids, part of ongoing enforcement efforts, targeted unlicensed massage parlours along MacPherson Road and Upper Paya Lebar Road. Condoms were found wrapped in foil and stashed in a pill bottle, and a masseuse was found in a state of undress during the raid. The arrests bring the total number of establishments checked over the three days to 15, with six arrests made previously at Little India.

site_title: Chinese court sentences human rights lawyer Li Heping in secret trial
summary: China sentenced human rights lawyer Li Heping to a three-year suspended sentence in a secret trial, raising concerns about the country's increasing transparency in high-profile cases. Li, known for defending blind lawyer Chen Guangcheng, was found guilty of "subverting state power" and will be released from detention but closely monitored by police. Human rights groups claim Li was likely tortured to force a confession and that the secret trial is a pattern of the government's handling of cases during the 2015 crackdown.

site_title: 12 points summing up the FAS saga: Implications for Singapore football
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department conducted raids on the Football Association of Singapore (FAS) office and several clubs on April 20, amid a police probe into suspected misuse of club funds and a purported attempt to obstruct audits. Four individuals, including FAS chairman Bill Ng, his wife Bonnie Wong, and two former officials, are out on police bail. The probe centers around Tiong Bahru FC's $500,000 donation to the Asean Football Federation and allegations of financial irregularities at other clubs. The FAS election, scheduled for April 29, will now be closely watched by world governing body FIFA amid the ongoing investigation.

site_title: Female clerics declare fatwa on child marriage in Indonesia
summary: Female Islamic clerics in Indonesia issued a fatwa against child marriage, calling it "harmful" and stating its prevention is mandatory. The fatwa, issued at a three-day conference, comes amid Indonesia's high rate of underage marriage, with one in six girls marrying before age 18. The clerics cited studies showing the negative effects of early marriage on girls' education and well-being, urging the government to raise the minimum marriage age for girls to 18. The fatwa, while not legally binding, aims to raise awareness and influence government action to address the issue.

site_title: The Colour Run Night to make South-east Asian debut in Singapore on Sept 23
summary: The Colour Run Night is set to debut in Singapore on September 23, marking the first time the event has taken place in South-east Asia at night. The 5km course will feature a "glow-fest" with neon hues, illuminating bubbles and colour shows. Registration opens on May 1, with a starting fee of $70 per participant and discounts available for CIMB Bank customers. The event celebrates health, joy, and individuality, with no winners or official times, and aims to bring the local community together.

site_title: Singapore stocks recover slightly, STI ends 35 points up for the week
summary: Singapore stocks ended the week 1.13% higher, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 35.61 points to 3,175.44. Local lenders drove gains, led by United Overseas Bank, which rose 1.5% after posting strong first-quarter earnings. Meanwhile, markets in Hong Kong and Tokyo pulled back, and Shanghai posted its worst month of the year due to fears of a crackdown on riskier financing. The week's gains were largely driven by cautious optimism ahead of the first 100 days of US President Trump's term.

site_title: More meal options on China's high speed rail trains soon
summary: China Railway Corp plans to introduce more food suppliers and offer passengers more meal options on high-speed trains, following criticism of overpriced boxed lunches. The company will build an online platform for qualified suppliers to sell meals directly to passengers, with no restrictions on suppliers. The move aims to increase competition and make the catering service more market-oriented. Prices will be determined by the market, with the cheapest meal option available at 15 yuan. The plan aims to improve the passenger experience and address concerns over high prices.

site_title: UIC posts flat earnings of S$59.8 million for Q1
summary: United Industrial Corp (UIC) posted flat earnings of S$59.8 million for Q1, despite a 31% jump in revenue to S$264.5 million. Revenue from trading properties increased 81% to S$127.3 million, while gross rental income from investment properties remained stable at S$69 million. Profit before share of results of associated companies and joint ventures rose 2% to S$70.5 million. UIC shares ended unchanged at S$3.16, driven by a steady take-up rate of office and retail spaces and improving sentiments in the residential sector.

site_title: OCBC faces shareholders questions on NPLs, executive pay at AGM
summary: OCBC faced questions from shareholders at its annual general meeting on asset quality outlook, NPL exposure to the oil and gas sector, and rising costs. CEO Samuel Tsien expressed caution, noting the uncertainty of oil prices and lack of consistent growth. The bank's NPL ratio stood at 1.26% in Q4, with 0.61 percentage points attributed to oil and gas loans. OCBC's chairman, Ooi Sang Kuang, was cautiously optimistic on the economic outlook, citing signs of growth in the EU and China. All nine resolutions were passed, with no executive pay cuts mentioned.

site_title: Afghan Taleban announce start of 'spring offensive'
summary: The Afghan Taliban launched their "spring offensive" on April 28, 2017, targeting foreign forces with conventional attacks and guerrilla warfare. The operation, named Operation Mansouri, aims to drive out foreign forces and establish a political approach in areas under Taliban control. The offensive comes after a devastating attack on a military base outside Mazar-i-Sharif, which killed at least 135 young recruits. The Taliban's annual spring offensive typically marks the start of the fighting season, but this year's campaign is expected to be particularly intense due to the group's recent successes.

site_title: 4 substances with effects like controlled drugs' reclassified as Class A controlled drugs: CNB
summary: Singapore reclassified four New Psychoactive Substances (NPSs) as Class A controlled drugs, effective May 1, with a fifth NPS, U-47700, also added to the list. The substances, similar to controlled drugs like cannabis and methamphetamine, pose a serious risk of abuse and dependence. Trafficking, manufacture, or consumption of these substances will carry a minimum sentence of at least five years' jail and five strokes of the cane. The move aims to combat the rapid increase in NPSs worldwide, which have been linked to adverse physical and psychological reactions, including seizures and death.

site_title: Football: Francesco Totti fires Rome derby warning to Lazio
summary: Francesco Totti has issued a warning to Lazio ahead of the capital derby, stating that Roma aims to "destroy" them and win the derby to claim the second automatic Champions League spot in Serie A. Roma holds a four-point lead over Napoli, and Totti expressed confidence in the team's chances despite the impending end of his career. The match is scheduled for Sunday, with Roma facing AC Milan, then Juventus at home.

site_title: Football: Banned Joey Barton got off lightly, says FA
summary: Joey Barton, a Burnley midfielder, has received an 18-month ban from football due to betting offences. The English Football Association (FA) deemed the ban the "shortest possible sanction" considering the severity of the breaches. Barton, who struggled with a gambling addiction, will appeal the length of the ban, citing it as a factor in his decision to retire early. Manager Sean Dyche has expressed disappointment with the ban, stating Barton will not be offered a new contract at the Premier League club. Barton's betting breaches occurred between 2006 and 2016.

site_title: Football: Monaco hoping for a Nice favour
summary: Monaco, who lead PSG in Ligue 1, have a favorable opportunity to gain an advantage this weekend with a helping hand from Nice, who host PSG. Monaco's Portuguese coach Leonardo Jardim fielded a young team in the French Cup semi-final, which PSG won 5-0, but Monaco remain focused on their league title bid. The match between Nice and PSG could be crucial in determining the top two spots in the league.

site_title: Cherie Chung on her beautiful life alone: My life is the happiest now
summary: Former Hong Kong actress Cherie Chung, 57, has been living alone for nearly 10 years after her husband's death in 2007. She enjoys her solitude, pursuing interests like philosophy, music, and photography. Chung has held exhibitions of her works and collaborated with brands like Amorepacific. She has no regrets about stopping her acting career, saying her life is now "the happiest now" and she controls her own time, doing things she chooses.

site_title: Football: Bayern sign Kingsley Coman on permanent deal
summary: Bayern Munich has activated a clause to make Kingsley Coman's transfer from Juventus permanent, signing him to a contract until 2020. The 20-year-old French international has scored eight goals in 58 games for Bayern since joining on a two-year loan deal in 2015. Bayern CEO Karl-Heinz Rummenigge praised Coman's potential, citing his experience playing for the French national team and at the European Championship. The move is seen as a strategic move by Bayern to strengthen their squad for the future.

site_title: Football: Sevilla close in on Champions League football next season
summary: Sevilla FC secured a 2-1 win over Celta Vigo, moving eight points clear in the Champions League spot in LaLiga. French striker Wissam Ben Yedder scored a 79th-minute winner, following a goal from Joaquin Correa in the first half. Celta Vigo's Pablo Hernandez was sent off in the 53rd minute. The win puts Sevilla level on points with Atletico Madrid, with four games remaining in the season. This victory solidifies Sevilla's position in the Champions League.

site_title: Thai court issues arrest warrant for Red Bull heir
summary: A Thai court has issued an arrest warrant for Worayuth Yoovidhya, heir to the Red Bull empire, over a 2012 hit-and-run that killed a policeman. Worayuth, 27 at the time, allegedly drove his Ferrari into the officer, dragging his body for several hundred meters before fleeing. The warrant, issued after hours of deliberation, marks a belated move to hold Worayuth accountable for the crime. The case has sparked concerns about the justice system's treatment of elites in Thailand, where Worayuth's family is the fourth richest in the country.

site_title: Turning leftover bread from bakeries into ale saves food from going to waste
summary: Food waste expert Tristram Stuart has developed a way to turn leftover bread into craft ale, reducing waste and creating a lucrative product. After partnering with breweries in London and New York, Stuart's Toast ale has been produced in quantities, recycling 3.6 tons of bread in its first 15 months. The beer is made with malt and citrus notes, and has been featured at the Tribeca Film Festival. Stuart plans to expand the concept globally, partnering with bakeries and nonprofits to create regional versions of the beer, with all profits going to his anti-food waste organization, Feedback.

site_title: Golf: Two-way first round tie at Zurich Classic
summary: World No. 5 Jordan Spieth and American Ryan Palmer tied for the lead at the PGA Zurich Classic after a six-under par 66 in alternate-shot play. They are tied with Australians Ryan Ruffels and Kyle Stanley, who also scored 66. The event shifted to a pairs format, and Spieth and Palmer birdied three of the last five holes to take the top spot. The leaders are one stroke ahead of South Koreans KJ Choi and Charlie Wi, who share third with 67.

site_title: Para sports: Yip Pin Xiu named Singapore's chef de mission for 2017 Asian Youth Para Games in Dubai
summary: Yip Pin Xiu, a three-time Paralympic gold medalist, has been appointed as chef de mission for the 2017 Asian Youth Para Games in Dubai. The 25-year-old para swimmer will be the youngest CDM for Singapore, replacing her previous role as the Republic's face of para sports. She will also serve as an athlete mentor for the Asean Para Games in Kuala Lumpur. Yip expressed her excitement and honor at being given this opportunity, aiming to share her knowledge and experience with the teams.

site_title: New Bukit Merah bus package to operate 18 services put up for tender
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has put up the Bukit Merah bus package for tender, comprising 18 bus services, including cross-border services to Johor Baru, with approximately 340 buses. The successful bidder will operate the services for five years, with the option for a two-year extension, and will serve areas such as Bukit Merah, Harbourfront, and the Central Business District. The package will be implemented in four tranches from 2018, with the LTA emphasizing the need for a smooth transition and safeguarding the welfare of bus sector employees.

site_title: ERP kicks in during morning peak hours at KPE stretch from May 8
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) will activate Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) on the Kallang-Paya Lebar Expressway (KPE) from May 8, with $2 ERP rates from 7am to 9:30am on weekdays. The ERP system aims to manage congestion, as traffic speeds along the stretch have consistently remained below the optimal range of 45-65km/h for the past 2.5 years. The ERP gantry will be situated after Defu Flyover, between Tampines Expressway and Airport Road. The next ERP rate review will take place in May.
