site_title: Football: Wayne Rooney not ready to call time on his career
summary: Manchester United captain Wayne Rooney is confident he can continue playing at the highest level for another 2-3 years, despite spending the current season mostly on the bench or injured. Rooney, 31, has made 31 appearances, mostly as a substitute, and credits his experience for helping the team target a Europa League triumph and top-four finish in the league. Rooney aims to perform to his best until the end of the season, despite media reports linking him to a move away from Old Trafford.

site_title: Government seeks public feedback on proposed changes to Co-operative Societies Act
summary: The Registry of Co-operative Societies in Singapore is seeking public feedback on proposed changes to the Co-operative Societies Act. The changes aim to improve governance standards, protect members' deposits, and increase regulatory powers. The proposed amendments include introducing qualification and training requirements for key officers, removing existing barriers to membership eligibility, and granting the Registry powers to de-register co-ops that fail to meet conditions. The public has until May 26 to submit feedback on the proposed changes, with the aim of implementing them next year.

site_title: Short film project, with Eric Khoo and K. Rajagopal, aims to inspire Singaporeans to do good
summary: A short film project, "15 Short Films," aims to inspire Singaporeans to do good through real-life stories. Fifteen film-makers, including Eric Khoo and K. Rajagopal, have signed on for the project, which will release 15 short films online and on traditional platforms from June to 2018. The films will focus on kindness and volunteerism, and will be funded through a crowd-funding site, with a target of raising $50,000. The project seeks to counter negative videos of Singaporeans behaving shamefully, promoting a positive message and encouraging giving and volunteerism.

site_title: NBA: Raptors, Spurs advance to second-round play-offs
summary: The San Antonio Spurs and Toronto Raptors advanced to the second round of the NBA playoffs. The Spurs defeated the Memphis Grizzlies 103-96 in Game 6, while the Raptors won 92-89 against the Milwaukee Bucks. Kawhi Leonard led the Spurs with 29 points, and Tony Parker added 27 points. DeMar DeRozan scored 32 points for the Raptors, who will face the Cleveland Cavaliers in the next round. Both teams will face a best-of-seven series, with the Spurs set to play the Houston Rockets and the Raptors set to play the Cavaliers.

site_title: Football: Chelsea will find it tough going to breach the fortress that is Goodison Park
summary: Everton manager Ronald Koeman believes his team's stellar home form will intimidate Chelsea ahead of their Premier League match on Sunday. The Toffees have won their last seven home league games, collecting 40 out of 51 available points at Goodison Park this season, with only Chelsea and Tottenham Hotspur having a better home league record. Koeman attributes his team's success to a good press, tempo, and quality, stating that opposition teams have growing doubts when visiting Goodison, which is a positive for the home team.

site_title: Indonesia holds interest rate as inflation concerns loom
summary: Indonesia's central bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 4.75% for the sixth consecutive month, maintaining a neutral stance as inflation concerns loom. Despite slower-than-expected consumer price growth in March, inflation is expected to average 4.3% this year, driven by volatile food prices and potential capital outflows due to the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening. The bank is closely monitoring the rupiah's stability, which could be threatened by aggressive rate hikes by the US Fed.

site_title: Football: Claudio Bravo's season likely to be over
summary: Manchester City goalkeeper Claudio Bravo's season may be over due to an injury sustained in a 0-0 draw with Manchester United. Bravo was carried off on a stretcher in the 79th minute and replaced by Willy Caballero. Manager Pep Guardiola expressed doubt about Bravo's availability for the remainder of the season, potentially missing the remaining five games. This injury could impact City's position in the Premier League standings, as they travel to Middlesbrough on Sunday. Bravo's injury may also affect the team's chances of securing a top-four finish.

site_title: Football: Ex-Newcastle midfielder Sylvain Marveaux under probe as British tax investigation widens
summary: Former Newcastle United midfielder Sylvain Marveaux is under investigation by French tax authorities in connection with a British tax probe. As part of the raid, English football clubs West Ham United and Newcastle United were targeted, with several men arrested for suspected Income Tax and National Insurance fraud. Marveaux cooperated with French investigators, stating he had few details about his 2011 transfer to Newcastle, and promised to continue cooperating with the investigation. French authorities conducted 10 searches and detained four people, with HMRC assisting the UK's tax collection body.

site_title: Maersk Line to pay S$5.5 billion for German rival Hamburg Sud
summary: Maersk Line has agreed to pay S$5.5 billion for German rival Hamburg Sud, combining the two companies to achieve annual operational savings of S$489-558 million. The deal, approved by Maersk and Hamburg Sud boards, as well as regulatory authorities, will strengthen Maersk's presence in global trade, particularly in Latin America. The acquisition is expected to close by the end of the year, with Maersk CEO Soren Skou stating that integrating shipping companies comes with obstacles, but the company aims to realize operational synergies.

site_title: Asean expresses grave concern over nuclear tests despite North Korea's appeal
summary: South-east Asian countries, including the Philippines, expressed "grave concern" over North Korea's nuclear tests and ballistic missile launches, despite a rare appeal from Pyongyang for support. The Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) foreign ministers criticized North Korea for two nuclear tests and subsequent launches, calling on the country to comply with UN resolutions and refrain from actions that may aggravate the situation. Asean also urged the resumption of dialogue to defuse tensions and create conditions for peace and stability on the Korean peninsula.

site_title: 150 officers across 25 agencies conduct chemical spill drill
summary: A joint chemical spill exercise was conducted by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) with 150 officers from 25 agencies, simulating a collision between a chemical tanker and a bunker barge. The exercise involved 600 tonnes of cyclohexane spilled and two crew members rescued. The MPA aims to test and demonstrate Singapore's readiness to tackle oil and chemical spills, emphasizing the importance of coordination and best practices among agencies. The exercise is one of three yearly drills led by the authority to ensure swift response to maritime incidents.

site_title: Will 'Frexit' follow Brexit?: ANN columnist
summary: French presidential candidate Marine Le Pen's populist victory in the first round has sparked concerns of a potential "Frexit" following in the footsteps of Brexit. The outcome has created uncertainty for the European Union, with France being the second-largest economy in the EU. Le Pen has advocated for France to exit the euro and potentially leave the EU, but a Frexit is unlikely without low voter turnout or a significant stumble by centrist candidate Emmanuel Macron. The EU's monetary union has been criticized for its flaws and institutional inadequacies, which have contributed to the economic crisis in Southern Europe.

site_title: Donald Trump to address NRA on eve of 100 days in office
summary: US President Donald Trump will address the National Rifle Association (NRA) on the eve of the 100th day in office, a rare occurrence for a sitting president. The event, held at the NRA's 146th annual convention in Atlanta, Georgia, is seen as a significant moment of symbolism, given the NRA's close ties to Trump. The organization backed Trump early in his 2016 presidential campaign and has since given him high marks for his appointments, including conservative judge Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court.

site_title: Manufacturing firms mostly optimistic but outlook mixed for services sector: Surveys
summary: Manufacturing firms in Singapore are mostly optimistic about business conditions, with 12% expecting improvement and 5% expecting decline, according to a survey by the Singapore Economic Development Board. Electronics and precision engineering clusters lead the optimism, with semiconductor firms anticipating strong demand for chips and machinery & systems segment expecting better prospects. In contrast, the services sector has a more mixed outlook, with 14% firms optimistic and 10% less optimistic compared to the previous quarter.

site_title: Football: Argentina have eyes only for Jorge Sampaoli to take over hot seat
summary: Argentina's national football team is set to appoint Jorge Sampaoli as their new coach, aiming to revitalize their 2018 World Cup qualifying campaign. The Argentinian Football Association (AFA) President Claudio Tapia confirmed Sampaoli as their top choice, despite the team being fifth in South American qualifying with four matches remaining. Sampaoli, currently coach of Sevilla FC, will be released from his contract once the LaLiga season concludes. The team faces a tough schedule, including a key away match against Uruguay, and will also play friendlies against Brazil and Singapore.

site_title: UBS Q1 profit jumps 79% on brighter outlook
summary: Swiss bank UBS reported a 79% jump in Q1 net profit to 1.3 billion Swiss francs, beating analyst estimates. The increase was driven by a brighter outlook for its investment bank and client trading in its core wealth management business. Despite global economic uncertainty, UBS attributed its success to its resilience. The bank's net profit for the first three months of 2017 exceeded expectations, with the company maintaining a cautious outlook due to ongoing macroeconomic risks.

site_title: Tips and tricks to making perfectly fluffy, and healthier, pancakes
summary: Casey Seidenberg shares her son's journey to perfecting fluffy and nutritious pancakes. Key tips include measuring ingredients carefully, using almond flour for extra protein, and separating eggs for fluffiness. Other recommendations include using grade B maple syrup, sautéed fruit as a topping, and a griddle at 190 degrees Celsius. Proper cooking techniques, such as not overmixing the batter and not pressing down on the pancakes, are also crucial for achieving the perfect pancake.

site_title: Ex-taxi driver jailed and banned for causing cyclist's death along Seletar Expressway
summary: A 58-year-old taxi driver, Lim Poh Guan, was jailed for three weeks and banned from driving for five years after negligently causing the death of a 28-year-old cyclist, Kanabathi S. Manokaran, on Seletar Expressway. Lim failed to check his blind spot before changing lanes, hitting the cyclist and causing fatal injuries. He pleaded guilty and had previously been a taxi driver for 18 years with a good driving record. The court considered Lim's remorse and mitigation plea, resulting in a reduced sentence.

site_title: Doctor charged with raping, molesting patient, ordered not to perform consultations for women
summary: A Singapore doctor, Wee Teong Boo, has been charged with raping and molesting a 23-year-old patient in 2015. He has been ordered not to perform consultations for female patients without a female chaperone present. The Interim Orders Committee has also restricted his ability to conduct examinations of female patients' sensitive areas, with chaperone involvement required. The conditions are in place until 2018, after which the order will be reviewed. Wee has not yet been convicted of the charges and remains presumed innocent until proven guilty.

site_title: Britons shun ebooks due to 'screen fatigue'
summary: British ebook sales declined by 3% in 2016, falling to £538 million, due to "screen fatigue" from excessive device use. Despite this, digital sales overall rose 6% driven by audiobook sales (up 28%) and academic/professional digital books (up 6%). Physical book sales rose 8% to £3 billion, their highest level since 2012. The Publishers Association attributes the increase in physical sales to the resurgence of bookshops and the appeal of physical books over digital ones.

site_title: Donald Trump vows to fix or scrap South Korea trade deal, wants missile system payment
summary: US President Donald Trump vowed to renegotiate or terminate the five-year-old US-Korea trade deal, calling it "unacceptable" and "horrible." He also expressed frustration over paying for the US anti-missile system in South Korea, estimated at $1 billion, and suggested Seoul should cover the cost. Trump blamed the trade deal on his 2016 opponent Hillary Clinton, stating it will be targeted for renegotiation after his administration completes a revamp of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

site_title: Biden calls on students to 'change the culture' to fight college sexual assault
summary: Former US Vice President Joe Biden called on college students to "change the culture" to combat sexual assault, urging them to speak up against "locker room talk" and intervene if they see a questionable situation. At a George Mason University event, Biden referenced his own father's lessons and said that if a man hears inappropriate conversations, he should say something. The event, part of the It's On Us campaign, comes amid concerns about President Donald Trump's handling of the issue. Biden's speech highlighted the prevalence of college sexual assault, with 1 in 5 women reporting an incident in the past four years.

site_title: Uneven growth could fuel extremism, instability in South-east Asia: Malaysian PM Najib Razak
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak warned that South-east Asia's uneven economic growth could fuel extremism and instability, citing the need for inclusive growth to prevent marginalized populations from turning to violent extremism or overthrowing political systems. The region's strong growth, which could make Asean the world's fourth-largest economy, must be equitable, Najib said. Economic disparity can fuel anger and populism, and the removal of trade tariffs and harmonized customs standards is crucial to promoting awareness and trade integration among Asean citizens.

site_title: Trump signs whistleblower protection order at Veterans Affairs
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order on April 27, 2017, creating a new whistleblower protection office at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The office aims to protect veterans' healthcare rights and hold those accountable who fail to provide adequate care. Trump stated that the new office will give veterans the healthcare they need and deserve, emphasizing accountability for those who fail to meet their responsibilities.

site_title: No Signboard Seafood launches vending machine cluster in Tampines
summary: No Signboard Seafood has launched a vending machine cluster, The Ma2 Shop, in Tampines, featuring six machines that dispense ready-to-eat meals, snacks, medical supplies, and knick-knacks. The machines accept cashless payments and will operate 24/7, with hot meal options starting on May 27. The venture aims to provide a more scalable and cost-effective alternative to traditional restaurants, with plans to export the machines to Japan. The Ma2 Shop is part of a larger expansion, with five more outlets set to open by May 27, offering a range of products including Asian food, pharmacy items, and household essentials.

site_title: Is South Korea's economy on the road to recovery?: The Korea Herald
summary: South Korea's economy is showing signs of recovery, with a bullish stock market performance and improved consumer sentiment. The benchmark index reached its highest mark in six years, and the consumer sentiment index rose for three months in a row. Exports are also on an upward path, with outbound shipments reaching a two-year high. However, challenges remain, including a lack of domestic demand, high unemployment, and household debt, which could be exacerbated by rising interest rates and trade protectionism. The government and businesses must work together to address these issues and boost consumption and investment.

site_title: Rising competition in Singtel's markets prompts one money manager to sell the stock
summary: Henderson Global Investors, a US$130 billion money manager, has sold its Singtel holdings due to rising competition in Asia's key markets. The company cited increased competition in Singapore, Australia, and India, leading to short-term pressure on the stock. Despite buy ratings from two-thirds of analysts, Singtel's stock has dropped 4.3% since April 4. The company faces a potential decline in annual operating profit for the fifth consecutive year, with regional businesses deemed unattractive except for Indonesia.

site_title: Museum of Ice Cream serves up sweet art
summary: The Museum of Ice Cream in Los Angeles features interactive installations where visitors can taste and touch various ice cream flavors. The exhibit, open through early July, includes colorful displays such as a Banana Split Room with 10,000 hanging banana replicas and a pool filled with 100 million custom-made sprinkles. Co-founder Manish Vora describes the experience as a social one, meant to be shared on social media. The museum plans to expand to other US cities and internationally in 2018.

site_title: Taiwan says no plan at this stage for phone call with US President Donald Trump
summary: Taiwan's presidential office stated that there are no plans at this stage for a phone call with US President Donald Trump. The decision comes after Trump dismissed the idea of such a call, following a comment by Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen that she would not rule it out. The US has priorities in handling Asia-Pacific regional affairs, and Taiwan's government will pursue its best interests. China reiterated its opposition to any official exchanges between Taiwan and countries with diplomatic ties to China, considering Taiwan a breakaway province.

site_title: Rare copy of US Declaration of Independence unearthed - in England
summary: A rare copy of the US Declaration of Independence, one of only two known parchment copies, was discovered in the West Sussex Record Office in southern England. The handwritten manuscript, dated to the 1780s, is believed to have been written in New York or Philadelphia. British and American experts are investigating how it ended up in the archive, with the parchment now set to undergo scientific tests at the British Library to determine its ownership. The document is valued and insured, but will remain under lock and key until the investigation and tests are complete.

site_title: State Courts seize assets of Mandala Fine Art gallery
summary: The State Courts in Singapore have seized assets of Mandala Fine Art gallery, a company convicted of not paying Central Provident Fund (CPF) contributions to its employees. Over 100 artworks, valued at $1 million, were seized from storage company Alliance Logistics on behalf of the CPF Board to recover $1.4 million in arrears owed to employees. The gallery's owner, Mr Vitharana Mudiyanselage Hemasiri Vitharana, is unknown, and some artists are claiming ownership of their works, with the deadline to file claims set for May 10.

site_title: Asean committed to de-escalating tensions in Korean peninsula, says grouping's sec-gen
summary: Asean secretary-general Le Luong Minh reaffirmed the grouping's commitment to de-escalating tensions in the Korean peninsula. North Korean Foreign Minister Ri Yong Ho sent a letter to Minh on March 23, expressing the country's position on the crisis. Asean has consistently called for de-escalation and denuclearization, and will continue to express its position at the Asean Regional Forum. The regional grouping will also discuss the issue at a meeting of Asean leaders in Manila on Saturday.

site_title: Van knocks onto woman who tries crossing busy road after stopping car at Balestier
summary: A woman was nearly hit by a van on Balestier Road in Singapore on April 27 after she got out of her car and tried to cross the busy road. Driver Amannda Toh posted a video of the incident, showing the woman stopping her car at a bus stop and trying to cross several lanes before being hit by a van. Toh claimed the woman was at fault and held up traffic, and she plans to send the police an email about the incident. The police have not commented on the matter.

site_title: China says situation on Korean peninsula could slip out of control
summary: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi warned that the situation on the Korean peninsula could escalate or slip out of control, according to a statement from China's Foreign Ministry. The warning came during a meeting with a senior Russian diplomat at the United Nations. Wang's comments suggest growing concerns over the escalating tensions on the Korean peninsula, where North Korea's nuclear program has been a major point of contention.

site_title: Charlie Young gives birth to twins: Other Asian celebrities who have given birth in Singapore
summary: Hong Kong actress Charlie Young, 42, gave birth to twins in Singapore. Young, who married Singaporean Khoo Shao Tze in 2013, shared a photo of the babies on Weibo. This is not the first time an Asian celebrity has given birth in Singapore, with other notable births including Taiwanese actress Sonia Sui, Taiwanese actress Vivian Hsu, and Chinese actress Vicki Zhao.

site_title: All eyes on gum-chewing, foul-mouthed Rodrigo Duterte as he hosts Asean meeting
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte hosts the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) summit, drawing attention to his unstatesman-like behavior. Duterte has a history of verbal outbursts, including cursing US President Barack Obama, criticizing human rights issues, and drawing parallels to the Holocaust. He has also been known for casual demeanor and attire, such as chewing gum, wearing casual clothes, and not wearing socks. Duterte's comments on The New York Times and his drug war have sparked controversy, with some calling him a "man of the people" while others criticize his behavior as unbecoming of a leader.

site_title: Sabana Reit unit holder revolt fails at EGM
summary: Sabana Reit's unit holder revolt failed at an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on April 28, 2017. Unit holders challenged property valuers Savills and Knight Frank, but their resolution to remove the Reit's manager was rejected with 69.48% of votes. An extraordinary resolution to direct the winding up of the Reit was also rejected with 71.67% of votes. One ordinary resolution, authorizing the Reit manager to issue units, was passed with 45.59% of votes. The revolt failed to achieve its goals, and the Reit's manager remains in place.

site_title: Camera that helps you dress and shower that saves water: 5 other quirky smart home devices
summary: Amazon has unveiled a voice-controlled camera, the Echo Look, that compares and judges outfits by blending advice from fashion insiders and algorithms. Meanwhile, the Public Utilities Board (PUB) in Singapore is seeking proposals for smart shower devices that track water usage in real time, aiming to save up to five litres of water a day. Other quirky smart home devices include a smart lighting system, a weather forecasting device, a smart toaster, and a coffee machine with Bluetooth capabilities.

site_title: Unemployment for locals stable in Q1, but drop in work permit holders sees total employment fall
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate for locals and permanent residents remained stable at 3.2% in Q1, while the overall unemployment rate rose to 2.3% due to a decline in work permit holders. The number of employed workers fell by 8,500, the largest drop in nearly 14 years, mainly in the manufacturing and construction sectors. Unemployment increased in March, and Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say warned of potential further rises as the economy restructures.

site_title: Germany to ban civil servants, judges, soldiers from wearing full-face veil
summary: Germany's Bundestag approved a draft law banning civil servants, judges, and soldiers from wearing full-face veils at work. The move follows Chancellor Angela Merkel's call for a ban on full-face Muslim veils "wherever legally possible." The law aims to promote integration by making clear values and boundaries. This decision comes after concerns about integration grew following the arrival of over 1 million migrants, mainly from the Middle East, in the last two years.

site_title: Bollywood veteran Vinod Khanna dies aged 70: A look at  5 of his significant films
summary: Veteran Bollywood actor Vinod Khanna died aged 70 due to cancer on April 27, 2017. With a 47-year career spanning over 140 films, Khanna received notable awards such as the Filmfare Lifetime Achievement Award in 1999 and the Zee Cine Award For Lifetime Achievement in 2007. Notable films include "Man Ka Meet" (1969), "Haath Ki Safai" (1974), "Amar Akbar Anthony" (1977), "Dabangg" (2010), and "Dilwale" (2015), showcasing his range from villain to military officer and on-screen father to modern Bollywood stars.

site_title: 143 NUS student volunteers' data breached; school directed to provide mandatory training
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) has been directed by the Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) to implement mandatory personal data protection training for all student leaders within 120 days. A data breach occurred at NUS College of Alice and Peter Tan in 2016, where personal data of 143 student volunteers was disclosed without authorization. The PDPC found that NUS had inadequate training, leading to the breach, and has since issued directives for additional training to be implemented, including online basic training and face-to-face briefing sessions.

site_title: I thought being president would be easier, says Donald Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump reflected on his first 100 days in office, stating that being president is harder than he expected. He misses driving and feels like he's in a "cocoon" due to 24-hour Secret Service protection. Trump also expressed surprise at the lack of privacy and how much work the job entails, despite having assumed it would be easier. He frequently seeks advice from outside friends and former business colleagues, and has been at odds with the media, deciding not to attend the White House Correspondents' Dinner.

site_title: Mobile phones can be used as e-identity for accessing online services by year-end
summary: By year-end, Singapore's three major telcos (Singtel, StarHub, and M1) will launch Mobile Connect, an e-identity service allowing consumers to use their mobile phones for seamless online access to various services, including media companies, travel agencies, and online payment gateways, eliminating the need to manage multiple passwords. Consumers will log in once and receive a verification code via SMS or a one-time password sent to their mobile phone, ensuring secure access to multiple services. The service is part of a global initiative with 52 operators in 29 countries.

site_title: Man fined $5,000 for helping friend take IPPT three times
summary: A 29-year-old man, Lee Rong Ci, was fined $5,000 for abetment of cheating after helping his friend, Melvin Zheng Junlong, take the Individual Physical Proficiency Test (IPPT) on three occasions over three years. Zheng had deceived the conducting officer into believing Lee was him, using his identity card. Lee was allowed to continue with the test after being questioned, and he passed. Lee's lawyer cited that he did not receive any monetary profit and committed the crime as a favor for a friend, potentially avoiding jail time.

site_title: Delta Air Lines passenger said he was removed from flight for using toilet before take-off
summary: A Delta Air Lines passenger, Kima Hamilton, was removed from a flight from Atlanta to Milwaukee after he used the restroom during takeoff. Hamilton, 39, claimed it was an emergency situation and he had paid for the ticket. He was told by an agent that the plane would lose its place in the line if he used the restroom, and he was subsequently asked to leave the plane. Hamilton was not allowed back on the flight, and Delta refunded the ticket cost but not taxes and fees. The incident has sparked criticism, with some comparing it to the recent United Airlines incident where a passenger was violently dragged off a plane.

site_title: Rosewood case: Boss gets 3 months' jail, $500k fine; firm fined $500k
summary: A Singaporean businessman, Wong Wee Keong, was sentenced to 3 months' jail and a $500,000 fine for importing $50 million worth of rosewood logs from Madagascar without a permit. Wong's company, Kong Hoo, was also fined $500,000. The confiscation of 29,000 logs, valued at $70 million, is the largest ever in the world. Justice See Kee Oon ruled that the punishment should deter wildlife crime, but noted that the logs were not illegally sourced. Wong's bail was extended as he plans to appeal to the Court of Appeal.

site_title: Latest data show private housing market may be bottoming out but any upturn will be slow and patchy
summary: The private residential property market in Singapore appears to be bottoming out, with overall prices down 0.4% in the first quarter, led by a decline in landed homes. Non-landed prices were flat, while condo prices in some regions, such as the city fringe, showed a small recovery. However, analysts warn that a rapid or sharp market recovery is unlikely, citing subdued resale market and other factors that could continue to weigh on the market, including a weak leasing market and potential interest rate hikes.

site_title: Donald Trump spurns Taiwan president's suggestion of another phone call
summary: US President Donald Trump has dismissed a suggestion from Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen to hold another phone call, citing his desire not to create trouble for Chinese President Xi Jinping. Trump believes Xi is working to help the US with the North Korea situation and doesn't want to interfere. The US and Taiwan have been strengthening ties, with Tsai hinting at potential arms purchases, including the F-35 fighter jet, which could anger China.

site_title: InstaScram: Exploring #Seletar and Yishun with actor Lim Yu-Beng
summary: Actor Lim Yu-Beng joins Nessa in an episode of InstaScram, exploring their favorite spots in the Seletar and Yishun area. They visit Yishun Dam, a historic causeway with a serene atmosphere during the day and a night-time hotspot for cyclists and car enthusiasts. The duo ends their day at Soek Seng 1954 Bicycle Cafe, a unique bicycle-themed cafe showcasing vintage bicycles and artwork.

site_title: Singapore bank lending up 6.3% year on year in March
summary: Singapore bank loans rose 6.3% year on year in March, reaching S$627.9 billion, driven by increased lending to general commerce and financial firms. Business loans grew 8.1%, while general commerce loans rose 15.5% and loans to financial institutions increased 24.3%. Consumer and housing loans also saw slight increases. This growth contrasts with a 0.08% rise in total bank lending compared to the previous month, and a 0.3% increase in Asian currency unit loans.

site_title: US to make case for tougher stance on North Korea at UN Security Council meeting
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson will chair a UN Security Council meeting on April 28 to push for a tougher stance on North Korea, urging China to use its leverage to rein in Pyongyang's nuclear and missile activities. The US wants stronger UN sanctions, but is seeking China's leadership in diplomatic efforts. China has called for talks on denuclearization but has been reluctant to use economic pressure. The meeting comes after weeks of warnings from the US administration and amid tensions over North Korea's missile launches and nuclear tests.

site_title: Republicans offer stop-gap to avert US government shutdown
summary: US congressional leaders announced a short-term spending measure to avert a government shutdown, giving lawmakers some breathing room to finalize negotiations. The stop-gap bill, set to pass the House and Senate by Saturday, will fund federal operations until May 5. Despite disagreements over priorities, including funding for a border wall and healthcare, President Trump has eased his threat to withhold health subsidies, bringing negotiations closer to a bipartisan agreement. The measure will keep the government open, avoiding a shutdown on Trump's 100th day as president, which falls on Saturday.

site_title: May Day Message 2017: Unemployment rate could rise further, says Lim Swee Say
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate rose to 3% in 2016, with some sectors still struggling with structural changes. Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say attributes the rise to the economy's slowing growth, which grew by 2% in the past two years. He emphasizes the need for employers and workers to adopt technology, innovate, and raise productivity to compete globally. The government, employers, and unions are working together to help businesses transform and workers cope with economic changes, with NTUC and SNEF announcing increased efforts in training and job placement.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.05% higher on Friday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.05% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,172.91 in early trade. This gain was driven by 81 gainers compared to 39 losers, with 156.9 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Amazon extends 20-year streak of double-digit revenue growth, shares hit new record
summary: Amazon has extended its 20-year streak of double-digit revenue growth, with first-quarter sales increasing 23% to $35.7 billion. The company's cloud-computing division, Amazon Web Services, saw 43% year-over-year growth, while its core e-commerce segment growth remained healthy. Amazon's stock hit a new record, gaining 5.1% in extended trading, and the company projects sales that may beat projections in the current period. The company's Prime subscription service, with 80 million US members, is driving growth and loyalty.

site_title: Japan data deluge points to economic growth, weak inflation
summary: Japan's economy showed signs of growth, with the economy expanding for the fifth consecutive quarter, according to data released Friday. Consumer prices rose 0.2% in March, while the unemployment rate was 2.8%. Industrial production fell 2.1% but retail sales climbed 2.1% from a year ago. Despite the growth, inflation remains weak, and wage gains are stagnant, affecting household spending. The Bank of Japan's target of 2% inflation remains elusive, and concerns over weak wage growth may impact future sales tax hikes.

site_title: South Korea paying for Thaad defence system ‘impossible’, says presidential frontrunner’s aide
summary: US President Donald Trump suggested South Korea pay for the $1 billion Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (Thaad) missile defense system, but a top adviser to presidential frontrunner Moon Jae-in says this is an "impossible option." Moon's camp is deliberating the demand, and Trump's comments are seen as boosting support for Moon ahead of the May 9 election. The Thaad system, which is expected to be operational by the end of the year, will have its main operation in the hands of the US, despite South Korea's efforts to purchase it.

site_title: Athletics: Shanti Pereira wins 200m race at Singapore Open, meets SEA Games qualifying mark
summary: Sprinter Shanti Pereira won the 200m race at the Singapore Open Track & Field Championships with a time of 23.87 seconds, meeting the Kuala Lumpur SEA Games qualifying mark. The 20-year-old also won the 2015 SEA Games 200m championship. Her coach, Margaret Oh, praised her performance, noting that Shanti hadn't run below 24 seconds for a long time. This victory solidifies Shanti's position as a top contender for the SEA Games, which will be held in Malaysia from August 19-30.

site_title: China warned North Korea of sanctions after any nuclear test: Rex Tillerson
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson stated that China warned North Korea it would impose unilateral sanctions if Pyongyang conducted another nuclear test. Tillerson also mentioned that US intelligence suggests North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is a rational actor who can be negotiated with. This comes after US President Donald Trump's summit with Chinese President Xi Jinping, which may have yielded China's toughest threat yet to take action against North Korea.

site_title: Trump advisers likely to decide in May on whether US should stay in Paris climate pact
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration is set to decide in May whether the US should stay in the Paris climate pact, with a group of advisers including Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and Energy Secretary Rick Perry likely to make the decision. The group will consider the views of both proponents and opponents of the pact, with some companies and lawmakers urging the US to stay in the agreement to protect competitiveness. The decision comes after Trump initially vowed to cancel the pact, but later expressed openness to staying in it if Washington gets better terms.

site_title: Tribeca Film Festival's top awards go to female film-makers
summary: The Tribeca Film Festival awarded top honors to female filmmakers, with Rachel Israel's "Keep The Change" winning the best narrative feature award, Elina Psykou's "Son Of Sofia" taking the prize for the best international narrative feature, and Elvira Lind's "Bobbi Jene" winning the best documentary award. Kaveh Mazaheri's Iranian short film "Retouch" also received a top prize, although the director was unable to accept due to visa issues. Each award comes with a $20,000 prize.

site_title: Slide in office and retail rents, prices worsen in Q1: URA
summary: Office rents in Singapore declined by 3.4% in Q1, while prices fell by 4%. The vacancy rate for office space rose to 11.6% at the end of the quarter. Retail prices and rents also declined, with a 4% drop in prices and a 2.9% decline in rents. The retail vacancy rate increased to 7.7% at the end of March. These declines are attributed to challenging market conditions, with signs of distress persisting in both the office and retail property segments.

site_title: Chinese navy sails through Miyako Strait, conducts more drills in Western Pacific
summary: China's navy sailed through the Miyako Strait between Japan's islands of Miyako and Okinawa, conducting drills in the Western Pacific. The exercises, aimed at enhancing communication and emergency response capabilities, involved various operations including search-and-rescue and anti-piracy. The drills are part of China's efforts to improve its military training and adapt to diverse tasks. This follows recent series of exercises in the Pacific, as China's navy continues to assert its presence in the region, with a rising star admiral taking command and new warships emerging.

site_title: HDB resale prices slip 0.5% in Q1 as sales drop 9.6%
summary: HDB resale prices declined 0.5% in Q1, marking a 10.3% drop from 2013 peak. Sales dropped 9.6% to 4,530 units, compared to the previous quarter. In May, about 4,600 BTO flats and 3,000 balance flats will be offered for sale. The number of approved subletting applications fell 6.5% to 9,981 cases, with 53,360 flats being sublet, a 0.8% increase.

site_title: Asian stocks tick up, euro subdued as ECB maintains easing bias
summary: Asian stocks rose on Friday, with the MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan up 0.1% to end the week 1.9% higher, its best week in six. The euro slipped 0.1% after the European Central Bank maintained its stimulus program, while the dollar index gained 0.1% despite a 2% weekly loss. US stocks were flat, with the Nasdaq reaching an all-time high on strong earnings reports from companies including Alphabet and Amazon. Investors await US GDP data and euro-zone inflation figures for more direction.

site_title: Great Eastern Q1 profit more than doubles to S$217.9m
summary: Great Eastern Holdings, the insurance arm of OCBC Bank, reported a 124% surge in first-quarter net profit to S$217.9 million, more than doubling from S$96.9 million last year. The increase was driven by higher non-operating profit from credit spreads and equity market rallies, as well as higher profit from shareholders' fund investments. Total weighted new sales and new business embedded value also grew 29% and 24% respectively in the quarter.

site_title: North Korea releases propaganda video showing simulated attack on White House
summary: North Korea released a propaganda video on April 27, 2017, showing a simulated attack on the White House, with the caption "the enemy to be destroyed is in our sights". The video comes at a tense time in relations between North Korea and the US, following large-scale artillery drills and the deployment of warships to the region. The US Navy's USS Michigan submarine docked in South Korea, and the USS Carl Vinson aircraft carrier is set to arrive in the Korean Peninsula area. The video is part of North Korea's bombastic rhetoric and exaggerated propaganda, with the US stressing its options include economic sanctions and military action.

site_title: Google parent Alphabet's earnings smash forecasts
summary: Alphabet, Google's parent company, reported a 29% increase in profit to $5.43 billion, beating Wall Street estimates. The company's core advertising business continued to grow at an extraordinary rate, and problems such as an advertiser boycott of YouTube had little impact. Revenue rose 22.2% to $24.75 billion, with paid clicks increasing 44%. The company's non-advertising revenue, including cloud computing and hardware, also grew significantly. Despite concerns about Alphabet's "Other Bets" segment, the company's overall performance was seen as a testament to its dominant position in digital advertising.

site_title: Donald Trump says 'major, major conflict' with North Korea possible, but seeks diplomacy
summary: US President Donald Trump warned of a "major, major conflict" with North Korea over its nuclear and missile programs, but expressed a desire for a peaceful resolution. Trump said he would prefer to use economic sanctions to resolve the crisis, but a military option was not ruled out. China, North Korea's only major ally, has been increasingly uncomfortable with Pyongyang's pursuit of nuclear weapons and has called for restraint. The US has deployed a carrier group to waters off the Korean peninsula and a missile defense system, which China has criticized as undermining its security. Trump has vowed to prevent North Korea from hitting the US with a nuclear missile, and North Korea has vowed to continue its nuclear and missile programs.

site_title: Private home prices fall for 14th straight quarter in Q1, with decline easing slightly to 0.4%: URA
summary: Singapore's private home prices fell for the 14th consecutive quarter in Q1, with a 0.4% decline from the last three months of 2016. The decline was slightly eased from the previous quarter's 0.5% drop. Core central region prices dropped 0.4%, while condos in the city fringe saw a 0.3% increase and suburban areas a 0.1% rise. Rentals also weakened by 0.9%, with 8.1% of private homes remaining vacant at the end of March.

site_title: Punchlines: April 28, 2016
summary: There is no article content provided.

site_title: Controversial director Polanski to show new film at Cannes
summary: Controversial film director Roman Polanski will premiere his new film "From A True Story" at the Cannes film festival outside the main competition. The film, starring Polanski's wife Emmanuelle Seigner and Eva Green, follows a female writer plagued by an obsessive admirer. Polanski, 83, has been on the run for almost four decades for statutory rape of a 13-year-old girl and was unable to negotiate a return to the US this month. The film's premiere comes despite protests by feminists and Polanski's continued fugitive status.

site_title: Anti-drug effort may be undermined by threat of punishment
summary: A coalition of 47 partners in Singapore's United Against Drugs Coalition launched an anti-drug initiative, but the threat of punishment may undermine its effectiveness. The focus on punishment rather than rehabilitation raises concerns about consistency and the impact on addicts' self-esteem and motivation. The Central Narcotics Bureau may also be forced to hide cases, rather than encouraging addicts to come forward. Experts emphasize the need for education and support to encourage abstinence, rather than punishment.

site_title: Veteran Bollywood actor Vinod Khanna dies at 70
summary: Veteran Bollywood actor Vinod Khanna, known for films like "Amar Akbar Anthony" and "Mere Apne", died at 70 due to advanced bladder carcinoma at a Mumbai hospital. He made his acting debut in 1968 and was also an MP in Punjab. Tributes poured in from the Hindi cinema world, with colleagues like Amitabh Bachchan and Rishi Kapoor paying their respects. Khanna won a Filmfare Best Supporting Actor Award in 1975 and received a lifetime achievement award in 1999.

site_title: Football: Fellaini sent off as Manchester United, City draw blank
summary: Manchester United's Marouane Fellaini was sent off for headbutting Sergio Aguero during a 0-0 draw against Manchester City in the Champions League. The match was a stalemate, with City remaining fourth and United fifth, both with a game in hand. Manchester City's Claudio Bravo suffered an apparent calf injury, and substitute Gabriel Jesus had an offside disallowed goal. The draw frustrated Manchester United's Champions League push, while City remain on course for a top-four finish.

site_title: Good change to income tax form
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore has introduced a convenient option to deduct a flat 15% from rental income for expenses incurred from a residential property that was tenanted out, simplifying the income tax form process. This change saves taxpayers time and effort in retrieving documents to prove expenditure. The option may be suitable for properties of all ages, with potential consideration for a progressive increase in the percentage for older properties requiring more maintenance.

site_title: Britain facing  ‘increased level of terrorist activity’, police say, after arrests
summary: British police confirmed an "increased level of terrorist activity" after six arrests were made in London and Kent, following a knifeman's arrest near parliament and a woman's shooting in a separate raid. The arrests came after a 27-year-old man, identified as Khalid Mohammed Omar Ali, was taken into custody near parliament on suspicion of terrorism offences. The woman, in her 20s, was shot in a raid in north London, where six people were arrested, including herself, and remains in a serious but stable condition.

site_title: Kim Kardashian less materialistic after Paris robbery
summary: Kim Kardashian shared her emotional experience after being robbed at gunpoint in her Paris apartment in October 2017. Thieves stole over $10 million in jewelry, and Kardashian reported feeling "badly shaken" during her recovery. However, the traumatic event has profoundly changed her outlook, making her realize that material possessions are not worth the risk. Kardashian stated she no longer cares about showing off her wealth and belongings, saying "it's not worth it." The experience has made her a "better person," and she is grateful to be safe and sound.

site_title: Football: Mourinho angry at Aguero over Fellaini red card
summary: Manchester United manager Jose Mourinho blamed Manchester City striker Sergio Aguero for Marouane Fellaini's red card in their 0-0 draw on April 27. Aguero was headbutted by Fellaini after being fouled, and Mourinho stated Aguero was "savvy enough to exploit the headbutt." The draw left City in fourth place and Manchester United in fifth, with both teams having a game in hand on third-placed Liverpool. Mourinho also criticized his midfielders for lacking quality, while City manager Pep Guardiola praised his team's performance despite creating few scoring chances.

site_title: UOB Q1 profit rises 5.4%, topping forecasts, as income offsets provisions
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 5.4% increase in first-quarter earnings to S$807 million, beating forecasts, as higher income from loans, trading, and wealth management outweighed higher bad loan provisions. Net interest income grew 2.3% and non-interest income increased 18% due to higher fees and commission income. Total allowances for loans rose 59% to S$186 million, but UOB's asset quality remained sound with a stable non-performing loans ratio of 1.5%. The bank's CEO attributed the results to a "steady growth trajectory" and confidence from investors.

site_title: Suspect in London knife incident may have had militant contacts outside UK: Intelligence source
summary: A 27-year-old man was detained near British Prime Minister Theresa May's office in London carrying knives, sparking a security operation. The suspect, from London, may have had contact with militants outside the UK, but investigators don't believe he was in contact with Islamic State. He was arrested as part of an intelligence-led operation and faces charges of possession of an offensive weapon and terrorism-related offenses. No immediate threat was identified, and police reopened streets after the suspect was questioned, with the incident coming weeks after a similar attack in Westminster.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, April 28 edition
summary: United Airlines reached a settlement with passenger Dr. David Dao, who was dragged from a plane in April, for an undisclosed sum. The carrier also agreed to offer up to $10,000 to passengers who give up their seats, reduce overbooking, and no longer involve law enforcement in denying ticketed passengers their seats. Meanwhile, a man carrying knives was detained near Prime Minister Theresa May's office in London on terror charges. A Singaporean man was sentenced to 40 months in a US prison for exporting bomb parts to Iran. Tennis star Maria Sharapova reached the Stuttgart Grand Prix quarter-finals, and Formula One champion Lewis Hamilton hailed Serena Williams as an inspiration after she responded to racist comments made by Ilie Nastase.

site_title: Consider other languages for SkillsFutureSG portal
summary: The SkillsFutureSG portal, a Singaporean online resource, may consider using other languages beyond English to cater to a more diverse population. This decision could be crucial for those who are less proficient in English, who might be excluded from accessing the portal. Relevant agencies are urged to weigh the benefits of having multiple languages to maximize the portal's reach and utility.

site_title: Microsoft’s quarterly revenue falls short of estimates
summary: Microsoft reported quarterly revenue that fell short of estimates, with its personal computing division experiencing a 7.4% decline to $8.84 billion. Revenue from the "Intelligent Cloud" business, including Azure, rose 11% to $6.76 billion. Despite a 93% increase in Azure revenue, the company's overall revenue missed analysts' average estimate of $23.62 billion. Microsoft's shares dropped 1.9% to $67 after the announcement.

site_title: Nasdaq ends at new record; oil shares fall
summary: The Nasdaq reached a new record, closing at 6,048.94, driven by positive earnings reports from Amazon, Alphabet, Microsoft, and Expedia. However, oil shares fell as US oil prices dropped below $50 a barrel, with Apache and Schlumberger losing 3.3% and 1.7% respectively. Airline shares declined after American Airlines raised employee pay, while Bristol-Myers Squibb and PayPal rose after reporting strong earnings.

site_title: Apple in talks to launch money-transfer service - Recode
summary: Apple is reportedly in talks to launch a money-transfer service, allowing iPhone users to digitally transfer funds to other iPhone users. The service, if launched, would compete with existing digital money transfer services such as Venmo and Square Cash. Apple is also exploring creating its own pre-paid cards tied to the new peer-to-peer service, potentially to boost Apple Pay usage, which has been lighter-than-expected since its launch two and a half years ago. An official announcement and launch date have not yet been confirmed.

site_title: Singapore man sentenced to 40 months in US for plot to export bomb parts to Iran
summary: A Singaporean man, Lim Yong Nam (Steven Lim), 43, was sentenced to 40 months in a US prison for exporting radio frequency modules to Iran in 2007-2008. The modules, some of which were used in bombs in Iraq, were illegally routed through Singapore. Lim pleaded guilty in December and was extradited from Indonesia in 2016. The US Justice Department stated that 14 of the 6,000 modules were recovered in Iraq, used to remotely detonate improvised explosive devices.

site_title: Google parent Alphabet’s profit soars on strong ad sales
summary: Google parent Alphabet reported a 29% rise in quarterly profit to $5.43 billion, driven by strong ad sales, particularly on mobile devices and YouTube. Ad revenue rose 18.8% to $21.41 billion, with paid clicks increasing 44%. The company's revenue from hardware and cloud businesses also grew, despite concerns over a recent controversy surrounding YouTube. Alphabet's shares rose 2.8% to $916.8, with the company expected to command a 61.6% share of the search ad market worldwide in 2017.

site_title: Formula One: Hamilton says inspired by Serena's response to Nastase
summary: Lewis Hamilton has praised Serena Williams for her response to Ilie Nastase's racist comments about her unborn child, saying the tennis star's statement "inspires" him. Hamilton, who has a tattoo of the same poem "Still I Rise" by Maya Angelou, has been friends with Williams since the Mexican Grand Prix last year. He expressed admiration for her strength as a powerful black woman and a born leader, stating that her words have inspired him and hopefully others, as she takes maternity leave for the rest of the tennis season.

site_title: Formula One: Vettel relishing breaking Mercedes stronghold in Russia
summary: Ferrari driver Sebastian Vettel aims to end Mercedes' three-year dominance at the Russian Grand Prix, where Mercedes have won all three previous races. Vettel, who leads the championship with two wins to one over Lewis Hamilton, says Ferrari has improved and could spring a surprise. Vettel rejects the idea of Ferrari team orders, while Mercedes teammate Valtteri Bottas says he will obey team instructions if needed. The two-way battle for the title is shaping up as a tight contest between Ferrari and Mercedes.

site_title: Two alleged Islamic militants held in Spain admit being at Brussels airport during attack
summary: Two alleged Islamic militants in Spain, Mohamed Lamsalak and Youssef Ben Hammou, have admitted being in Brussels airport during the 2016 attack, but deny involvement. They were heard by a judge and said they met a relative of two brothers who carried out the attack, which killed 32 people. The men were in Brussels from March 16-23 and were among nine people taken in for questioning by Spanish police in conjunction with Belgian authorities. Investigators are trying to determine if the men used funds for a car purchase to finance the attack or facilitate logistics.

site_title: Facebook steps up fight on state-led propaganda
summary: Facebook is expanding its security efforts to counter "fake news" and manipulate public opinion, particularly by governments and non-state entities. The initiative, announced in a white paper, focuses on three areas: targeted data collection, content creation, and false amplification. Facebook aims to detect and monitor information operations, but acknowledges it cannot attribute the actors behind these efforts. The move follows criticism over its role in spreading misinformation during the 2016 US presidential campaign. The company reported a 9% increase in government requests for account data in the second half of 2016.

site_title: Football: Video refs for 2018 World Cup
summary: Fifa president Gianni Infantino announced that video assistant referees will be used at the 2018 World Cup in Russia, marking the first time the technology will be used in a Fifa competition. The decision comes after positive results from its introduction at the Club World Cup in Japan last year. Conmebol, the South American Football Confederation, has also vowed to clean up after losing millions due to corruption cases, with its new president promising to recoup the stolen funds and prioritize football development.

site_title: 'Venezuela is a mess,' says Donald Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed sadness over Venezuela's crisis, calling the country "a mess." Trump welcomed Argentine President Mauricio Macri to the White House amidst anti-government unrest that has claimed 29 lives. The unrest is fueled by deteriorating living conditions and a deepening political impasse under leftist President Nicolas Maduro. Venezuela is withdrawing from the Organisation of American States, citing US-led efforts to force Maduro from office. The country's economic collapse and political turmoil have sparked widespread protests, with the Maduro government facing international pressure.

site_title: Tennis: Murray stays perfect, Nadal hits 50 in Barcelona
summary: Andy Murray won his 11th consecutive match against Feliciano Lopez, 6-4, 6-4, to advance to the quarterfinals in Barcelona. Rafael Nadal also reached the quarterfinals, securing his 50th win in the city with a 6-3, 6-4 victory over Kevin Anderson. Murray will face Roberto Bautista Agut or Albert Ramos-Vinolas, while Nadal will play Hyeon Chung, after the 20-year-old Korean stunned Alexander Zverev 6-1, 6-4.

site_title: Angela Merkel, Theresa May draw Brexit battle lines
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May and German Chancellor Angela Merkel have drawn Brexit battle lines, with Merkel warning the UK of "illusions" about its post-Brexit rights and May accusing other EU countries of lining up against Britain. Merkel stated that a non-EU state will not have the same rights as a member state, while May said the EU's approach could lead to "uncertainty and instability" for the UK. The two leaders are set to meet at a summit in Brussels, where the EU will outline its "red lines" for Brexit negotiations, which include Britain's financial obligations and immigration policies.

site_title: United Airlines reaches settlement with passenger dragged from plane
summary: United Airlines has reached a settlement with passenger Dr. David Dao, who was dragged from a Chicago flight in April 2017. The airline will pay an undisclosed sum for the incident, which sparked international outrage and calls for new regulations. As part of the settlement, United will offer up to $10,000 to passengers who give up their seats on overbooked flights, reduce overbooking, and stop involving law enforcement in seat removals. The settlement also releases Republic Airways from responsibility. The airline's CEO, Oscar Munoz, has emphasized the need to prioritize customer satisfaction.

site_title: Tennis: Sharapova eases past Makarova into Stuttgart quarters
summary: Maria Sharapova eased past fellow Russian Ekaterina Makarova 7-5, 6-1 to reach the Stuttgart Grand Prix quarter-finals. Sharapova, returning from a 15-month doping ban, has won the title three times and has yet to drop a set in the tournament. She credited her execution of a great plan and trust in her training for her victory. Sharapova will face Estonian qualifier Anett Kontaveit in the quarter-finals.

site_title: Six Thai rangers killed in ambush in restive south
summary: Six Thai army rangers were killed in an ambush in Narathiwat province after their truck was struck by a roadside explosive. The attack, which occurred on April 27, is the latest in a series of violence in Thailand's insurgency-plagued south. The Muslim-majority region has seen near-daily shootings and bombings since 2004, claiming over 6,800 lives. The attack comes ahead of the anniversary of a 2004 army raid on a mosque, and follows the rejection of peace talks by the most active insurgent group, the Barisan Revolusi Nasional (BRN).

site_title: Teen admits plotting 'Elton John' bomb attack
summary: A 19-year-old radical Islamist, Haroon Syed, admitted plotting a bomb attack in London, with potential targets including an Elton John concert and Oxford Street. Syed considered using a machine gun, handguns, and a suicide vest, and planned to detonate a bomb in a crowded place. He was arrested on September 8, 2016, after agents discovered his online chats and arranged to buy a custom-made bomb. Syed pleaded guilty and faces jail; his lawyer argued the state should have referred him to a de-radicalisation programme instead.

site_title: Tennis: 'I'm way above' Bouchard 'cheat' blast, says defiant Sharapova
summary: Maria Sharapova responded to Eugenie Bouchard's claims that she cheated by saying she's "way above" the controversy, dismissing Bouchard's suggestion that Sharapova should be banned from tennis for life. Sharapova had returned to the sport after a 15-month suspension following a positive test for meldonium at the 2016 Australian Open. Bouchard criticized the Women's Tennis Association for allowing Sharapova to compete, while Sharapova believes the WTA sends a wrong message to young players. Sharapova will learn on May 16 whether she'll receive a wildcard for the French Open.

site_title: Russia’s Putin, Japan’s Abe call for talks, calm with North Korea
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe called on North Korea and other countries to avoid increasing tensions around the secretive Asian state's nuclear programme. During talks in Moscow, they agreed to cooperate closely to help defuse tensions and expressed a desire to see a resumption of six-party international talks with North Korea. Both leaders urged peaceful constructive dialogue and warned against belligerent rhetoric, amid North Korea's growing nuclear and missile threat, which poses a major security challenge to the US.

site_title: IFA deems offer for Top Global shares as 'not fair but reasonable'
summary: The independent financial adviser to Top Global's independent directors, Stirling Coleman Capital, has deemed SW International's offer for shares at 33 Singapore cents apiece as "not fair but reasonable". The offer, launched on March 28, is a 72.3% discount to the group's RNAV per share as of December 2016. The IFA advises the board to recommend shareholders accept the offer or sell on the open market for a higher price. The offer price is below comparable ratios and precedent transactions, but deemed reasonable by the IFA.

site_title: Pentagon launches probe into Donald Trump's ex-security adviser Michael Flynn
summary: The Pentagon's inspector general has launched an investigation into former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn for allegedly accepting money from foreign entities without required approval. The probe compounds Flynn's existing legal issues, including taking hundreds of thousands of dollars from Russia Today and a Turkish businessman after retiring as an Army lieutenant-general. If substantiated, the failure to obtain approval would violate military regulations and potentially violate the constitutional prohibition on accepting emoluments from foreign powers.

site_title: NBA: Knicks centre Noah undergoes right shoulder surgery
summary: New York Knicks center Joakim Noah has undergone surgery on his right shoulder to repair a torn rotator cuff, according to the team. The procedure was performed by Dr. David Altchek at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan. Noah, 32, averaged 5.0 points and 8.7 rebounds in 46 games this season, his first under a four-year, $72 million contract. The expected rehabilitation process is five months, which would see him recovered in time for the 2017-18 pre-season training camp. Noah missed 89 games over the past two seasons due to shoulder and knee injuries.

site_title: Suspect packages sent to UK political offices ahead of election
summary: Three suspicious packages containing white powder substances were sent to Scottish political offices between April 25-26, prompting police investigation. The packages were sent to an elected official, a party headquarters, and a local council building. Police have issued further advice to elected representatives and are investigating a letter sent to Labour lawmaker Peter Hain. The incidents come ahead of the UK's national election on June 8, following a recent terrorist attack in London. Police have also arrested a man carrying knives near Prime Minister Theresa May's office.

site_title: At least 4 Singaporeans stranded in China after Tigerair delay, police called in to contain commotion
summary: At least four Singaporeans are stranded in Xi'an, China, after their Tigerair flight was delayed due to a fuel leak on the aircraft wing. The passengers waited for over two hours before being told to disembark and were later accommodated in a hotel with meals provided. A replacement plane was supposed to arrive at 4am, but it departed at 4.35am instead. The situation led to a commotion, with passengers gathering at the hotel and police officers being called in to control the situation. The airline paid for hotel and food, but passengers expressed disappointment.

site_title: Samsung, Apple keep top spots in smartphone market
summary: Samsung and Apple maintained their top spots in the smartphone market in early 2017, with Samsung holding 22.8% share and Apple at 14.9%. Huawei's sales surged 21.7% to 9.8%, while low-cost handset makers are expected to drive growth. The market tracker, IDC, attributes the growth to affordable devices with premium styling, shifting the focus away from high-end flagships. The industry is expected to rebound in 2017, with the new Samsung Galaxy S8 and Apple's upcoming iPhone set to impact the market. Smartphone shipments grew 4.3% to 347 million units in the first quarter.

site_title: New Maritime Apprenticeship Scheme aims at improving employability
summary: A new Maritime Apprenticeship Scheme was launched in Singapore to improve employability in the maritime industry. The scheme, launched on April 27, 2017, matches jobseekers with potential employers through a month-long shipboard work trial and a three-day foundational maritime training course. Upon completion, participants can land a job with the company and attend additional training to become steersmen, engine drivers, and tug masters. The aim is to train 50 people over the next year, with the scheme starting by the end of next month.

site_title: Canada's Justin Trudeau urged Donald Trump not to pull out of Nafta, says source
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau urged US President Donald Trump not to withdraw from the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) in a call, saying such a move would be counter-productive and cause job loss and instability. Trump had expressed frustration with Congress, but Trudeau advised him that pulling out of Nafta would be a step that would not yield desired results. The White House later stated that Trump would not terminate Nafta at this stage but would begin renegotiating it with Canada and Mexico.

site_title: British police detain man with knives on terror charge near PM Theresa May’s office
summary: British police detained a 27-year-old man carrying knives near Prime Minister Theresa May's office in London on April 27, 2017, on suspicion of preparing an act of terrorism. The suspect, from London, was arrested during a counter-terrorism operation and was found to have knives and a rucksack on the ground. No one was injured, and May was not at the scene. The arrest comes after a recent terrorist attack in Westminster, and police reopen streets two hours later, indicating no further public risk.

site_title: K. Shanmugam rebukes academic Donald Low over remarks misrepresenting his comments on criminal sentencing
summary: Law and Home Affairs Minister K. Shanmugam rebuked academic Donald Low for misrepresenting his comments on considering public opinion when deciding on criminal sentences. Shanmugam clarified that his remarks referred to factors the government should consider when deciding what conduct should be criminalized and the range of penalties, not individual case sentencing. He emphasized the importance of public opinion in informing law-making, but noted it should not be the sole or decisive factor. Shanmugam also criticized Low for not understanding his comments and suggested academics should read and understand the original statement before criticizing.

site_title: Car that exploded in Bukit Batok carpark was rental vehicle that went missing, says owner
summary: A rental Nissan Dualis car exploded in a Bukit Batok carpark on April 26, injuring a 32-year-old man with burns. The car's owner, Adrian Lim, confirmed it was a rental vehicle that had gone missing after its hirer failed to pay rental fees and return the car. Portable butane gas canisters were found at the scene, and the police are investigating the cause of the blast. The incident has left Lim with additional financial problems, including potential damage claims and excess fees.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding net profit up 49% in Q1
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 49% increase in net profit to 667.7 million yuan (S$135.1 million) in Q1, driven by a 73% rise in revenue to 4.7 billion yuan. The company delivered 14 vessels, a decrease from 15 last year, but core shipbuilding revenue rose 43% to 2.89 billion yuan. Earnings per share increased to 17.42 yuan cents, and net asset value per share rose to 609.62 yuan cents.

site_title: Tennis: Nadal into quarter-finals, aiming for 10th title at Barcelona
summary: Rafael Nadal advanced to the quarter-finals of the Barcelona Open with a 6-3, 6-4 victory over Kevin Anderson. This is his 50th win at the tournament, and he's aiming for a 10th title. The match was played on a slower court due to rain, and Nadal plans to face Hyeon Chung on Friday. Other notable results include Dominic Thiem's 7-6, 6-2 win over Dan Evans, and Yuichi Sugita's elimination of Pablo Carreno Busta.

site_title: Formula One: Valtteri Bottas ready to take one for the team in Russia
summary: Valtteri Bottas stated he would move aside for Lewis Hamilton if Mercedes asked him to, prioritizing the team's goal of securing maximum points. Bottas has previously moved aside for Hamilton in Bahrain, but emphasized that he is not accepting Hamilton as the team's number one driver. Mercedes team boss Toto Wolff acknowledged the need for a strategy rethink due to Ferrari's victories, while Hamilton expressed opposition to imposed "team orders." The team's approach remains to prioritize winning the race, with Bottas and Hamilton set to face off in the Russian Grand Prix.

site_title: No sign of terrorism in Berlin shooting incident, police say
summary: A German police officer shot and wounded a mentally unstable man who threatened another officer with a weapon in a hospital car park in Berlin on April 27, 2017. The incident did not appear related to terrorism, according to police. The motives of the man are unknown, and he made no statements while pointing his weapon. The man was shot in the leg and underwent surgery at the hospital. German authorities have been on high alert since a December terrorist attack on a Christmas market, killing 12.

site_title: Creative Technology swings into red in Q3
summary: Creative Technology reported a net loss of US$4.6 million in Q3, reversing a net profit of US$4 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 13% to US$16 million due to uncertain market conditions. The loss per share was US$0.07, down from US$0.06 last year. Net asset value per share fell to US$1.14 from US$1.40 last year. This marks the group's third consecutive quarterly loss.

site_title: Nasa spacecraft survives dive through Saturn's rings
summary: NASA's Cassini spacecraft successfully navigated through Saturn's rings on April 27, 2017, at a record-breaking speed of 124,000km/h. The spacecraft briefly lost contact but re-established communication 20 hours later, sending back a signal. This achievement marks the closest any spacecraft has come to Saturn, with the gap between the rings and the planet's atmosphere being approximately 2,400km wide. Cassini will make 22 dives between the rings and Saturn before its final plunge into the gas giant in September, following a mission that began in 1997 and orbited Saturn since 2004.

site_title: Changi Airport recognises partners at annual awards
summary: Changi Airport held its 12th annual Changi Airline Awards, recognizing 25 airlines for their contributions to the airport's growth and development in 2016. Singapore Airlines Group topped the list for passengers and cargo volume, while DHL Express was named Partner of the Year for its automated South Asia Hub. Changi Airport expects to receive 60 million passengers this year, building on last year's record 58.7 million. The airport aims to continue transforming to meet future challenges through initiatives such as Airport Collaborative Decision Making and sustainable growth strategies.

site_title: Kids who crashed dad's BBC interview now stars of their own cartoon series
summary: The children who crashed their father's BBC Skype interview in March 2017 now star in their own cartoon series, "The Adventures Of Mina And Jack." The 3-minute video follows the misadventures of a precocious girl named Mina and her pesky baby brother Jack as they help their dad, a United Nations official, out of jams. The series was conceptualized by writer Lauren Martin and app developer Jarryd Mandy, who were inspired by the viral video. The show has received positive feedback from YouTube users, with some calling it "amazing" and "super sweet."

site_title: Wall Street little changed with eyes on earnings
summary: US stocks were little changed on Thursday amidst a flood of quarterly earnings reports and President Donald Trump's tax reform plan. The one-page plan proposed deep tax cuts for businesses but offered no detail on how it would be paid for. Despite a two-day rally, stocks ended lower on Wednesday after the plan's unveiling, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 11.43 points at 20,986.52. Nearly 77% of S&P 500 companies that have released results so far have reported earnings above analysts' expectations.

site_title: Uber not ruling out expansion into the Singapore taxi industry
summary: Uber Singapore's general manager Warren Tseng has hinted that the company is open to expanding into the taxi industry, provided it benefits both riders and drivers. Tseng mentioned that Uber will evaluate options that make trips more affordable, reliable, and give drivers consistent earning opportunities. Recent developments in the taxi industry, such as dynamic pricing, have forced Uber to innovate, and the company is working harder to meet commuter needs. Uber currently operates UberTaxi, a metered taxi service, in Singapore and has over 300 employees in the city-state.

site_title: AWWA holds inclusive sports day for children with disabilities
summary: The Association of Women with Children and Adolescents (AWWA) hosted an inclusive sports day for children with disabilities, with over 280 students aged 7-18 participating in modified sports like soccer, volleyball, and rugby. Seven-year-old Nur Iman Sirajdeen, who uses a board with wheels due to a disability, played a simulated rugby game with his father, demonstrating the benefits of inclusive sports for children with disabilities. AWWA emphasized the importance of providing such opportunities, highlighting the need for more accessible sports programs for children with special needs.

site_title: 25-year-old Taiwanese teacher donates organs after sudden death in Singapore
summary: A 25-year-old Taiwanese teacher, Audrey Luan Yi Shiuan, died in Singapore after being declared brain dead following a brain-related illness. Despite her untimely death, her family chose to donate her organs, which can save up to seven lives. Taiwanese singer Selina Jen paid tribute to Luan on Facebook, praising her as a loyal fan. Luan's friends also shared heartfelt messages, describing her as kind and pure. The donation of her organs aims to honor her memory and bring comfort to her family.

site_title: United Airlines says review shows 'many things went wrong' in passenger-dragging incident
summary: United Airlines has released a report admitting that several mistakes were made before, during, and after a passenger was violently dragged off a flight in April. The airline had allowed internal policies to distract from treating passengers with dignity and respect. The incident involved a 69-year-old man, David Dao, who refused to give up his seat for off-duty crew members. The airline has outlined 10 changes to prevent a repeat of the incident, including offering more compensation and training for employees. CEO Oscar Munoz has apologized for the events and promised a culture shift towards becoming a better, more customer-focused airline.
