site_title: Indonesia-Philippines sea border pact ratified
summary: Indonesia's Parliament has ratified a landmark sea border agreement with the Philippines, setting exclusive economic zone boundaries in the Mindanao and Celebes seas. The 1,161km boundary, finalized in 2014 after 20 years of negotiations, aims to resolve territorial disputes and promote security and economic opportunities. The agreement was hailed as a model for peaceful settlement of territorial disputes in the region, and its ratification comes ahead of President Joko Widodo's visit to Manila for the 30th Asean Summit. The pact is expected to allow Indonesia to take tougher enforcement action against illegal fishing in its waters.

site_title: PAS president Hadi Awang's son Muhammad Khalil rises as new youth chief
summary: PAS president Hadi Awang has secured full control of his party, and his son Muhammad Khalil Abdul Hadi has risen as the new youth chief. At 40, Dr. Khalil, a doctorate student, won the position unopposed and is known for his calm and clear delivery of religious lectures. Fluent in Arabic and English, he often merges politics with Islam, echoing his father's views. Born in Terengganu, Khalil began his involvement with PAS in his teenage years and is seen as a promising future leader as the party prepares for the next general election.

site_title: Badminton: Lee Chong Wei checks into last eight of Asia C'ships
summary: Malaysian badminton player Lee Chong Wei advanced to the quarter-finals of the 2017 Badminton Asia Championships, defeating Japanese shuttler Kenta Nishimoto in the second round. Lee, the world No. 1 and defending champion, won the match in 44 minutes with scores of 22-20, 21-12. This success marks a strong performance for Lee, who continues his form in the tournament.

site_title: Teen admits planning London attack targeting Buckingham Palace and Elton John concert
summary: A 19-year-old from Hounslow, London, Haroon Syed, has pleaded guilty to planning a bomb attack targeting Buckingham Palace and an Elton John concert in Hyde Park. Syed attempted to purchase weapons online, researched busy areas, and expressed desire to obtain bomb-making materials, inspired by ISIS. He was arrested after chatting with undercover British agents. Syed will be sentenced in June for his charge of preparing terrorist acts between April and September last year.

site_title: 102 people arrested for loan shark activities in 3-day operation by CID, police
summary: In a 3-day operation by Singapore's CID and police divisions, 102 people, including 79 men and 23 women aged 21-75, were arrested for loan shark activities. The suspects were found to have opened bank accounts, shared ATM cards and PINs, and carried out graffiti. Investigations are ongoing, with charges ranging from fines to imprisonment and caning. The police advise the public to stay away from loan sharks and report any information to the authorities.

site_title: Formula One: Kevin Magnussen fears added dangers of cockpit 'shield'
summary: Formula One driver Kevin Magnussen expressed concerns about the proposed transparent cockpit 'shield' saying it could make racing more dangerous in wet conditions. The International Automobile Federation (FIA) is focusing on the shield concept, with track tests planned for the season, rather than a previously tested 'halo' system. Magnussen, who prefers to continue without either system, warned that the shield would be difficult to see in the wet and increase the risk of accidents. The FIA plans to implement the shield in 2018.

site_title: One-way Sentosa Gateway Tunnel to ease congestion opens
summary: Singapore's 1.4km one-way Sentosa Gateway Tunnel, completed in nearly 10 years and costing $200 million, officially opened on April 27, 2017. The tunnel allows cars and motorcycles to bypass congestion at busy junctions, particularly during evening peak hours and weekends. It is not accessible to buses, goods vehicles, or vehicles taller than 3.5m, which must use existing surface roads for fire safety reasons. The tunnel is expected to alleviate traffic congestion, but its limited accessibility may affect certain users.

site_title: Donald Trump vows to terminate Nafta if no 'fair deal'
summary: US President Donald Trump vowed to terminate the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) if a "fair deal" is not reached, contradicting earlier claims he would renegotiate the trade pact. Trump campaigned on scrapping Nafta, calling it "the worst trade deal maybe ever signed," but agreed to keep it intact after calls with Mexican and Canadian leaders. Trump said he will terminate Nafta if a deal is not reached, but expressed optimism that a deal is possible, stating "deal very possible."

site_title: Football: Bill Ng meets FAS affiliates ahead of election, first time media have spotted him since police raids
summary: Bill Ng, chairman of Hougang United and Tiong Bahru FC, met with FAS affiliates ahead of the upcoming election, his first public appearance since police raids on his clubs' clubhouses on April 20. Ng, a presidential candidate for the Game Changers, was seen leaving a restaurant in Bussorah Street, where he met with representatives of the clubs that will vote in the election. The FAS election, which will elect a new set of leaders, is set to take place on Saturday.

site_title: ECB keeps money taps wide open but may hint at June tone shift
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its ultra-easy monetary policy stance, keeping interest rates at 0.0%, 0.25%, and -0.4%. Despite inflation undershooting its target for the fifth consecutive year, ECB President Mario Draghi hinted at a potential tone shift towards further policy easing, leaving room for future rate cuts or asset buys. Economic growth in the eurozone is on its best run since the global financial crisis, and Draghi acknowledged this, but also noted underlying inflation pressures remain subdued.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust Q4 DPU up 3.3%
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust reported a 3.3% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.86 cents. Net property income rose 10.5% to S$80.3 million, driven by stabilisation of conversions, asset enhancement projects, and accretive acquisitions. However, lower contributions from properties in Singapore and South Korea partially offset the growth. The amount distributable to unitholders increased 4.1% to S$46.6 million.

site_title: FAS saga: Who's who on Game Changers & Team LKT
summary: Singapore's Football Association (FAS) will hold an historic election on April 29 to choose its new leaders. Two teams, Game Changers and Team LKT, are vying for the nine-member slates, including president, deputy president, and council member positions. Game Changers, led by Bill Ng, aims to expand the S-League to 12-14 teams and promote inclusiveness, while Team LKT, led by Lim Kia Tong, focuses on creating change, increasing football facilities, and establishing high performance targets for national teams. Seven independent candidates are also running for council member positions.

site_title: Lawyer jailed, fined and banned for second drink driving offence
summary: Lawyer Favian Kang Kok Boon was jailed for 2 weeks, fined $4,000, and banned from driving for 3.5 years after admitting to a second drink driving offence in October 2016. His blood alcohol level was 128mg/100ml, exceeding the 80mg/100ml limit. This is his second conviction, with a previous fine and 2-year ban in 2009. Kang, 31, claimed he was compelled to drink due to business custom, but his lawyer acknowledged he had learned his lesson and would not drive if he knew he would be drinking.

site_title: Tuan Sing net profit dives 44% in Q1
summary: Tuan Sing, a Singapore-based property developer, reported a 44% decline in net profit to S$5.4 million in the first quarter, mainly due to the sale of completed residential units. Revenue fell 29% to S$74.8 million, with property revenue down 44% to S$22.7 million. The group plans to launch Kandis Residence in the third quarter and issue S$140 million notes to finance acquisitions and working capital. Despite the decline, Tuan Sing remains optimistic about achieving a profit for the year 2017.

site_title: Malaysia's PAS sets ambitious target of 40 seats at polls
summary: Malaysia's Islamist party, Parti Islam SeMalaysia (PAS), has set an ambitious target of winning 40 parliamentary constituencies in the next nationwide polls, with key victories in five states. The party's proposal to introduce tougher Islamic punishments could lead to amendments in syariah laws at the state level. Despite analysts labeling the goal as overly ambitious, PAS is hoping to capitalize on an economic downturn and appeal to its membership by raising livelihood issues. The party's electoral ambitions seem at odds with its budding relationship with the ruling party Umno, but PAS president Abdul Hadi Awang has pushed for closer ties with Prime Minister Najib Razak's party.

site_title: FAS saga: A timeline of events
summary: Police raided FAS offices on April 20, amid a probe into the misuse of funds at Tiong Bahru Football Club, where FAS officials, including former president Zainudin Nordin and secretary general Winston Lee, were detained to assist with investigations. FAS president Bill Ng had made donations totaling $850,000 to the association, but the origin of the funds was disputed. The FAS election, set for April 29, was overshadowed by the scandal, with the police probe widening to include other FAS officials. Despite the controversy, the election was set to proceed, with the FAS electoral committee chairman stating that the election would go ahead unless FIFA advised otherwise.

site_title: The Straits Times' News In A Minute: April 27, 2017
summary: Singaporean junior ministers Josephine Teo and Desmond Lee will be promoted to full ministers in the Prime Minister's Office starting May 1. The Social Science Research Council has awarded $21 million in grants for research projects on Singaporean society, covering topics such as racial biases and coping strategies for low-income families. Additionally, four new MRT stations on the Tuas West Extension will open on June 18, including Gul Circle, Tuas Crescent, Tuas West Road, and Tuas Link.

site_title: Over 100 bees found dead in Jurong West HDB, bee hive found in Fuhua Secondary School
summary: Over 100 dead bees were found in a Jurong West HDB block on April 27, with a bee hive discovered at a nearby Fuhua Secondary School. The incident was reported by residents who had seen stray bees on Wednesday night, with some finding dead bees in corridors and staircases. Pest control was deployed, and the bee hive was removed from the school. This is not the first time bee swarms have invaded HDB blocks in Singapore, with previous incidents reported in Punggol, Sengkang, and Woodlands.

site_title: Teo Ser Luck plans to create, invest in start-ups and businesses after retirement from office
summary: Minister of State for Manpower Teo Ser Luck plans to transition into the private sector after stepping down from public office on June 30. He aims to create, invest in, and help start-ups and businesses, focusing on tech and products he's passionate about. Teo expressed gratitude for the support he received during his time in public office, highlighting his active role in promoting small and medium enterprises. He will hand over as Mayor for North East District to Desmond Choo on May 26.

site_title: Sample a range of Greek dishes at Alati
summary: Alati, a Greek restaurant in Singapore, offers a range of authentic dishes inspired by Athens. The restaurant, owned by Athens native executive chef Ioannis Stefanopoulos, sources seafood directly from Greece. Dishes such as the juicy Greek Octopus, tangy Taramosalata, and crispy Fyllo-wrapped Feta showcase the flavors and freshness of Greek cuisine. The menu features sharing plates, including the Greek Fried Donuts and a side of yogurt. Alati's menu has been refreshed, offering a unique dining experience for those looking to try Greek food.

site_title: China military apologises for mocked photoshopped navy picture
summary: China's Defence Ministry apologized for allowing a poorly photoshopped picture of navy ships and fighter jets to appear on its social media accounts, marking the navy's 68th birthday. The image, which showed fighter jets over the country's first aircraft carrier, was mocked for its inaccuracies and unprofessional appearance, with internet users pointing out that the warships were likely US vessels and the fighter jets were not the navy's J-15s. The ministry spokesman admitted to the "carelessness" and expressed "sincere apologies" for the image's release.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit DPU down 6.3% in Q3
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 6.3% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) in Q3 to 1.18 cents, primarily due to disruptions in revenue from mall repositioning in China and lower contributions from Wisma Atria Retail. Net property income decreased 0.9% to S$41.2 million, while income available for distribution dropped 3.1% to S$27.1 million. Despite higher contributions from master tenants in Singapore and Malaysia, the effects of mall repositioning and lower retail contributions weighed on the company's performance.

site_title: Thai Red Bull heir threatened with arrest after latest no-show
summary: Thai prosecutors have vowed to seek an arrest warrant for Worayuth Yoovidhya, heir to the Red Bull fortune, after he missed his latest summons to hear charges over a 2012 hit-and-run that left a policeman dead. Worayuth, 27 at the time, allegedly smashed his Ferrari into the officer, dragging his body for several hundred meters before fleeing. The case has dragged on for years due to his lack of appearances, and prosecutors claim to have no connection to his family's wealth. An arrest warrant is expected to be requested if Worayuth fails to show up by 4pm today.

site_title: Keppel wins S$55.8 million contract for tension leg wellhead platform
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine has secured a S$55.8 million contract to provide engineering and construction management support services for the Repsol Ca Rong Do Tension Leg Wellhead Platform in Vietnam. The contract includes hull and mooring engineering, topsides basic engineering, and construction management support. The TLWP, set to be the first in Vietnam, will be deployed in a 320-meter water depth, hosting up to 20 wells for oil production, water injection, and gas injection. It will be the first three-column TLWP in the offshore oil and gas industry.

site_title: Field of fake Trumps battle it out in LA
summary: Donald Trump impersonators gathered at the Laugh Factory in Los Angeles to compete in a comedy club event. Ten comedians, including one from New Zealand, performed two-minute skits on various Trump topics. The winner, who will host a weekly show and headline at Laugh Factory clubs, was determined by audience applause. The event aimed to find the best impersonator of the American President, Donald Trump.

site_title: Heavy rain causes flash floods in several areas including Tai Seng and Tampines
summary: Heavy rain caused flash floods in eastern Singapore on April 27, 2017, affecting areas such as Tai Seng and Tampines. The National Environment Agency and PUB issued warnings of heavy rain and flash floods, with photos showing vehicles stranded in shin-deep water. The National Water Agency advised against driving through floodwaters, citing safety concerns. An entire street in Tampines was flooded, with construction workers wading through water.

site_title: South Korea gives anti-submarine warship to Philippines for US$100
summary: South Korea has agreed to donate an ageing Pohang-class anti-submarine warship to the Philippines in exchange for $100. The transfer is expected to boost the Philippines' capability to patrol its vast maritime borders. The warship will undergo refurbishment, and the Philippines may acquire up to three more vessels in the future. This donation is part of South Korea's efforts to support the Philippines' military capabilities, following their historical ties and contributions to the 1950-53 Korean War.

site_title: North Korea seeks Asean support in row with US
summary: North Korea has appealed to the Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) for support in its row with the US, warning of a "nuclear holocaust" due to Washington's actions. In a letter to Asean's secretary general, North Korean Foreign Minister Ri Yong Ho criticized US-South Korean military exercises, calling them a threat to regional peace. Tensions have escalated in the region following North Korea's missile tests and tough rhetoric from Washington, with the US deploying an aircraft carrier strike group to the Korean peninsula.

site_title: Is there a shift in China's approach to North Korea?: The Korea Herald
summary: China appears to be taking a tougher stance on North Korea, putting unprecedented pressure on the country. State-controlled media outlets have suggested Beijing may condone a US surgical strike against a nuclear facility, and the government has limited imports of North Korean coal and discontinued flights to Pyongyang. Chinese President Xi Jinping has earned confidence with US President Trump, with Trump praising Xi's efforts to pressure North Korea. However, North Korea remains defiant, with its state media warning of "catastrophic consequences" if China applies sanctions.

site_title: Theatre company and IT retailers among anchor tenants at new Funan mall
summary: Local theatre company W!ld Rice, IT retailers Newstead Technologies and AddOn Systems, and other anchor tenants will occupy the new Funan mall when it opens in the fourth quarter of 2019. The 887,000 sq ft mall will feature Singapore's first theatre venue, a Lenovo flagship, and a dedicated test zone for drone videography and photography. Other tenants include Golden Village, Kopitiam, and Climb Central, with a total retail net lettable area of about 324,000 sq ft.

site_title: DBS cuts executive pay in 2016 amid surging NPLs, control lapses
summary: DBS Group Holdings reduced senior executive pay by 13% in 2016 due to weaker performance in Greater China and "control lapses" on the regulatory front. The bank, led by CEO Piyush Gupta, reported a 93% surge in bad-debt allowances, which reduced annual profit by 2%. Despite this, the bank's share price rose 3.9% last year, while Gupta's pay fell 23% to S$8.44 million. The cuts were made to hold managers accountable for weaknesses in nonperforming loans, regulatory control, and overall performance.

site_title: Airbag maker Takata shares plunge nearly 20% on bankruptcy report
summary: Takata shares plummeted nearly 20% on April 27 after a media report suggested the Japanese airbag maker was considering bankruptcy and would roll its key businesses into a new company, prompting the Tokyo Stock Exchange to lift a trading suspension.

site_title: Donald Trump's 100 days in office: What he has done and failed to do so far
summary: US President Donald Trump's 100-day mark in office has seen him struggle to achieve major legislative accomplishments, despite confirming Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch and signing key executive orders on immigration, trade, and energy. Trump's approval ratings remain at record lows, with his administration facing challenges in finding funding for the proposed border wall. The president has also faced criticism for his handling of healthcare, taxes, and foreign policy, with some experts warning of potential trade wars with China and increased tensions with North Korea.

site_title: China coal miner said to vie for M1
summary: A Chinese coal miner, Shanxi Meijin Energy, and China Broadband Capital are among bidders for Singapore's wireless carrier M1, worth $1.4 billion. The two companies have submitted first-round offers, with Bahrain Telecommunications and private equity funds also making non-binding bids. The sale comes as Singapore prepares for a fourth mobile operator and the regulator seeks to introduce more competition to bring down phone bills and improve services. M1's largest owners, Axiata Group, Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation, and Singapore Press Holdings, have appointed Morgan Stanley to explore options, including a sale of the telecom operator.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine net profit down 28.8 per cent in Q1
summary: Sembcorp Marine's net profit fell 28.8% to S$39.6 million in Q1, with revenue dropping 17.2% to S$760 million. Lower revenue from drillships and ship repair orders contributed to the decline. Despite this, the company remains cautiously optimistic about its outlook, citing expected increases in global exploration and production spending, and strong customer interest in liquefied natural gas solutions. Earnings per share fell to 1.89 cents, but the net asset value rose to S$1.2412 per share.

site_title: Two police wounded by ‘Islamist’ on France’s Reunion island: Official
summary: A man suspected of being a radicalized Islamist shot and wounded two French police officers on Reunion island, a French overseas territory in the Indian Ocean. The suspect, in his 20s and believed to be a recent convert to Islam, refused to be arrested and fired a rifle at police. The lives of the officers are not in danger, and the attack is being investigated by France's anti-terrorist department. This incident comes a week after a similar attack on Paris' Champs Elysses avenue, which was claimed by the ISIS militant group, and follows a string of terror attacks on the French mainland since 2015.

site_title: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte says pointless discussing China's island-building at Asean summit
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte stated at the Asean summit that discussing China's island-building in the South China Sea is pointless and no one dares to pressure China. He emphasized the need for dialogue and suggested that action is not feasible. The Philippines, as Asean chair, is expected to adopt a softer tone about the disputes, excluding references to militarization or island-building. Duterte's approach has been criticized as taking a defeatist position on China and defending Philippine sovereignty.

site_title: Cabinet changes: Josephine Teo, Desmond Lee promoted to full ministers
summary: Singapore's Cabinet has undergone changes with Junior Ministers Josephine Teo and Desmond Lee promoted to full ministers. Teo will be appointed Minister in the Prime Minister's Office and Second Minister in the Ministry of Manpower and Ministry of Foreign Affairs, while Lee will hold the same roles in the PMO and be Second Minister in the Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of National Development. The changes, effective May 1, are part of leadership renewal, with other ministers also taking on new roles, including Senior Ministers of State and senior parliamentary secretaries.

site_title: Football: Dick Advocaat set to return as Dutch coach - report
summary: Veteran coach Dick Advocaat is set to return as coach of the Dutch national team for a third stint, with Ruud Gullit as his assistant. Advocaat, currently at Fenerbahce, will replace Danny Blind, who was sacked after a 2-0 defeat to Bulgaria. The Netherlands, three-time World Cup runners-up, face a World Cup qualifying spot in doubt. Advocaat's contract at Fenerbahce ends in June, allowing him to join the team for a friendly against Morocco on May 31.

site_title: A whole butterflied trout which cooks faster, and has better flavour
summary: A new cooking technique called "butterflied" trout, where the fish is cut in half lengthwise and the fillets are separated, has been discovered. This method allows for faster cooking times and better flavor, as the skin and bones add flavor to the flesh. The technique is simple, requiring only 10 minutes of preparation time, and can be paired with a variety of herbs and seasonings. The resulting dish is a succulent and flavorful whole fish experience, making it a great alternative to traditional fillet cooking.

site_title: Taiwan president Tsai Ing-wen says phone call with Donald Trump can take place again
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen expressed openness to a second direct phone call with US President Donald Trump, saying it could take place again depending on the situation. She also urged China to step up to its global responsibility, calling on President Xi Jinping to act like a leader. Tsai emphasized Taiwan's improving ties with the US, mentioning the potential purchase of F-35 fighter jets, and expressed hope for a different perspective on cross-Strait relations. Despite China's opposition to any country selling arms to Taiwan, Tsai remains committed to maintaining peace with China while refusing to bow to pressure.

site_title: Time for Asean to combat climate change: Philippine Daily Inquirer Columnist
summary: The Philippines is urging Asean to prioritize climate change efforts, citing the region's devastating impact on marine life and ecosystems. The country notes that Asean has failed to give climate change the priority it deserves, despite integrating marine conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity into its strategic programs. With the Paris Agreement entering into force, Asean is urged to invigorate its efforts on climate change resiliency, addressing issues such as oceanic destruction, overfishing, and plastic pollution, which threaten the region's waters and the planet's future.

site_title: Badminton: Chinese head coach Li Yongbo replaced by Xia Xuanze and Zhang Jun
summary: Chinese badminton head coach Li Yongbo steps down after 24 years, replaced by Xia Xuanze as men's singles coach and Zhang Jun as men's and women's doubles coach. Zhang Jun, a two-time Olympic gold medallist, will oversee doubles, while Xia Xuanze, a men's singles bronze medallist, will coach singles. The coaching staff will be reshuffled before the 2017 Sudirman Cup in Australia, and former deputy head coach Tian Bingyi and Zhong Bo will become consultants.

site_title: NBA: Washington Wizards, Boston Celtics back on top in East playoffs
summary: The Washington Wizards regained control of their first-round playoff series against the Atlanta Hawks, defeating them 103-99 with Bradley Beal's 27 points. The Wizards now lead the series 3-2, with Game Six set for Sunday. Meanwhile, the Boston Celtics took a 3-2 lead over the Chicago Bulls with a 108-97 win, setting up a potential series-clinching game on Friday. The Celtics' Isaiah Thomas scored 11 of his 24 points in the fourth quarter, while Al Horford added 21 points, nine rebounds, and seven assists.

site_title: Tennis: 'Cheater' Maria Sharapova should not be allowed to play again: Eugenie Bouchard
summary: Canadian tennis player Eugenie Bouchard has criticized Maria Sharapova, who returned to competition after a 15-month doping ban, calling her a "cheater" who should not be allowed to play again. Sharapova was banned for two years but had her sentence reduced to 15 months. Bouchard believes the WTA's decision sets a bad example for young players and undermines the integrity of the sport. Sharapova will continue to compete in tournaments, including the French Open, despite Bouchard's strong disapproval.

site_title: FAS saga: SportSG chief believes new FAS council should listen to different voices
summary: Singapore SportSG chief Lim Teck Yin urges the new Football Association of Singapore (FAS) council to listen to diverse voices and consider different views when making decisions. He emphasizes the importance of input from the community and encourages the new council to work towards a sustained programme to build a strong national team. Lim also denies that local sport is in disarray, stating that the majority of national sports associations are well-managed and trying to serve the community.

site_title: 145 young inmates receive National Youth Achievement Awards, highest number ever
summary: 145 young inmates aged 25 and below from Changi Women's Prison and Tanah Merah Prison received National Youth Achievement Awards, the highest number ever. The awards, which began in 2000, recognize young people for participating in activities promoting positive qualities such as self-reliance and perseverance. This year's recipients, including Kayla, a 25-year-old who completed a community project, will gain greater awareness of their roles in society and the community through the program. The awards aim to inspire others as they rebuild their lives, according to Parliamentary Secretary for Home Affairs Amrin Amin.

site_title: Need for concerted global strategy to address underlying causes of radicalisation: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Home Affairs and Law Minister K Shanmugam urges a concerted global strategy to address the underlying causes of radicalization, calling for international cooperation to counter extremist ideologies. He highlights the threat posed by returning foreign terrorist fighters, particularly in Southeast Asia, where ISIS seeks to establish a caliphate. Shanmugam emphasizes that dealing with the root causes of radicalization is crucial, warning that ignoring these issues will only lead to a cycle of violence and new recruits.

site_title: China flags global naval role after new carrier launch
summary: China has successfully launched its first domestically built aircraft carrier, amid rising tensions over North Korea and regional concerns about Beijing's assertiveness. Foreign Minister Wang Yi stated that China needs to raise its military capabilities to protect its growing overseas interests, but vowed not to pursue expansionism. China's navy has been taking a prominent role, with plans to establish at least six carriers and overseas bases to support them, although this would still leave it short of challenging the US's 10 carriers.

site_title: Google Street View to capture running and walking trails in Singapore
summary: Google Singapore has partnered with JustRunLah! to visually map 30 running and walking trails across Singapore using the Google Street View Trekker. The trekker, equipped with 15 cameras, captures 360-degree images and weighs 20kg. The mapped trails will allow runners to visualize and plan their routes. Additionally, Google's Special Collections programme has been updated with 30 indoor and outdoor attractions in Singapore, including Coney Island Park and the National Gallery Singapore, to aid tourists in trip planning.

site_title: Charlie Young and Singaporean husband welcome twins
summary: Hong Kong actress Charlie Young, 42, has welcomed twins with her Singaporean husband Khoo Shao Tze. The couple, who married in 2013, announced the birth of the babies on Weibo, thanking doctors, nurses, and friends for their support. This marks the latest twin birth among celebrities, following actress Lee Sinje and pop star Beyonce.

site_title: MP Tin Pei Ling to work for tech investment firm from May
summary: Singapore MP Tin Pei Ling will start working at tech investment firm Jing King Tech Group in May, offering her job flexibility as a full-time MP. As group director of corporate strategy, she will oversee a firm with total assets of approximately US$250 million. Despite taking on the new role, Tin expects to continue fulfilling her MP responsibilities, attending meet-the-people sessions and grassroots events, and strengthening the ward's volunteer team.

site_title: AA Reit's Q4 DPU down 5.8%
summary: Aims AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) reported a 5.8% decline in its fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.78 cents, down from the same period last year. Gross revenue increased 1.1% to S$30.6 million, driven by new property contributions, while net property income dropped 2% to S$20 million. The decline in DPU was partly offset by higher rental contributions from certain properties.

site_title: Robotic ice-cream machine dealer convicted of false PIC claim
summary: A Singaporean robotic ice-cream machine dealer, Robofusion Asia, was fined $60,000 for giving false information on the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) cash payout application form. Director Yong Tai Kok was ordered to pay a penalty of $120,000 and fined $4,000 for aiding in the false claim. The company was not eligible for the PIC cash payout as it did not meet the requirement of having three local employees. The fine and penalty were imposed after an investigation showed the company used non-employees' names and made contributions to their Central Provident Fund accounts.

site_title: Five agreements inked to boost innovation in Singapore's maritime sector
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) in Singapore signed five memoranda of agreements (MOUs) with industry players to boost innovation in the maritime sector. The agreements, signed at the opening of the Singapore Maritime Technology Conference, aim to advance research, innovation, and pilot adoption of emerging technologies in areas such as digitalisation, connected community systems, and automation. The MOUs include collaborations with PSA, ST Electronics, and other partners to develop smart ships, improve port operations, and enhance maritime cybersecurity. The agreements are part of the MPA's efforts to drive competitiveness and new growth areas in the sector.

site_title: Thai mother saw daughter's Facebook Live murder
summary: A Thai mother, Jiranuch Trirat, 22, witnessed her 11-month-old daughter Natalie being murdered by her boyfriend Wuttisan Wongtalay on Facebook Live. Wuttisan hanged Natalie from an abandoned building before taking his own life. The graphic video was broadcast live on Facebook for 24 hours, sparking outrage and renewed calls for social media companies to remove such content more quickly. Jiranuch forgave her boyfriend, saying holding onto anger won't bring her daughter back, and the incident highlights the need for greater action by Facebook and other social media platforms to address violent crimes being broadcast live.

site_title: Junior college, school mergers a painful but necessary decision: Ng Chee Meng
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Education (MOE) has announced the merger of 14 schools, including eight junior colleges, due to the country's declining birth rate. Education Minister Ng Chee Meng described the decision as "painful but necessary", citing the need to ensure schools can fill desired intakes. The mergers will limit students' educational and CCA experiences, but Ng emphasized that the changes are made for the students' benefit, and he encourages everyone to work together to make the transition. The decision affects students, alumni, parents, and teachers, but Ng assures that the identities of the schools will be honored.

site_title: Copenhagen's Noma restaurant goes to Mexico in its latest pop-up in the jungle
summary: Copenhagen's Noma restaurant, known for being the "Best Restaurant in the World," has opened a pop-up in the jungle of Tulum, Mexico, with chef Rene Redzepi at the helm. The seven-week pop-up, which runs through May 28, features dishes made with local ingredients and innovative techniques, such as using ants as a flavor enhancer. Tickets sold out in two hours, with diners paying $600 per person for the experience. The pop-up was made possible by a team of over 145 employees, including staff, family members, and guests from Noma in Copenhagen, and has received support from local organizations and sponsors.

site_title: New apprenticeship scheme for seafaring jobs launched
summary: A new apprenticeship scheme for seafaring jobs was launched in Singapore on April 27, 2017, by the Tripartite Maritime Manpower Taskforce for Seafaring. The scheme aims to raise employability by providing vocational skills training and a month-long shipboard work trial for Singaporeans and permanent residents. The training costs and allowance will be supported by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, e2i, SOS, and WSG, with a target of training up to 50 candidates per year. The first batch is expected to start the familiarisation course by the end of May.

site_title: Syria accuses Israel of strike near Damascus airport
summary: Syria has accused Israel of triggering an explosion near Damascus International Airport on April 27, 2017, by firing missiles at a military position. The blast caused material damage and no casualties, according to preliminary reports. Israeli Intelligence Minister Yisrael Katz said the attack was consistent with Israel's policy of preventing arms transfers to Hezbollah, but did not confirm his country's involvement. The incident is the latest in a series of Israeli air strikes in Syria targeting Hezbollah, with which Israel has been at odds since the Syrian civil war began in 2011.

site_title: New thyroid surgery spares patients from neck scar
summary: A scar-free thyroid surgery, known as transoral endoscopic thyroidectomy, has been successfully performed at Singapore General Hospital since 2015, sparing patients from visible neck scars. The procedure, which takes about 2-3 hours, involves three small incisions made in the inner lower lip to allow a camera and instruments to reach the thyroid gland. Patients who undergo the procedure typically experience faster wound healing and fewer complications compared to conventional thyroid surgery, which can leave a visible scar. The surgery is typically performed on patients with small lumps and no previous neck or thyroid surgery.

site_title: Los Angeles mayor declares April 25 'La La Land Day'
summary: Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti declared April 25 'La La Land Day' in honor of the Oscar-winning film. The declaration was marked by brightly-dressed dancers abseiling down City Hall and a performance of the film's duet 'City of Stars' by the film's jazz band and Mayor Garcetti. The day aims to celebrate dreams, romance, and love for the city, with Mayor Garcetti encouraging residents to take dates to Griffith Park and dance safely. The declaration was presented to writer and director Damien Chazelle.

site_title: Too early to tell if stronger economic growth is here to stay
summary: Singapore's economy appears to be on the upswing, driven by a rebound in manufacturing and trade-related sectors. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's Macroeconomic Review noted that growth has been volatile and uneven, with a 10.2% jump in factory output in March. However, other sectors such as retail and food services continue to struggle. A stronger, more sustained global economic recovery is needed for the upswing to broaden beyond manufacturing, and it remains too early to determine if the global economy can sustain improved momentum.

site_title: In Pictures: Alien movie collectibles at the Mint Museum of Toys
summary: The Mint Museum of Toys in Singapore is hosting "The Colony: Alien Movie Pop-up Exhibition" from April 27 to May 28, featuring collectible statues and toys from the Alien movie franchise. The exhibition showcases 500 pieces, including a 3.1kg solid pewter bust, and highlights the franchise's 38-year history. The event is open to the public, with admission priced at $15 per person and access to other galleries in the museum. The exhibition coincides with the release of Alien: Covenant on May 10, starring Michael Fassbender and Katherine Waterston.

site_title: 'Pope Francis' Laundry' opens in Rome
summary: Pope Francis has launched a laundromat for the poor in Rome, where homeless and impoverished individuals can wash their clothes and blankets for free. The laundromat, located in an old hospital complex near the Vatican, is open four days a week and offers washing machines, tumble dryers, detergent, and fabric softener. The initiative, in partnership with a Catholic charity and leading manufacturers, aims to restore dignity to the homeless. Pope Francis' latest gesture has been hailed as a "miracle" by those who rely on the laundromat, providing a vital service to Rome's poor and homeless population.

site_title: Singapore economy picking up but growth remains volatile and uneven: MAS
summary: The Singapore economy has picked up in recent months, driven by an improving global economy, particularly in trade-related sectors such as manufacturing and air cargo handling. However, growth remains volatile and uneven, with domestic-oriented sectors like retail and construction experiencing subdued growth. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has maintained its forecast of 1-3% economic growth for this year, citing firm external demand and support from the IT and semiconductor industries.

site_title: Why getting fired is worse than divorce or the death of a spouse
summary: Losing a job causes a significant drop in life satisfaction, surpassing the negative effects of being widowed or getting divorced, according to a review of over 4,000 research papers. Unemployed individuals rarely recover to pre-employment levels of well-being, with men being more affected than women. In contrast, people who lose a partner or go through a divorce can bounce back, with their well-being returning to normal levels within two to four years. The review suggests that the importance placed on having a meaningful job contributes to the lasting impact of unemployment on mental health and self-esteem.

site_title: Hong Kong police arrest nine more democracy activists
summary: Hong Kong police arrested nine democracy activists on Thursday over an anti-Beijing protest, amid growing concerns that the city's freedom is under threat. The arrests come ahead of China's President Xi Jinping's visit to mark the 20th anniversary of the handover of Hong Kong to China. The activists, including members of pro-democracy parties, were charged with illegal assembly and obstructing a police officer. Pro-democracy leader Joshua Wong warned that the arrests are part of a broader crackdown on street activists, saying "the police have set out to arrest all street activists so they won't dare to protest when Xi Jinping visits."

site_title: White tiger cubs born in Austrian zoo
summary: Four white Bengal tiger cubs, named Falco, Toto, Mia, and Mautzi, were unveiled at the White Zoo in Austria, born to Thalie, a six-year-old tigress, and Samir, a nine-year-old male. The cubs, two males and two females, were born on March 22 and weighed about one kilogram each. They will stay at the zoo for a year before being donated to other zoos, never to be sold. The zoo's director stated that the cubs will have a new "family" in other zoos, ensuring they won't end up in shows or circuses.

site_title: Donald Trump agrees with Canada, Mexico not to terminate Nafta, will swiftly renegotiate trade deal
summary: US President Donald Trump has agreed with Canada and Mexico not to terminate the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) at this time, instead opting to renegotiate the trade deal with the two countries. This decision comes after White House officials considered issuing an executive order to withdraw the US from the pact. Trump and his advisors will proceed swiftly with the renegotiation process, aiming to make the agreement better for all three countries, with potential benefits including stronger trade and economic growth.

site_title: United Airlines to offer passengers up to $14,000 to surrender seats on overbooked flights
summary: United Airlines is offering passengers up to $14,000 to surrender seats on overbooked flights as part of efforts to repair damage from a viral video of a passenger being forcibly removed from a flight. The airline will no longer call law enforcement to deny passengers boarding and will adopt a "no questions asked" policy on permanently lost baggage. This move comes after a national conversation sparked by the incident, in which passenger David Dao was removed from a flight and suffered injuries. United aims to reduce overbooking incidents and improve customer satisfaction.

site_title: Free hotel smartphone device to hit 1m rooms
summary: Hong Kong-based company Tink Labs aims to provide a free smartphone in every hotel room worldwide, offering guests unlimited calls, internet, and city guides. By the end of the year, 500,000 devices will be installed in hotel rooms, with half in Europe. The device can act as a room key, in-room control device, and remote control, allowing guests to navigate and access hotel services without incurring heavy roaming charges. Tink Labs plans to expand its services and eventually install devices in every hotel room globally.

site_title: $21 million in grants awarded for 12 research projects on Singapore society, identity
summary: The Social Science Research Council in Singapore has awarded $21 million in grants for 12 research projects on Singaporean society and identity. The projects, which include studies on early childhood development, racial biases, and low-income families, will focus on understanding social integration, innovation, and human development. The grants are part of the Ministry of Education's $350 million drive to boost social science research, and are expected to provide insights into pressing challenges facing Singapore, such as an ageing population and preserving social mobility.

site_title: New SGX regulatory unit open to reviewing quarterly report requirement
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo), an independent subsidiary of the Singapore Exchange, will review existing market rules, including the quarterly reporting requirement for listed companies. SGX RegCo chairman Professor Tan Cheng Han aims to ensure the rules are "relevant and balanced" and will be free of "profit and loss concerns" to maintain independence. The entity is expected to start operating by August and will oversee listing and trading rules, investigations, and enforcement actions, reporting to a five-member board with three independent directors. This move aims to improve existing regulations and bring a fresh perspective.

site_title: Ancient Chinese recipes inspire Forbidden City food range which is being sold online
summary: The Palace Museum's flagship food store, Regard From The Emperor, is now available online at Tmall, a Chinese online marketplace. The store offers a range of traditional Chinese foods inspired by ancient recipes from the Qing Dynasty, including porridge powder, cookies, and tea. The products are made with high-quality ingredients, such as organic ginger and royal chestnuts, and are available for purchase as part of the museum's effort to develop its cultural creative products and combine traditional food culture with online shopping habits.

site_title: Push for South China Sea code stirs Asean suspicions about Beijing's endgame
summary: China's support for a code of conduct in the South China Sea has sparked hopes for resolving disputes, but Asean members remain skeptical about Beijing's sincerity. China's recent desire to work with Asean to finalize the framework this year has been met with skepticism, with some viewing it as a ploy to stall until it achieves its strategic objectives. The framework aims to advance a 2002 Declaration of Conduct, but China's continued island-building and militarization in the South China Sea have raised concerns. Asean is taking a "leap of faith" with China, and experts believe Beijing's strategy is to project a responsible image while avoiding binding rules that could weaken its geopolitical position.

site_title: PUB seeks supplier for smart shower devices to monitor water usage
summary: National water agency PUB is seeking proposals for smart shower devices that monitor water usage in real-time. The devices, to be installed in 10,000 new homes, could help households save up to 5 litres of water a day. According to a study, successful use of these devices could save 3% of monthly water bills. PUB aims to explore innovative features, including real-time feedback and smartphone connectivity, to encourage water conservation and reduce overall water consumption, which accounts for 29% of a household's monthly usage. The Smart Shower programme is set to start in 2018.

site_title: More young people have liberal attitude towards drugs: Survey
summary: A survey conducted by the National Council Against Drugs (NCADA) found that 58% of young people learned about drug-related content via social media, and liberal attitudes towards drugs have increased from 11% in 2013 to 16% in 2016. The survey also showed that about a third of young people did not perceive cannabis as addictive, and 35% saw it as a popular drug of abuse. Despite this, 81% of respondents had strong support for Singapore's drug-free approach and laws, with parental influence being effective in deterring drug abuse.

site_title: Travelling this June holidays? ICA reminds Singaporeans to apply for passports early
summary: The Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) of Singapore is advising citizens to apply for new passports early if their current ones are expiring during the mid-year school holidays in June. Many countries require a passport to be valid for at least six months for entry. ICA encourages applicants to make an appointment and come on time to avoid longer waiting times, particularly during busier periods. Passports can be applied for online, by post, or in deposit boxes, with options to collect at ICA Building, self-collect at iCollect, or at selected Post Offices.

site_title: China March industrial profits soar 23.8% on property but off highs
summary: China's industrial firms saw profits rise 23.8% in March, driven by a boom in the real estate sector. The growth was off multi-year highs, but still boosted by a construction boom in China. Industrial profits rose to 688.7 billion yuan in March, with the first quarter seeing a 28.3% increase to 1.7 trillion yuan. Analysts note that producer price inflation may be peaking, potentially tempering profitability later this year.

site_title: Bank of Japan sounds most upbeat on economy in 9 years
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary policy steady, with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressing confidence in the economy's recovery, the first time in nine years the BOJ described it as "expansion". The central bank cut its inflation forecast for this fiscal year to 1.4% but maintained its 2% target. The BOJ reiterated its commitment to massive monetary stimulus, with interest rates at minus 0.1% and a pledge to guide 10-year government bond yields around zero. Analysts expect the BOJ to tighten monetary policy, but most do not anticipate this until next year.

site_title: SCMS renamed Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon, bids to join big league of World Marathon Majors
summary: The Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon (SCSM) is set to bid to become an Abbott World Marathon Majors (WMM) event, potentially joining the ranks of prestigious marathons like Boston and Berlin. The event has been an IAAF Gold Label race since 2012 and has gained popularity in the region. The SCSM's organiser, Ironman Asia, and sponsor, Standard Chartered Bank, have announced a three-year sponsorship deal worth $11.4 million to support the bid. The event will introduce new features and loyalty programs, including a runners' loyalty program and a new route for the full and half-marathon categories.

site_title: Punchlines: April 27, 2017
summary: No article content provided.

site_title: Earliest China data signal economic momentum eased in April
summary: China's economic momentum eased in April, according to the first data release for the quarter, with a slight decrease in confidence among small- and medium-sized enterprises and a steel sentiment index. The economy expanded faster than expected in the first quarter, driven by factory price surges and accelerating investment, but stricter property-market curbs and slower producer-price gains cast doubt on its durability. Global financial market experts remain optimistic about China's growth, with a survey showing increased expectations for the country's growth.

site_title: 4 MRT stations on Tuas West Extension to open on June 18
summary: Singapore's Tuas West Extension of the East-West Line MRT will open on June 18, 2017, with four new stations: Gul Circle, Tuas Crescent, Tuas West Road, and Tuas Link. The 7.5km extension is expected to serve 100,000 daily commuters, particularly workers in Jurong and Tuas Industrial estates. The project includes the construction of a 26ha integrated depot and enhancements to the existing bus service network. The extension is expected to reduce travel time from Ang Mo Kio to Tuas West by about 35 minutes.

site_title: Bake fish with chimichurri for an easy flavourful meal
summary: A simple and flavorful baked fish dish with chimichurri sauce is perfect for a long weekend meal. The recipe uses angkoli (goldband snapper) and can be made with minimal effort. The chimichurri sauce is made with lemon juice instead of red wine vinegar for a brighter taste. To serve, the fish is baked at 180°C for 25 minutes, then topped with additional sauce before serving. This recipe yields four servings and can be adjusted to suit individual tastes.

site_title: New schemes to help PMETs find jobs in manufacturing industry
summary: Singapore has launched eight new Professional Conversion Programmes (PCPs) to help professionals, managers, executives and technicians (PMETs) find jobs in the manufacturing industry. The schemes cover precision engineering sector jobs and aim to help workers displaced by the economic downturn and restructuring. A one-day career fair was also held, with companies looking to fill over 900 jobs. Manufacturing Minister Lim Swee Say emphasized the sector's importance to economic growth and job creation, noting that more than 70% of its jobs are held by foreign work permit holders.

site_title: Downton Abbey exhibition to begin in Singapore in June
summary: A Downton Abbey exhibition is set to launch in Singapore on June 17 at Marina Bay Sands. The "fully immersive" showcase will feature the sets and costumes from the hit British period drama, including Mrs. Patmore's kitchen and Lady Mary's dresses. The exhibition will be a multi-million dollar museum-quality experience, delighting fans of the show. After Singapore, the exhibition will travel to the US next year, extending the brand's global reach. The exhibition is part of NBCUniversal International Studios' efforts to expand the Downton Abbey legacy and offer fans a unique experience.

site_title: A surprise from Donald Trump's first 100 days: First international rescue is Muslim American woman
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration prioritized the release of Aya Hijazi, a 30-year-old Muslim American woman detained in Egypt for nearly three years on human trafficking charges, despite his earlier "Muslim ban" executive order. Hijazi was acquitted after backroom negotiations between the Trump administration and Egyptian officials. The move has surprised some Muslims in the US, who are concerned about Trump's treatment of Muslims, but others see it as a positive sign that the president is responsible for all Americans. Trump's actions have been criticized for missing an opportunity to highlight Hijazi's humanitarian work and for not prioritizing persecuted Christians overseas.

site_title: Myanmar police investigate ' first ever high-definition' locally-made porn movie
summary: Myanmar police launched a criminal investigation into a high-definition pornographic movie, "The Violet Of Myanmar", after it was posted on Facebook. The film, produced by Art Of Myanmar, is the first locally-made HD porn movie in the socially conservative country. The actress in the film wears a surgical mask and has her face blurred. Police are investigating the production company for violating laws on obscene material, which is illegal in Buddhist-majority Myanmar. The company's Facebook page was taken down after receiving over 2,000 messages, and the film's trailer was removed from social media.

site_title: GIC affiliate to take minority stake in US clinical research firm PPD
summary: A GIC affiliate and Abu Dhabi Investment Authority affiliate are taking minority stakes in US-based contract research organization PPD, valuing the company at over $9 billion. The deal is expected to close in the second quarter and is subject to regulatory approval. Private equity firms Hellman & Friedman and The Carlyle Group, which took PPD private in 2011, will maintain majority joint ownership and invest in new funds. PPD provides services to pharmaceutical, biotechnology, and medical device companies, employing over 19,000 globally. The deal is a significant investment for GIC and ADIA, both long-time investors in Carlyle and Hellman & Friedman.

site_title: Not sure what to wear? Amazon's Echo Look may help
summary: Amazon unveiled the Echo Look, a voice-controlled camera that recommends outfits using fashion specialists' advice and algorithms. The device, part of the Alexa ecosystem, allows users to submit photos of their outfits for personalized style recommendations. The service aims to provide Amazon with data on customer preferences and help the company compete with traditional retailers in the fashion market. The Echo Look is priced at $199.99 and is expected to be released to the public, with potential applications including home surveillance and augmented reality in e-commerce.

site_title: There's a red button on President Donald Trump's desk - for Coke
summary: US President Donald Trump has a red button on his desk in the Oval Office that summons a butler to bring him a Coca-Cola, not to launch missiles. This was revealed in an Associated Press interview and has garnered attention from social media users. Trump's affinity for fast food, including Coke, Big Macs, and KFC, has been well-documented, but it appears he no longer eats fast food due to the high quality of cuisine at the White House.

site_title: Tennis: A stoic Maria Sharapova returns to the tour unbowed by attention or criticism
summary: Maria Sharapova returned to the tennis tour after a 15-month doping ban, facing intense scrutiny and criticism. Despite being the subject of every interview at the Porsche Tennis Grand Prix, Sharapova had been practicing in a nearby facility. She won her first match against Roberta Vinci 7-5, 6-3, and will play Svetlana Kuznetsova in the round of 16. In a post-match press conference, Sharapova showed battle-faced and armoured to face her critics, answering questions about her doping ban and return to the sport. She emphasized that what matters is her performance on the court, not what others say about her.

site_title: British Airways offloads British couple at military base over demand for business class upgrade
summary: British Airways offloaded a British couple from a London-to-Jamaica flight at a Portuguese air force base after a dispute over a business class upgrade. The couple, who wanted to be transferred from economy class to first class, reportedly filmed the incident on a mobile phone. The pilot landed in Lajes, Terceira, to resolve the issue, and the couple will remain there to be questioned by police. The flight continued to Kingston, Jamaica.

site_title: Samsung Q1 profit jumps 46% on rebound in chip, phone sales
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 46% increase in Q1 profit to 7.49 trillion won, surpassing analyst estimates. The company's chip business saw a record 6.3 trillion won operating profit, driven by price gains for DRAM and NAND memory chips. Samsung regained the global smartphone lead and unveiled the Galaxy S8, which has generated strong pre-orders. The company will pay its first quarterly dividend of 7,000 won and is on track for its best year ever.

site_title: China welcomes US saying it’s open to talks on North Korea
summary: China welcomed US statements on the North Korean nuclear crisis, calling them "positive" and expressing a desire for peaceful resolution through dialogue. China opposes the deployment of a US missile defense system in South Korea, while the US has agreed to swift punitive measures against North Korea in the event of further provocation. The US aims to push North Korea into dismantling its nuclear and missile programs through tougher sanctions and diplomatic pressure, with China supporting non-military avenues.

site_title: Difficult legal path forward for Donald Trump in sanctuary cities case
summary: US President Donald Trump's executive order on sanctuary cities, issued on January 25, 2017, faces a difficult legal path despite potential appeals. A court ruling blocking the order's withdrawal of federal funding for non-cooperative cities may harm the administration's efforts to cut off funds, as the government's narrower argument may restrict its ability to cut off funds in the future. The Justice Department may appeal to the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals and potentially the Supreme Court, but experts suggest the administration's strategy could be limited by procedural issues and the need to establish actual harm to the cities.

site_title: Football: Eriksen strikes late to keep Spurs in title hunt
summary: Tottenham's Christian Eriksen scored a late 1-0 win against Crystal Palace, keeping his team in the title hunt with five games remaining. Eriksen's 25-yard strike sealed a vital victory for Spurs, closing the gap on leaders Chelsea to four points. The win, Tottenham's eighth successive league victory, comes as they look to avenge their FA Cup semi-final defeat against Chelsea and potentially be crowned champions for the first time since 1961.

site_title: Two Chinese companies among bidders for M1: Sources
summary: Chinese coal producer Shanxi Meijin Energy Co and China Broadband Capital are among bidders for Singapore's wireless carrier M1, valued at $1.4 billion, according to sources. Other bidders include Bahrain Telecommunications Co and private equity funds. The sale comes as Singapore prepares to roll out a fourth mobile operator, aiming to increase competition and lower phone bills. M1's largest owners, Axiata Group, Keppel Telecommunications, and Singapore Press Holdings, have appointed Morgan Stanley to explore options, including a sale, amid the regulator's push for increased competition.

site_title: Football: Arsenal boost Champions League hopes with late own goal
summary: Arsenal secured a 1-0 win over Leicester City at The Emirates Stadium, keeping their hopes alive for a 20th consecutive Champions League campaign. The match saw Arsenal dominate possession but Leicester create the best early chances. Robert Huth scored an own goal in the 86th minute, deflecting a shot from Nacho Monreal past Kasper Schmeichel. The win leaves Arsenal four points short of the fourth Champions League spot, while Leicester are six points above the relegation places.

site_title: How China's aircraft carriers stack up against carriers from other military powers
summary: China has entered the elite club of countries with its own aircraft carriers, with the launch of the Type 001A, its second carrier, expected to be fully operational by 2020. China's carriers, including the 85,000-tonne third carrier under construction, stack up against other military powers. The US has 10 carriers, the largest in the world, with the Nimitz-class carriers weighing 100,000 tons and using nuclear power. Britain and India are also building carriers, with the UK's Queen Elizabeth-class and India's INS Vikrant and INS Vishal expected to enter service in the coming years.

site_title: Asian shares retreat from highs on doubts over Trump tax plan
summary: Asian shares retreated from a near two-year high on Thursday, April 27, as a long-awaited US tax cut plan failed to inspire investors. Despite concerns over the US economy slowing, global growth prospects and receding European political risks supported sentiment. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index fell 0.4% and Japan's Nikkei dipped 0.3% after the US President proposed slashing tax rates for businesses. Analysts expect the US tax plan to be difficult to pay for without increasing the deficit, and a potential government shutdown could raise fresh worries about President Trump's agenda.

site_title: First Sponsor posts 16.4% rise in Q1 profit
summary: First Sponsor Group reported a 16.4% rise in Q1 net profit to S$14.2 million, marking the 10th consecutive quarter of profit growth since its IPO in 2014. Revenue jumped 78.6% to S$81.3 million, driven by property sales and hotel operations. The company handed over 600 residential units in its Millennium Waterfront project, with over 1,000 units sold, equivalent to 70% of last year's sales. As of March, 969 units remain unsold out of 7,302 units in the project.

site_title: Backlash after report claims saturated fats do not increase heart risk
summary: Three cardiologists have challenged the long-held medical thinking that saturated fats increase the risk of heart disease, citing a study that showed no association between saturated fat consumption and heart problems. The cardiologists argue that a Mediterranean-style diet and 22 minutes of walking a day are the best ways to prevent heart issues. However, their views have sparked fierce criticism from experts, who say the views are not based on reliable evidence and could mislead consumers. Critics argue that reducing saturated fat intake has been shown to lower cardiovascular events and that a more balanced approach is needed.

site_title: Companies cheer Donald Trump's plan for tax cuts, but jobs are less certain to follow
summary: US businesses are expected to benefit from President Donald Trump's proposed tax cuts, with corporate tax rates potentially falling below those of neighboring countries. The plan includes a cut to 15% for public companies, but lacks details on spending cuts to control budget deficits. Companies with $1.8 trillion in overseas cash, such as Apple, may bring it back if tax rates are lowered. However, it's unclear whether these cuts will stimulate job creation, as studies of past tax holidays have shown that offshore cash is often used for share buybacks or acquisitions rather than investments.

site_title: South Korea's Q1 GDP expands at fastest in 3 quarters on exports, capital spending
summary: South Korea's economy expanded at its fastest pace in three quarters in Q1, growing 0.9% on strong exports and capital spending. This is a relief for policymakers amid a host of challenges, including a presidential election and rising tensions with North Korea and China. The growth was driven by a 4.3% gain in facility investment and a 1.9% increase in exports. The Bank of Korea upgraded its growth outlook to 2.6% for this year, but remains wary of geopolitical risks. The election is set to take place on May 9.

site_title: Venezuela death toll hits 29, protesters battle security forces
summary: Venezuela's death toll from anti-government unrest has risen to at least 29, with 20-year-old protester dying after being hit by a tear gas canister in Caracas. Clashes between security forces and protesters continued, with water cannons and tear gas used against rock-throwing demonstrators on a bridge. The protests, sparked by opposition demands for elections and economic aid, have sparked the nation's worst violence since 2014.

site_title: Bill Cosby discusses his loss of sight as trial nears
summary: Bill Cosby, set to go on trial in June for sexual assault charges, is discussing his loss of sight in a rare interview. His daughter, Evin Cosby, has defended him, stating he is not abusive or violent, and his lawyer, Angela Agrusa, plans to shift the "optics" to change public opinion, citing that many people already believe him guilty. Cosby has denied the allegations and discussed his philanthropic efforts, including paying for the education of thousands of low-income African-American students.

site_title: Trump administration talks tough on  North Korea, but frustrated lawmakers want details
summary: US President Donald Trump and his national security advisers briefed congressional lawmakers on the "very grave threat" posed by North Korea, emphasizing economic, diplomatic, and military measures to pressure Pyongyang. The administration is developing a range of options, including additional economic sanctions and military options, but offered few details on its strategy. Lawmakers expressed frustration over the lack of clarity, with some calling for more aggressive action, including a preemptive strike. The administration has vowed to "solve" the North Korea problem unilaterally if necessary, but has not defined a new policy that differs significantly from past administrations.

site_title: Fox News anchor, others hit network with race bias claims
summary: Eleven current and former Fox News employees, including news anchor Kelly Wright, have filed an amended lawsuit in New York state court alleging racial discrimination. They claim they were demeaned, paid less than white coworkers, and passed over for promotions. The lawsuit adds class action claims to an existing lawsuit filed last month. The network denies the claims and will "vigorously defend these cases." The allegations come after Fox parent company Twenty-First Century Fox severed ties with star Bill O'Reilly over sexual harassment complaints.

site_title: Football: Real Madrid hit Deportivo for six, Barca relegate Osasuna
summary: Real Madrid defeated Deportivo la Coruna 6-2 to maintain their lead in the La Liga title race, while Barcelona secured a 7-1 win over Osasuna, relegating them to the second division. Madrid made nine changes from their previous game without key players Cristiano Ronaldo, Karim Benzema, and Gareth Bale, but still dominated the match. Barcelona's Lionel Messi scored twice, including his 500th goal for the club, and his teammate Gerard Pique also found the net. The results leave Madrid and Barcelona tied on 78 points, with Real having a game in hand.

site_title: K-drama Goblin beats Descendants Of The Sun in video-on-demand sales
summary: K-drama "Goblin" has surpassed "Descendants Of The Sun" and "Reply 1988" in video-on-demand sales, earning $12.5 million through internet protocol television and digital cable networks. This achievement comes after the drama's conclusion in January. Prior to "Goblin", "Descendants Of The Sun" and "Reply 1988" held the top spot in video-on-demand sales, with "Reply 1988" bringing in $6.2 million. The revenue from "Descendants Of The Sun" is reportedly similar to "Reply 1988", but exact figures were not disclosed.

site_title: Confessions of an inactive active wear addict
summary: Lisabel Ting, a self-proclaimed "Active Wear Addict," confesses to her comfort-first lifestyle after embracing the athleisure trend. She initially justifies her habit by claiming she'll be hitting the gym later or that exercise clothes are cheap. However, as her addiction worsens, she realizes the issue and decides to fully accept her new wardrobe. She abandons attempts to dress up and instead feels at ease wearing exercise gear for everyday activities, embracing her newfound comfort and normalizing active wear.

site_title: Fed, wary of inflation, could lean against Trump tax cut
summary: The US Federal Reserve may need to reconsider its interest rate hikes due to President Donald Trump's tax cut plan, which could boost the economy and push inflation above the Fed's target of 2%. The plan, which slashes corporate and household taxes, could add $700 billion to the economy annually, potentially fueling inflation and requiring the Fed to raise rates faster than expected. The Fed aims to maintain a measured pace of rate hikes, but the uncertainty surrounding the tax plan's implementation adds to the challenges of charting its course over the next few months.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, April 27 edition
summary: US President Donald Trump unveiled a major tax cut plan, slashing the corporate rate to 15% and compressing tax brackets for individuals to three. The plan aims to boost the US economy and families, but faces a tough fight in Congress. Meanwhile, two Taiwanese trekkers were found alive in Nepal after seven weeks, but one, Liu Chen-chun, died just three days before rescue. Tennis star Maria Sharapova won her first match back from a 15-month doping ban, while Christian Eriksen's late goal sealed a 1-0 win for Tottenham in the Premier League. Oscar-winning director Jonathan Demme died at 73 due to complications from esophageal cancer.

summary: English soccer clubs West Ham United and Newcastle United were raided by tax officials on April 26 as part of a wide-sweeping probe into Income Tax and National Insurance fraud. Several men were arrested, and business records, financial records, computers, and mobile phones were seized. HMRC stated that secret payments to evade taxes were suspected, particularly during player transfers between French and Premier League clubs. The raids were part of an international investigation with French authorities, with four people detained in France and 180 HMRC officers deployed across the UK and France.

site_title: Britain’s May tries to warm the Brexit atmosphere with EU
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May met with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker on April 26, 2017, in an effort to warm the Brexit atmosphere. May reiterated the UK's commitment to a "deep and special relationship" with the EU, while the meeting was described as "constructive" but offered few details. The talks precede the UK's departure from the EU, following last June's referendum vote, and come ahead of a June 8 election in which May hopes to strengthen her parliamentary majority.

site_title: Football: South America confed lost US$140 million to graft - president
summary: Conmebol, the South American football confederation, lost over US$140 million to graft under former managers indicted in a US corruption investigation. President Alejandro Dominguez unveiled the findings of an external audit, revealing that the body was defrauded between 2010 and 2014. Three former Conmebol presidents, including Nicolas Leoz and Eugenio Figueredo, have been indicted in the US investigation, accused of accepting bribes. The confederation has taken steps to root out graft, including separating political functions and limiting contract lengths.

site_title: US wants to bring North Korea back to ‘path of dialogue’
summary: The US aims to bring North Korea back to the "path of dialogue" over its nuclear program, using diplomatic measures and additional sanctions to increase pressure. The White House statement, issued after a meeting with top officials, toned down military rhetoric and urged the international community to help find a solution. The move comes as tensions rise on the Korean peninsula following recent missile launches and warnings of military action. The US is considering adding North Korea to its list of "state sponsors of terrorism," but officials stress there are no easy options for military interventions.

site_title: Football: Messi scores twice as Barca hit Osasuna for seven
summary: Lionel Messi scored twice as Barcelona thrashed Osasuna 7-1, moving three points clear of Real Madrid in La Liga. Andre Gomes and Paco Alcacer also scored doubles, while Javier Mascherano scored his first Barca goal in seven years from the penalty spot. The win keeps Barca in the title race, with Madrid having two games in hand. Osasuna remain rock-bottom and will be relegated if Leganes beat Las Palmas.
