site_title: Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob makes official visit to Mexico
summary: Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob is on an official visit to Mexico from April 23-28, at the invitation of Mexico's President of the Senate. She will meet with legislators, the Secretary of Foreign Affairs, and Undersecretary of Foreign Trade, and deliver a message to Mexican senators. The visit aims to enhance parliamentary dialogue and strengthen bilateral trade between Singapore and Mexico, which reached $4.3 billion in 2016.

site_title: Man's 'vandalised' car turns out to be anniversary prank by his girlfriend
summary: A 36-year-old Singaporean man's car was vandalized, with words like "Prada Power" and "Fat and Fabulous" painted on it, sparking widespread concern that it was the work of loan sharks. However, the owner, Mr. Sim Yumin, revealed that the vandalism was actually an anniversary prank planned and executed by his 29-year-old girlfriend, Shereen Tan, and their friends. The pranksters thought it would be a great way to celebrate their 10-year anniversary, and Mr. Sim is now amused by the whole affair, looking forward to getting his car professionally painted.

site_title: Football: Same standards apply to me, says Guardiola
summary: Pep Guardiola asserts he will be judged by the same standards as predecessor Manuel Pellegrini, despite City missing their target of winning the Premier League and Champions League. Guardiola, who has won 10 titles in his managerial career, downplays pressure from being at a wealthy club, saying he's "welcome" to the added expectations. He credits his improved performance to losing more games than usual, which he believes has helped him learn and grow as a manager. Guardiola is entering his second season with City, who finished fourth in the Premier League and reached the Champions League semi-finals last season.

site_title: North Korea says ready to strike US aircraft carrier
summary: North Korea threatened to sink a US aircraft carrier, the USS Carl Vinson, to demonstrate its military might, amid rising tensions over its nuclear and missile tests. The US had sent the carrier strike group to the western Pacific in response, with two Japanese navy ships joining the group for exercises. The North's military is combat-ready to strike the aircraft carrier with a single attack, the state-run newspaper Rodong Sinmun said. The US has vowed to prevent North Korea from hitting the US with a nuclear missile, with all options on the table, including a military strike.

site_title: Saudi royal decree sacks civil service, information ministers
summary: Saudi King Salman issued a royal decree on April 22, replacing the information minister and sacking the civil service minister, amidst allegations of abuse of office. A committee will investigate these allegations. The decree also established a national security centre under the royal court and appointed Ibrahim al-Omar as governor of the General Investment Authority.

site_title: Saudi air force pilot son of king named US envoy
summary: Saudi Arabia has appointed Prince Khaled bin Salman, son of King Salman, as the new ambassador to the US, replacing Prince Abdullah bin Faysal. The move comes as ties between Riyadh and Washington improve under President Donald Trump, who has expressed concerns over Iran's influence in the Middle East. Prince Khaled, an air force pilot, has flown missions against ISIS in Syria and is seen as a strong and organized individual by those pushing for closer Saudi-US relations. This appointment reflects the kingdom's efforts to strengthen its alliance with the US.

site_title: Pope says some refugee centres 'concentration camps', pays tribute to woman slain in front of husband
summary: Pope Francis describes some European refugee centres as "concentration camps" due to overcrowding and poor conditions, calling for greater attention to human rights. He paid tribute to an unknown Christian woman slain for her faith in front of her Muslim husband, whom he met during a visit to a Greek island refugee camp. The Pope urges Europe to adopt a more generous spirit towards migrants, warning that a lack of openness is "suicide."

site_title: IMF members set aside trade split as French vote rattles nerves
summary: International Monetary Fund members dropped their pledge to fight protectionism amid a split over trade policy, shifting focus to the first round of France's presidential election. The decision, made at the IMF's spring meetings, comes as concerns grow over US trade policy and the potential impact of a far-right or far-left leader on global economic integration. IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde warned that a policy shift towards "sharing and inclusive growth" is needed to address geopolitical risks.

site_title: Football: Hull, Swansea win to lift survival hopes, Middlesbrough sink deeper
summary: Hull City and Swansea City secured crucial 2-0 victories, lifting their Premier League survival hopes, while Middlesbrough suffered a 4-0 defeat at Bournemouth, sinking deeper into relegation danger. Hull's wins over Watford and Swansea, and Swansea's win over Stoke City, increased pressure on Crystal Palace and Burnley. Hull now sit just above the drop zone with 33 points, while Middlesbrough are in 19th spot with 24 points.

site_title: Boy's legs amputated after alleged abuse from religious school assistant warden in Malaysia
summary: An 11-year-old boy in Malaysia had both legs amputated after allegedly being beaten with a water hose by a private religious school assistant warden. The boy, Mohamad Thaqif Amin Mohd Gadaffi, was taken to the hospital after his mother discovered his condition and reported it to the authorities. The boy's mother claims the abuse occurred in March, and he was admitted to the hospital on April 19 with fever and blood clots in his legs. The police are investigating the matter, with the hospital to conduct further investigation into the boy's condition.

site_title: NBA: Griffin out for playoffs with big toe injury
summary: Los Angeles Clippers star forward Blake Griffin will miss the remainder of the NBA playoffs due to a right big toe injury sustained in the first half of Game 3 against the Utah Jazz. Griffin, a five-time NBA All-Star, injured the plantar plate on the bottom of his toe while landing awkwardly. He will be re-evaluated by a specialist when the team returns to Los Angeles. The Clippers will proceed to Game 4 without Griffin, who averaged 25 points and six rebounds in the first two games of the series.

site_title: French presidential poll a bellwether for Europe
summary: France held its first round of presidential election on April 23, 2017, with nearly 47 million voters participating, a 28.54% turnout. Centrist Emmanuel Macron is the frontrunner to win the first round, followed by far-right Marine Le Pen and far-left Jean-Luc Melenchon. The outcome is seen as a bellwether for Europe, with potential implications for the global economy. Macron's victory would mark a shift away from the traditional left-right divide, while Le Pen's or Melenchon's win would pose significant challenges for investors and France's EU partners.

site_title: Lunch With Sumiko: The world is conductor Wong Kah Chun's stage
summary: Conductor Wong Kah Chun, 30, has become a global sensation after winning the prestigious Gustav Mahler Conducting Competition. He is now booked until 2020 and has been appointed as the chief conductor of Germany's Nuremberg Symphony Orchestra, the first Asian to hold this role. Wong, who comes from a modest background, learned to play the cornet in primary school and later pursued a career in Western classical music, despite having no formal music lessons until his late teens. He has led orchestras in over 20 cities and has a scholarship to study in Berlin and Cambridge. Wong is now focusing on giving back to his community through his work with the Singapore National Youth Orchestra and his co-founded Project Infinitude, a global music education initiative.

images.alt_text: Seng Hong coffee shop in Bukit Merah, now known as Hollywood Bistro, is a pit stop for conductor Wong Kah Chun. His arts project with children, Project Infinitude, is based at the nearby Enabling Village.

site_title: Football: Pochettino proud as Tottenham fall short again
summary: Tottenham Hotspur suffered a 4-2 loss to Chelsea at Wembley, despite outplaying them for long periods. The defeat marked Tottenham's seventh successive FA Cup semi-final loss and left fans feeling disappointed. However, manager Mauricio Pochettino expressed pride in the team's performance, stating that they are becoming a top-level team. With six games remaining in the season, Tottenham remain in contention for the Premier League title, four points behind Chelsea. Pochettino rejected the notion that Spurs are "nearly men," emphasizing the need to build the present to achieve a better future.

site_title: Football: Hazard fires Chelsea into FA Cup final as Conte gamble pays off
summary: Chelsea advanced to the FA Cup final with a 4-2 win over Tottenham, thanks to Eden Hazard's decisive strike in the 75th minute. Chelsea boss Antonio Conte's bold decision to start with Willian and Michy Batshuayi instead of Hazard and Diego Costa paid off, with Hazard's goal sealing the win. The victory boosts Conte's team ahead of their Premier League match against Southampton, while Tottenham's loss leaves them without an FA Cup final appearance since 1991.

site_title: Donald Trump visits wounded US service members at military hospital
summary: US President Donald Trump visited wounded US service members at Walter Reed National Military Medical Centre in Bethesda, Maryland, on April 22. Trump awarded Army Sergeant First Class Alvaro Barrientos the Purple Heart for his injuries sustained in an Afghan base attack on March 17, resulting in the amputation of his right leg. This was Trump's first visit to the hospital, following a tradition set by former President Barack Obama. The visit came amidst criticism of Trump's frequent trips to his Florida resort, Mar-A-Lago.

site_title: Fascist salutes as Franco minister is buried
summary: Former Spanish dictator Francisco Franco's minister Jose Utrera Molina, who died at 91, was buried with a fascist salute at his funeral in Nerja, Spain. Mourners, including Molina's son-in-law, sang the "Cara al sol" anthem of the Spanish Phalanx party and wore the party's blue shirt. Molina served under Franco from 1939-1975, never wavering in his loyalty. Spain has passed an amnesty law, making it difficult to prosecute Franco-era officials for human rights abuses.

site_title: Football: West Ham and Everton in poor goalless draw
summary: West Ham United and Everton drew 0-0 in a Premier League match at the London Stadium on April 22. The game was marked by few scoring opportunities, with the first shot on goal coming 28 minutes in. Everton goalkeeper Maarten Stekelenburg made key saves to deny Havard Nordtveit and Manuel Lanzini. The tempo improved after a double change by visiting manager Ronald Koeman, but neither team created significant chances. The 0-0 draw marked a poor performance from both teams, with few nervous moments throughout the match.

site_title: Japan's Taro Aso pushes back on US call for scrutiny of currency moves
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso pushed back against US calls for IMF scrutiny of currency moves, stating that exchange-rate adjustments alone cannot fix trade imbalances. Aso argued that Japan's recent current account surplus is driven by dividend payments and repatriation of overseas investments, not exports boosted by a weak yen. The US Treasury Secretary, Steven Mnuchin, had called for enhanced IMF surveillance of exchange rates and external imbalances to promote "free and fair" trade. Aso suggested that macroeconomic and structural policy measures should address imbalances, rather than relying solely on exchange-rate adjustments.

site_title: Tennis: Nadal reaches Monte Carlo final after controversial umpire call
summary: Rafael Nadal advanced to the Monte Carlo Masters final with a 6-3 6-1 win over David Goffin in the semi-finals. A disputed point call by chair umpire Cedric Mourier, who ruled a Nadal shot in despite the Hawkeye system showing the ball was long, contributed to Goffin's loss. Nadal will face fellow Spaniard Albert Ramos in the final on Sunday, after Ramos beat Lucas Pouille 6-3 5-7 6-1 in the other semi-final.

site_title: Football: Hazard salutes Conte after Chelsea star seals Wembley thriller
summary: Chelsea's Eden Hazard hailed manager Antonio Conte's tactical decision as he scored a winning goal in a 4-2 FA Cup semi-final victory over Tottenham. Hazard came off the bench after being left out, with Willian scoring twice before him. Hazard's strike put Chelsea ahead, while Nemanja Matic's long-range goal sealed a spot in the FA Cup final for the first time since 2012. Hazard praised Conte's decision, saying it was a "great choice" that helped secure a thrilling win. The victory boosts Chelsea's confidence ahead of their next Premier League match on Tuesday.

site_title: Macron v Le Pen
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen, leader of the National Front, are set to face off in the second round of the presidential election on May 7, after Macron led Le Pen by just 977,833 votes in the first round on April 23. Macron, a centrist liberal pro-EU candidate, and Le Pen, a protectionist and nativist anti-EU candidate, will compete for the next five-year term. Polls and prediction markets suggest Macron has a higher chance of winning, but the election is considered highly unpredictable.

site_title: Venezuelans stage 'silent protest' in wave of unrest
summary: Venezuelans staged a silent protest in Caracas on April 22, demanding the ouster of President Nicolas Maduro amid three weeks of unrest that left 20 people dead. The protest, which was largely peaceful, tested the authorities' tolerance for demonstrations and came after a brief scuffle with police. The opposition accuses Maduro's government of repressing protests and sending armed thugs to attack them, while the government blames the opposition for sponsoring a "spiral of terrorism." The protests come as pressure on Maduro mounts, with seven in 10 Venezuelans disapproving of him according to a poll.

site_title: Football: Griezmann strike enough for Atletico to beat Espanyol
summary: Atletico Madrid secured a 1-0 win over Espanyol on April 22, thanks to Antoine Griezmann's late goal. Griezmann scored with a left-footed volley in the 73rd minute, extending Atletico's unbeaten record to 12 games. The win tightens Atletico's grip on third place in La Liga, with Diego Simeone's side now three points ahead of Sevilla. Espanyol remain ninth, while Sporting Gijon lost ground in their relegation bid with a 2-2 draw against Osasuna.

site_title: Football: Ibrahimovic suffers 'significant knee ligament damage'
summary: Manchester United striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic suffered significant knee ligament damage in a Europa League match against Anderlecht on April 20, 2017. The injury, along with that of defender Marco Rojo, will require specialist opinions and treatment plans. Ibrahimovic's season, which included 28 goals and a League Cup victory, appears to be over, while Rojo's injury is a blow to United's depleted defense. The club's depleted resources may be exacerbated by the expected mid-May returns of injured central defenders Phil Jones and Chris Smalling.

site_title: Football: Llorente outjumps Stoke to keep Swansea survival bid alive
summary: Swansea City secured a 2-0 win over Stoke City, keeping their Premier League survival bid alive. Fernando Llorente scored the opening goal in the 10th minute with a trademark header, and Tom Carroll doubled the lead in the 51st minute. Despite a penalty miss by Marko Arnautovic, Swansea's victory maintained their two-point gap to fourth-bottom Hull City. The win keeps Swansea in contention for Premier League survival, with a crucial match against Hull City remaining.

site_title: Football: Barca ready for 'must win' Clasico with or without Neymar
summary: Barcelona coach Luis Enrique is preparing for Sunday's "must-win" Clasico against Real Madrid with or without suspended player Neymar. Neymar's three-match suspension was upheld by the Spanish football federation and the Catalan club took his case to the Spain's Court for Sport, but a ruling was delayed due to a court member's absence. Despite a warning from TAD, Barcelona is considering fielding Neymar, who was sent off for two yellow cards earlier this month. A win is crucial for Barcelona's season, as they trail Real Madrid by three points in La Liga.

site_title: Tennis: Sharapova draws Vinci with critic Radwanska waiting
summary: Russian tennis player Maria Sharapova will face Italian Roberta Vinci in her opening match at the Stuttgart tournament, her first event after a 15-month doping ban. Sharapova, a five-time Grand Slam champion, was handed a wildcard entry due to her ranking loss. She could face Poland's Agnieszka Radwanska, one of her critics, in the second round, who expressed opposition to Sharapova's wild card entry. Sharapova's return to competition coincides with the tournament's 40th anniversary celebrations, which are expected to boost ticket sales.

site_title: Tennis: Wrist injury rules Nishikori out of Barcelona
summary: Japan's Kei Nishikori withdrew from the Barcelona Open due to a wrist injury, citing it's not recovered enough to play. This move boosts Rafael Nadal's chances of claiming a 10th title in Barcelona. Top seed Andy Murray also announced his participation, set to face Bernard Tomic or Dustin Brown in the second round. Nishikori plans to return to the tour as quickly as possible, flying back to Florida with his team to work on recovery.

site_title: Thousands join March for Science to fight 'alternative facts'
summary: Thousands of people gathered in Washington, DC for the March for Science, protesting against President Donald Trump's proposed cuts to science and research budgets. The rally, part of a global movement, aimed to fight "alternative facts" and promote the importance of science in daily life. Despite rainy weather, the event featured music, speeches, and teach-ins by scientists, with chants and signs calling for action to curb fossil fuel emissions and protect the environment. The non-partisan protest was echoed in hundreds of satellite events across the US and around the world.

site_title: Football: 10-man Hull defy odds to boost survival bid
summary: Hull City secured a crucial 2-0 win over Watford with 10 men, boosting their bid for Premier League survival. Senegal international Oumar Niasse was sent off for a tackle in the 25th minute, but Hull responded with goals from Lazar Markovic and Sam Clucas in the 62nd and 70th minutes. The win keeps Hull two points above the relegation zone with four games left, as they aim to avoid crashing into the Championship. Hull's impressive home form, earning 19 points out of 21 since Marco Silva's appointment, may be enough to secure their survival.

site_title: Canary Islands battles two-mile oil slick after ferry crash
summary: A ferry crashed into underwater fuel pipes in Las Palmas, Canary Islands, Spain, on April 21, causing a 3-kilometre oil slick. Emergency teams responded to the incident, and the regional government activated emergency plans to control and clean up the spill. The 140 passengers were unhurt, apart from minor injuries. The ferry suffered a technical fault that caused a power cut, leading to the accident.

site_title: Tennis: Abusive Nastase banned as Fed Cup boils over
summary: Romanian tennis legend Ilie Nastase was expelled from the Fed Cup after making a series of derogatory remarks, including a racial slur about Serena Williams' unborn baby and calling female players "f***ing bitches". The International Tennis Federation (ITF) launched an investigation and removed his accreditation, stating they do not tolerate discriminatory language and behavior. The incident overshadowed the Fed Cup semi-finals, with Britain and Romania playing in Constanta, while other ties took place in Minsk and Tampa.

site_title: Tennis: Ramos beats Pouille to reach Monte Carlo final
summary: Spanish tennis player Albert Ramos Vinolas reached the Monte Carlo final after defeating local favorite Lucas Pouille 6-3 5-7 6-1. Ramos, the 15th-seeded claycourt specialist, beat Pouille despite struggling with back pains in the third set. Ramos will face either Rafa Nadal or David Goffin in the final on Sunday. The win marks Ramos' first Masters final and follows victories over world number one Andy Murray and fifth seed Marin Cilic in the semi-finals.

site_title: Football: Bournemouth push 10-man Middlesbrough to brink of relegation
summary: Bournemouth secured a 4-0 win over 10-man Middlesbrough, boosting their Premier League survival chances. The Cherries scored two goals in the opening 20 minutes, with Gaston Ramirez sent off for a second booking and then a lunging tackle. Joshua King and Benik Afobe added two more goals, with Charlie Daniels scoring the fourth. The win marked Bournemouth's first in four league games and pushed Middlesbrough towards relegation, who have not won in 16 league games.

site_title: British PM Theresa May refuses to rule out personal tax hikes after election
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May refused to rule out personal tax hikes if her Conservative Party wins the June election, sparking controversy among supporters. May made the statement at a campaign event, contrasting her party's stance on lower taxes with the Labour Party's plan to raise taxes. The move has been criticized by opposition parties and some of May's own lawmakers, who argue it could hit ordinary workers. May's election gamble aims to strengthen her hand ahead of Brexit talks and increase her majority in parliament.

site_title: Football: Lacklustre Bayern dig deep to rescue 2-2 draw against Mainz
summary: Bayern Munich drew 2-2 against Mainz 05, staying nine points clear at the top of the Bundesliga with four matches remaining. The Bavarians struggled in the first half, but came from behind twice, with Arjen Robben and Thiago Alcantara scoring equalizers. Bayern coach Carlo Ancelotti expressed disappointment, citing a lack of spark and organization. The draw marked Bayern's third consecutive match without a victory in all competitions, with Borussia Dortmund taking over third place after a 3-2 win against Borussia Moenchengladbach.

site_title: Irish citizens' assembly recommends change to abortion laws
summary: Ireland's citizens' assembly has recommended changing the country's restrictive abortion laws. A panel of 99 randomly selected citizens voted 6-1 to amend the 8th amendment of the constitution, which enshrines equal rights for both mother and unborn child. The assembly's report is due by June, and the government plans to set up a parliamentary committee to respond, potentially paving the way for a 2018 referendum. Thousands of Irish women travel abroad for abortions, and opinion polls show a large majority of voters support some change to the law.

site_title: Paris station panic as man arrested with knife
summary: Armed police arrested a 20-year-old Malian man carrying a knife at Paris' Gare du Nord station on April 22, sparking panic among travelers. The incident occurred just days after a policeman was killed in a militant attack. The man, with no police record, claimed he had been attacked outside the station and took the knife before entering. No one was injured, and the station was briefly closed before reopening. The incident heightened concerns in France ahead of presidential elections, where Islamic militants are feared to target the vote. France remains under a state of emergency.

site_title: Rugby: Highlanders trounce Sunwolves 40-15 in Invercargill to continue rebound
summary: The Otago Highlanders secured a 40-15 bonus-point victory over the Sunwolves in Super Rugby, marking their fourth consecutive win. Centre Matt Faddes scored a brace of tries, while Malakai Fekitoa, Liam Squire, Aaron Smith, and Ben Smith also crossed the line. The Highlanders dominated the game, with the Sunwolves scoring late consolation tries. Despite a strong performance, Highlanders captain Ben Smith expressed concerns about their form ahead of their next match against the Stormers, citing areas for improvement.

site_title: Death at 91 of one of former Spanish dictator's last ministers
summary: Jose Utrera Molina, a former Spanish minister under dictator Francisco Franco, died at 91, his son announced. Molina served as housing minister, deputy head of the Nationalist Movement, and deputy head of government during the last two years of Franco's dictatorship. Despite being a signatory to the death warrant of a young anarchist, Molina was not extradited due to Spain's 1977 amnesty law. His death comes amid ongoing efforts to remove street names honouring Franco-era figures, with his own son expressing gratitude from his family.

site_title: FAS saga: Neither Team LKT nor Game Changers believe police probe will affect their chances at April 29 election
summary: Singapore's Football Association (FAS) election is set for April 29, despite a police probe into alleged misuse of funds at Tiong Bahru FC. Team LKT, led by Lim Kia Tong, and Game Changers, led by Krishna Ramachandra, claim the investigation will not impact their chances. Both teams emphasize their commitment to integrity and creating change in football governance. The police probe has resulted in raids on several clubs and the FAS offices, with several individuals questioned, including former FAS president Zainudin Nordin and current general secretary Winston Lee.

site_title: FAS saga: Former football chief Zainudin Nordin says Bill Ng was not his business partner
summary: Former Football Association of Singapore (FAS) president Zainudin Nordin has denied having business ties with Tiong Bahru FC chairman Bill Ng. Nordin told the Today newspaper that they are not business partners and have no business dealings. This comes after police raids on Tiong Bahru and FAS clubhouses, amid allegations of fund misuse. The FAS is set to hold its inaugural election on April 29, with Ng leading the "Game Changers" slate against Lim Kia Tong's team. Nordin is cooperating with authorities in their investigations.

site_title: Puppy's tail apparently 'chopped off' in suspected abuse case: AVA investigating
summary: A puppy was found with its tail allegedly cut off in Singapore, sparking a suspected abuse case. The puppy, found along Pasir Ris Farmway on April 21, has been taken to a vet and will be rehomed. Dog trainer Sam Chan posted photos and a video on Facebook, describing the incident as "abuse" due to the clean cut. The Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority (AVA) is investigating the case, while a dog rescue group, Voices for Animals, has raised concerns about the possibility of abuse or animal cruelty.

site_title: Table tennis: Feng Tianwei to play Ishikawa in S. Korea, her first final after national team cut
summary: Feng Tianwei, the world No. 3 table tennis player, has advanced to the final of the ITTF World Tour's Korea Open in Incheon, South Korea. She defeated Chen Szu-yu 4-3 in a closely contested match. Feng will face world No. 4 Kasumi Ishikawa in the final on Sunday. This is Feng's first final appearance since being dropped from the Singapore national team in October 2016.

site_title: Football: Clasico will not decide title race, says Real Madrid boss Zinedine Zidane
summary: Real Madrid coach Zinedine Zidane has downplayed the significance of Sunday's Clasico match against Barcelona, saying it won't decide the Spanish title race. With Real Madrid leading La Liga by three points, Zidane is focusing on each game individually, emphasizing that all remaining matches are crucial. He also confirmed Gareth Bale's inclusion in the squad, but did not confirm his starting status. Zidane praised Cristiano Ronaldo, saying his energy is positive and amazing, but Real Madrid will be the main act in the highly anticipated match.

site_title: Over 100 soldiers killed, wounded in Taleban attack on Afghan military base
summary: Over 100 Afghan soldiers were killed and wounded in a coordinated Taleban attack on an army base in northern Afghanistan, according to the country's defense ministry. The assault, which targeted soldiers at a mosque and dining facility, occurred on April 21 near Mazar-i-Sharif city. The attack, claimed by the Taleban, has raised concerns about rising insecurity in the war-torn country as it prepares for an intense fighting season. The incident is the latest in a series of deadly assaults against Afghan military sites, highlighting the need for additional support from international forces.

site_title: Football: The Sun apologises to Ross Barkley over column
summary: The Sun newspaper has apologized to Everton midfielder Ross Barkley for a column that made unfavourable comparisons to a gorilla, sparking outrage in Liverpool. The column, written by Kelvin MacKenzie, was published on April 14, 2017, and made "unfavourable comparisons" to a gorilla, with MacKenzie claiming the only other people in Liverpool with Barkley's income were drug dealers. The Sun has apologized and suspended MacKenzie, who claimed he was unaware of Barkley's Nigerian heritage. The incident has led to further bans on The Sun in Liverpool, including from Liverpool FC and several shops.

site_title: Thousands join March for Science rallies over 'alternative facts'
summary: Thousands of people in Europe, Australasia, and over 600 cities worldwide participated in the March for Science rallies on Earth Day, April 22, 2017, to celebrate the scientific method and protest "alternative facts" and rising populism. The rallies were sparked by concerns over government attacks on science, including proposed cuts to research budgets and climate change denial. Demonstrators called for politicians to support the scientific community and emphasized the importance of facts-based evidence in addressing global challenges.

site_title: German intelligence spied on Interpol: German magazine
summary: Germany's BND foreign intelligence agency allegedly spied on Interpol and Europol for years, monitoring their email addresses, phone numbers, and fax numbers in dozens of countries. The agency added Interpol's contact information to its sector surveillance list and also monitored Europol, a police agency based in The Hague. This comes as the BND faces scrutiny over its activities, including spying on news organizations and Chancellor Angela Merkel's phone. A parliamentary investigation has criticized the agency's lack of oversight, calling it "scandalous and unfathomable" and a "danger to our rule of law".

site_title: Malaysia's controversial bomoh released on bail after police questioning
summary: Malaysian self-styled bomoh Raja Bomoh Ibrahim Mat Zin was released on bail after police questioning for allegedly uttering words that wound the religious feelings of others. He was arrested at a hotel in Johor and questioned over his claims of protecting the country from North Korea, which were deemed against Islamic tenets. The bomoh, known for his unconventional methods, has been summoned by police and the Malaysian Islamic Development Department, sparking criticism and mockery. He claims to have protected the country in the past, but his actions have brought shame to the nation.

site_title: US defence secretary visits key ally Qatar
summary: US Defense Secretary James Mattis visited Qatar on April 22, 2017, as part of a regional tour. During the visit, Mattis met with Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al-Thani to reinforce relationships and discuss key issues such as the fight against the Islamic State, the conflict in Syria, and Iran's regional role. The talks aimed to strengthen cooperation and counter Iran's influence in the region. Mattis also expressed concerns over Syria's alleged retention of chemical weapons and warned President Bashar al-Assad's regime not to use them.

site_title: French expatriates vote ahead of knife-edge election
summary: French expatriates in the US, Canada, and Latin America cast their ballots on April 22, 2017, ahead of France's presidential election. Over 119,000 French voters are registered in the US, with many hoping to prevent a right-wing candidate like Marine Le Pen from winning. The overseas voting is seen as crucial, as France faces a deeply divided country and the European Union. The election has tightened in the final days, with any of the four candidates potentially reaching the runoff vote on May 7, with Emmanuel Macron and Le Pen leading the polls.

site_title: Another Abu Sayyaf leader killed in fresh clashes in Philippine resort province Bohol
summary: Philippine troops killed a senior Abu Sayyaf leader, Joselito Melloria, 33, in a clash in Bohol province on April 22. Melloria, described as the group's pointman, was involved in a previous firefight on April 11 that killed Abu Sayyaf spokesman Muamar Askali and four other extremists. Melloria was being groomed to lead another militant group, Ansar al-Khilafah Philippines. The latest violence comes as ASEAN wraps up a meeting in Bohol, with assurances that the terror threat in the region has been contained.

site_title: NBA: Thunder, Celtics earn crucial wins to trail 1-2 in play-off series, Clippers stun Jazz to take lead
summary: The Oklahoma City Thunder and Boston Celtics each secured crucial wins in their NBA playoff series, narrowing the deficit to 2-1. The Thunder edged the Houston Rockets 115-113, thanks to Russell Westbrook's triple-double, while the Celtics defeated the Chicago Bulls 104-87, with five players scoring in double figures. Meanwhile, the Los Angeles Clippers stunned the Utah Jazz 111-106, taking a 2-1 lead in their series, despite losing Blake Griffin to a toe injury.

site_title: Four-legged fugitive in Vegas police chase
summary: A four-legged fugitive, identified as a Patagonian Mara native to South America, was caught in Las Vegas after leading police on a wild chase. The animal, which was dumped in the street with no care, was initially mistaken for a baby kangaroo or rabbit. Authorities were aided by nets and eventually took the animal into custody. The original owner remains at large, and the Humane Society has expressed concern over the disturbing trend of abandoning exotic animals. The Mara is now at a county shelter.

site_title: Cycling: Veteran Italian Scarponi, the 2011 Giro champion, killed in road accident while training
summary: Italian cyclist Michele Scarponi, the 2011 Giro d'Italia champion, has been killed in a road accident while training near his home in Filottrano, Italy. The 37-year-old was hit by a van at a crossroads on Saturday morning. Scarponi finished the Tour of Alps on Friday and was on a training ride when the accident occurred. The veteran cyclist is survived by his wife and two children, with his team paying tribute to him on social media, calling him a "great champion" and a "special guy".

site_title: I'm not dating Taylor Swift, says Sohu founder Charles Zhang
summary: Sohu founder Charles Zhang, 52, has denied speculation that he is dating Taylor Swift, saying he doesn't know who she is. Zhang made the comments on Sohu's live-streaming platform Qianfan after netizens speculated that a middle-aged Chinese tech tycoon was Swift's new love interest. Zhang stated, "It's a rumour! No taste for foreign women!" The speculation comes after Swift was named the world's highest-paid celebrity in 2016. Other tech tycoons, including Lei Jun, were also ruled out due to their English skills.

site_title: Thousands of customers first in Singapore to get new S8 phones
summary: Thousands of customers in Singapore collected their new Samsung Galaxy S8 and S8+ phones on April 22, a week ahead of the official launch on April 29. Despite concerns following the 2016 Note7 recall, the reception for the S8 was strong, with over 260,000 phones sold in South Korea on launch day. In Singapore, over 260,000 pre-orders were received, exceeding the number of pre-orders for last year's S7 and S7 Edge models. The phones retail at $1,148 and $1,298, respectively.

site_title: Peaceful resolution of North Korea's nuclear threat still possible: Mike Pence
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence stated that peaceful resolution of North Korea's nuclear threat is still possible due to warming ties between Beijing and Washington. Pence cited China's efforts to rein in North Korea as a positive development, saying a nuclear-free Korean peninsula is achievable through peaceful means. Despite growing fears of a new nuclear test, Pence emphasized the US's commitment to preventing North Korea from hitting the US with a nuclear missile, while China continues to pressure its ally and neighbor.

site_title: New public housing projects and mini-dragons in Toa Payoh facelift
summary: Singapore's oldest HDB estate, Toa Payoh, will undergo a major facelift under the Housing Board's Remaking Our Heartland programme. Two new public housing areas will be built, along with quirky street furniture and new parks, aiming to preserve the town's charm and heritage. The estate, which has around 37,000 flats, will also become more senior-friendly with designated Silver Zones and heritage markers. The makeover is expected to be completed within the next 5-10 years, with a focus on community interaction and modernization.

site_title: 70-year-old man who shouted at and slapped foreigner on train arrested
summary: A 70-year-old man was arrested in Singapore for allegedly shouting at and slapping a foreigner, Joe DeMarini, on a train. DeMarini, from Pennsylvania, reported the incident, which was captured on video and shared on Facebook, garnering over 1.2 million views. The suspect was identified and arrested on April 21, charged with causing public nuisance and voluntarily causing hurt. He faces fines and possible jail time if convicted. DeMarini received an outpouring of support from Singaporeans, with many apologizing for the incident and welcoming him to the country.

site_title: Donald Trump warming to EU trade deal with Britain behind in queue: Times
summary: US President Donald Trump has warmed to a free-trade agreement with the European Union, potentially pushing post-Brexit Britain behind in the queue. Germany's Angela Merkel persuaded Trump that talks on a deal would be simpler than he thought, according to the Times. Britain will not be free to agree new trade deals until it leaves the EU in 2019, and a US-EU deal could come as a blow to Prime Minister Theresa May's efforts to secure deeper trade ties. A deal could be reached by financial leaders in July, but details remain uncertain.

site_title: American Airlines employee suspended after row with passengers over stroller
summary: An American Airlines employee has been suspended after a video showed him violently taking a stroller from a woman carrying a young child on a flight from San Francisco to Dallas. The incident occurred over a dispute about bringing a stroller on the flight, and the employee hit the woman with the stroller before missing her child. The airline apologized and offered the woman and her family an upgrade to first class for the remainder of their international trip. The employee is under investigation.

site_title: Protesters in Vietnam free final hostages in land dispute
summary: Protesters in Vietnam's Dong Tam village released the final 20 officials held hostage in a land dispute after a visit by Hanoi's People's Committee Chairman Nguyen Duc Chung. The officials, including police officers, were seized last weekend in retaliation for protests over insufficient compensation for a telecommunications project. Chung promised a comprehensive investigation and no prosecution for the protesters, who were treated well during their detention. The release came after 15 officials were released on Monday and three escaped. The villagers claimed they received insufficient compensation and are seeking justice.

site_title: Windsor Nature Park opens: 5 things to do in Singapore's parks and reserves
summary: Windsor Nature Park, Singapore's fourth buffer park, was opened on April 22, 2017, with three new trails and a 150m-long sub-canopy walkway. The 75-hectare park offers various activities, including birdwatching, wildlife appreciation, cycling along park connectors, and free nature tours. Visitors can explore the park's fauna, flora, and wildlife, including rare species like the Sunda pangolin and Nordmann's Greenshank. The park is part of the Central Catchment Nature Reserve, the largest nature reserve in Singapore, and is accessible via the Park Connector Network.

site_title: China's first cargo spacecraft Tianzhou-1 docks with orbiting Tiangong-2 space lab
summary: China's first cargo spacecraft, Tianzhou-1, successfully docked with the Tiangong-2 space lab on April 22, 2017, marking a major step towards establishing a permanently manned space station by 2022. The automated docking process was accomplished after the spacecraft took off from the Wenchang Satellite Launch Centre. The mission provides a technological basis for building a Chinese space station, capable of carrying six tonnes of goods and fuel. The docking is seen as a significant advancement in China's space programme, which aims to strengthen national security and surpass the US and Russia in space capabilities.

site_title: New internship and training programmes for jobs in sustainability sector
summary: Singapore is launching two new internship and training programmes to boost job opportunities in the sustainability sector. The Sustainability Internship Programme, targeting students, and the Sustainability Professional Programme, geared towards professionals, will provide skills and experience in corporate sustainability. The programmes, launched by the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) and the Global Compact Network Singapore, aim to increase demand for sustainability professionals amid growing global push for sustainable business practices. The initiatives are expected to start in the second half of 2017.

site_title: FAS saga: We will cooperate fully with the authorities, says FAS general secretary Winston Lee
summary: FAS general secretary Winston Lee has pledged to cooperate fully with authorities investigating the misuse of funds at Tiong Bahru Football Club (TBFC). Lee made his first public comments on the matter during the unveiling of the National Football League logo. The investigation was sparked by a police report from Sport Singapore, which alleged misuse of funds and obstruction of audits. Lee's comments come ahead of the FAS election on April 29, with the investigation expected to impact the outcome. Lee stated that the FAS will cooperate fully with the authorities.

site_title: Sex prank gets Canadian man off New Zealand mailing list
summary: A Canadian man, Ian Campbell, was mistakenly added to the email list of a New Zealand golf club due to a similar email address to a member. Campbell, who runs a home meal service, sent a fake invitation to a swingers' party to a golf club group, hoping to get removed from the list. The prank was successful, and Campbell believes he has been removed after sending a third email apologizing and asking to be removed.

site_title: Mental illnesses in Hong Kong's young rose by over 50% in 5 years: Government report
summary: Mental illnesses among Hong Kong's young people have risen by over 50% in the past 5 years, according to a government report. The caseload of child and adolescent psychiatric teams increased from 18,900 in 2011-12 to 28,800 in 2015-16, with Autism Spectrum Disorders and ADHD being the most prevalent disorders. The report highlights the need for community efforts to flag, treat, and limit mental illnesses, and recommends a three-tier model for mental services delivery. The hospital authority's mental health budget has increased by 38% in the same period.

site_title: Paris gunman was small-time criminal apparently inspired by ISIS
summary: A 39-year-old Frenchman, Karim Cheurfi, inspired by ISIS, carried out a deadly attack on police officers in Paris, killing one and injuring two others. Cheurfi, with a criminal record, had been convicted of multiple crimes and had been monitored by authorities for his extremist views. He was shot dead as he tried to escape, with ISIS claiming responsibility. The attack occurred on the eve of France's pivotal presidential election, with far-right candidate Marine Le Pen using the event to reinforce her anti-immigrant message.

site_title: Windsor Nature Park opens, new park near Rifle Range Road announced
summary: The National Parks Board (NParks) opened the 75-hectare Windsor Nature Park in Singapore, featuring three new trails and a 150m long walkway four meters above the ground. The park was enhanced over two years with repairs and new additions, including a marsh habitat and over 500 trees. Senior Minister Desmond Lee also announced plans for Rifle Range Nature Park, a 67-hectare buffer park to the Bukit Timah Nature Reserve, set to open in 2020, with a focus on conserving natural heritage.

site_title: Malaysian police probe school gangsterism after videos of rowdy youths go viral
summary: Malaysian police have arrested 13 schoolboys and five others for gangsterism after videos of rowdy youths went viral. The arrests follow a commotion outside a school in Klang, where motorcyclists were seen creating a ruckus, shouting, and holding up banners. Authorities have set up a task force to investigate gangland activities in schools, which have been a recurring issue in Malaysia. The motive behind the commotion is still being probed, but the arrests are seen as a step towards combating gangsterism in schools.

site_title: Wanted: 10,000 volunteers to help the elderly in Central Singapore
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong launched The Silver Alliance, a recruitment drive to raise 10,000 volunteers to help elderly residents in Central Singapore, particularly those with mobility issues. The program, run by the Central Singapore Community Development Council, aims to match volunteers from companies and schools with seniors who need assistance. The initiative is crucial as one in seven Singaporeans is aged 65 and above, and it's essential for seniors to stay connected to the community and feel valued citizens.

site_title: Donald Trump promises big announcement on tax reform on April 26
summary: US President Donald Trump promised a big announcement on tax reform on April 26, ordering an administration review of Obama-era tax rules to cut taxes and Dodd-Frank regulations. The review aims to discourage US companies from relocating overseas. Trump's plan, initially proposed in 2016, proposes deep cuts in tax rates, a reduction in tax brackets, and repeal of the estate tax. The review is expected to include rules against tax-driven foreign corporate deals known as inversions, a key goal of Trump's tax reform efforts.

site_title: Malaysia teacher throws chair, nearly breaks boy's head
summary: A Malaysian teacher lost his temper and threw a chair at a boy in his class after the boy refused to stop creating a nuisance. The chair hit another boy, causing a deep cut that required eight stitches. The boy's mother was notified and a police report was lodged. After discussions with education officials, the mother decided not to pursue legal action but hopes the teacher will face disciplinary action. The teacher has been instructed to stop teaching until the matter is resolved.

site_title: Let's be dementia-friendly in our words
summary: A Singaporean writer, Pang Huey Ling, emphasizes the importance of using dementia-friendly language to promote understanding and inclusion of people living with dementia. She argues that casual misuse of words can stigmatize and infantilize individuals, perpetuating negative stereotypes. Ling advocates for using respectful and empowering language that acknowledges the person's needs, desires, and capabilities beyond the disease. By adopting this approach, she believes people living with dementia can remain positively engaged and maintain their self-worth.

site_title: DPM Tharman appointed chairman of top G20 group tasked to review global financial governance
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam has been appointed chairman of an Eminent Persons Group on global financial governance, tasked with reviewing issues related to global financial governance. The group, formed at the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting in Washington, aims to review the work of international finance institutions, including the IMF and multilateral development banks. The group's planned work will be presented at the next G20 meeting in October, with confirmed members including prominent economists and leaders from around the world.

site_title: Embrace the inconvenience of tight security
summary: Singapore's recent MRT station closures sparked debate on the balance between security and convenience. The government's swift response to security threats, although inconvenient, is crucial in protecting citizens from real terror threats. Terror attacks in Singapore, including a foiled plan to target Marina Bay, demonstrate the need for a robust security system. Embracing security measures, despite slight disruptions, is essential for a society to be prepared and resilient against threats, ultimately prioritizing the greater convenience of safe living and working.

site_title: Tributes and discord one year after Prince death
summary: One year after Prince's death, tributes poured in as fans celebrated the pop legend's life with concerts and panel talks at his Paisley Park estate. However, the anniversary was marred by controversy over the commercialization of his legacy, with a temporary halt on a new Prince EP and a dispute between his estate and a sound engineer over the release of unreleased music. Despite this, Prince's music continues to top charts, with over 2.23 million albums sold in the US last year.

site_title: French police officer killed on Champ Elysees was proud defender of gay rights
summary: French police officer Xavier Jugelé, 37, was killed in a terrorist attack on the Champs-Élysées in Paris on April 20, 2017. Jugelé, a proud defender of gay rights, was a committed policeman who responded to a 2015 terrorist attack at the Bataclan concert hall. He was shot dead while in a police vehicle, along with two other officers and a bystander, and was later claimed by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) group. An official tribute will be paid to Jugelé in the coming days, with flags at police stations flown at half-staff in his honor.

site_title: SMRT in talks to sell taxi business to Grab
summary: SMRT, Singapore's third-largest taxi operator, is in talks to sell its taxi business to Grab, a Malaysian private-hire operator. The proposed deal would see SMRT exiting the business after 27 years, but may be hindered by Grab's reluctance to take on more staff, affecting SMRT Taxis workers. The sale could also signal SMRT's disposal of other low-margin businesses, such as buses, as the company reviews its focus on the rail business under Temasek Holdings' ownership.

site_title: United Airlines chief executive Oscar Munoz will not chair board in 2018 following passenger removal
summary: United Airlines CEO Oscar Munoz will not chair the board in 2018, following an uproar over the removal of a passenger, Dr. David Dao, from a flight. An amendment to his employment agreement was approved, allowing the board to make future chairman decisions. The company also revised its 2017 executive compensation to tie incentives to customer satisfaction improvements. United is developing targeted compensation programs to address recent events and improve customer experience, following a global backlash to the incident.

site_title: France on edge as presidential vote looms
summary: France is on high alert ahead of its presidential election on Sunday, following a gunman attack in Paris that claimed the life of a police officer. The shooting, carried out by a 39-year-old man with a history of violent crimes, has shifted attention to security and may benefit far-right candidate Marine Le Pen, who has dominated the campaign on the issue. With nearly a quarter of voters undecided, the election is seen as crucial for the future of France and the European Union, with nearly 50,000 police and 7,000 soldiers deployed to protect voters.

site_title: Golf: I am not disappearing, Poulter says after losing US Tour status
summary: Former European Ryder Cup hero Ian Poulter has relinquished his exempt status on the PGA Tour after missing the cut at the Valero Texas Open. Poulter, 41, stated he will continue to play US tournaments on sponsor invitations and add European Tour events to his schedule. Despite struggling, Poulter remains optimistic, saying "Golf's a funny game" and that he could easily win the next tournament. He currently ranks 190th in the world and will team up with Geoff Ogilvy at the Zurich Classic of New Orleans.

site_title: US will honour refugee deal with Australia: Vice-President Mike Pence
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence announced the US will honour a refugee deal with Australia, under which the US will resettle 1,250 asylum seekers from offshore processing camps in Papua New Guinea and Nauru in exchange for Australia resettling refugees from El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras. The deal, initially described as "dumb" by President Donald Trump, will be subject to vetting, with the US applying "extreme vetting" to those seeking resettlement. The move aims to strengthen the alliance and address Australia's pressure to close the camps, which have seen recent violence.

site_title: Nine-year-old crowned winner of Big Spell 2017, takes home top prize of $5,000
summary: A 9-year-old student, Eashaa Pillai from Raffles Girls' Primary School, won the sixth edition of the RHB-The Straits Times National Spelling Championship with a $5,000 top prize. She was crowned the winner after beating out 15 competitors in an intense final round. Second place went to Raghav Kumar from Anglo-Chinese School (Primary) with a $3,000 prize, while Lee I-Shiang from Rosyth School took third place with a $1,000 prize. The event was co-organized by RHB and The Straits Times, and aimed to promote English language skills and good character.

site_title: Gunman attacks regional Russian security service office, kills two
summary: A gunman attacked Russia's Federal Security Service office in the far east on April 21, killing one employee and a visitor from former Soviet states. The attacker, identified as a local resident born in 1999, was killed and another person was injured. Islamic State in Iraq and Syria claimed responsibility for the attack. The incident occurred after a similar suicide bombing in St. Petersburg metro earlier this month, which killed 16 people.

site_title: Punchlines: April 22, 2017
summary: I couldn't find any article content to summarize. The provided text appears to be a publication information section, including the author's name and publication date, but it does not contain the actual article content.

site_title: Donald Trump in 'no rush' to get health-care legislation done before first 100 days is up
summary: President Donald Trump stated there's no "rush" to pass Republican health-care legislation before his 100th day in office, set to occur next weekend. Trump expressed confidence that the bill will be voted on "eventually," but declined to specify a timeline. He emphasized that the outcome won't be determined by a particular deadline, saying "next week, next week does not matter." Trump's comments suggest a lack of urgency in the Republican-led push for health-care reform.

site_title: Football: Ibrahimovic faces long layoff, say reports
summary: Manchester United striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic faces a long injury layoff due to a knee injury sustained during the Europa League quarter-final win over Anderlecht. The 35-year-old is expected to miss the rest of the season, potentially until the end of the year, and is uncertain about his future at the club. Ibrahimovic, who has been leading scorer for United this season, is out of contract at the end of the season and has been linked to a move to the Los Angeles Galaxy or Los Angeles FC.

site_title: San Francisco goes dark amid major power outage
summary: A major power outage affected San Francisco on April 21, 2017, leaving approximately 88,000 customers without electricity in the downtown area. The outage began in the morning and continued into the afternoon, with traffic lights and shops plunged into darkness. However, many residents took the outage in stride, socializing on streets with reduced traffic. Firefighters responded to over 100 calls, including 20 related to people trapped in elevators. Electricity was restored to 15,000 customers by 1pm, with an expected full restoration by the afternoon.

site_title: Donald Trump greets Egyptian-American freed from Egyptian detention
summary: US President Donald Trump welcomed Aya Hijazi, an Egyptian-American charity worker detained in Egypt for nearly three years, back to the White House on Friday. Hijazi was released from jail after Trump personally requested her release in a meeting with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi. She was acquitted of human trafficking charges along with seven others, and was flown back to the US on a military jet. Trump's efforts to secure her release were seen as a success, following failed attempts by the Obama administration.

site_title: Tennis: Nadal into Monte Carlo semi-finals
summary: Rafael Nadal advanced to the Monte Carlo Masters semi-finals, defeating Diego Schwartzman 6-4, 6-4. Nadal will face David Goffin, who upset world number two Novak Djokovic 6-2, 3-6, 7-5, in the next round.

site_title: High-seas snafu, Whitelash and Spy Games
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration has faced criticism for a series of mishaps, including a snafu involving the aircraft carrier USS Carl Vinson, which was sent to exercise with Australia instead of heading to the Korean Peninsula. The move was seen as a loss of credibility and has strained relations with South Korea. Meanwhile, Australia and New Zealand have introduced stricter immigration policies, mirroring the US, and are at risk of being seen as part of the "Whitelash" against immigrants. In Pakistan, a former Indian naval officer, Kulbhushan Jadhav, has been sentenced to death for espionage, and tensions between the two countries remain high.

site_title: What to watch for in the first round of the French presidential election
summary: The first round of the French presidential election is underway, with centrist Emmanuel Macron leading the polls. However, populists like Marine Le Pen and Jean-Luc Melenchon are gaining momentum, potentially drawing mainstream voters away from the centrist parties. Investigations into candidates Francois Fillon and Le Pen may impact the outcome, with Fillon facing allegations of embezzlement and Le Pen accused of misusing EU funds. A Le Pen victory could lead to a referendum on EU membership and a more lenient stance on Russia, potentially benefiting Vladimir Putin.

site_title: NBA: Wizards centre Mahinmi will miss at least two games
summary: Washington Wizards centre Ian Mahinmi will miss at least the next two NBA playoff games due to a strained left calf. Mahinmi, a 30-year-old reserve, was re-evaluated and has improved but will not play in games three and four against the Atlanta Hawks. The Wizards lead the series 2-0 and there is no set timetable for Mahinmi's return, with coach Scott Brooks stating he will play when ready. Mahinmi has averaged 5.6 points and 4.8 rebounds in 31 games this season, mostly off the bench.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic looking for answers on clay ahead of looming French Open
summary: Novak Djokovic is seeking answers on clay ahead of the French Open, which starts in five weeks. He lost to David Goffin in the Monte Carlo Masters quarterfinals, citing a lack of ideas and struggling with movement on the surface. Despite playing well overall, Djokovic is short on practice and experience on clay, which he plans to rectify by sticking to the Madrid and Rome Masters events in May. His French Open title defense defense is a concern, but Djokovic remains optimistic and will continue to prepare for Paris.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, April 22 edition
summary: The Group of 20 major economies reached a "broad consensus" that protectionism would be damaging to the global economy, according to German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schäuble. The G-20 finance ministers also agreed to make growth "more inclusive" to combat protectionism. In other news, a gunman in Paris who killed one police officer on the Champs Elysees was described as an unstable and violent individual with no known religious conviction. US President Donald Trump welcomed back Egyptian-American charity worker Aya Hijazi, who was released from jail after nearly three years of detention. Tennis player Novak Djokovic was eliminated from the Monte Carlo Masters, while Manchester United striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic faces a long injury layoff after landing awkwardly on his knee.

site_title: US stocks dip ahead of French election
summary: US stocks declined on April 21 ahead of the French presidential election, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.2% to 20,547.55. The S&P 500 dropped 0.3% to 2,348.70, while the Nasdaq Composite Index lost 0.1% to 5,910.52. Mixed earnings reports from General Electric, Schlumberger, and Honeywell International contributed to the downturn, while Mattel's poor first-quarter results and a toy glut after the holiday season weighed on the market. The election, which is expected to be a tight contest, has investors cautious about taking new positions.

site_title: Sometimes we should say it like it is. It's a characteristic of obstreperous Singaporeans
summary: Singaporeans are known for their straightforward and honest approach to discussing national issues, as exemplified by recent articles that encourage "plain speaking." A Senior Transport Correspondent, Christopher Tan, argued that pedestrianizing Orchard Road may not be the best solution, instead suggesting that the area's issues stem from its lack of unique shops and welcoming entrances. Former Straits Times Editor Han Fook Kwang questioned the effectiveness of Singapore's R&D spending, while Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong paid tribute to Mr. Othman Wok, a pioneer of multi-racialism, highlighting Singaporeans' "obstreperous" nature of being honest and resistant to control.

site_title: UN chief holds first meeting with Donald Trump
summary: UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres met with US President Donald Trump at the White House on April 21, marking the first high-level exchange between the two leaders. The meeting was described as "interesting and constructive" and focused on cooperation between the US and UN on issues such as North Korea, Syria, and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Guterres and Trump agreed to meet again in the near future, with UN Security Council ambassadors set to meet with Trump on Monday and US lawmakers on Capitol Hill.

site_title: More than 100 men arrested in Canada child sex case
summary: Police in Toronto announced the arrest of over 100 men accused of using the internet to solicit sex with minors as young as 13. The arrests, made over a four-year period, followed a 2013 investigation that found nearly a third of women prostitutes in the York suburb were under 18. Officers posed as underage girls online, and 104 men attempted to arrange meetings, with 35 pleading guilty or confessing to prison terms of 3-7 months.

site_title: Mike Pence on charm offensive in Australia after disastrous first phone call between Donald Trump, Malcolm Turnbull
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence is set to meet Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull on April 22, 2017, following a disastrous first phone call between Donald Trump and Turnbull in January. Pence will take a more amiable approach to focus on cooperation on trade, defense, and other issues. The meeting comes after Trump's administration cancelled a trans-Pacific trade deal and faced criticism for its handling of the refugee agreement. Pence aims to strike a conciliatory tone, with a focus on Australia's expertise in the South China Sea, an issue of concern for both countries.

site_title: US forces kill ISIS militant linked to Turkey nightclub attack
summary: US forces have killed Abdurakhmon Uzbeki, an ISIS operative linked to the 2017 Istanbul nightclub attack that left 39 people dead. Uzbeki, believed to be from Uzbekistan, was a close associate of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi and helped facilitate the attack. The operation, a secret military ground assault, occurred near Mayadin, Syria, on April 6. The US has confirmed the link between Uzbeki and the attack, which was claimed by ISIS as revenge for Turkish military involvement in Syria.

site_title: Ousted Fox host Bill O'Reilly could get US$25 million
summary: Former Fox anchor Bill O'Reilly is set to receive an exit payout of up to $25 million after being ousted over sexual harassment allegations. O'Reilly, who was a major draw at the network, will be replaced by Tucker Carlson in the primetime 8pm slot. The move comes after numerous companies pulled advertisements from O'Reilly's show and Fox News contributor Julie Roginsky filed a lawsuit charging that she was harassed by former Fox CEO Roger Ailes. The scandal may not be fully resolved, with more women potentially coming forward to share their allegations.

site_title: Consensus in G-20 that protectionism 'damaging' for global economy
summary: The Group of 20 (G-20) major economies have reached a broad consensus that continued protectionism would be damaging to the global economy. German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schäuble stated that free trade is better for global growth and protectionism would harm economies. The G-20 agreed to make growth more inclusive to counter the rise of protectionism. The meeting came ahead of the International Monetary Fund's semi-annual meeting, which has also flagged protectionism and trade wars as a threat to the global economic recovery.

site_title: Football: Mourinho says no sense in Rashford playing for England Under-21s
summary: Manchester United manager Jose Mourinho has expressed his opposition to Marcus Rashford playing for England's Under-21 team in the European Championship. With Rashford having risen above the age-group level, Mourinho believes it makes no sense for the 19-year-old to play at that level. Mourinho cited Rashford's recent performances for Manchester United, saying he doesn't want to see him playing at a lower level, and instead wants him to focus on the senior team.

site_title: Taleban kill dozens at army HQ in northern Afghanistan
summary: Dozens of Afghan soldiers were killed or wounded in a Taliban attack on a military base in northern Afghanistan, with the US estimating over 50 casualties. The attack, which occurred near a mosque on the base in Mazar-i-Sharif, was carried out by gunmen disguised as Afghan soldiers who gained entry by claiming to be wounded. At least eight soldiers were killed, 11 wounded, and five attackers were arrested or killed. The attack was described as "murderous and reprehensible" by the Nato command, and has sparked calls for a thorough investigation into the incident.

site_title: US judge orders Volkswagen to pay US$2.8 billion criminal penalty
summary: A US federal judge ordered Volkswagen to pay a $2.8 billion criminal fine and placed the German automaker on three years of probation for its role in the emissions cheating scandal. The company agreed to plead guilty to three felony charges and will pay a separate $1.5 billion civil penalty. This is part of a larger settlement of over $23 billion in fines and compensation in the US. The company also agreed to cooperate with federal investigators and has undergone a significant change process.

site_title: Four men aged 21 to 26 arrested for robbery in 2 cases along Ophir and Tannery Roads
summary: Four men aged 21-26 were arrested for robbery in two separate cases along Ophir Road and Tannery Road in Singapore. In the first case, two men were robbed near a bus stop on April 18, and in the second case, a man was robbed of his phone and wallet on April 19. The suspects were arrested on April 20 and charged with attempted armed robbery and robbery, carrying potential jail sentences of up to 20 years and 14 years, and 12 strokes of the cane.

site_title: US fighter pilot with Korea-bound carrier had to eject: Navy
summary: A US Navy pilot preparing to land on the aircraft carrier Carl Vinson, en route to waters off Korea, was forced to eject on his final approach. The F/A-18E Super Hornet fighter jet was recovered by helicopter from the Celebes Sea, with no apparent injuries reported. The incident occurred amid heightened tensions in the region, with the carrier part of a naval strike group sent towards Korea. The ships initially sailed in the wrong direction on an earlier mission before turning north. The pilot's identity remains unknown.

site_title: Hunting party held hostage in Iraq since 2015 freed
summary: Twenty-six hostages, including members of Qatar's ruling royal family, were freed in Iraq after being held for 16 months. The hostages were handed over to a Qatari delegation and flown to Doha. Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi was thanked by Saudi Arabia for his efforts to secure their release. The abduction occurred in December 2015, and negotiations involved Iran, Qatar, and Hezbollah. The freed hostages were in good health and left the Iraqi capital on the same day.

site_title: Football: Time for Spurs to prove their worth - Conte
summary: Chelsea manager Antonio Conte believes Tottenham is ready to end their 56-year wait for English champions and their nine-year trophy drought. Conte, who leads Chelsea in the title race, says Tottenham is a "really great power in English football" and now has no excuses to be considered an underdog. Tottenham, led by England internationals Harry Kane and Dele Alli, face Chelsea in the FA Cup semi-final on Saturday, with a Chelsea win potentially boosting Conte's squad's morale. Conte also revealed Gary Cahill will likely miss the match due to gastroenteritis.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic crashes out of Monte Carlo Masters
summary: Novak Djokovic lost to Belgian David Goffin in the Monte Carlo Masters semi-finals, 6-2 3-6 7-5. Djokovic saved four match points but ultimately cracked under pressure, setting up a meeting with claycourt king Rafa Nadal. Goffin's gritty display and timely wins by Albert Ramos and Lucas Pouille complete the semi-finals lineup.
