site_title: NBA: Jazz centre Rudy Gobert ruled out of Game Three against Clippers
summary: Utah Jazz centre Rudy Gobert has been ruled out of Game Three against the Los Angeles Clippers due to a left knee injury. Gobert hyperextended his knee in Game One and the team has been cautious in his recovery, with coach Quin Snyder stating that rushing him back could compromise his long-term health. Power forward Derrick Favors will replace Gobert at centre. The Jazz have struggled without Gobert, allowing 60 points in the paint in Game Two.

site_title: Teenager, 18, arrested for loanshark activities in areas including Punggol and Tampines
summary: An 18-year-old teenager was arrested for loanshark activities in areas including Punggol and Tampines. He was identified and arrested after a vandalized car was reported, with debtors' notes found on the vehicle. Preliminary investigations suggest he was involved in other harassment cases in multiple areas. He will be charged under the Moneylenders Act, which carries penalties of up to five years imprisonment, fines, and caning. Two other men, aged 30 and 27, were also arrested for similar offenses.

site_title: Twenty killed in school minibus crash in South Africa
summary: A minibus carrying 20 school children, including the driver, crashed and exploded in a fire in Mpumalanga province, South Africa. The collision occurred between Verena and Bronkhorstpruit, north-east of Pretoria. At least 20 people, including 19 children, were killed, with several injured. The cause of the collision is unknown. The incident occurred during a time when South Africa's road safety record is dire, with 235 road fatalities reported during the Easter weekend, a significant increase from last year. The truck driver survived the accident.

site_title: Spate of attacks masks a weakening ISIS: Experts
summary: ISIS, despite recent attacks in Europe, is weakening due to international coalition efforts and improved intelligence. The group has fallen back on lone-wolf attacks, which are easier to detect and less complex. Experts say these attacks are symbolic of the end of a jihadist state, while individuals acting alone pose a new threat. The Champs Elysees attack in Paris may not impact the outcome of the French election, but it highlights the group's continued attempts to claim responsibility for attacks. ISIS is described as a "criminal organisation" that uses terror to appear global.

site_title: Football: Gabriel Jesus in line to make comeback against Arsenal in FA Cup semi-final
summary: Manchester City striker Gabriel Jesus is in line to make a comeback against Arsenal in the FA Cup semi-final on Sunday, manager Pep Guardiola announced. Jesus returned to training after a foot injury and will travel to Wembley with the squad. Guardiola also ruled out defender John Stones due to a muscular problem. The manager expressed his desire to win the FA Cup to prove his players' abilities and alleviate stress and pressure. City have won the FA Cup five times, with their last victory coming in 2011.

site_title: Three men, aged between 32 and 49, arrested for breaking into restaurant and stealing
summary: Three men aged 32-49 were arrested in Singapore for breaking into a restaurant and stealing $1,000 in cash and a mobile phone. The trio was identified by police and arrested on April 21. They will be charged with housebreaking and theft by night with common intention, facing up to 14 years in jail and a fine. The police advise property owners to secure their premises with good quality grills, refrain from keeping large sums of cash, and install burglar alarms and surveillance cameras to prevent future break-ins.

site_title: Tennis: Spanish giant-killer Ramos-Vinolas strikes again in Monte Carlo against Cilic
summary: Spanish tennis player Albert Ramos-Vinolas defeated tournament number five Marin Cilic 6-2, 6-7 (5/7), 6-2 in the Monte Carlo Masters quarterfinals, his second straight upset. Ramos-Vinolas, the 15th seed, advances to the semi-finals for the first time in his career, where he will face Lucas Pouille. The Spanish player attributes his success to playing well, but remains perplexed about the source of his form, citing a strong performance in February's clay tournaments in South America.

site_title: Football: Frank Lampard hails world-class Dele Alli as the 'No. 10' England have crying out for
summary: Former Chelsea player Frank Lampard praises Tottenham midfielder Dele Alli as the "number 10" England has been waiting for. Alli's movement and finishing ability have made him a key player for Tottenham, scoring 16 goals in the Premier League this season. Lampard, who played as an attacking midfielder, believes Alli's intelligence and awareness on the field are crucial to his effectiveness. Lampard expects Chelsea to focus on stopping Alli, particularly his ability to get into the box without being marked, as they face Tottenham in their FA Cup semi-final.

site_title: Paris shooting: Champs Elysees gunman was unstable criminal who 'hated police'
summary: A gunman, Karim Cheurfi, 39, was killed in a shootout with French police on the Champs Elysees in Paris. Contrary to initial speculation, Cheurfi was not motivated by Islamic extremist ideology, but rather was an unstable and violent individual with a long criminal record. He had been arrested multiple times for violent crimes and had been released from prison in 2013. A handwritten note praising the Islamic State was found near his body, but authorities say he was not linked to the group.

site_title: 28-year-old arrested for using dud cheques to buy $14,000 worth of alcohol
summary: A 28-year-old man in Singapore was arrested for using counterfeit cheques to purchase $14,000 worth of liquor and wine. He ordered the items, paid with fake cheques, and then resold them at discounted prices. The police identified the suspect and arrested him on April 20. He will face charges of cheating, which can result in up to 10 years in jail and a fine.

site_title: Man tackled by officers at Changi Airport had hurled vulgarities and pushed one of them
summary: A 44-year-old man was tackled by police officers at Changi Airport Terminal 2 on April 20, after allegedly hurling vulgarities and pushing one of the officers. He was being uncooperative when approached and had previously snatched and smashed a man's phone. The suspect was arrested for "using abusive language against public servants and criminal force to deter public servants from discharging their duties". Police investigations are ongoing, with videos of the incident going viral on social media.

site_title: Wall Street opens little changed
summary: Wall Street opened little changed on Friday, with major indexes holding onto gains from a rally on Thursday driven by Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's comments on tax reform. Earnings reports showed 75% of S&P 500 companies beat expectations, with profits estimated to have risen 11.1% in the quarter, the best since 2011. Investors braced for the first round of the French presidential election, where centrist Emmanuel Macron is expected to lead Marine Le Pen in a closely contested contest.

site_title: British PM May says June election result 'not certain' despite front-runner status
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May said she is not taking anything for granted despite her governing Conservative party's strong lead in polls, which suggest a landslide victory in the upcoming June election. Polls indicate a 20-point lead, potentially securing over 100 seats. May emphasized that the election campaign has just begun and the result is not certain. She also confirmed her commitment to spending 0.7% of national income on foreign aid and sticking to her pledge to reduce annual net migration to below 100,000.

site_title: Football: Unfashionable Celta Vigo aim to dash United's Europa League dreams
summary: Celta Vigo, a LaLiga side from Galicia, will face Manchester United in the Europa League semi-finals, despite lacking footballing pedigree. The team, led by coach Eduardo Berizzo, has shown impressive progress under his intense pressing game, with key players Iago Aspas and John Guidetti forming a potent attacking partnership. Celta has claimed notable victories, including beating Barcelona and Real Madrid, and is confident in their ability to upset tournament favourites. The first leg against United is on May 4, with the final set to be played in Stockholm on May 24.

site_title: US VP Mike Pence to talk trade, security and koalas during Australian visit
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence is set to discuss trade and regional security with Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull during his visit. Pence's 10-day tour of US allies in the Asia-Pacific region aims to strengthen economic ties and security cooperation. The meeting comes amid disputes in the South China Sea and tension on the Korean peninsula. Pence will emphasize the long-term partnership between the US and Australia, despite Australia's growing ties with China. The visit follows a rocky start to US-Australia relations under President Trump, who previously criticized a refugee resettlement deal between the two countries.

site_title: Football: Gary Cahill to miss Chelsea's FA Cup semi-final against Spurs
summary: Chelsea manager Antonio Conte revealed that Gary Cahill will miss the FA Cup semi-final against Tottenham due to a small stone in his kidney, which required hospital treatment. Cahill was released from hospital on Thursday but Conte fears it's too soon for him to return to action. The England centre-back's absence is a significant blow to Chelsea, who are leading the Premier League. Conte also praised Tottenham, saying it's time for them to shed their underdog status and consider themselves a top team in English football.

site_title: Thai man arrested over suspected smuggling of semen into Laos
summary: A 25-year-old Thai man, Nithinon Srithaniyanan, was arrested and fined 200,000 baht for suspected smuggling of semen into Laos. He claimed to have been hired to transport semen to a clinic in Vientiane for people with infertility, having done it 12 times before. The nitrogen tank and vials were sent for inspection, and test results are expected on Monday. If confirmed to be semen, Nithinon could face up to three years in prison for violating Thailand's surrogacy law.

site_title: US probe on 1MDB 'pushed KL-Abu Dhabi settlement'
summary: Malaysia and Abu Dhabi have reached a settlement in a long-standing dispute over a multibillion-dollar financial assistance arrangement for 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB). The agreement, led by Abu Dhabi's Mubadala Development and Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak's principal troubleshooter, will see Kuala Lumpur repay a loan of about US$1.2 billion in two equal instalments, with Malaysia also honouring obligations to bondholders of a 10-year US$3.5 billion bond issue. The settlement avoids messy arbitration and may impact legal action against 1MDB by foreign governments, including the US Department of Justice.

site_title: Tennis: Spanish giant-killer strikes again at Monte Carlo
summary: Albert Ramos-Vinolas, a 15th seed, defeated fifth seed Marin Cilic 6-2, 6-7 (5-7), 6-2 in the Monte Carlo Masters quarterfinals on April 21, 2017. This was Ramos-Vinolas' second upset in the tournament, following his win over world No. 1 Andy Murray. The victory marked his first Masters 1000 semi-final appearance, as he advances to the semifinals. Cilic struggled with forehand errors, leading to a 2.5-hour match on the clay court.

site_title: All bets are off for French presidential election after Paris attack
summary: A gunman claimed by the Islamic State attacked a police van on the Champs Elysees in Paris, killing one officer and wounding two others, in the final days of France's hotly contested presidential election. The attack occurred on Thursday, just before the election on Sunday, raising concerns about security and potentially benefiting far-right candidate Marine Le Pen. Le Pen has campaigned on stronger security measures, and a pollster says 51% of anti-terror police support her. The election remains a tight four-way race, with centrist Emmanuel Macron leading the pack, but Le Pen's chances may increase due to the attack.

site_title: Four injured in accident between ambulance, taxi and three cars on CTE
summary: Four people were injured in a multi-vehicle accident on the Central Expressway (CTE) in Singapore on Friday afternoon. The incident involved a private ambulance operator, a taxi, and three cars, and occurred while the ambulance was transporting a child to the KK Women's and Children's Hospital. Four victims were taken to Tan Tock Seng Hospital, and the child was transported to the hospital in another ambulance. Police are conducting ongoing investigations into the incident.

site_title: Study links diet soda to higher risk of stroke, dementia
summary: A new study links diet soda consumption to a higher risk of stroke and dementia, with daily diet soda drinkers almost three times more likely to develop these conditions as those who consumed it weekly or less. The study, which tracked 2,888 individuals, found no causation but an association between diet soda and increased risk of ischemic stroke and Alzheimer's disease dementia. Experts emphasize caution and advise drinking more water and less diet soda, with more study needed to confirm the findings.

site_title: Philippines' Rodrigo Duterte tours Russian warship
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte toured a Russian warship, the guided missile cruiser Varyag, during a goodwill visit in Manila, April 21, 2017. This marked the second visit in four months, highlighting his growing closeness to Moscow. Duterte stated, "The Russians are with me, I shall not be afraid," as he toured the ship and met with Russian sailors. The visit indicates closer ties between the Philippines and Russia, with plans to purchase military equipment from Russia instead of the US and a scheduled visit to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in May.

site_title: Jakarta polls a proxy for Jokowi versus Prabowo race in 2019
summary: Indonesia's presidential election in 2019 has already seen a proxy contest in the Jakarta gubernatorial election, with President Joko Widodo's loss to Anies Baswedan to opposition-backed candidate. The outcome has raised questions about Jokowi's prospects for re-election, and opposition leader Prabowo Subianto is consolidating support from political and religious elites. Prabowo is seen as a potential challenger to Jokowi, and his party's victory may fracture Jokowi's ruling coalition, potentially paving the way for a resurgence of old elite power in Jakarta.

site_title: Nanyang Girls' High and Princess Elizabeth Primary triumphs in National Chinese Challenge 2017
summary: Nanyang Girls' High School and Princess Elizabeth Primary School won the National Chinese Challenge 2017, a competition that tested students' knowledge of Chinese dialect, literature, and general knowledge. The schools defeated other top-performing teams, including Dunman High School and Raffles Girls' Primary School, in the secondary and primary school categories, respectively. The winning teams received awards from Minister for Education Ng Chee Meng, marking the third time Nanyang Girls' High School has claimed the title.

site_title: Six hopefuls in Kuomintang leadership race in Taiwan
summary: Six candidates have qualified to run for the leadership of Taiwan's Kuomintang (KMT) party, including former vice-president Wu Den-yih and incumbent chair Hung Hsiu-chu. The election, set for May 20, will determine the party's new leader, who will face the challenge of rebuilding the party after its loss to the Democratic Progressive Party in 2016. The winner will need to rally the party's supporters and bring together divided factions to regain seats in local elections and potentially challenge President Tsai Ing-wen in 2020.

site_title: Basketball: Slingers fall 72-76 to HK Lions, face must-win Game 4 on Sunday
summary: The Singapore Slingers lost Game 3 of the Asean Basketball League (ABL) Finals to Hong Kong Eastern Long Lions 72-76, falling 1-2 in the best-of-five series. The Slingers had led 17-12 in the first quarter but trailed 57-56 in the final 10 minutes, allowing the visitors to take control. The Slingers now face a must-win Game 4 on Sunday to stay in the championship hunt, with Game 5 potentially on Wednesday in Hong Kong if necessary.

site_title: Football: Police question ex-FAS chief Zainudin Nordin, FAS gen sec Winston Lee, Tiong Bahru chairman Bill Ng and his wife
summary: Singapore police widened a probe into alleged misuse of funds at Tiong Bahru Football Club, questioning former FAS president Zainudin Nordin, current general secretary Winston Lee, and club chairman Bill Ng along with his wife Bonnie Wong. The investigation started after Sport Singapore made a police report, citing concerns over a $500,000 donation and the presence of 29 jackpot machines at the club's clubhouse. Police raided the clubhouses of three football clubs and the FAS offices, seizing documents and computers. The probe is ongoing, with the FAS election scheduled for April 29.

site_title: HKEX and LME announce new leadership structure for the metal exchange
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd. (HKEX) and its subsidiary London Metal Exchange (LME) have announced a new leadership structure to strengthen LME's role in global metals trading. Matthew Chamberlain has been appointed as LME's chief executive, effective immediately, subject to FCA approval. Chamberlain will work with Adrian Farnham and James Proudlock, who will oversee LME Clear and the LME, respectively. HKEX CEO Charles Li expressed confidence in the new leadership team, citing plans to grow the business and expand geographical reach.

site_title: Thousands of Bangladeshi Muslims stage protests over statue
summary: Thousands of Bangladeshi Muslims protested in Dhaka, calling for the removal or destruction of a statue of "lady justice" from the nation's highest court, citing it as a Greek god unbefitting Bangladesh. The protesters, affiliated with the hardline Islamist group Islami Andolan Bangladesh, gathered after Friday prayers, with nearly 10,000 attendees. The statue, which represents justice, has sparked controversy, and the protesters also demanded the removal of the chief justice, who they claim has "procrastinated" in addressing their concerns.

site_title: Actress Joanne Peh gives birth to second child after 16-hour labour
summary: Local actors Qi Yuwu and actress Joanne Peh welcomed a baby boy on April 21, 2017, after a 16-hour labor. Joanne chose not to use pain relief, defying expectations that the second delivery would be easier. The couple's one-year-old daughter was told she would have a brother, but the experience was just as painful and long as the first. Qi will care for the new baby, while Peh may take a few months off to act in upcoming projects. Plans for a third child are not currently on the cards.

site_title: The Straits Times' News In A Minute: April 21, 2017
summary: Kong Hee and four others surrendered at State Courts in Singapore, starting their jail terms. The incident relates to the New Life Church scandal. Google was named as the company in Singapore most wanted to work for, according to a survey. The Singapore Tourism Board countered criticisms from the TV show Criminal Minds, which depicted the city-state in a negative light.

site_title: Australia struggling to rein in growing drug menace
summary: Australia is struggling to control the growing methamphetamine trade, with record-breaking seizures and record-high street prices fueling the problem. Syndicates from China, Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia smuggle large quantities of the drug into the country, with street prices about 10 times higher than in China. The Australian government has set up global task forces, including a joint police effort with China, resulting in massive seizures, such as a 903kg haul worth A$900 million. Experts say the task forces may only be a small dent in the supply, and demand reduction is key to addressing the issue.

site_title: Singapore researchers turn water into 'lemonade'
summary: Researchers in Singapore have developed a system to make water taste like lemonade using sensors and electrodes. By transmitting the pH value of lemonade to a glass of water, the flavor can be replicated. The team claims this technology could be used to send virtual drinks to loved ones, potentially aiding those looking to cut down on calories. The first prototype was tested, with participants enjoying the idea but suggesting minor improvements. The digital lemonade system is seen as a potential future innovation in beverage sharing.

site_title: What the City Harvest Church leaders can expect in Changi prison
summary: City Harvest Church leaders Kong Hee, John Lam, Tan Yee Peng, Sharon Tan, and Serina Wee began serving their prison sentences at Changi Prison, where their church has provided services since 2001. The convicted leaders will likely not have access to CHC's services to avoid conflict of interest. They will have access to Christian counselling services offered by other churches and will undergo a medical examination to determine their housing. The women will be housed at the Changi Women's Prison, while the men will be housed at Changi Prison Complex, with the possibility of earning remission or home detention.

site_title: Sri Lanka bans anti-garbage protests after dump disaster
summary: Sri Lanka has banned anti-garbage protests following a devastating garbage dump collapse that killed 32 people and destroyed 145 homes in Colombo. The government has outlawed disrupting garbage disposal, with offenders facing indefinite jail time. Armed collectors began clearing trash on garbage collectors began clearing the trash, while a Japanese delegation advised on a long-term solution to dispose of Colombo's waste. Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe promised permanent housing for survivors within two months, and vowed to shift the dump to a safer location.

site_title: Cases of hepatitis B and C hit 325 million: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) reports that approximately 325 million people worldwide are living with hepatitis B or C, with death tolls from the viruses rising. Hepatitis B and C can lead to liver cirrhosis and cancer if untreated, and a lack of awareness among infected individuals is driving the virus's spread. Only 9% of those infected with hepatitis B and 20% of those infected with hepatitis C know their status, hindering efforts to treat and prevent the disease. WHO aims to treat 80% of sufferers worldwide by 2030.

site_title: Football: United to face Celta Vigo, while Ajax play Lyon in Europa League semi-finals
summary: Manchester United will face Celta Vigo in the Europa League semi-finals, while Ajax Amsterdam will play Olympique Lyonnais. The semi-final matchups were determined in a draw on Friday, with the first legs to take place on May 4 and the return fixtures on May 11. The final will be held in Stockholm on May 24.

site_title: Spaniard sentenced to death in Thailand for grisly murder
summary: A Spanish national, Artur Segarra, was sentenced to death in Thailand for the gruesome murder of fellow Spaniard David Bernat. Segarra, 38, was convicted of kidnapping and killing Bernat to steal millions of baht from the businessman. Forensic evidence and witness testimony implicated Segarra in the crime, which took place in 2016. The verdict, read out in court, marks a rare execution in Thailand, with the last one occurring in 2009. Segarra's lawyer plans to file an appeal, and the case is expected to be taken to the end.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust ekes out 1.1% gain in Q1 distribution per unit
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 1.1% gain in Q1 distribution per unit to 2.74 Singapore cents. Gross revenue and net property income rose 8.2% and 9.8% to S$60.1 million and S$40.3 million, respectively, driven by contributions from newly acquired CapitaMall Xinnan. The trust's portfolio occupancy improved to 96.2%, and management expects to further enhance unitholders' value through optimising retail mix and strengthening mall appeal.

site_title: I don't know how I survived: Man who walked away from crushed car in trailer accident
summary: A 45-year-old Singaporean service engineer, Eddie Wong, miraculously survived a trailer accident in the Tuas tunnel on April 19, where his car was crushed from outside to halfway inside the tunnel. Wong, who sustained only bruises on his fingers, posted a video from his car's dashboard camera and a photo of the damaged vehicle on Facebook, which has garnered over 3,000 views. Wong plans to continue driving for work and is trying to settle his insurance claims, which are complicated due to the trailer being a Malaysia-registered vehicle.

site_title: Cabby gets maximum $5k fine and ban for causing grievous hurt to cyclist
summary: A 70-year-old taxi driver, Pui Keng Tiong, was sentenced to a $5,000 fine and a two-year ban from driving after causing grievous hurt to a 36-year-old cyclist, Mr Wang Qiang, in a downhill accident on Boon Lay Way in February last year. Pui mistakenly stepped on the accelerator instead of the brake pedal, steering his taxi into a kerb and hitting Mr Wang, who suffered a spinal fracture and head injury. The driver admitted to failing to maintain proper control over his vehicle and pleaded for a light sentence due to his 30 years of driving experience and remorse.

site_title: Paris attack to have 'big effect' on presidential poll, says Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that a deadly attack in Paris, claiming responsibility from the Islamic State, will have a "big effect" on France's upcoming presidential election. The attack, which killed a policeman and wounded two others, occurred on the famous Champs Elysees boulevard, forcing security to the forefront of the campaign. The shooting has led to three presidential frontrunners canceling campaign events, and Macron is presenting himself as a guarantor of the EU, promising reform. The vote is being closely watched amid a global swing to the right, with Trump's election in November cited as a comparison.

site_title: Indonesian President Joko Widodo's coalition faces fractures, exit poll shows
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo's coalition is facing fractures after his ally, Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, was defeated in the Jakarta governor election. The election exposed the influence of Islamic identity politics, with 34% of voters citing "same religion" as the primary reason for supporting the winner, Anies Baswedan. The outcome also showed that voters who were allied to Joko's parliamentary coalition rejected Basuki, despite the parties' formal backing. The defeat highlights the growing conservative Islamic influence in Indonesian politics and raises concerns about the stability of Joko's ruling coalition.

site_title: Two Israeli authors make Man Booker global shortlist
summary: Two Israeli authors, Amos Oz and David Grossman, have been shortlisted for the 2017 Man Booker International Prize, along with Argentine writer Samanta Schweblin and four European writers. The shortlist, announced on April 20, features novels that explore complex themes and characters, and the winner will receive a £50,000 prize. The winner will be announced on June 14 at London's Victoria and Albert Museum.

site_title: Lauren Hutton turns heads at 73 in new lingerie ad
summary: Lauren Hutton, 73, stars in Calvin Klein's new lingerie ad, directed by Sophia Coppola. The black-and-white campaign features Hutton and other women, aged 18-73, showcasing "cool, smart women with real bodies and who are approachable." This marks a departure from typical lingerie ads, highlighting a growing trend of models of all ages in fashion and beauty ads. Hutton, a veteran model and actress, was one of the world's first supermodels in the 1960s and 1970s, continuing to make a statement in the fashion industry at an advanced age.

site_title: Heavy security in Teheran as campaigning starts for Iran's presidential vote
summary: Iran's presidential campaigning began on April 21, 2017, with six candidates, including President Hassan Rouhani, set to compete in the May 19 vote. Hardline former President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was disqualified, despite registering as a candidate. The US has reassessed its policy on Iran amid the election, with the Senate delaying a bill to slap new sanctions. Analysts see a challenge to Rouhani from influential cleric Ebrahim Raisi, who is close to Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. The election is seen as a test of the clerical establishment's legitimacy and a show of defiance against US pressure.

site_title: 62 drug offenders arrested in week-long CNB operation, $313k worth of drugs seized
summary: Sixty-two suspected drug offenders were arrested in a week-long operation by the Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) in Singapore, resulting in the seizure of over $313,000 worth of drugs. The seized substances included heroin, methamphetamine, cannabis, and ecstasy tablets. The operation, supported by the Singapore Police Force, took place across 10 areas and led to the recovery of various drugs and drug-taking utensils. The CNB emphasized the importance of community support in combating drug abuse, encouraging parents to engage in conversations with their children to guide them away from drugs.

site_title: Mini-mart among first micro-retailers to adopt self-checkout counters
summary: A mini-mart in Singapore, Food-Joy, has adopted self-checkout counters, becoming one of the first mini-marts to do so. The introduction of self-checkout counters reduced queuing time to 1 minute, increasing sales transactions by 15% and revenue by 20% compared to 2015. The counters also reduced manned cashiers by half, allowing employees to take on new roles. While the store still requires one manned cashier counter for controlled items, the technology has enhanced the mini-mart's productivity and competitiveness, according to Minister for Trade and Industry S. Iswaran.

site_title: Lorry drives against traffic, hits at least five vehicles at Loyang Avenue
summary: A lorry crashed into at least five vehicles, including a Go Ahead bus, taxi, and four cars, while driving against traffic on Loyang Avenue in Singapore on April 20, 2017. The incident occurred at the junction of Loyang Avenue and Tampines Expressway. Two people were taken to hospital, a 55-year-old male driver and his 43-year-old female passenger, with the police investigating the cause of the accident.

site_title: China moves to discredit tycoon's claims of Communist Party corruption
summary: China has sought to discredit billionaire Guo Wengui's claims of corruption within the Communist Party, labeling him a "criminal suspect" whose allegations should not be believed. Guo, a former property mogul, has made explosive claims of corruption and bribery involving top officials, including a 23-minute video purportedly of a former official confessing to accepting bribes. China has also issued an Interpol "red notice" for Guo, citing his alleged crimes. The government is conducting a damage-limitation effort, with state media outlets publishing investigations into Guo's business dealings and ties to a disgraced former official.

site_title: Golf: South Africa's Branden Grace takes first-round lead at Texas Open
summary: Branden Grace of South Africa took the first-round lead at the Valero Texas Open with a six-under par 66 at TPC San Antonio. He trailed Americans Stewart Cink, Will MacKenzie, and John Huh by one stroke. Grace attributed his success to his low-ball flight, which suits windy conditions, and precision on the greens. He praised his form after the US Masters and said playing in the wind was a factor in his performance. The world No. 21 expressed satisfaction with all aspects of his game despite missing a few birdie opportunities.

site_title: Tourists venture back to Champs Elysees after attack
summary: Tourists returned to the Champs Elysees in Paris on April 21, 2017, a day after a man shot and killed a policeman on the avenue, just before France's presidential election. Despite shock and fear, many visitors showed defiance and calmness, with some even taking pictures of bullet-punctured shop windows. The area was heavily patrolled by security forces, and tourists expressed mixed emotions, but many remained determined to visit the city. The attack was the latest in a series of militant attacks in France, which has led to increased security measures.

site_title: Tennis: Andy Murray denies pressure of being world No. 1 is getting to him
summary: Andy Murray has dismissed suggestions that the pressure of being world No. 1 is affecting his performance after losing to Albert Ramos-Vinolas in the Monte Carlo Masters. Murray attributed his inconsistent results to an elbow injury and a stop-start year, but expressed hope that his results will improve as he focuses on staying healthy. He is uncertain about participating in the upcoming Barcelona and Hungarian Opens, considering a focus on fitness over playing matches.

site_title: Golf: Bernd Wiesberger storms to Shenzhen International lead after bogey-free round
summary: Austrian golfer Bernd Wiesberger took a four-shot lead at the Shenzhen International after a bogey-free 65 in the first round and a 67 in the second round, finishing 12-under at the halfway mark. Heavy rain and lightning suspended play on Friday, and the second round will resume on Saturday. Wiesberger, chasing his fourth European Tour title, praised his round, saying it was a "long day" but he played well, hitting a drive down 17 and putting really well. The second round will resume on Saturday with round three set to go off two tees in three-balls.

site_title: Fallen tree blocks lane on Cavenagh Road, parts of road closed temporarily
summary: A 44-year-old driver reported a fallen tree blocking Cavenagh Road in Singapore on April 21, 2017, after a rainstorm. The tree, described as as long as a double-decker bus, was cleared by 9am, with no reports of injuries. The road was closed temporarily, and an alternative route was advised to motorists. The incident occurred during wet weather, with short thundery showers forecasted for the last half of April, which may be linked to falling trees.

site_title: Football: Gareth Bale's potential absence may be a blessing in disguise for Real ahead of 'Clasico'
summary: Real Madrid may benefit from Gareth Bale's potential absence ahead of the 'Clasico' match against Barcelona. Despite Bale's significant contributions, Madrid have thrived with a more solid structure, with coach Zinedine Zidane favoring a balanced side over individual stars. Lucas Vazquez has excelled in Bale's absence, and the team's depth has been a key factor in their success this season. Real Madrid are well set to deliver their first league title in five seasons, three points clear of Barcelona, and Zidane will have to decide whether to start Bale or prioritize the team's collective glory.

site_title: China denies violations of ban on North Korean coal imports
summary: China denies violating its ban on North Korean coal imports, saying it is "seriously enforcing" the policy. Despite reports of North Korean ships entering Chinese ports, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Lu Kang stated that the country is not allowing North Korean coal back in. The ban was imposed in February to comply with UN sanctions, and China made exceptions for humanitarian deliveries. Three North Korean vessels were spotted at the Tangshan port, but it's unclear what they were hauling. China claims it is respecting its obligations to enforce UN resolutions.

site_title: Japan's advice in case of a missile strike: Don't forget a handkerchief
summary: Japan's government has released advice on how to prepare for a ballistic missile strike, which would take approximately 10 minutes to reach the country from North Korea. The recommended steps include getting indoors, keeping away from windows, and switching on the TV. If a missile lands nearby, residents should cover their nose and mouth with a handkerchief and quickly evacuate. Japan's early-warning system, the J-Alert system, will issue alerts across the country via loudspeakers and mobile phones. The government emphasizes that the country's missile-defence system is not foolproof.

site_title: Football: Real to take on Atletico, Monaco will play Juventus in Champions League semi-finals
summary: Real Madrid will face Atletico Madrid in the Champions League semi-finals, while Monaco will play Juventus. The draw was made on Friday, with Real and Monaco set to play the first leg at home on May 2 and 3, and the return fixtures on May 9-10. Real has a history of beating Atletico in the finals, but playing the second leg away could favor their rivals. Monaco, who have scored 24 goals since reaching the group phase, will face a steely Juventus defense that has conceded only two goals throughout the campaign.

site_title: Philippine defence chief visits disputed Spratly island
summary: Philippine Defence Secretary Delfin Lorenzana visited Thitu Island in the disputed South China Sea, asserting Manila's territorial claim to the region. The visit came after a Chinese military warning, which Lorenzana said was a routine protocol. Construction on the island is planned to begin within weeks, with the Philippines allocating 1.6 billion pesos for military installations. The visit was seen as a reversal of President Rodrigo Duterte's earlier decision to pull back from visiting the island. Tensions between the two countries remain, following a reported incident in which Chinese coast guards allegedly shot at a Filipino fishing vessel.

site_title: Football: Arsenal's tumultous season could still have a silver lining, says Nacho Monreal
summary: Arsenal's season has been underwhelming, but defender Nacho Monreal says the team's twin targets of winning the FA Cup and finishing in the top four remain achievable. With seven points behind fourth-placed City, Arsenal need a strong finish to secure a top-four spot. Monreal hopes to repeat the Gunners' consecutive FA Cup wins in 2014 and 2015, stating that winning the FA Cup would be a "special" moment and a way to show the fans they can win trophies. The FA Cup semi-final against Manchester City is a crucial test for the team's prospects.

site_title: Robust demand for Chinese property as mortgage loans jump in Q1
summary: China extended 1.7 trillion yuan in property loans in Q1 2017, a 14% increase from the previous year, according to the People's Bank of China. Property loans accounted for 40.4% of all new loans, with outstanding loans rising 26.1% to 28.39 trillion yuan. Individual mortgages saw a 35.7% year-over-year increase to 19.05 trillion yuan. This rebound from previous quarters, marked by property curbs, reflects robust demand in the sector and a significant rebound from the previous quarter.

site_title: Lionfish could soon be served at restaurants
summary: Celebrity chefs have gathered in Bermuda for a cooking competition, dubbed the "Lionfish Throwdown," to raise awareness about the invasive lionfish threatening marine ecosystems in the Atlantic Ocean and Caribbean Sea. A newly developed unmanned robot, the Guardian, capable of catching lionfish, is being tested and aims to make the process more efficient and affordable. The robot can capture and hold about 10 fish before resurfacing, and its developer plans to turn lionfish hunting into an online sport, potentially creating a new market for chefs to serve the invasive species as a gourmet cuisine.

site_title: Marine Le Pen says France must reinstate border checks to fight terrorism
summary: Far-right presidential candidate Marine Le Pen urged the French Socialist government to immediately reinstate border checks and expel foreigners on intelligence watch lists to fight terrorism. This move is part of her campaign manifesto, which she claims will protect France from Islamist terrorism and judicial laxity. Following a police officer's killing claimed by ISIS, Le Pen emphasized the need for swift action, saying the government should not wait until after the April 23 presidential election.

site_title: Investor education vital to attracting more high-growth tech companies to SGX
summary: Singapore can attract more high-growth tech companies by educating retail investors about these firms, according to SVCA chairman Jeffrey Chi. The country's plans to allow dual class share listings are a step in the right direction, but more needs to be done. Private equity investments in Southeast Asia rose to $6.8 billion last year, with experts expecting continued growth but flagging challenges in regional capital markets, including companies' reluctance to list on local bourses. Education is key to addressing these challenges and attracting unicorns to list in Singapore.

site_title: New DSO Complex launched, featuring facilities for robotics and artificial intelligence research
summary: Singapore's Defence Science and Technology Agency (DSO) unveiled its new headquarters, the DSO Complex, on April 21, 2017. The 69,000 sq m complex features facilities for robotics and artificial intelligence research, including the Playground, an experimental space for prototyping and testing ideas, and a 500 sq m robotics laboratory. The complex will drive innovative concepts and experimental laboratories to provide the Singapore Armed Forces with indigenous capabilities to meet security challenges. The DSO Complex is expected to house over 1,000 staff across more than 200 offices and laboratories.

site_title: Community hospital adopts tracking system developed by SMU students
summary: Ang Mo Kio-Thye Hua Kwan Hospital in Singapore has adopted a new visitor tracking system, Stepwise, developed by six Singapore Management University (SMU) students. The system uses NRIC scanning to track visitor entries and exits, allowing hospital staff to monitor contact between visitors and patients. Developed without government funding, Stepwise has improved the hospital's efficiency, cutting down processing time by over half. The system will also help track overcrowding and is designed to aid in disease tracking, particularly in emergencies. It will be made available for free to other agencies.

site_title: 28 Wilkie - Caviar bar serves Italian food with a Japanese twist
summary: 28 Wilkie, a Singaporean restaurant, serves Italian food with a Japanese twist, defying expectations of a traditional caviar bar. The casual, smart-casual atmosphere and relaxed jazz piano soundtrack create a comfortable dining experience. The menu features dishes such as Hokkaido scallops, scallop mentaiko pasta, and risotto with unagi, showcasing equal parts Italian and Japanese flavors. Prices range from $18 for tiramisu to $400 for a tin of Siberian caviar. Despite some minor issues with salt levels, the restaurant earns a 7-star rating for its cohesive and well-honed European cuisine.

site_title: Football: Monaco train sights on Ligue 1 title after European exploits
summary: Monaco, semi-finalists in the Champions League, will attempt to win their first French league title since 2000 with a visit to Lyon on Sunday. Reigning champions Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) are expected to beat Montpellier at home, while Nice must win at Toulouse to stay in the three-way battle for the top spot. Monaco and PSG are tied on 77 points, but Monaco have a game in hand. Monaco's European exploits, led by young talents Kylian Mbappe and Tiemoue Bakayoko, have attracted attention from top clubs, but coach Leonardo Jardim prioritizes the French league title.

site_title: Football: Bayern seek domestic silverware to make up for Champions League heartache
summary: Bayern Munich, still reeling from their Champions League exit to Real Madrid, are focused on securing a domestic double. Eight points clear in the Bundesliga, they aim to win their fifth straight title and German Cup. Defender Mats Hummels urged his team to put aside their disappointment and prioritize the league title and cup semi-final against Borussia Dortmund. Bayern are without several key players, including Manuel Neuer and Javi Martinez, but remain hot favorites to win both titles.

site_title: EU has no 'Plan B' if French voters deliver upset, say diplomats
summary: The European Union has no "Plan B" if Marine Le Pen and Jean-Luc Melenchon win the French presidential election, diplomats say. A victory by Le Pen, who threatens to leave the EU without a quick renegotiation, would mean the EU's existence as it is ceases to exist. EU leaders are concerned that neither Le Pen nor centrist Emmanuel Macron has the vision or authority to bring economic change to France, which remains the euro zone's No 2 economy. A Macron victory is seen as the best option to defeat Le Pen and heal Franco-German rifts within the EU.

site_title: Authorities rule out cyber attack as cause of StarHub's 2016 broadband disruption
summary: Authorities in Singapore have ruled out cyber attacks as the cause of disruptions to StarHub's home broadband services in October 2016. The disruptions were instead attributed to insufficient network capacity, exacerbated by a surge in internet traffic from StarHub customers accessing US-based content providers after a DNS service switch. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) and Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) have since increased StarHub's network capacity and directed the telco to review its infrastructure.

site_title: Jail for milk powder thief who stole $10,600 worth of products over 8 months
summary: A 34-year-old Singaporean man, Chan Yik Kee, was jailed for four months for stealing $10,600 worth of milk powder from supermarkets over eight months. Chan, who was unemployed and facing personal financial difficulties, admitted to stealing three cans of milk powder and 170 cans of milk powder worth nearly $8,000. He planned to sell the milk powder for cash, but was caught by police at his home on March 20. Chan pleaded remorseful and was sentenced backdated to March 22.

site_title: Pakistan opposition vows protests to press PM Nawaz Sharif to resign during investigation
summary: Pakistan's opposition party lawmakers demanded Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's resignation during an investigation into his finances, following a Supreme Court ruling that called for further investigation into corruption allegations. Opposition leader Imran Khan vowed to lead protests, citing the prime minister's loss of moral authority. The court ordered a joint investigation team to look into allegations surrounding Sharif's children's use of offshore companies to buy properties in London. The team has two months to complete its inquiry, with a special bench deciding on action thereafter.

site_title: South Korean presidential candidate denies role in attempted date rape
summary: South Korean presidential candidate Hong Joon Pyo denied his role in an attempted date rape, as described in his 2005 memoir, amid mounting voter outrage. The incident involved a roommate who attempted to drug a girl and engage in a sex crime, but she resisted and the drug was deemed ineffective. Hong claimed he only heard the story from other residents of his boarding house and did not participate. The controversy has fueled criticism of Hong's sexist remarks and behavior, with some comparing him to Donald Trump. Hong remains a strong candidate in the presidential election on May 9.

site_title: Eurozone economy hits 6-year high in April
summary: The eurozone economy reached a 6-year high in April, with the IHS Markit Composite Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) hitting 56.7 points, its highest reading since 2011. This indicates the economy is expanding, driven by strong demand, job creation, and widespread optimism about future prospects. The manufacturing sector saw a significant jump to 58 points, while the services sector rose to 56.2 points. Economists predict the economy will grow 0.7% in the second quarter, with exports boosted by a weak euro and job creation accelerating to nearly a decade high.

site_title: Some train, bus services extended on Labour Day eve: SMRT, SBS Transit
summary: Train services on the North-South, East-West, Circle Line, and Bukit Panjang LRT lines will be extended on April 30 and May 1, with last trains departing at 12:30am and 1:27am respectively. Some bus services, including those in Choa Chu Kang, Woodlands, and Bukit Panjang, will also be extended until after 1am. SBS Transit will extend train services on the North East and Downtown Lines by half an hour, with 19 bus services also being extended.

site_title: Thai king's coronation likely by the end of 2017: Deputy PM
summary: Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn's coronation is likely to occur by the end of 2017, according to Deputy PM Wissanu Krea-ngam. The coronation follows the king's ascension to the throne in December after his father King Bhumibol's death in October. The event is expected to signal the resumption of politics and potentially lead to a general election. The king has endorsed the new military-backed constitution, which critics argue gives the generals significant power, although restrictions on political activities remain in place until after the king's cremation and coronation.

site_title: Artbox Singapore moves 2 rows of shops, adds food queue system for crowd control
summary: Artbox Singapore has introduced crowd control measures after severe overcrowding at its pop-up event last weekend. The market has relocated two rows of shops, set up gates, and implemented a wireless paging system to inform visitors when their food is ready. A new system will also allow visitors to walk around while waiting, reducing congestion. The event will be open from April 21 to 23, with regular crowd status updates posted on social media. Admission remains free, with the most crowded times expected between 5pm and 8pm.

site_title: 'No doubt' Syria has retained chemical weapons: US Defence Secretary Jim Mattis
summary: US Defence Secretary Jim Mattis stated that Syria has "no doubt" retained chemical weapons, violating a 2013 agreement to remove them. Mattis warned President Bashar al-Assad's regime not to use them, citing a UN Security Council resolution and a US strike against a Syrian airbase. Assad's regime has denied using chemical weapons, but an Israeli assessment found Syria still possesses "a few tonnes" of chemical weapons. Mattis emphasized the need for diplomatic action to address the issue.

site_title: Football: Former England international defender and Spurs coach Ugo Ehiogu dies
summary: Former England international defender Ugo Ehiogu, 44, has died after suffering a heart attack at Tottenham's training headquarters. Ehiogu, who played for Aston Villa and Middlesbrough, was being treated in hospital. He had been the under-23 coach at Tottenham since 2014. The club announced his passing in a statement, describing it as "immense sadness." Ehiogu was capped four times by England during his playing career.

site_title: Football: Roma in the driving seat for Champions League, not Napoli, says Edin Dzeko
summary: Roma striker Edin Dzeko believes the pressure is on Napoli in the Serie A battle for second spot, as Roma are just two points ahead of their rivals. Despite Napoli's need to claim the second automatic Champions League spot, Dzeko thinks Roma have the psychological edge. Roma's Champions League-boosting win at Pescara and Juventus' 3-0 aggregate win over Barcelona have shifted the focus to Napoli, who must now secure second spot to qualify for the Champions League.

site_title: NBA: Cavs put Pacers on the brink, Grizzlies maul Spurs, Bucks run riot over Raptors
summary: The Cleveland Cavaliers stunned the Indiana Pacers 119-114 in Game 3 of their Eastern Conference playoff series, taking a 3-0 lead. LeBron James recorded 41 points, 13 rebounds, and 12 assists, while Channing Frye's clutch 3-pointer sealed the win. Meanwhile, the Memphis Grizzlies defeated the San Antonio Spurs 105-94, and the Milwaukee Bucks beat the Toronto Raptors 104-77, giving the Bucks a 2-1 lead in their series.

site_title: Thai royal agencies brought under control of new King Maha Vajiralongkorn
summary: Thailand's parliament has agreed to transfer control of royal agencies to new King Maha Vajiralongkorn, further increasing the monarch's authority. The agencies, including the Royal Guard Command and the Royal Court Security Police, will report directly to the king, following a pattern of the new constitution that enshrines more royal assertiveness. This move comes as King Vajiralongkorn reshapes the palace and asserts his authority, with his coronation expected later this year. The decision is seen as a sign of an increasingly absolutist monarch, with implications for the country's future political landscape.

site_title: Three more charged with rioting at Clarke Quay carpark
summary: Three more men, Fino Foo Zhi Peng, Terence Tan Chun Hon, and Chew Wen Cai, have been charged with rioting in connection with the April 16 attack at Clarke Quay carpark that left one man, Jeffrey Tan Jun Jie, dead. The men allegedly used a metal rod to strike three others, and are being remanded until April 27. They could face up to 10 years in jail and caning if found guilty. Nine suspects, aged 20 to 30, have been arrested in relation to the case, with investigations ongoing against the last three suspects.

site_title: Football: Ajax, Celta and Lyon join United in the Europa League semi-finals
summary: Ajax Amsterdam came back from 3-0 down to defeat Schalke 04 4-3 on aggregate in the Europa League quarter-finals, despite being down to 10 men. Celta Vigo also advanced with a 4-3 aggregate win over Racing Genk, while Olympique Lyonnais won a penalty shootout against Besiktas. Schalke's defeat marked the first time since 2004-05 that no German team would reach the Europa League semi-finals. Ajax's comeback was led by late goals from Nick Viergever and Amin Younes.

site_title: US Treasury Secretary welcomes Singapore's effort in combating illicit finance
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin welcomed Singapore's continued cooperation in combating illicit finance and preventing North Korea from abusing financial systems during a meeting with Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam on April 20, 2017. Mnuchin highlighted Singapore's hosting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) meetings next year and expressed his commitment to working with Tharman. The meeting also underscored the long-standing cooperation between the US and Singapore, with Tharman visiting Washington DC from April 18 to 23 to meet with top US officials and multilateral institutions.

site_title: Kishore loves SE Asia. So do I. But don't dismiss Europe
summary: A German journalist responds to Prof. Kishore Mahubani's statement that Europe represents the past and South-east Asia represents the future. The journalist argues that Europe still has life and potential, despite its current challenges. He highlights Europe's cultural richness, intellectual capacity, and resilience, citing examples of its artistic and literary heritage, such as Hieronymus Bosch's "The Garden of Earthly Delights." The journalist also notes that Europe's populist tide is a corrective to its past mistakes, and that it may lead to a stronger, more cooperative European Union in the future.

site_title: President Donald Trump invites Vietnam PM Nguyen Xuan Phuc to visit US
summary: US President Donald Trump has invited Vietnam's Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc to visit the United States, following a series of diplomatic efforts since Trump's election in November. This invitation comes as Vietnam seeks to strengthen ties with the US amid a maritime dispute with China in the South China Sea. Trump will also attend the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Vietnam in November. The visit is seen as part of efforts to promote US-Vietnam relations, which were boosted under former President Barack Obama. A letter of invitation was delivered by US National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster to Vietnam's Deputy Prime Minister.

site_title: Syria evacuees on move again after two-day delay
summary: Hundreds of Syrian evacuees began moving again after a 48-hour delay due to a bombing that killed dozens of civilians. Ten buses carrying civilians and loyalist fighters from Fuaa and Kafraya left a rebel-held transit point in Rashidin, Syria, heading towards government-controlled Aleppo. The evacuees were delayed after a bombing on Saturday killed 126 people, mostly children, at the same transit point. The evacuations, part of a deal brokered by Iran and Qatar, aim to exchange 8,000 people from Fuaa and Kafraya for 2,500 from opposition areas, with a second phase set to begin in June.

site_title: Punggol Road closed after fire at house, no one injured
summary: A fire broke out at a terraced house on Punggol Road in Singapore on Friday, April 21. The fire involved the contents of one bedroom and was extinguished using one water jet. No one was injured. Firefighters from the Singapore Civil Defence Force responded to the scene, closing the road to traffic for about two hours until 4:30pm. The fire was under control, and the road was reopened.

site_title: Complaints and queries over health-related advertisements on the rise
summary: Complaints and queries about health-related advertisements in Singapore have increased, with 28 cases reported last year, up from 19 in 2015 and 17 in 2014. The Advertising Standards Authority of Singapore (ASAS) found that 22 advertisements needed to be amended due to unsupported claims, including a health supplement maker's claim that its product improved sleep quality based on animal studies. ASAS also received feedback about mosquito trap and repellent advertisements, which it deemed ineffective against the Aedes aegypti mosquito.

site_title: North Korea's Air Koryo airline diversifies as it faces threats of sanctions
summary: North Korea's Air Koryo airline is diversifying its business, expanding into consumer products such as cigarettes, cola, gas stations, and taxis, amid threats of US sanctions. The airline's conglomerate owns these businesses, which share the same flying crane logo as the carrier. Despite the loss of international routes, Air Koryo now flies only to China and Russia, and has added new domestic flights. The US is considering tougher measures, including a global ban on Air Koryo, but this would not be binding on other nations unless China and Russia agree. Sanctions on Air Koryo are unlikely to have a significant impact on the North Korean economy.

site_title: Football: United pay heavy price for Europa League win with Rojo and Ibrahimovic injuries
summary: Manchester United manager Jose Mourinho expressed concern over injuries to striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic and defender Marcos Rojo, which may result in lengthy absences from the team. Both players suffered knee injuries during the Europa League quarter-final win over Anderlecht. Mourinho urged injured defenders Chris Smalling and Phil Jones to make a special effort to return quickly, and praised left-back Luke Shaw for his willingness to play despite cramps. Mourinho's team is currently without two central defenders and will need to accelerate the return of injured players to maintain their position in the team.

site_title: Three debt collectors jailed for being part of an unlawful assembly at Funan Digitalife Mall
summary: Three debt collectors, Andra Chew Keng Leng, Lim Boon Tiong, and David Tan, were jailed for their roles in an unlawful assembly at Funan Digitalife Mall in Singapore. They pleaded guilty to harassing a Chinese soup stall cashier and causing $880 in damages. The men, employed by debt recovery services, had attempted to collect a debt of $21,000 from the stall owner. Tan received a three-month jail sentence, Chew five months, and Lim four months. Sentencing for the remaining three men is scheduled for April 26.

site_title: 500-kg Egyptian woman sheds half of weight after emergency treatment in India
summary: Egyptian woman Eman Ahmed Abd El Aty, known as the "world's heaviest woman," has lost half of her weight, shedding 250kg in two months after undergoing emergency weight-loss surgery in India. Abd El Aty, 37, weighed 500kg when she arrived in Mumbai in February and was put on a special liquid diet before surgery. Her condition, caused by elephantiasis, has led to various health issues, including strokes, diabetes, and sleep deprivation. Doctors hope to put her on a trial obesity drug in six months and are monitoring her rapid weight loss.

site_title: Court approves judicial management for debt-laden Swissco
summary: A Singapore court approved Swissco Holdings Ltd's application for judicial management, a court-supervised process to help the debt-burdened rig and vessel charter firm return to financial health. The decision comes after Swissco reached an impasse with major lenders in 2016, citing US$255.7 million in outstanding debt repayable within one year. Judicial management will be overseen by EY's Angela Ee and Purandar Rao. This move follows other distressed companies in the offshore and marine industry, including Swiber Holdings and Ezra Holdings Ltd, which also filed for judicial management or bankruptcy protection.

site_title: Tourism Board counters Criminal Minds: Beyond Borders' depiction of Singapore
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board countered the negative portrayal of Singapore in the TV series Criminal Minds: Beyond Borders with photos of the city-state's picturesque views and accurate depictions. The board posted images of Marina Bay, Changi Airport, and Makansutra Gluttons Bay on its Facebook page, quipping that this was the "real Singaporean 'proverb'". The move was praised by Facebook users, who praised the board for a classy response. The Singapore Police Force also chimed in, highlighting the country's low crime rates and ranking first in a global law and order report.

site_title: A timeline of terror attacks in France
summary: A timeline of terror attacks in France highlights a series of violent incidents since 2015, including the Charlie Hebdo shootings, a Jewish supermarket attack, and a beheading at a gas plant. The violence has claimed over 200 lives and injured hundreds more. The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) has claimed responsibility for several attacks, including the 2015 Nice truck attack and the 2016 Bastille Day attack. The latest attack, on April 20, 2017, resulted in the death of a policeman and two others on the Champs Elysees.

site_title: Football: Atletico the team to watch in the Champions League semi-finals, warns Buffon
summary: Gianluigi Buffon warns that Atletico Madrid are the "trickiest" team in the Champions League semi-finals, citing their defensive strength and ability to rest players due to being out of the LaLiga title race. Juventus goalkeeper Buffon believes Atletico's edge over Real Madrid and Monaco could be decisive in the semi-finals, which will be played in Cardiff on June 3. Buffon's team, Juventus, are considered strong contenders for the title after beating Barcelona 3-0 in the first leg and holding them to a 0-0 draw.

site_title: Why did Najib appoint Hisham as special functions minister?: Sin Chew Daily Columnist
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Datuk Seri Najib Tun Razak appointed Defence Minister Datuk Seri Hishammuddin Hussein as special functions minister, sparking speculation about Najib's intentions and potential changes within the ruling party, Umno. The move is seen as an attempt by Najib to consolidate Hishammuddin's power and balance out rival factional forces within the party ahead of the upcoming general elections. Hishammuddin will oversee specific international affairs, while Najib and Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid focus on domestic issues. The appointment has raised concerns among Umno leaders and party supporters, potentially leading to a power struggle within the party.

site_title: Healthway Medical shareholders vote overwhelmingly for Gateway bond deal at EGM
summary: Healthway Medical Corp has approved a $60 million convertible bond deal with private equity fund Gateway Partners, securing its financial survival. The 95.2% majority vote from shareholders allows Gateway to issue the bonds in exchange for cash and a 39% stake in the enlarged company. This move may hinder Indonesian conglomerate Lippo Group's efforts to acquire a majority stake in Healthway, which had been struggling with cash flow issues and impaired relationships with staff and suppliers.

site_title: Asean leaders meeting in Manila a chance for grouping to show its relevance: The Nation
summary: Asean leaders are convening in Manila for their 30th meeting, aiming to demonstrate the bloc's relevance in a rapidly shifting global landscape. The bloc's traditional stabilizing role has become increasingly important amid the rise of new global powers, including China and India, and the unpredictable presidency of Donald Trump. Asean must strengthen its foundations and balance national and regional interests to maintain its unity and bargaining power, and to show its continued importance in maintaining global peace and stability.

site_title: Britain's Queen Elizabeth celebrates 91st birthday
summary: Britain's Queen Elizabeth celebrated her 91st birthday on April 21 in a low-key manner, with artillery gun salutes in London's Hyde Park and Tower of London. Born on April 21, 1926, she became queen at 25 in 1952 and still carries out official duties, although reducing engagements to family members. Despite her age, she remains popular among Britons, with royal aides ruling out abdication. The queen's official birthday is in June, marked by Trooping the Colour, and she has cut back on formal engagements, passing them to Prince Charles and grandsons Prince William and Prince Harry.

site_title: US police officer detained in Taiwan for travelling with gun in hand luggage
summary: US police officer Noell Grant, off-duty from California, was detained in Taiwan for a week after mistakenly bringing a handgun in her hand luggage. Grant arrived in Taiwan on April 13, intending to vacation, and notified authorities at the airport. She was barred from leaving until the matter is resolved, but allowed to move about. Federal officials acknowledged that security procedures at the Los Angeles airport were not followed, with a police officer passing through the checkpoint with a firearm. Grant's disciplinary measures are unclear upon her return to California.

site_title: Philippine fishermen accuse China of firing on vessel in South China Sea
summary: Philippine fishermen accuse China's coast guard of firing on their vessel, the Princess Johann, in disputed South China Sea waters on March 27. The incident occurred near a Chinese-occupied section of the Spratly archipelago, with no casualties reported. Philippine authorities are investigating, while China's Foreign Ministry has denied any involvement and claims ignorance of the incident. This would be the first hostile episode between the two countries in nearly a year, despite warming relations since Duterte's election in 2016.

site_title: Police believe Dortmund bomb suspect hoped to profit from drop in football club's share price
summary: Police in Germany have arrested a 28-year-old suspect, Sergej W, in connection with the April 2017 bomb attack on Borussia Dortmund's team bus. The motive behind the attack was financial gain, with prosecutors alleging that W hoped to profit from a drop in the team's share price. W had bought put options on the team's shares, which could have been sold at a predetermined price if the team's share price fell. The suspect had also taken out a loan to purchase the options, and police believe he could have gained millions of euros in profit.

site_title: Paris shooting: Gunman’s criminal past in focus as police hunt second suspect
summary: A gunman, identified as Karim Cheurfi, opened fire on a police vehicle in Paris, killing one officer and injuring two others, before being shot dead. Cheurfi, a French national with a history of armed assaults on law enforcement officers, had been convicted 16 years prior. A second suspect, Youssouf El Osri, is being hunted by police after being flagged by Belgian security services. ISIS claimed responsibility for the attack, and authorities found a Koran and a handwritten note praising the group at the scene.

site_title: South Korea on heightened alert as North Korea prepares for army celebration
summary: South Korea is on high alert ahead of North Korea's 85th anniversary of the Korean People's Army, with a large concentration of military hardware amassed on both sides of the border. US officials have noted a higher-than-usual level of activity by Chinese bombers, signaling a possible heightened state of readiness by Beijing. The US and South Korea have warned North Korea against a new nuclear test, amid concerns about the country's pursuit of a nuclear program. The situation remains tense, with speculation that North Korea may use the anniversary to test-launch a ballistic missile or conduct a nuclear test.

site_title: Criminal Minds' beyond belief depiction of Singapore: 6 other movies, TV shows featuring the little red dot
summary: The American TV series "Criminal Minds: Beyond Borders" sparked controversy with its inaccurate and stereotypical portrayal of Singapore, including describing Geylang as an "overcrowded slum with a thriving underworld." This is not an isolated incident, as other TV shows and movies have also depicted the country inaccurately, such as "Cold Feet," "Independence Day: Resurgence," "Equals," "Hitman: Agent 47," "Serangoon Road," and "Krrish." These depictions often involve altering or removing authentic locations to fit the narrative.

site_title: Company in Singapore we most want to work for? Google
summary: Google has been ranked as the most attractive employer in Singapore by Randstad, a recruitment firm, according to its "people's choice" survey. Google topped the list in all nine criteria, including work-life balance, job security, and career progression, winning the Randstad Employer Brand Award in its first year. Changi Airport Group came in second, while ExxonMobil took third place. This is the fourth consecutive year Changi Airport Group was ranked in the top three. The survey was based on responses from over 5,000 employees and job-seekers in Singapore.

site_title: Ocean drift analysis shows MH370 most likely in new search area: Australian scientists
summary: Australian scientists say a new ocean debris drift analysis suggests missing Malaysia Airlines MH370 is most likely within a 25,000 sq km zone, previously rejected by Australia and Malaysia. The analysis, conducted by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), uses actual Boeing 777 flaperon data, contradicting previous models. The findings increase confidence in the location, with experts noting the flaperon's arrival at Reunion island in 2015 makes sense. The report does not provide a specific location, but Australia will consider future requests to search for MH370 in conjunction with Malaysia's lead investigation.

site_title: New phase in financial regulation call for tech-savvy, collaborative central banks: Ravi Menon
summary: Monetary Authority of Singapore managing director Ravi Menon emphasized the need for tech-savvy, collaborative central banks as regulators enter a new phase, nine years after the 2008 financial crisis. Menon called for regulators to evaluate and fine-tune existing reforms, while also addressing technological changes and cyber risks. He urged regulators to work with financial institutions, fintech companies, and central banks to harness fintech, develop predictive analytics, and share cyber intelligence to enhance financial stability and mitigate risks.

site_title: Donald Trump praises China's efforts on North Korea, Pyongyang warns of 'super mighty' strike
summary: US President Donald Trump praised China's efforts to rein in North Korea, saying "some very unusual moves have been made" by Beijing. Chinese bombers have been seen at a higher-than-usual level, sparking speculation of a possible heightened state of readiness. North Korea warned the US of a "super mighty preemptive strike," but officials downplayed concerns, citing possible reasons such as defensive exercises or Chinese concerns over North Korea. The US and China have both warned against another nuclear bomb test, with Trump taking a hard line against North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

site_title: Australian court dismisses Chevron appeal in landmark tax case
summary: The Australian Federal Court has dismissed Chevron's appeal against a tax bill of A$340 million, covering five years from 2004 to 2008. The court ruled that Chevron underpaid taxes by setting up an intercompany credit facility with an abnormally high interest rate, reducing its taxable income. Chevron has expressed disappointment and plans to review the decision, potentially appealing to the High Court of Australia. The ruling has significant implications for multinational companies and transfer pricing cases, with the Australian Taxation Office welcoming the outcome.

site_title: SEA private equity investments boosted by interest in Internet sector: Bain & Co report
summary: South-east Asia's private equity and venture capital market saw a surge in deal flow last year, with investments reaching $6.8 billion, a 14% increase from the previous year. The Internet sector accounted for a quarter of total deal value, driven by the region's growing middle class. Despite rising interest rates, investors remain optimistic, with experts predicting another strong year in 2017. However, mounting competition is driving up prices, making it tougher to identify good investments, and private equity firms are looking for new ways to add value to their investments.

site_title: Sign up for April's Big Read Meet: Pankaj Mishra's new book Age Of Anger
summary: The Big Read Meet, a monthly non-fiction book club, will discuss Indian-born author Pankaj Mishra's new book "Age Of Anger" on April 26, 2017. The book challenges the Western narrative of progress, criticizing capitalism for creating a cycle of consumption that benefits the wealthy at the expense of the poor. The event, moderated by Senior Writer Cheong Suk-Wai, will be held at the Central Public Library in Singapore from 6:30pm, and registration is available at NLB e-Kiosks.

site_title: Apple Maps update for Europe includes focus on electric vehicles
summary: Apple has updated its Maps app in Europe to include locations of electric vehicle charging stations, partnering with Cirrantic's Moovility service to list re-juicing points for Tesla and Nissan cars. The feature is now available in the UK, with over 3,000 charging locations marked on the map. Apple is also adding public bicycle rental and drop-off points in London, New York, and Paris. The update aims to enhance user experience and compete with rival Google's mapping services, as part of Apple's broader efforts to improve its mapping products and attract more iPhone users.

site_title: It's been an amazing journey: PM Lee marks 5 years on Facebook with memorable stories of Singaporeans
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong marked his 5-year Facebook anniversary by sharing inspiring stories of Singaporeans, including foster mother Madam Indranee Elizabeth Nadisen, who has cared for 45 children over 35 years, and young people who have made a positive impact through charity work. Lee also shared personal updates and photos, showcasing his photography skills and interactions with former colleagues and Singaporeans living overseas. His page has amassed 1.1 million followers since he joined in April 2012.

site_title: Punchlines: April 21, 2017
summary: No summary provided as the article content is missing.

site_title: Boosting your body's iron levels could lead to better workplace performance
summary: A 2016 study by the World Health Organization found that iron deficiency anaemia is the most common form of anaemia, caused by insufficient iron in the body. The condition can lead to fatigue, pale skin, and decreased productivity at work, affecting up to 40% of women of reproductive age in Southeast Asia. Iron supplements, such as Sangobion, can help improve daily iron intake, but it's essential to consult a doctor for a proper diagnosis and follow daily recommended amounts to avoid excessive intake.

site_title: Pioneer leader Othman Wok gets special mention during Friday prayers at mosques
summary: Singaporean pioneer and former Cabinet minister Othman Wok was remembered in Friday prayers at mosques across the island, with special mention of his contributions to racial harmony. Wok, who died at 92, was the first Malay Cabinet minister in independent Singapore and championed multiracial policies. His efforts helped establish Singapore as a successful pluralistic society. The Islamic Religious Council of Singapore emphasized the importance of preserving peace and harmony, a shared national responsibility, and encouraged future generations to contribute to the betterment of the state and religion.

site_title: Rickmers to sell entire container fleet for US$113m to repay creditors
summary: Singapore-listed shipping trust Rickmers Maritime has agreed to sell its entire fleet of 14 containerships for US$113 million to Navios Maritime Partners. The sale proceeds will be used to repay senior secured loan facilities, with remaining funds distributed to unsecured creditors. Unitholders are not expected to recover any of their investments. The sale, subject to conditions, is expected to be completed by May 15, 2017. This move aims to deliver value to creditors quickly, avoiding uncertainties and risks in a prolonged winding-up process.

site_title: Fiesta on Orchard Road starting Friday aims to boost shopper numbers
summary: Orchard Road Business Association launches "Fiesta on a Great Street" to boost shopper numbers. The month-long event features pop-up food and beverage establishments, shopping promotions, and master classes. Local businesses such as Good Chance Popiah and Keng Eng Kee Seafood participate, donating 20% of sales to the Singapore Red Cross. The event aims to draw more people to the shopping district, which has seen a tepid retail scene, with retail sales excluding motor vehicles falling 2.6% last year. The association plans to use the event space to support future semi-pedestrianization plans for Orchard Road.
