site_title: New Christian Dior store in Tokyo a boost to Japan's efforts to woo more tourists
summary: Christian Dior launched its new Tokyo store with a rooftop fashion show, featuring designs from its first female creative director Maria Grazia Chiuri. The event drew inspiration from cherry blossoms and Dior's 1953 "Jardin japonais" dress. The new boutique occupies five floors in Ginza Six, a luxury mall in Tokyo's popular shopping district. This launch comes as Japan aims to nearly double its annual overseas visitors to 40 million by 2020, and Dior is focusing on the local market, targeting Japanese customers who are "super customers" for luxury and high fashion.

site_title: 18 nabbed in Malaysia after videos of bike gang go viral
summary: In Malaysia, 18 people have been detained for their involvement with Gang 24 after videos of a group of motorcyclists causing a commotion outside a school went viral. The videos, posted on Thursday night, showed the group shouting, revving engines, and holding up banners with gang symbols. Inspector General of Police Tan Sri Khalid Abu Bakar congratulated the Special Taskforce on Organised Crime for making swift arrests, with 13 students and 5 others detained so far. More arrests are expected to follow.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.19% lower on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.19% lower on Friday, contrary to the initial report of an increase. The benchmark Straits Times Index fell to 3,147.84, down 9.96 points, in early trade.

site_title: US, Indonesian companies sign 11 deals valued at more than $14 billion
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence announced 11 deals worth over $14 billion between US and Indonesian companies, primarily in energy and defense. The agreements include ExxonMobil supplying liquid natural gas, General Electric building electrical infrastructure, and Lockheed Martin providing technology for F-16 fighter jets. The deals aim to strengthen US-Indonesia relations amid US President Donald Trump's global trade study, which has raised concerns in Jakarta about potential trade abuse.

site_title: Asian stocks gain on Kuroda, US tax reform hopes
summary: Asian stocks rose on optimism for a US tax overhaul, with Tokyo shares gaining 0.8% and the S&P 500 Index experiencing its second-best day since March. Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's comments on keeping accommodative policy in place also boosted Tokyo shares. The yen weakened after dropping 0.4% on Thursday, and futures on the S&P 500 were up less than 0.1% ahead of the US tax reform plans.

site_title: EU to demand Britain pay for existing commitments, protect rights of EU citizens: Draft Brexit document
summary: Britain will be required to pay off existing commitments to Brussels, remain subject to EU courts, and allow relatives of European immigrants to settle in Britain after Brexit, according to a draft EU negotiating document. The EU aims to protect the rights of three million EU citizens living in Britain and extract cash from London to cover existing commitments. A "schedule of annual payments" will be fixed in euros, with the amount to be determined later. The document also ensures EU judges can hold Britain to the treaty after Brexit.

site_title: Paris attack overshadows last campaign day in French election first round
summary: France's presidential election first round overshadowed by a policeman's killing in an Islamist militant attack on the Champs Elysees. Centrist Emmanuel Macron held onto his frontrunner status with 65% projected votes against Marine Le Pen's 35%. Other candidates, including Francois Fillon and Jean-Luc Melenchon, narrowed Macron and Le Pen's lead. The attack, claimed by ISIS, highlights Le Pen's immigration and security concerns, while Macron attributes the risks to "zero risk" and blames Le Pen for being irresponsible and deceitful.

site_title: Make a Teochew favourite: Steamed song fish head
summary: A Singaporean food writer shares a recipe for steamed song fish head, a Teochew favorite, in honor of her late father who introduced her to the dish. The recipe involves steaming the fish head with garlic, shallots, ginger, and fermented black beans, then serving it with a black bean-based sauce. The dish is said to have a gelatinous texture and a strong umami flavor, and is often cooked with less oil and salt for a healthier option. The writer's father used to cook the dish for special occasions, and she recreates it here based on her memories.

site_title: Japanese lawmakers visit Yasukuni shrine for war dead, PM Shinzo Abe sends offering
summary: Japanese lawmakers, including Communications Minister Sanae Takaichi and Health Minister Yasuhisa Shiozaki, visited the Yasukuni Shrine on April 21, 2017, for the shrine's spring festival. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe sent a ritual offering, marking the first time he has done so since becoming premier in 2012. The visit could spark protests in Asia, where the shrine is seen as a symbol of Japan's past militarism. Abe has sought to improve ties with China and South Korea by avoiding in-person visits to the shrine.

site_title: Paris shooting: Suspect had history of attempting to kill police officers
summary: A 39-year-old suspect in Thursday's Islamic State-claimed shooting on Paris's Champs-Élysées has been identified and killed in return fire. The suspect, with a history of attempting to kill police officers, was previously arrested in February on suspicion of plotting to kill officers but was released due to lack of evidence. He had been convicted of three counts of attempted murder, including two against police officers, in 2005. The suspect's past convictions date back to 2001, when he seriously wounded two police officers. Officials are investigating whether he had accomplices for the attack.

site_title: Prince's one-year death anniversary marked by celebration - and also controversy
summary: Prince's one-year death anniversary was marked by a celebration at Paisley Park, with concerts, panel talks, and a dance party. However, the event was marred by controversy over the commercialization of his legacy. A six-song EP, Deliverance, was set for release but was halted due to a dispute between the estate and a sound engineer, George Boxill, who released the music on an independent label. The estate accused Boxill of seeking to profit from Prince's music, while Boxill claimed to be respecting the star's wishes and donating most proceeds to the estate.

site_title: Free-marketeer Francois Fillon fights on despite heavy blow from fake jobs scandal
summary: Conservative candidate Francois Fillon's presidential campaign in France was hit by a fake jobs scandal, with his wife Penelope reportedly paid hundreds of thousands of euros for little work. Fillon has denied wrongdoing and claims to be the victim of a government plot to destroy his candidacy. Despite resignations and pressure to withdraw, Fillon is fighting on, trailing behind far-right leader Marine Le Pen and centrist Emmanuel Macron in the polls. Fillon's campaign now faces a wider investigation into luxury gifts and alleged hypocrisy on economic policies.

site_title: Flash floods in some parts of Singapore on wet Friday morning
summary: Heavy rain caused flash floods in Singapore on Friday morning, with cars splashing through puddles on Upper Cross Street. The National Environment Agency (NEA) issued a "high flood risk" warning for Tanjong Pagar Road and Craig Road, as moderate to heavy thundery showers with gusty winds affected many areas from 7:45am to 8:45am.

site_title: Panama Papers law firm boss says fallout has spurred tax shelter boom in US
summary: The co-founder of Mossack Fonseca, Juergen Mossack, claims that the fallout from the Panama Papers scandal has led to a "thriving" boom in tax shelter creation in the US, with jurisdictions like Delaware and Nevada experiencing a significant increase in incorporations. Mossack notes that Panama, where the scandal originated, has implemented new legislation and transparency measures, leading clients to shift to US jurisdictions with "zero transparency." This shift has resulted in a 30% decrease in new tax shelters created in Panama, while US jurisdictions have seen a rise in tax shelter creation.

site_title: Donald Trump to order US Treasury to delve into taxes, post-crisis reforms
summary: US President Donald Trump is ordering the Treasury Department to review tax burdens and post-financial crisis reforms. Trump will issue an executive order directing the Treasury to reduce tax burdens and review the Dodd-Frank Wall Street reform law, including the Orderly Liquidation Authority and the Financial Stability Oversight Council. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin will assess significant tax regulations and create a sweeping overhaul. The review aims to cut out parts of the law that hinder banks and insurance companies from doing business, and will be completed within 180 days.

site_title: US teacher accused of kidnapping student arrested
summary: Tad Cummins, a 50-year-old former Tennessee high school teacher, was arrested in northern California after a month-long search for him and his 15-year-old student, Elizabeth Thomas. The pair was found safe in a remote cabin near the Oregon border. Cummins faces charges of aggravated kidnapping and sexual contact with a minor. He was arrested after a tip led authorities to the cabin, and Thomas will be flown back to Tennessee to be reunited with her family. Cummins' wife reported him missing after finding a note at their home, and authorities believe he had been grooming Thomas for an unknown purpose.

site_title: Football: Rashford fires United into Europa League semi-finals
summary: Manchester United secured a 3-2 aggregate victory over Anderlecht in the Europa League quarterfinals, advancing to the semi-finals. Marcus Rashford scored the winning goal in extra time, securing a 2-1 win at Old Trafford. However, the victory came at a cost as defender Marcos Rojo and forward Zlatan Ibrahimovic suffered possibly serious knee injuries. Rashford's goal secured a spot in the Europa League semi-finals, keeping Manchester United's Champions League hopes open.

site_title: City Harvest Church founder Kong Hee and 4 leaders surrender at State Courts to start jail terms
summary: City Harvest Church founder Kong Hee and four other church leaders surrendered at the State Courts in Singapore, starting their jail terms for misappropriating $50 million in church funds. Kong, 52, was sentenced to 3½ years, the longest term, while Sharon Tan faces 7 months, and the others received sentences ranging from 1½ to 3 years. The leaders had their jail terms reduced from 8 years to 7 months to 3½ years after the High Court reduced their charges. The church has asked its members to continue praying for the convicted leaders and their families.

site_title: No hot spots detected, low chance of transboundary haze in coming days, says NEA
summary: Singapore's haze situation improved after a Sumatra squall cleared hazy conditions on April 21, 2017. The National Environment Agency (NEA) reported no significant hot spots or smoke haze detected in the nearby region. The 24-hour Pollutant Standards Index (PSI) reached its highest level at 89 in the south, but the likelihood of transboundary haze affecting Singapore in the coming days is low. The air quality is expected to remain moderate, allowing most people to continue their normal activities.

site_title: Ascott Reit posts 14% fall in Q1 DPU after share placement, absence of one-off gain
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) reported a 14% drop in Q1 2017 distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.51 Singapore cents, mainly due to a share placement and absence of one-off gains. Revenue grew 5% to S$111.3 million, driven by the acquisition of Sheraton Tribeca New York Hotel in 2016. The trust's asset size is expected to reach S$5.3 billion with recent acquisitions, solidifying its position as the largest hospitality Reit.

site_title: US Fed fines Deutsche Bank US$156.6m for forex violations
summary: The US Federal Reserve fined Deutsche Bank $156.6 million for violating foreign exchange rules and failing to detect traders using chat rooms to communicate with competitors. The bank agreed to improve its oversight of foreign exchange trades as part of the agreement. The fine stems from a four-year review of dealings at the bank, which found gaps in compliance with the Volcker Rule. Deutsche still faces a probe by New York's Department of Financial Services into its automated trading platform's potential manipulation of foreign exchange rates.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, April 21 edition
summary: A French policeman was shot dead and two others wounded in a Paris shooting on April 20, 2017, before the gunman was killed by officers. A second suspect remains on the loose. President Trump ordered an investigation into US steel imports to bolster American production and jobs. A Slovakia-based company unveiled a flying car priced over $1 million, with pre-orders expected to begin by 2020. An Italian court ruled a mobile phone caused a benign brain tumor in a work-related case. Manchester United advanced to the Europa League semi-finals with a 3-2 aggregate victory over Anderlecht.

site_title: Nasdaq jumps 0.9 per cent, ends at record close as US stocks rally
summary: US stocks surged on Thursday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index reaching a record close, up 0.9% to 5,916.78. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also gained, 0.9% and 0.8% respectively. Investors put aside concerns over geopolitics, focusing on better earnings and optimism about the US economy. Analysts estimate corporate earnings will rise 10% in the first quarter, while President Trump's tax cuts are seen as a priority. Companies like American Express and United States Steel saw significant gains, while Verizon lost 1.1% after reporting a drop in earnings.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust sees 2.4% rise in Q2 DPU
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a 2.4% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) for the second quarter, reaching 2.51 Singapore cents. The trust's distributable income increased 3.5% to S$20 million, driven by stronger results from its Australian portfolio and a stronger Australian dollar. Gross revenue rose 3.2% to S$40.2 million, with net property income up 4.1% to S$30 million. The trust's portfolio had a committed occupancy rate of 91.8% as of end-March, with upgrades to China Square Central and Alexandra Technopark expected to be completed by mid-2019 and mid-2018, respectively.

site_title: France's Fillon cancels Friday election campaign event after Paris shooting
summary: French conservative presidential candidate Francois Fillon has cancelled a planned campaign event in the French Alps on Friday following a shooting in Paris that killed a policeman. The shooting occurred during a televised debate, just days before Sunday's election, which is the first round of a two-part election. Fillon cited the incident as the reason for his cancellation, and campaigning was set to wrap up on Friday. The circumstances of the shooting are unclear, with the assailant also killed. The election is scheduled to take place on Sunday.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde: A far-right Le Pen victory in France would mean 'major disorder'
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde warned of "major disorder" if far-right candidate Marine Le Pen wins France's presidential elections. Le Pen's pledge to leave the euro zone and hold a referendum on EU exit could lead to economic upheaval. Lagarde emphasized the importance of trade integration and liberalization, citing the European Union's role in maintaining peace after World War II. She urged caution against nationalist sentiment, highlighting the need to preserve the EU's harmonization efforts.

site_title: Tesla recalls 53,000 of its Model S, Model X cars
summary: Tesla is recalling 53,000 Model S and Model X cars globally due to a parking brake issue, where a small gear may have been manufactured improperly by a third-party supplier. The issue has caused no accidents or injuries, but less than 5% of the vehicles being recalled may be affected. The recall is expected to take less than 45 minutes to complete, and Tesla will send an official notice to its customers. The company is working with supplier Freni Brembo to obtain replacement parts.

site_title: Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage won't stand in Britain's snap election
summary: Former UK Independence Party leader Nigel Farage announced he won't stand in Britain's upcoming snap election, instead traveling to European cities to campaign for a good Brexit deal. Farage, who spearheaded the Brexit campaign, will exert pressure on fellow MEPs. UKIP leader Paul Nuttall will likely face challenges in the election, with the party struggling to define itself post-referendum. Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party is expected to gain support, according to a recent poll, with Farage predicting a "huge" lead for the Conservatives.

site_title: The ST Guide To... getting a good night's sleep
summary: Depriving oneself of sleep is a form of torture, as research shows that prolonged sleep deprivation increases the risk of diabetes, stroke, heart attacks, Alzheimer's disease, and certain cancers. To improve sleep, experts recommend hiding clocks, skipping the snooze button, using a body clock, getting out of malls, keeping lights low, going analogue, keeping pets out of the bedroom, recording snoring, trying sleep apps, and making time for sleep. By implementing these tips, individuals can improve their sleep quality and wake up feeling refreshed and alert.

site_title: Nigeria charges 53 over gay wedding
summary: Nigerian prosecutors have charged 53 men with conspiracy to organize a gay wedding, punishable by up to 14 years in jail. The suspects, mostly students aged 20-30, were arrested after attending the alleged wedding in a hotel. The couple managed to escape, while the remaining suspects pleaded not guilty and were released on bail until May 8. Nigeria's laws, which combine secular and Islamic codes, prohibit gay relationships and impose penalties ranging from 10 to 14 years in prison.

site_title: Clashes erupt between protesters and police in Venezuela
summary: Clashes broke out in Caracas, Venezuela, on April 20, 2017, between protesters and police during a demonstration against President Nicolas Maduro. Thousands of demonstrators gathered at a freeway, where riot police, backed by an armored truck, attempted to disperse them. The protesters retaliated with rocks and tear gas, leading to violent exchanges between the two groups. The incident occurred amidst a large-scale rally against Maduro's government.

site_title: Stoke game a 'must-win' for Swansea in relegation fight
summary: Swansea City manager Paul Clement describes their upcoming match against Stoke City as a "must-win" to avoid relegation. The Welsh side is two points behind 17th-placed Hull City, with only five games left in the season. Clement hopes his players will respond to the pressure and secure a win, as a loss would make their season "for nothing." A win against Stoke would be a crucial step towards staying up, with Clement also expressing interest in speaking to former Chelsea captain John Terry about a potential move to Swansea if they avoid relegation.

site_title: Paris shooting: ISIS claims responsibility, attacker is reportedly a known terror suspect
summary: A shooting on Paris's Champs-Élysées claimed by ISIS has left one dead and two wounded, including a police officer. The attacker, identified as Abu Yussef, a Belgian fighter for ISIS, was killed in return fire. The incident occurred just days before France's presidential election, prompting a state of emergency and increased security measures. Far-right leader Marine Le Pen and conservative Francois Fillon cancelled campaign events, and polls show voters are becoming increasingly concerned about terrorism and security. The attack is the latest in a string of atrocities by extremists in France since 2015.

site_title: Rex Tillerson to meet with South-east Asian foreign ministers in Washington in May
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson will meet with the foreign ministers of South-east Asian countries on May 4 in Washington. The meeting was requested by the 10-member Association of South-east Asian Nations (ASEAN) to engage with the new US administration. Discussions will focus on trade, territorial claims in the South China Sea, trafficking, crime, and other regional issues. The meeting is ahead of planned regional summits in November.

site_title: Italian court rules mobile phone caused tumour
summary: An Italian court has ruled that excessive mobile phone use caused a 57-year-old executive to develop a benign brain tumour. Roberto Romeo testified that his work duties required him to use his mobile for 3-4 hours daily for 15 years, leading to a 23% damage to his bodily function. The court awarded Romeo a state-funded pension of €500 a month, recognizing a causal link between mobile phone use and the tumour. This is the first time a court has made such a ruling, which has sparked debate about the potential health risks of mobile phone use.

site_title: Golf: Tiger Woods undergoes back surgery, could be out six months
summary: Tiger Woods, 41, has undergone another back surgery, four times since 2014, to alleviate pain in his back and leg. The minimally invasive procedure aims to relieve back spasms and pain, with Woods expected to be away from competitive golf for six months. He has not played since February due to back spasms and will rest, begin therapy, and treatment before resuming activity, typically taking around six months to return to full activity. Woods' back issues stem from previous herniations and operations, causing sciatica and severe back and leg pain.

site_title: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad barred as Iran Guardians pick vote candidates
summary: Iran's Guardian Council has approved six candidates, including President Hassan Rouhani, to run in the May 19 presidential election. Former president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was barred, along with his ally Hamid Baghaie, due to their failure to meet the council's requirements. The approved candidates include hardliners Ebrahim Raisi and Mostafa Mirsalim, as well as moderate cleric Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf and Rouhani's ally Eshaq Jahangiri. The election comes as Iran faces economic stagnation and high unemployment, creating an opportunity for conservative opponents to challenge Rouhani's moderate stance.

site_title: Football: Ex-England defender Ehiogu collapses at Spurs training ground
summary: Former England defender Ugo Ehiogu, 44, collapsed at Tottenham's training ground on April 20, requiring hospital treatment. The under-23 coach, who played for Aston Villa, Middlesbrough, and others, is receiving well-wishes from the club. Ehiogu, capped four times by England, had been on Tottenham's coaching staff since 2014. His condition is currently unknown.

site_title: Olympic high jumper Germaine Mason dies in motorbike crash
summary: High jump star Germaine Mason, a British Olympic silver medalist, died in a motorbike crash outside Jamaica's capital, Kingston. Mason, 34, lost control of his motorcycle on a main road at around 4:20 am and was pronounced dead at hospital. He held the Jamaican high jump record and competed for Britain, winning a silver medal at the 2008 Beijing Olympics. Tributes poured in from across the athletics world, including sprinter Michael Frater, who described Mason as a "friend from high school days" and was "just devastated" by the news.

site_title: Russia's richest get richer in 2017, ranking shows
summary: Russia's 200 richest individuals became US$100 billion richer in 2017, with their total worth increasing to US$460 billion, driven by rising commodities prices and strengthened oil markets. The number of Russian billionaires grew from 77 to 96, with Leonid Mikhelson, Alexei Mordashov, and Vladimir Lisin leading the list. The ranking saw its highest cutoff at US$500 million, and the majority of the wealthy are men. However, the recovery in Russian markets has not benefited most Russians, with real household earnings falling 2.5% year-on-year.

site_title: Explorer Ernest Shackleton's great grandson drives car across Antarctic
summary: British tech entrepreneur Patrick Bergel has completed the first car journey across the Antarctic, 100 years after his great grandfather Ernest Shackleton's failed attempt on foot. Bergel, 46, drove a modified 2.2-litre diesel car across the 5,800km route in 30 days, encountering temperatures as low as -28°C. The trip, which started at Union Glacier, passed the South Pole and ended at Leverett Glacier. Bergel used GPS and expert advice to avoid ice caps and successfully completed the journey, stating that he hoped his great grandfather would be proud of his achievement.

site_title: 2 students filmed fighting in video disciplined, counselled: Hai Sing Catholic Secondary School
summary: Two students at Hai Sing Catholic Secondary School in Singapore were disciplined and counselled after a fight was filmed at the school canteen on April 17. The video, published on citizen journalism site Stomp, showed one boy being punched and headlocked by another. The victim called the police after the incident. The school took "appropriate disciplinary measures" and counselled the students, while also working with their parents to help them learn from the incident. The matter is currently under police investigation.

site_title: Flying car costing more than $1 million goes on show in Monaco
summary: A Slovakia-based company, AeroMobil, unveiled the commercial design for a flying car priced over $1 million, set for pre-orders with deliveries by 2020. The teardrop-shaped vehicle can switch to flight mode in under three minutes and requires driving and pilot licenses. Owners will need to find approved airfields for takeoff, with the company aiming to produce up to 500 units of the first commercially available edition. AeroMobil's flying car complies with air and road regulations, but must overcome flight safety issues before becoming mainstream.

site_title: IMF's Christine Lagarde downplays differences with Trump White House
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde downplayed differences with the Trump White House over free trade, stating she has reason to believe progress will be made. The IMF is gathering in Washington to discuss trade liberalization, financial regulation, and climate change amid signs of friction with the White House. Lagarde emphasized the need for a "fair and level playing field" with no protectionist measures, while also warning against the lure of protectionism. The IMF forecasts global growth at 3.5% for this year, citing improving conditions in Asia and Europe.

site_title: Football: Spurs still the underdogs ahead of FA Cup semi-final, says Mauricio Pochettino
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Mauricio Pochettino believes his team is still underdogs ahead of the FA Cup semi-final against Chelsea, despite Tottenham's impressive form. Chelsea, favored to win, have looked vulnerable in recent defeats, while Tottenham have built up a head of steam with seven consecutive league wins. Pochettino acknowledges Chelsea's experience and managerial prowess, but is proud of Tottenham's progress and momentum, which has seen them reduce the gap to the top four and challenge for the Premier League title.

site_title: Donald Trump orders steel imports probe in ‘fight for American workers’
summary: President Donald Trump has ordered an expedited probe into US steel imports under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act, citing a "fight for American workers and American-made steel." The investigation aims to protect US production and jobs, with the Commerce Department expected to complete the probe within 50 days. The move is seen as a response to the rise of steel imports, which have increased by 19.6% in the first two months of this year, and is likely to impact countries such as China, Germany, and others that have faced stiff duties on certain steel exports to the US.

site_title: Football: Jurgen Klopp facing Liverpool backline dilemma against Crystal Palace
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp faces a defensive dilemma ahead of Sunday's Premier League clash with Crystal Palace due to injuries to Joel Matip, Ragnar Klavan, and Lucas Leiva. The trio, along with injured midfielders Adam Lallana and Jordan Henderson, are uncertain for the match. Klopp is concerned about Palace's aerial threat, led by Christian Benteke, and warns that if Liverpool focus solely on him, they'll be vulnerable to Wilfried Zaha and Andros Townsend. The match is crucial for Liverpool's top-four spot and Champions League qualification.

site_title: Football: Barcelona look to 'El Clasico' for redemption after Champions League humbling
summary: Real Madrid hosts arch-rival Barcelona in "El Clasico" on Sunday, seeking a crucial win to claim their first LaLiga title in five years. The match could leave Barcelona trailing by three points with only five games remaining. Real Madrid, unbeaten since February, will rely on Cristiano Ronaldo, who has scored five goals in his last two appearances, including a hat-trick against Bayern Munich. The match will be a significant test for Barcelona, who have lost two of their last five games, and will be without forward Neymar due to suspension.

site_title: New Prince music release blocked by US court
summary: A US judge has blocked the release of Prince's new music, "Deliverance", due to a confidentiality agreement with his former sound engineer, Ian Boxhill. The six-song EP was set to be released on the anniversary of Prince's death. The Minnesota district court ordered Boxhill to hand over the original recordings to Prince's estate, citing a breach of the confidentiality agreement. The release was halted just hours before it was scheduled to go on sale, with the title track already reaching the No. 1 spot on the iTunes rock songs charts.

site_title: Turkey's Erdogan to meet US President Trump on May 16-17
summary: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan announced plans to meet US President Donald Trump in Washington on May 16-17, marking their first meeting since Trump's inauguration in January. The meeting comes amid deteriorated ties between the US and Turkey since a failed military coup in July, with Turkey seeking the extradition of cleric Fethullah Gulen. Erdogan expressed optimism for improved relations under Trump, citing their recent phone calls and the narrow win of his constitutional referendum, which granted him sweeping new powers. The meeting is seen as a significant step in repairing strained US-Turkey relations.

site_title: NFL: Aaron Hernandez reportedly found with 'John 3:16' written on his forehead
summary: Former NFL player Aaron Hernandez was found dead in his prison cell with the Bible verse "John 3:16" written on his forehead. Hernandez, 27, had been serving a life sentence for a separate murder conviction after being acquitted of double murder charges. Authorities say he hanged himself with a bed sheet, without leaving a suicide note, and no one was under suicide watch at the time. An investigation into his death is ongoing, and his death may impact his family's compensation from the NFL and Patriots.

site_title: 31-year-old man dies after attack at Clarke Quay carpark; 9 arrested for rioting
summary: A 31-year-old man, identified as Mr Tan Jun Jie, died after being attacked in a carpark at Clarke Quay on April 16. He suffered bleeding in the brain and was taken to Singapore General Hospital, where he died on April 19. Nine men, aged 20-30, were arrested for rioting and are facing charges of up to 10 years in jail and caning. Three have already been charged, while investigations are ongoing against the remaining three suspects.

site_title: Federal International inks MOU with China Merchants for Indonesia oil projects
summary: Federal International has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with China Merchants Industry Holdings Co (CMIH) to collaborate on oil and gas projects in Indonesia. The partnership will leverage Federal International's expertise in flowline control products and CMIH's engineering, procurement, and construction capabilities. The MOU aims to enhance the group's strategic advantage and secure oil and gas projects in Indonesia. The partnership is expected to benefit from Federal International's established business ties and network in the South-east Asia region, particularly in Indonesia.

site_title: Wall Street opens higher as earnings season kicks into gear
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Thursday as investors became more optimistic about the first-quarter earnings season. The S&P 500 rose 0.29%, with 75% of reported companies beating expectations, and profits estimated to have risen 10.8% in the quarter. Despite this, geopolitical concerns and mounting tensions between North Korea and the US kept investors cautious. Brent crude futures fell 6 cents due to bloated inventories. The Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq Composite also rose, with the financial index leading the gains.

site_title: A unit of Manhattan Resources served with injunction order
summary: A unit of Manhattan Resources, MRN, has been served with an injunction order by Ningbo City Yinzhou District Court in China. The plaintiff, MCC TianGong Group Corporation, claims MRN owes services under a 2013 agreement, which MRN denies. MRN's 45.3 million yuan deposits will be frozen. The company intends to vigorously defend against the claims and has sufficient cash to meet its financial obligations. MRN is seeking legal advice on the next steps.

site_title: Uphold by-laws to weed out vandalism in new estates
summary: New HDB estates in Singapore are plagued by opportunistic salesmen and contractors posting advertisements and fliers on walls, lifts, and common areas, defacing public property and giving the estates a rundown appearance. Despite numerous complaints, the town council has failed to take action. The Town Councils Act requires town councils to uphold by-laws, but it appears that this law is not being enforced. The contact details of the perpetrators are often provided on the advertisements, but no action has been taken against them. This vandalism is seen as a blatant disregard for the law.

site_title: UN condemns North Korea missile launch after Russia, US spar over words
summary: The United Nations Security Council condemned North Korea's missile test, calling for an end to nuclear and missile programs. The statement, delayed due to US-Russia disagreements over language, demanded no further nuclear tests and prepared to consider additional sanctions. The council's traditional condemnation was rare, with the US and Russia sparring over wording amid tensions over Syria's civil war. The US dropped the words "through dialogue" to avoid "overly narrowing" the solution, while Russia requested its inclusion. China agreed to the statement.

site_title: A look back at the Abu Dhabi-Malaysia 1MDB dispute
summary: Malaysia and Abu Dhabi have reached a settlement on a $1.75 billion debt dispute involving 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB), a scandal-scarred state investment firm. The agreement, expected to be signed Friday, resolves a bitter dispute between the two countries that strained bilateral ties. The settlement plan, reached in April 2017, was facilitated by senior financial executives and high-level approvals from both governments, marking a significant step towards resolving the international money-laundering probe surrounding 1MDB.

site_title: Labour's Jeremy Corbyn sets election tone, targeting British establishment
summary: Opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn has pledged to defeat a "cosy cartel" at the heart of British politics in a snap election called by Prime Minister Theresa May. Corbyn has vowed to impose higher taxes on the wealthy and crack down on powerful corporations, tapping into widespread voter frustration with the political elite. Despite opinion polls pointing to a heavy defeat, Corbyn aims to assert control over his divided Labour Party and convince the country that the people, not the elite, should prevail. The election, set for June 8, is seen as a challenge to Corbyn's leadership and the Labour Party's position on Brexit.

site_title: AsiaMedic to buy LuyeEllium for S$42 million
summary: AsiaMedic has agreed to acquire LuyeEllium Healthcare for S$42.2 million. LuyeEllium, a hospital management services provider in South Korea and China, will become a wholly-owned subsidiary of AsiaMedic upon completion. The acquisition aims to broaden AsiaMedic's healthcare services offerings, including non-clinical support and consultancy services. The deal will be funded through the issuance of 527.1 million new shares at eight cents per share, with an independent valuer to prepare a valuation report on LuyeEllium.

site_title: ST Exclusive: Malaysia, Abu Dhabi to settle dispute over 1MDB debt
summary: Malaysia and Abu Dhabi have reached a settlement over a dispute involving billions of dollars in debt obligations of 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB). The agreement requires Malaysia to repay Abu Dhabi $1.2 billion by the end of the year, with the bulk of the payment coming from the sale of fund units. The deal also calls for negotiations to resolve a dispute over $3.5 billion in cash advances and payments. The settlement aims to weaken international legal challenges confronting Prime Minister Najib Razak's administration over the 1MDB saga.

site_title: 2 men arrested for separate loanshark cases in areas including Ang Mo Kio, Bedok and Yishun
summary: Two men aged 30 and 27 were arrested in Singapore for separate loanshark cases in Ang Mo Kio, Bedok, and Yishun. Police seized mobile phones, debtors' records, and markers from the suspects. In one case, housing board flats were vandalized with paint and loanshark graffiti. Both suspects will be charged under the Moneylenders Act, which carries fines of at least $5,000 and up to $50,000, as well as up to five years in jail and six strokes of the cane. The arrests follow a crackdown on loanshark harassment in the country.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust reports sharply lower Q1 payout
summary: Cache Logistics Trust reported a sharply reduced distribution per unit of 1.8 Singapore cents for Q1, down 11.7% from the same period last year. Revenue dropped 2.9% to S$27.1 million and net property income fell 5.8% to S$20.8 million. The decline was attributed to lower revenue from divested assets and higher property expenses. Despite this, the trust's portfolio occupancy improved to 97.2% and lease-to-expiry was 3.6 years. The trust manager aims to rebalance and grow revenue outside of Singapore through strategic acquisitions.

site_title: Iran's foreign minister says US must meet own obligations for nuclear deal
summary: Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif said the US must meet its obligations under the 2015 nuclear deal, rather than making accusations against Iran. Zarif's comments followed US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson's remarks accusing Iran of destabilizing the Middle East. Zarif tweeted that the US should "fulfill its own commitments" and criticized the US accusations of Iran's role as a state sponsor of terrorism, stating that Iran is compliant with the nuclear accord. The US is reviewing its policy towards Iran, including the 2015 nuclear deal.

site_title: 16-year-old boy arrested after attacking girl with knife at Bedok View Secondary School
summary: A 16-year-old boy from Bedok View Secondary School was arrested for attacking a female student with a kitchen knife on Wednesday. The incident occurred due to relationship issues, and the girl, a Secondary 3 student, sustained a minor 1cm-deep wound. The boy was arrested at 11:05am and police investigations are ongoing. The school is providing support to the affected students and is cooperating with the police investigation.

site_title: SEA Games 2017: More than 800 make first cut to represent Singapore in Kuala Lumpur
summary: More than 800 athletes have been selected to represent Singapore at the SEA Games in Kuala Lumpur, with 840 athletes from 34 sports making the initial cut. The selection committee, chaired by Tan Chuan-Jin, will review athletes' qualifying marks, with those yet to meet the mark having until mid-June to do so. The Kuala Lumpur Games will feature 405 events across 38 sports, with Singapore looking to build on its record-breaking performance at the 2015 SEA Games, where it won 84 golds and 102 bronzes.

site_title: Art book on historic buildings recognised at industry book awards
summary: An art book titled "Building Memories: People. Architecture. Independence" about four iconic Singaporean buildings won the top Book of the Year award and Best Illustrated Non-Fiction Title at the Singapore Book Awards. The 136-page interactive book features historic buildings such as the National Library and National Theatre, and was praised by the judging panel for its beautiful production and presentation. The book's publisher, Achates 360, is a small independent company that was also surprised by the win, which confirms that publishing a book goes beyond just text.

site_title: Two new locally transmitted Zika cases at Glasgow Road: NEA
summary: Two new locally transmitted Zika cases were confirmed in Singapore, both residents of the Glasgow Road area, according to the National Environment Agency (NEA) on April 20, 2017. This new cluster, combined with another confirmed case at Nouvelle Park, expands the total cases in the area. Vector control operations and outreach efforts are underway. The NEA urges residents to maintain vigilance and eliminate mosquito breeding habitats to prevent further transmission of the virus.

site_title: The Straits Times' News In A Minute: April 20, 2017
summary: A joint team attempted to capture mischievous monkeys at Segar Road, but details are not provided. In other news, 13 foreigners were arrested for vice activities in Kaki Bukit's forested areas. A man escaped with minor injuries after his car was crushed by a trailer in the Tuas tunnel.

site_title: Chinese tycoon Guo Wengui accuses Beijing of meddling in interview
summary: Chinese property tycoon Guo Wengui accused Beijing of meddling in a live interview with the US Voice of America broadcaster, where he planned to reveal corruption allegations against high-ranking Communist Party officials. The interview was abruptly stopped after Guo mentioned "the Wang Qishan situation", which is widely considered a reference to Chinese President Xi Jinping's top lieutenant. Guo claims Beijing used Interpol to pressure the broadcaster into cutting off the interview, despite Chinese officials declining to respond to his allegations. Guo vows to continue releasing documents and information despite the interference.

site_title: Tennis: Murray crashes in Monte Carlo Masters,  Djokovic struggles on
summary: Andy Murray lost in the third round of the Monte Carlo Masters to Spain's Albert Ramos-Vinolas, surrendering a 4-0 lead in the decisive third set. Murray's 2017 season has hit another setback, following a second-round loss at Indian Wells. Ramos-Vinolas' victory marked his first win over a world number one and sent him to the quarter-finals. Meanwhile, Rafael Nadal dominated Alexander Zverev 6-1, 6-1, and Novak Djokovic edged Pablo Carreno Busta 6-2, 4-6, 6-4.

site_title: Retired Filipino cop who says he was a hitman seeks refuge in Singapore
summary: A retired Filipino police officer, Arturo Lascanas, has sought refuge in Singapore after revealing his involvement with the Davao Death Squad (DDS), a secret killing squad he claims was responsible for the extrajudicial killings of approximately 300 people, including criminals, drug addicts, and political opponents. Lascanas, who served as a hitman from 1989 to 2015, accused former Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte of giving orders for the killings. Lascanas' allegations have been denied by the Duterte administration, but he hopes to bring closure to the families of the victims and face the consequences of the law.

site_title: Sexual violence still shrouded in silence and shame
summary: A Singaporean man was acquitted of raping his lover's 15-year-old daughter, with the judge citing the victim's delay in reporting the assault as a factor. However, experts from Aware's Sexual Assault Care Centre note that victims often face fear, shame, and reluctance to report the crime, with 61% of survivors reaching out within a year and 20% after five years. The majority of cases are committed by someone known to the survivor, and false ideas about sexual violence are perpetuated by the criminal justice system, echoing myths that trauma is a "phase" with an end.

site_title: Local singers Alfred Sim and Tay Kewei expecting their first child
summary: Singers Alfred Sim, 35, and Tay Kewei, 33, are expecting their first child. The couple, who tied the knot in 2015, had been trying to start a family for about a year. Tay Kewei discovered the news on Chinese New Year and broke the news to her husband in the car. The baby will be the first grandchild for both sides of the family and Tay Kewei is due to give birth in late September or early October. The couple has no preference for the child's gender, with Tay hoping for a healthy baby and Sim wanting a boy.

site_title: Football: FAS election will go on despite police raids, says ad hoc electoral committee
summary: The Football Association of Singapore (FAS) election, scheduled for April 29, will proceed as planned despite police raids on FAS' headquarters and clubs. The raids followed Sport Singapore's report on suspected misuse of funds by Tiong Bahru Football Club. The FAS' ad hoc electoral committee stated it has no power to postpone or call off the election and will act independently and impartially. The police will conduct a thorough investigation and take action against those who committed offences.

site_title: China's Xi Jinping kicks off congress with formal election in ally's province
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping was formally elected as a delegate to the Communist Party congress, solidifying his hold on power. He was unanimously elected by a party meeting in the province of Guizhou, a trusted ally of Xi. Xi will seek to appoint allies to the 25-member Politburo and 7-member Politburo Standing Committee, cementing his control over the party's inner core. The congress, once every five years, is set to take place with the exact dates yet to be announced.

site_title: Higher sales lift Q3 profit at GuocoLand
summary: GuocoLand reported a 63% increase in Q3 revenue to $271.1 million and a 28% rise in gross profit to $63.2 million, driven by higher sales and favorable foreign exchange rates. The company's net profit more than doubled to $29.6 million, while earnings per share increased to 2.66 cents. Despite challenges in the Singapore and Malaysian markets, GuocoLand sees opportunities in China's soft property market, where new home prices rose in 56 cities in February.

site_title: Covered walkway linking HDB block to Khatib MRT station will be completed by December: Lee Bee Wah
summary: A covered walkway linking a HDB block to Khatib MRT station in Singapore will be completed by December 2017, according to Nee Soon GRC MP Lee Bee Wah. The shelter was initially incomplete, with a gap 10m from the MRT station's entrance. The issue was resolved after HDB and the Land Transport Authority explained that the area was designated as an emergency fire escape route, preventing the completion of the walkway as originally planned.

site_title: Epilepsy drug valproate behind up to 4,100 'severe birth defects' in France: Officials
summary: A preliminary French study found valproate, an epilepsy medication, linked to 2,150 to 4,100 severe birth defects in France since 1967. Women taking the drug during pregnancy were four times more likely to give birth to babies with congenital malformations. The French National Agency for the Safety of Medicines (ANSM) and national health insurance administration jointly released the report, confirming valproate's highly teratogenic nature.

site_title: Thieves grab S$4.9 million in cash in brazen Japan mugging
summary: Three masked robbers in Japan's Fukuoka city grabbed S$4.9 million in cash from a 29-year-old businessman who had just withdrawn the money from a bank. The mugging occurred in daylight, with the attackers using tear gas to subdue the victim. The robbers made off in a car with a suitcase containing 380 million yen, weighing over 38kg. The incident is unusual given Japan's safety record and low rates of street crime, suggesting possible involvement of yakuza organized crime syndicates.

site_title: Trump heading to Asia for summits: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump will attend key summits in Asia in November, including the US-Asean and East Asia meetings in the Philippines and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit in Vietnam. Vice-President Mike Pence announced the move, stating it shows the US' "unwavering commitment" to the region. The trip comes after Trump's "America first" rhetoric and decision to abandon a Pacific trade pact, but is seen as a signal to calm nerves among Asian allies. Pence's Asia tour aims to reassure nations of the US' security commitments.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust posts stable Q1 DPU of 2.73 cents
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) reported a stable Q1 DPU of 2.73 cents, unchanged from the previous year. Revenue fell 4.3% to S$172.02 million due to the redevelopment of Funan mall, and net property income decreased 6.1% to S$120.06 million. Despite this, portfolio occupancy remained high at 97.7%. The trust's 16 shopping malls, including Tampines Mall, maintained a strong occupancy rate. The counter closed one cent lower at S$2.01 following the earnings announcement.

site_title: China launches first cargo spacecraft as part of space station goal
summary: China successfully launched its first cargo spacecraft, Tianzhou-1, on April 20, 2017, as part of its goal to establish a permanently manned space station by 2022. The spacecraft lifted off on a Long March-7 Y2 rocket from the Wenchang Satellite Launch Centre in Hainan, China. Designed to dock with the Tiangong 2 space laboratory, Tianzhou-1 can carry 6 tonnes of goods and fly unmanned for three months. The launch marks an important technological step for China's space program, which aims to strengthen national security and advance its space capabilities.

site_title: Indonesia central bank holds interest rate as inflation concerns loom
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, kept its key interest rate unchanged at 4.75% as it maintained a neutral policy stance. Governor Agus Martowardojo and his board cited a slower-than-expected first-quarter economic growth, driven by declining private consumption. Consumer prices rose 3.6% in March, but inflation is expected to pick up to 4.3% this year. Despite a weak economic outlook, a rate cut is unlikely due to inflation concerns. The bank's executive director, Dody Budy Waluyo, stated that the position is biased towards neutral, with a focus on controlling inflation.

site_title: Bangkok 'unique' despite street vendor ban, says Thai tourism boss
summary: Bangkok's street food culture will survive a crackdown on vendors, Thailand's tourism chief vowed, despite a ban on street food stalls from main roads. The city plans to relocate nearly two-thirds of the 30,000 vendors, but will allow some to set up shop on smaller streets and reorganize hawkers in tourist hubs. The tourism chief assured travelers that Bangkok's "chaotic charm" will remain, and the city's unique character will not be gentrified like Singapore. The crackdown aims to reclaim pavements for pedestrians, but tourism is a major pillar of Thailand's economy.

site_title: SGX reports 6.8% dip in Q3 earnings
summary: SGX reported a net profit of S$83.1 million for Q3, down 6.8% from the same period last year. Excluding a one-off loss, net profit would have been S$87 million, still 2% lower than the previous year. Operating revenue dipped 1.5% to S$202.7 million, while operating profit remained little changed. The board proposed a dividend of five cents per share, unchanged from previously.

site_title: Football: United goalkeeper Sergio Romero not content to play second fiddle to David de Gea
summary: Manchester United's Sergio Romero expressed his desire to become the team's first-choice goalkeeper, despite currently playing second fiddle to David de Gea. Romero, 30, has featured in 13 games this season, including Europa League appearances, and has been praised by manager Jose Mourinho for his stability and experience. Mourinho confirmed Romero will start against Anderlecht, but stated that de Gea's priority is the Premier League, and that the team's goal is to qualify for the Champions League through either the top four or the Europa League.

site_title: Football: Wonderkid Kylian Mbappe's stock continues to rise
summary: Kylian Mbappe, 18, became the youngest player to net five Champions League goals, leading Monaco to a 6-3 aggregate win over Borussia Dortmund. Mbappe scored three times in the two-legged tie, including three in the first leg, and is the first to score in each of his first four Champions League games. Monaco joins Juventus, Real Madrid, and Atletico Madrid in the semi-finals. Mbappe's impressive performance has attracted interests from Real Madrid and Manchester United, but he remains focused on his team's success.

site_title: Keppel Corp posts 23.7% rise in Q1 earnings
summary: Keppel Corp reported a 23.7% increase in Q1 earnings, with a net profit of S$260.4 million, driven by higher contributions from the infrastructure and investments divisions. Revenue declined 28.4% to S$1.25 billion, mainly due to lower volumes in the offshore and marine division. The infrastructure division saw revenue growth of S$77 million, while the property division experienced a 48% drop. Earnings per share rose 24% to 14.3 cents.

site_title: Instagram food trend: Colourful and sparkly 'Unicorn food' goes mainstream with Starbucks
summary: Starbucks launched its "Unicorn Frappuccino" on April 19, 2017, a colorful and sparkly drink inspired by Instagram's "unicorn food" trend. The trend, started by health and wellness blogger Adeline Waugh, features food items dyed or decorated with cute accessories. Waugh's initial creations used natural ingredients, while commercial versions may differ. Starbucks' drink is made with white mocha, classic syrup, and blue citric acid powder, sparking debate over its adherence to the trend's all-natural ethos. The trend is expected to continue, despite Waugh's skepticism about its commercialization.

site_title: Aviation sector unveils masterplan to improve efficiency and productivity amid intensifying competition
summary: Singapore's Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has unveiled a masterplan, the Air Transport Industry Transformation Map (ITM), to improve efficiency and productivity in the aviation sector amid intensifying competition. The plan aims to create 8,000 "good jobs" by 2025, focusing on professionals, technicians, and cabin crew, while increasing productivity by 40% and reducing manpower needs. Initiatives include adopting 3D printing for aircraft spare parts, deploying automated check-in kiosks, and integrating air traffic control tower operations. The plan is part of a larger national strategy to promote growth and competitiveness for 23 industries across the economy.

site_title: NParks working with 'hash' runners to reduce practice of marking out running routes
summary: The National Parks Board (NParks) has been working with Hash House Harriers to reduce the practice of marking out running routes in NParks-managed areas using flour, chalk, or toilet paper. After a security scare at Woodleigh MRT Station where three Hash House Harriers members left flour, NParks has advised the group to use only toilet or tissue paper as markings, which must be cleaned up immediately after the event. The group has agreed to this condition, with members picking up all remaining paper within the same day.

site_title: Singapore raises minimum legal age for smoking from 18 to 21: 4 other suggestions to deter first puff
summary: Singapore raises the minimum legal age for smoking from 18 to 21 in an effort to combat youth smoking. Despite a decline in smoking rates among adults since 1992, the rate has stagnated at 13.3% since 2013, with the average age of first-time smokers decreasing to 16 years old. To deter first-time smokers, the government is considering four measures: limiting tobacco sales points, adopting a not-for-profit model for tobacco shops, implementing a cohort ban, and potentially implementing a total ban.

site_title: Boxing: Tyson Fury firmly in Anthony Joshua's thoughts after Wladimir Klitschko fight
summary: Anthony Joshua is set to face Wladimir Klitschko in a world heavyweight title fight on April 29, but says he would prefer to face former champion Tyson Fury. Fury beat Klitschko in 2015, handing him his first loss in 11 years, and Joshua believes a fight with Fury would be a bigger challenge. Joshua and Fury have exchanged barbs on Twitter, with Joshua calling Fury's comments "a lack of respect" and Fury referring to Joshua as "a poor man's Frank Bruno". The two are expected to face off at Wembley Stadium.

site_title: Police raid offices of FAS, 3 football clubs; Bill Ng says will 'fully cooperate' with probe into suspected misuse of funds
summary: Police raided the offices of the Football Association of Singapore (FAS) and three football clubs, including Tiong Bahru Football Club, as part of an investigation into the alleged misuse of funds. The raids were sparked by a report from Sport Singapore, which lodged a police complaint after discovering a $500,000 donation by TBFC to the Asean Football Federation. TBFC chairman Bill Ng said he would fully cooperate with the authorities. The investigation is ongoing, with police promising to take action against those who have committed offenses. The FAS has pledged to cooperate with the probe.

site_title: MMA: Holly Holm calls on Ronda Rousey to quit, ahead of UFC Fight Night Singapore
summary: UFC fighter Holly Holm has called on Ronda Rousey to retire from mixed martial arts if she no longer has the desire to fight. Holm, who knocked out Rousey in 2015, believes fighters should only compete if they truly want to, as those who don't will struggle. Rousey, 30, had a 13-fight winning streak before her loss to Holm, but has since lost three consecutive bouts. Holm is set to face 11th-ranked Brazilian Bethe Correia in Singapore on June 17, while Rousey is looking to revive her career.

site_title: Four junior colleges will halt intake of students in 2018, a year ahead of mergers
summary: Four Singapore junior colleges - Jurong Junior College, Innova Junior College, Serangoon Junior College, and Tampines Junior College - will halt intake of students in 2018, a year ahead of planned mergers in 2019. The move aims to minimize disruptions and allow for a smoother transition when the schools relocate. JC2 students will occupy the premises in 2018, while JC1 students will not be admitted. The Ministry of Education has assured that special programs and student organizations will be preserved in the merged schools, and alumni will have opportunities to organize orientation for partner schools.

site_title: NBA: Golden State Warriors take a 2-0 play-offs lead over Portland Trail Blazers
summary: The Golden State Warriors secured a 110-81 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers, taking a 2-0 lead in their first-round playoff series. Without injured star Kevin Durant, the Warriors clamped down on defense, holding the Trail Blazers to 12 points in the third quarter. Stephen Curry led the team with 19 points, while Klay Thompson added 16. The Warriors will travel to Portland for the next two meetings, taking their lead into game three on Saturday.

site_title: Football: Emre Can not for sale, despite Liverpool contract expiring in 2018
summary: Liverpool intends to keep Emre Can despite his contract expiring in 2018, as the German midfielder has yet to commit to a long-term deal. Can has been in form for Liverpool, but has a preference for a deeper midfield role. The club believes his worth to Jurgen Klopp's team is greater than the cost of buying a replacement. Liverpool's manager, Jurgen Klopp, is willing to wait for a resolution, unlike Everton's Ronald Koeman, who has urged Ross Barkley to make a decision or face the possibility of being sold.

site_title: Low-cost carrier Norwegian launches non-stop flights between Singapore and London
summary: Low-cost carrier Norwegian is launching non-stop flights between Singapore and London starting September, with one-way economy class tickets starting from $199 and premium class tickets from $839. The airline will operate a four-times weekly service, increasing to five-times weekly during the Northern winter season. The new route will offer over 300 seats per flight and cater to the 1.2 million passengers who traveled between Singapore and London last year, making it Changi Airport's 14th busiest route.

site_title: How to keep the tender in pork tenderloin
summary: Pork tenderloin, known for its lean and tender nature, can be challenging to cook without drying out. To preserve moisture, Melissa Clark suggests stuffing the tenderloin with a mixture of shallots, capers, and herbs, such as sage, rosemary, and thyme. Butterfly the tenderloin, close it, and tie it with kitchen twine to create an evenly shaped cylinder. Cooking the tenderloin to an internal temperature of 62°C (145°F) while it's still slightly pink on the inside ensures succulent and flavorful meat.

site_title: URA launches two residential sites for sale by public tender
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched two residential sites for sale by public tender in Singapore. The sites, which span 34,508.1 sq m, are located in Lorong 1 Realty Park and Stirling Road, and could potentially yield 1,160 homes. Analysts expect competitive bidding, as developers are eager to build up their land banks. The tender for the Stirling Road plot closes on May 18, while the Lorong 1 Realty Park site closes on June 1.

site_title: Football: Chelsea and Spurs players dominate PFA's Team of the Year
summary: Chelsea and Tottenham players dominate the Professional Football Association's (PFA) Team of the Year, with eight Premier League title-chasers occupying starting 11 spots. Chelsea midfielder N'Golo Kante, Manchester United goalkeeper David De Gea, and Tottenham trio Dele Alli, Danny Rose, and Harry Kane make the team for the second consecutive season. The PFA Team of the Year was chosen by all 92 English Football League clubs and eight Women's Super League sides, with notable omissions including Manchester United's Zlatan Ibrahimovic and Arsenal's Alexis Sanchez.

site_title: US-Russian crew blasts off for space station with one empty seat
summary: A two-man US-Russian crew, consisting of NASA astronaut Jack Fischer and Russian cosmonaut Fyodor Yurchikhin, launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on April 20 for a six-hour ride to the International Space Station. The crew is part of a scaled-down crew due to Russia's reduced staffing at the space station until its science laboratory is installed next year. Fischer, in his first space voyage, will face challenges, including the station's zero-gravity toilet, and will be joined by station commander Peggy Whitson and Yurchikhin until September.

site_title: North Korea warns of ‘super-mighty preemptive strike’ as US plans next move
summary: North Korea has threatened a "super-mighty preemptive strike" against the US mainland, warning that it could wipe out the country. The warning comes after US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said the US was looking to apply pressure on North Korea over its nuclear program. The US and South Korea are conducting joint air drills, and tensions are high amid ongoing tensions over North Korea's missile tests and nuclear ambitions.

site_title: A step-by-step guide to making your own pasta, and two recipe variations
summary: A step-by-step guide to making pasta from scratch involves mixing flour and eggs, kneading the dough, resting it, and then rolling and cutting it into noodles. The process can be time-consuming, but using a pasta machine is recommended for efficiency. Two recipe variations are provided: herbed pappardelle with parsley and garlic, and whole grain pasta. The key to making perfect pasta is to monitor humidity, temperature, and the type of flour used, and to cook the pasta just until it's al dente to preserve its texture and flavor.

site_title: Japan's deputy prime minister Taro Aso tells US audience: Our airline crews won't beat you
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Taro Aso of Japan addressed a US audience, highlighting the country's strengths, including its people's resilience, high worker morale, and the quality of its taxi services. Aso made a comment about airline crews not beating passengers, referencing a recent United Airlines incident. He also praised Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's leadership and Japan's progress in labor participation rates and corporate governance, while expressing concerns about its aging population.

site_title: 13 foreigners arrested for vice activities in Kaki Bukit's forested areas
summary: Thirteen foreigners, 10 men and 3 women, were arrested on April 19, 2017, in forested areas of Kaki Bukit for vice activities. The group was raided by Central Narcotics Bureau and Bedok Division officers after receiving information. They were charged with various offences, including wilful trespass on state land, suspected controlled drug consumption, and offences under the Women's Charter and Immigration Act. Those convicted can face fines up to $1,000. Investigations are ongoing.

site_title: Pakistan’s top court rejects call to disqualify Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif
summary: Pakistan's Supreme Court has rejected a call to disqualify Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif over corruption allegations linked to the Panama Papers leak in 2015. Two judges recommended Sharif step down, but were outvoted. The court ordered a joint investigation into allegations of offshore companies used to buy properties in London, giving Sharif and his party a temporary reprieve. The ruling was seen as a blow to Sharif's credibility, and analysts say it could weaken him ahead of a general election by May 2018.

site_title: Ex-sales associate at Bally jailed 2 years for misappropriating $186,000
summary: A former sales associate at Bally Singapore, Jimuhit Ulliel Abdul Nahar, was jailed for 2 years for misappropriating $183,983 over 8 months. He pleaded guilty to criminal breach of trust and admitted to dishonestly taking the money to repay debts and personal expenses. $25,944 was recovered after his arrest, but no restitution was made. Nahar could have faced up to 15 years in prison, but his father's medical bills were taken into consideration during sentencing.

site_title: EU's top diplomat says China's new Silk Road must be open to Europeans
summary: EU's top diplomat, Federica Mogherini, stated that China's new Silk Road initiative must be open to Europeans, amid China's preparations for its first summit dedicated to the plan. Mogherini emphasized the need for a "positive signal" of economic globalization and free trade, following US President Trump's protectionist policies. The EU and China have been working together on issues like North Korea and Syria, but tensions remain due to China's human rights record and restrictions on foreign NGOs. A bilateral investment treaty between the EU and China has been stalled since 2012.

site_title: History of the 4 junior colleges moving out of their current sites
summary: Four Singapore junior colleges - Serangoon Junior College, Innova Junior College, Tampines Junior College, and Jurong Junior College - will merge with other colleges in 2019, bringing the total number of junior colleges to 19. The merged schools will adopt a combination of their original names, with the older college's name coming first. The mergers are due to Singapore's declining birth rate and are the first time junior colleges have been affected by school mergers. The new names announced are Anderson Serangoon, Yishun Innova, Tampines Meridian, and Jurong Pioneer.

site_title: SCOGA partners Twitch to boost local e-sports scene
summary: The Singapore Cybergames and Online Gaming Association (SCOGA) has partnered with Twitch to boost the local e-sports scene. The partnership will provide expertise in live-streaming and gaming, including classes taught by top game streamers. Classes will be offered in gaming, live-streaming, and shoutcasting, with a mix of free and paid options. The academy aims to train aspiring e-sports professionals and provide opportunities for local content creators to make a living on Twitch. The partnership comes ahead of the 2022 Asian Games, where e-sports will be an officially included medal sport.

site_title: Banking outlook very tough, says UOB's Wee Cho Yaw
summary: UOB chairman emeritus Wee Cho Yaw has warned that the banking sector's outlook will be "very tough" for the next one to two years, citing the sector's poor performance last year. The bank's full-year net profit dropped to S$3.11 billion from S$3.22 billion in 2015, largely due to major provisions for non-performing loans in the oil and gas sector. Despite this, UOB expects new non-performing loan formation to peak last year and provisions to normalize downward this year, with asset prices dropping by 30% still allowing the bank to break even.

site_title: Was Angelababy's baby born through surrogacy? Actress' official microblog is drawn into discussion
summary: Angelababy and her husband Huang Xiaoming welcomed a son in Hong Kong in January. Speculation arose that the child was born through surrogacy, with China's No.1 Paparazzo Zhuo Wei stating on social media that it was a "biological" child. Angelababy's official microblog responded, dismissing the rumors and warning others that reposting false information could lead to legal consequences. The couple had previously undergone a medical examination in Beijing to disprove plastic surgery claims. The incident sparked online discussion about the authenticity of Angelababy's child's birth.

site_title: Next South Korea leader to rein in Trump over North Korea: Analysts
summary: South Korea's next leader will likely rein in US President Donald Trump's aggressive approach towards North Korea, according to analysts. The impeachment of former President Park Geun Hye has given the White House free rein in the crisis, prompting dire threats from North Korea. Both front-runner Moon Jae In and challenger Ahn Cheol Soo urge Trump to cool his position, opposing any first strike by the US and seeking dialogue with the North. Whoever wins the election will pursue a more active dialogue with North Korea and put a damper on harsh US rhetoric.

site_title: Coca-Cola to launch new Coke Zero Sugar
summary: Coca-Cola is launching Coca-Cola Zero Sugar, a new sugar-free version of its signature soft drink, in May 2017. The new recipe is designed to taste like the original Coca-Cola without sugar, targeting consumers who want to reduce their sugar intake but still enjoy the classic taste. This move comes as the company seeks to cater to the growing demand for healthier options, following the Singapore Ministry of Health's declaration of a "war" on diabetes. The new packaging will feature red cans, replacing the black can of Coca-Cola Zero and the silver can of Coca-Cola Light.

site_title: Football: Europa League would be the 'perfect' end to the season, says Jose Mourinho
summary: Manchester United manager Jose Mourinho believes playing in the Europa League final would be the "perfect" way to end the season, given the team's struggles in the league. With the club currently fifth in the Premier League, Mourinho hopes winning the Europa League would secure an automatic Champions League spot for next season. Reaching the final would also be a fitting end to striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic's season, who is set to be honored with a statue in his native Sweden.

site_title: NBA: John Wall, Bradley Beal shine as Wizards topple Hawks
summary: The Washington Wizards secured a 109-101 win over the Atlanta Hawks in Game 2 of their NBA playoff series, taking a 2-0 lead. John Wall led the Wizards with 32 points, while Bradley Beal added 31 points, including 16 in the final quarter. The Wizards overcame a late deficit, capped by Wall's free throw with 25 seconds left. The series will continue in Atlanta on Saturday.

site_title: Vietnam village sealed off as hostage crisis deepens
summary: A group of Vietnamese farmers took over 38 police and officials hostage in a land dispute in Dong Tam commune, outside Hanoi, over allegations of illegal land seizure. The farmers, who have sealed off their village, have threatened to resist any rescue attempt and vowed to set fire to the hostages' house if authorities move in. The incident marks a rare act of defiance in authoritarian Vietnam, where anger over corruption and land seizures often meets a forceful response from police. Three hostages have escaped, and 15 were released, leaving 20 still held.

site_title: NTU professor pleads guilty to shoplifting
summary: NTU professor Er Meng Joo, 55, pleaded guilty to two counts of shoplifting, totaling $225.15 in stolen items, from an NTUC FairPrice outlet in January 2016. Caught on CCTV, he admitted to the offenses and will face a report assessing his suitability for a mandatory treatment order. He can be jailed up to three years and fined for each count. Despite being a full professor, he is still employed at Nanyang Technological University, where he previously served as an elected member of the Advisory Board and won several awards.

site_title: Young couple get help after losing nearly everything in house fire
summary: A Singapore couple, Ms Jessica Ong and her husband Xiang Liang, lost nearly everything in a house fire on April 11, 2017, after being away at work. Their one-room flat was severely damaged, with all furniture burnt or in poor condition. The couple, who are both UberEats drivers, were unaware they needed fire insurance and are struggling financially. They have received donations of basic items and are working to rebuild, but are still tight and stressed. The cause of the fire is currently under investigation.

site_title: Falling birth rate hits home with news of JCs merging
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Education announced plans to merge 28 schools in 2019, including four junior colleges, due to the decline in birth rate. The mergers, which will reduce the number of junior colleges from 23 to 19, are expected to cut JC intake by a fifth, from 16,000 in 2010 to 12,800 in 2019. The move aims to preserve educational programmes and co-curricular activities by maintaining a critical mass of students, with affected schools having potentially as few as 200-300 students.

site_title: South Korea to allow those who lost their jobs or whose business went bust to delay debt repayment
summary: South Korea's Financial Services Commission has announced plans to allow individuals who lost their jobs or went out of business to delay repaying principal on their loans for up to three years. The move aims to reduce debt burden on vulnerable households as borrowing costs rise. To qualify, borrowers must own a property valued at 600 million won or less and continue making interest payments. This move comes amid a record-high household debt, which increased 11.7% in the fourth quarter of last year. The plan will be implemented by banks and financial institutions within the year.

site_title: New e-commerce membership programme LiveUp launches to pre-empt Amazon entry
summary: Lazada and online supermarket RedMart have launched a membership programme called LiveUp in Singapore, anticipating Amazon's entry into the market. The programme offers benefits such as rebates, discounts, and free services like Netflix and Uber rides. Members pay a fee of $28.80 for the first year and $49.90 annually. Lazada CEO Alexis Lanternier believes LiveUp can compete with Amazon's Prime membership, providing users with a way to try out multiple services and gain value. The programme aims to attract users who may not have tried other services before.

site_title: Football: Robbie Fowler linked with A-League's Newcastle Jets coaching job
summary: Former England striker Robbie Fowler, 42, has expressed interest in the vacant coaching job at Australia's Newcastle Jets. Fowler, a Liverpool legend, has been linked to the position since Mark Jones' sacking following the Jets' wooden spoon finish in the A-League season. Jets CEO Lawrie McKinna confirmed an agent representing Fowler has contacted the club, citing his big profile as a potential advantage. Fowler, who previously played for North Queensland Fury and Perth Glory in the A-League, is among several candidates vying for the job, with discussions expected to begin soon.

site_title: Bollywood star Anil Kapoor gets first wax figure after three decades in the industry
summary: Bollywood star Anil Kapoor has unveiled his first wax figure at Madame Tussauds Singapore, marking his over three-decade-long career in the industry. The figure, depicting his character from the Oscar-winning movie Slumdog Millionaire, is part of the new IIFA Awards Experience exhibition. Kapoor expressed appreciation for the tribute, stating that it highlights his growth and career milestones. The exhibition also features wax figures of other iconic Bollywood actors, offering visitors an immersive experience.

site_title: Southern Thailand attacks reflect tension over peace talks, conflict monitor says
summary: A series of gun and grenade attacks in southern Thailand killed two people and wounded eight others, reflecting tension over peace talks aimed at ending violence in the region. The attacks follow the Thai government's rejection of a conditional offer for peace talks by the Barisan Revolusi Nasional (BRN) insurgent group. The violence is seen as the BRN's attempt to show its capability for coordinated strikes and create conditions for future peace talks. The attacks are the latest in a long-running separatist insurgency in southern Thailand, which has resulted in over 6,500 deaths since 2004.

site_title: US Vice-President Mike Pence tours Indonesian mosque in outreach to Muslims
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence visited Indonesia's Istiqlal Mosque, the world's largest mosque, as part of a tour aimed at smoothing relations with the Islamic world. Pence praised Indonesia's moderate Islam, saying it's "an inspiration" to the world. His visit contrasts with the Trump administration's efforts to ban travellers from Muslim-majority nations and echoes a similar trip by former President Barack Obama. Pence's outreach is seen as a bid to heal divisions, but concerns remain that the Trump administration's rhetoric has damaged its reputation in the Islamic world.
