site_title: Mon Ngon Sai Thanh eatery in Hanoi serves authentic south Vietnamese delicacies
summary: Mon Ngon Sai Thanh, a restaurant in Hanoi, serves authentic southern Vietnamese delicacies, including the highly-regarded ga nuong xoi chien phong (grilled chicken with fried sticky rice) and lau thuyen bong (flowers boat hotpot). The restaurant boasts over 100 southern dishes and features high-quality ingredients, including imported vegetables and flowers. Chef Nguyen The Anh shares the passion and skill that goes into preparing these dishes, which he claims are a representation of the beauty of nature and culture in southern Vietnam.

site_title: Government initiatives to be rolled out to address worksite vehicle safety, prevent falls and amputation injuries
summary: Singapore's Workplace Safety and Health Council and Ministry of Manpower have announced initiatives to address workplace accidents, focusing on preventing falls, amputation injuries, and on-site vehicular safety. Minister of State for Manpower Sam Tan emphasized that workplace accidents are preventable through simple measures, such as risk assessments and safety training. The government plans to launch programs like the Mobile Work at Heights program and a compliance assistance program for on-site vehicular safety, aiming to reduce workplace fatalities and injuries.

site_title: Football: Argentina stars Lionel Messi, Sergio Aguero to play friendly against Lions at National Stadium
summary: Argentina football stars Lionel Messi and Sergio Aguero will play a friendly match against Singapore's national team, known as the Lions, at the National Stadium on June 13. The match marks the FAS' 125th anniversary and is part of a four-nation tour. Messi, ranked world No. 2, will face off against Brazil on June 9, while the Lions will take on Australia on the same day. The match is expected to provide valuable exposure for local players and coaches, with tickets priced from $25 to $188.

site_title: Opec chief sees oil producers near to re-balancing market
summary: OPEC Secretary-General Mohammad Barkindo stated that oil producers, including OPEC and non-OPEC countries, are nearing the end of a global oil glut and are committed to reducing stockpiles. The group will decide on May 25 whether to extend output cuts beyond June, which have led to a 19% increase in benchmark Brent crude since January. Compliance with the cuts has improved, with OPEC reaching 104% and non-OPEC producers reaching 64% in March, indicating a strong path towards market recovery.

site_title: Indian politicians to face trial over mosque demolition
summary: The Indian Supreme Court has ruled that three senior members of the ruling Hindu nationalist party, including a government minister, should face trial over the 1992 demolition of the 16th century Babri mosque. Uma Bharti, L K Advani, and M M Joshi are accused of inciting Hindu zealots to pull down the mosque, which led to widespread riots and thousands of deaths. The court overturned a lower court's decision to drop the charges, paving the way for their trial. The ruling is seen as a significant victory for India's Muslim minority, who have long sought justice for the mosque's destruction.

site_title: India bus crash kills 44: Official
summary: A bus carrying 56 passengers plunged into a deep ravine in northern India's Himachal Pradesh state, killing at least 44 people. The accident occurred near Shimla, with rescue efforts underway. The cause of the accident is unclear, but officials suspect reckless driving. This incident is the latest in a series of fatal bus accidents in India, where poor roads and reckless driving contribute to over 150,000 fatalities annually.

site_title: Famous Osaka eatery Kushikatsu Daruma has opened in Manila
summary: Kushikatsu Daruma, a famous Osaka eatery, has opened its first location in Manila at Uptown Mall BGC. Founded by entrepreneur Charles Paw, the restaurant serves deep-fried skewered meat and vegetables with a secret sauce flown in from Japan. The menu features a variety of options, including classic kushikatsu, prawn, chicken, and foie gras, and customers can order from beginner to advanced sets or individual sticks. The restaurant aims to be an affordable spot for drinking, with a late-night opening schedule and a range of drinks available.

site_title: Beware of scam involving fake Singapore Police Force website: Police
summary: The Singapore Police Force has warned the public of a scam involving a fake website that impersonates the official SPF website. Victims receive calls claiming their bank accounts contain large amounts of money, directing them to a phishing site to provide confidential information, resulting in extensive monetary losses. The public is advised to ignore suspicious calls, not provide personal or bank details, and report any information to the SPF hotline (1800-255-0000) or online. The official SPF website is www.police.gov.sg.

site_title: Football: Broken foot leaves Manuel Neuer's season in serious doubt
summary: Bayern Munich goalkeeper Manuel Neuer may be sidelined for the rest of the season after fracturing his left foot during the Champions League quarter-final second leg against Real Madrid. Neuer suffered the injury in extra time during the 4-2 loss, which Bayern lost 6-3 on aggregate. An initial diagnosis suggests a fracture, and Neuer will undergo further examination before a decision on treatment is made. This could impact Bayern's remaining seven matches in the season, including a crucial German Cup semi-final against Borussia Dortmund.

site_title: Danish court upholds extradition order for daughter of ousted South Korean president’s friend
summary: A Danish court upheld an extradition order for Chung Yoo Ra, daughter of Choi Soon Sil, a friend of ousted South Korean President Park Geun Hye. Chung, a 20-year-old dressage rider, was detained in Denmark on January 1 for overstaying her visa. The court backed the Public Prosecutor's decision to extradite her to South Korea for questioning in relation to the scandal that brought down Park Geun Hye. Chung's extradition is the latest development in the ongoing investigation into her mother's alleged collusion with Park.

site_title: Korean actor Lee Min Ho confirms May enlistment into military service
summary: Korean actor Lee Min Ho has confirmed his enlistment into military service, set to begin on May 12 as a public service officer. Due to an injury from a 2006 car accident, Lee will be assigned to a noncombat position. This marks the beginning of Lee's mandatory military service, which he will spend preparing for until his enlistment date. Lee, 29, is best known for his roles in popular dramas like "Boys Over Flowers" and has recently completed recording a nature documentary that will premiere on June 5.

site_title: Football: Last-gasp winner from Blaise Matuidi helps PSG go level with Monaco
summary: Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) secured a 3-2 win over Metz in a last-minute thriller, thanks to Blaise Matuidi's stoppage-time winner. The French midfielder scored twice in the first half, with Edinson Cavani also scoring, before Metz equalized through Yann Jouffre and Cheick Diabate. PSG's victory puts pressure on Ligue 1 leaders Monaco, who are now level with PSG on goal difference, with 77 points each.

site_title: Britain's Prince William says shock of mother's death lingers 20 years on
summary: Prince William has stated that the shock of losing his mother, Princess Diana, 20 years ago still lingers within him. He shared his feelings in a BBC documentary, saying the shock can't be overcome but can be learned to deal with. This comes after his brother Prince Harry spoke about his own struggles with grief, revealing he came close to a "complete breakdown" and sought counseling in his late 20s. Both princes are part of a campaign to raise awareness of mental health challenges and encourage open discussion about emotions.

site_title: Football: The lion's den that is Camp Nou awaits Juventus, warns Dani Alves
summary: Dani Alves, Juventus' Brazilian defender, warns his team that a knockout of Barcelona in the Champions League quarter-finals would eliminate the best team in the world. Alves, who played for Barcelona for eight seasons, believes his side has a 60% chance of progression despite a 3-0 lead from the first leg. He expects a tough game at Camp Nou and hopes to score a goal to hurt Barcelona and gain an advantage. Alves, who may return to Barcelona in the future, says he would only consider it if the club's management changes.

site_title: US Marines' commander in Australia says US remains committed to Asia pivot
summary: US Marines' commander Lieutenant Colonel Brian Middleton stated that the deployment of 1,250 Marines to Darwin, Australia, reflects President Donald Trump's commitment to a security "pivot" to Asia, despite early rhetoric on Asian allies' security burden. The 25-year programme, initiated by former President Barack Obama, aims to grow the force to 2,500 Marines. Middleton emphasized the deployment's significance in communicating a sustained commitment to the region, citing joint training exercises with Australian, Japanese, and Chinese troops.

site_title: Images show North Koreans playing volleyball at nuclear test site
summary: US experts monitoring North Korea's Punggye-ri Nuclear Test Site were surprised to see volleyball games underway in satellite images taken on Sunday. Analysts had expected activity suggesting preparations for a nuclear test, but instead found volleyball games at multiple locations within the facility. The games may be a sign that the test site is going into a "standby mode" or an attempt to confuse observers. North Korea has conducted recent ballistic missile launches and is under pressure to conduct a sixth nuclear test, sparking fears of military confrontation with the US.

site_title: Cereal company Post Holdings to acquire Weetabix for S$2.51 billion
summary: US cereal company Post Holdings has agreed to acquire British breakfast cereal brand Weetabix from China's Bright Food Group for £1.4 billion (S$2.51 billion), expanding its international business. The deal will allow Post to establish a European base and distribute Weetabix and its Barbara's brand in North America. Weetabix's manufacturing and distribution assets in Europe will also enable Post to more easily acquire other overseas businesses. The acquisition is expected to boost Post's revenue and earnings, with Weetabix's revenue remaining flat and earnings boosted by cost-savings.

site_title: Uproar over top university's offer of honorary law degree to President Duterte
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has been offered an honorary doctor of laws degree by the University of the Philippines, sparking outrage over his human rights record. The decision was met with widespread criticism on social media, with many calling it a "step backward" for the university. Duterte has declined the offer, saying it's not in his character to accept awards. The offer has also raised questions about the university's tradition of activism and its decision to confer honorary degrees on Philippine presidents. Duterte's human rights record has been marred by thousands of deaths in his war on drugs.

site_title: Scientists find giant shipworm in Philippines
summary: Scientists in the Philippines have discovered a giant shipworm, a species never before studied, that can grow up to 155cm in length. The worm, known as Kuphus Polythalamia, relies on bacteria in its gills to digest hydrogen sulphide from the mud, rather than eating wood like its smaller cousins. Researchers found that the worm's digestive system is shrunken and redundant, and its bacteria are being studied for possible pharmaceutical use. The discovery was made in the coastal town of Kalamansig and local people have known about the edible and aphrodisiac properties of the shipworm for years.

site_title: Fire breaks out at vehicle scrapyard along Penjuru Road, buses diverted for safety
summary: A fire broke out at a vehicle scrapyard along Penjuru Road in Singapore on April 19, 2017, prompting bus services to skip nearby stops. The blaze sent thick black smoke into the air and was extinguished using two water jets. There were no reported injuries, and the cause of the fire is currently under investigation. Two fire engines, two Red Rhinos, and other support vehicles were dispatched to the scene. The fire involved two scrap cars, industrial containers, and discarded items outside a building.

site_title: British PM Theresa May says early election averts clash with end of Brexit talks
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May announced that holding an early election in June 2017 instead of 2020 would prevent a simultaneous crunch in European Union talks and a domestic election. This decision allows May to maintain a wider margin of manoeuvre during the Brexit negotiations, which are expected to conclude by March 2019. The early election will give May a reprieve until 2022, when she will face voters again, providing her with more flexibility at the end of the Brexit talks.

site_title: LG Signature W7 Oled TV arrives in stores next month
summary: LG's 65-inch Signature W7 Oled TV will be available in stores next month at $12,888. Weighing 8kg and measuring 2.57mm in thickness, the ultra-thin TV can be mounted to the wall using magnetic brackets. It features organic light-emitting diodes, producing deeper blacks and up to 20% brighter images compared to last year's models. The W7 is part of LG's Oled TV lineup, which also includes the G7, E7, and C7 series, with pricing for the G7 and E7 models to be announced in May.

site_title: Famous Medan durian shop Ucok sets up shop in Jakarta
summary: Ucok Durian Medan, a renowned durian shop in Medan, North Sumatra, has expanded to Jakarta with its new shop, Kedai Ucok Durian Jakarta. Owned by re-seller Nurul Wardah, the shop offers a variety of durian products, including peeled durian, pancakes, juice, ice cream, and sambal. The shop buys durians directly from Ucok Durian Medan and is open daily from 10am to 9pm. Prices range from Rp 19,000 to Rp 100,000, with special deals available for purchasing multiple boxes. This expansion brings the famous durian shop to Jakarta's durian enthusiasts.

site_title: In Pictures: Premiere of Unforgettable
summary: Cheryl Ladd attended the premiere of the thriller "Unforgettable" at the TCL Chinese Theater in Hollywood, California, on April 18. The movie, starring Katherine Heigl, opened in Singapore on May 4. Director Denise Di Novi and other actors, including Ben Barnes and Rosario Dawson, also attended the event. The premiere marked the release of the dramatic film, which sees Ladd play Katherine Heigl's domineering mother.

site_title: 15 new commissions from local artists at Singapore International Festival of Arts
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts features 23 productions, including 15 from local artists. The festival director, Ong Keng Sen, has curated the program to promote unity and counter populism. Local artists include Nine Years Theatre and Pangdemonium, with productions such as an original Mandarin play and a new play about hope in a post-Brexit world. Seven overseas productions also make their Asia-Pacific premieres, including a K-pop retelling of the Trojan War and a piece by the Kronos Quartet. The festival runs from June 28 to September 9.

site_title: Myanmar's bid to shut down camps raises questions about fate of refugees: The Nation
summary: Myanmar is shutting down refugee camps in Rakhine state, sparking concerns about the fate of thousands of displaced people, including ethnic Rakhine and Muslim Rohingya. The international community, particularly ASEAN, demands more information on the government's long-term plan for the refugees. Despite previous recommendations from a commission led by Kofi Annan, the government has provided no clear timeline or measures for relocation or aid. The shutdown of camps raises questions about Myanmar's treatment of the Rohingya, who face severe restrictions and denial of citizenship.

site_title: Jakarta Election: Quick count of polls point to Ahok losing to Anies, Ahok congratulates rival on victory
summary: Indonesian gubernatorial election results show Anies Baswedan and Sandiaga Uno leading with almost 60% of the votes, while incumbent governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama and his deputy Djarot Saiful Hidayat received about 40%. The quick counts, which project results based on a sample of votes, indicate a decisive lead for Baswedan, who will likely become the next Jakarta governor, marking a test of Indonesia's religious tolerance and pluralism.

site_title: Muffin has 63,000 followers on Instagram. Here's how to be an animal social media star
summary: Singapore's Muffin, an 8-year-old shih tzu with over 63,000 Instagram followers, shares his tips on building a social media empire with other famous pets at Pet Expo. Muffin and six other pet stars, including their owners, met fans and discussed what works best for their online presence. Their advice includes posting high-quality content, engaging with followers, and being authentic to their personalities. The event aimed to provide insights into the world of animal social media stardom and inspire aspiring pet influencers.

site_title: India and China compete for influence in South Asia: The Kathmandu Post Columnist
summary: India and China are competing for influence in South Asian countries through various means, including economic aid, military cooperation, and diplomatic engagement. India has been struggling to maintain its influence, particularly in Bangladesh, where China has been increasing its presence. Bangladesh's Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina recently visited India, signing multiple agreements, but failed to secure a water-sharing deal, sparking criticism from opposition parties. Meanwhile, China is expanding its influence in countries like Nepal, Bhutan, and the Maldives, with a growing military, political, and diplomatic engagement with Pakistan.

site_title: CNN names pandan cake as Singapore's national cake, promotes Pine Garden and Bengawan Solo
summary: CNN has named pandan cake as Singapore's national cake, along with Malaysia, after listing it as one of the world's 17 best cakes. The cake, described as a chiffon cake infused with green pandanus palm juice, was praised by local bakeries Pine Garden and Bengawan Solo. In contrast, CNN identified Indonesia's national cake as kueh lapis, Japan's as dorayaki, and Hong Kong's as "mai lai go".

site_title: Approval for President Rodrigo Duterte's drug war slips in Philippines
summary: The Philippines' public satisfaction with President Rodrigo Duterte's war on drugs has declined to 78% in the first quarter of this year, down from 85% in December. A survey found 12% of respondents were dissatisfied, while 73% were worried about extrajudicial killings. 92% believed authorities should capture drug suspects alive, and 44% were undecided on the police's honesty. The decline in satisfaction has been attributed to concerns over police involvement in killings, with some accusing the police of receiving bribes and carrying out extrajudicial killings.

site_title: China's Xi Jinping restructures military, consolidates control
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has announced a military restructuring of the People's Liberation Army (PLA), transforming it into a leaner fighting force with improved joint operations capability. The 84 new units, centered around a condensed structure, will have commanders holding the rank of major-general or rear-admiral. This is part of Xi's ongoing efforts to modernize the PLA, which include streamlining troop numbers and introducing reforms to combat corruption. The restructuring aims to build a world-class military, with Xi stating it has "profound and significant meaning" in achieving this goal.

site_title: Aaron Kwok weds, his father-in-law says: 'I grew up listening to your songs. Treat my daughter well'
summary: Heavenly King Aaron Kwok, 51, married model Moka Fang, 29, in a low-key ceremony at The Peninsula Hong Kong. The couple, who dated for less than two years, exchanged vows in a Chinese marriage ritual and were officially married by a lawyer. Kwok's father-in-law expressed his hopes for the couple's future, saying he would treat Fang well after growing up listening to Kwok's songs. The wedding was attended by over 100 guests, including singer Julian Cheung and actress Anita Yuen.

site_title: Maid jailed four weeks after falsely accusing employers of abuse
summary: An Indonesian maid, Susilawati Narsim Sunah, was jailed for four weeks after pleading guilty to falsely accusing her elderly employers of physical abuse. She lied to the Ministry of Manpower and police, claiming her employer's 85-year-old wife had abused her multiple times, in an attempt to return home to Indonesia. Susilawati initially denied the allegations but later confessed, stating she had fabricated the claims due to her employer's silence. The court took into consideration a second charge, and the four-week sentence was handed down.

site_title: North Korea marks founder's birthday with mock video showing missiles blowing up US
summary: North Korea marked the birthday of its founder Kim Il Sung with a musical show that ended with a mock video of missiles engulfing the US, prompting cheers and smiles from current leader Kim Jong Un. The video featured a missile test in February, which was joined by other missiles exploding in flames in the US. The display was seen as a threat to the US, with Vice President Mike Pence warning of an "overwhelming response" if North Korea takes military action. China expressed concern over the recent comments and the possibility of nuclear war.

site_title: ST Electronics wins Sri Lankan cyber security contract, inks MOU for SAF's cyber defence training
summary: ST Electronics has won a contract with Sri Lanka's Information and Communication Technology Agency to implement the country's first National Cyber Security Operations Centre (SOC). The Singapore firm will provide consultancy services, training, and awareness programs to strengthen the country's cyber readiness. This marks a significant milestone for ST Electronics' cyber security global business, expanding its footprint overseas. The company also signed a memorandum of understanding with the Singapore Armed Forces to strengthen cyber defence training.

site_title: Singapore Heritage Festival 2017: Spotlight on Caldecott, Little India, Bukit Pasoh and the Singapore River
summary: The 14th edition of the Singapore Heritage Festival will take place from April 28 to May 14, featuring over 110 programmes across 80 community partners. Temporary stalls selling food, including satay, will be set up along the Singapore River, while Caldecott Broadcast Centre will be open to the public for the first time, showcasing the site of Singapore's first radio station. Little India will celebrate its second anniversary with street art installations, performances, and food trails, while Bukit Pasoh will host lion dance troupes and martial arts demonstrations.

site_title: City Harvest case: Sharon Tan to start jail term earlier, Chew Eng Han's sentence stayed
summary: Sharon Tan, a former City Harvest Church finance manager, has been granted permission to start serving her 7-month jail term earlier. Her request was accepted by the High Court, allowing her to begin serving her sentence sooner. Meanwhile, former CHC fund manager Chew Eng Han's 3-year and 4-month jail term has been stayed pending a Court of Appeal ruling on important questions of law. The court's decision also affects the other five defendants, who had previously been allowed to defer their sentences by two weeks.

site_title: Boy finds maggots in Four Leaves sausage bun; NEA says no lapses at Hougang Mall outlet
summary: A customer in Singapore found live maggots in a sausage bun from Four Leaves Bakery at Hougang Mall. The incident has been shared over 12,000 times on social media. The bakery chain has stopped selling sausage products and is conducting an investigation with suppliers and the National Environment Agency (NEA). Despite an inspection by NEA, the agency found no hygiene lapses, but will continue to monitor the outlet's practices. Four Leaves apologizes for the incident and assures that all buns are freshly baked daily.

site_title: Founding member of Mahathir's opposition party quits
summary: A founding member of Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia (PPBM), led by former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, has quit the party due to a loss of confidence in its leadership. Kamarulzaman Habibur Rahman accused the party of jostling for power and position. He rejected an offer to be party secretary and plans to revive the disbanded group, Gabungan Ketua Cawangan Malaysia (GKCM), previously led by him.

site_title: Thai king's cremation set for Oct 26: Government official
summary: Thailand's King Bhumibol Adulyadej's cremation is set for October 26, following a five-day funeral period. The coronation of his son, King Maha Vajiralongkorn, has been put on hold until after the funeral. The event marks the end of a year-long mourning period and is expected to lead to a general election. The government and the palace have confirmed the plans, with officials stating that the cremation will be a lavish affair, and the funeral is expected to attract huge crowds.

site_title: Death by overwork: Japan's move to cap overtime at whopping 100 hours slammed
summary: Japan has unveiled its first-ever plan to limit overtime, capping it at 100 hours a month, in an effort to address a national health crisis caused by excessive work hours. The plan, proposed by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, aims to tackle "karoshi," or death from overwork, which has led to hundreds of deaths each year. However, critics argue the cap is too lenient and will do little to prevent overwork deaths, with some labeling it "outrageous" and "impossible to support."

site_title: Man sentenced to 15 months' jail after permanently disfiguring woman following a disagreement at a nightclub
summary: A 54-year-old man, Lek Lai Seng, was sentenced to 15 months' jail for permanently disfiguring a 37-year-old woman, Ms Tan Mei Ji, after a disagreement at a nightclub in 2014. The incident occurred when Lek smashed a glass against Ms Tan's left cheek after a monetary dispute over a business venture that did not materialize. The woman now has a permanent scar and nightmares, while Lek claims the injury was self-inflicted, although the prosecution disputes this.

site_title: Rising seas could push some US migration to areas far from coast: Study
summary: A study published in Nature Climate Change suggests rising sea levels due to climate change may drive US coastal residents to areas far from the coast, including landlocked states like Arizona and Wyoming. By 2100, these states are projected to see significant increases in population, with Nevada's Clark County expected to receive up to 117,000 climate migrants. Residents tend to move to destinations with family connections or better job prospects, often far from the coast, highlighting the need for municipalities to consider climate migrants in their long-term planning.

site_title: Britain’s PM Theresa May urges parliament to vote for early election
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May urged parliament to vote for an early election on April 19, 2017, citing a need to heal divisions in Britain before starting divorce talks with the European Union. May announced the election, scheduled for June 8, 2017, to strengthen her hand in negotiations and avoid a clash of priorities in the final stages of the two-year Brexit talks. The move was met with criticism from opposition politicians, but May predicted she would comfortably win the backing of more than two-thirds of parliament.

site_title: US$2,000 Balenciaga bag looks suspiciously like an Ikea shopping bag
summary: A $2,000 Balenciaga tote bag has been criticized for its resemblance to an Ikea shopping bag, priced at $0.99. The Arena Extra-Large Shopper Tote features a similar design, with blue wrinkled leather and gold-stamped logo, selling for $2,145. This is not the first Balenciaga bag to draw inspiration from affordable brands, with earlier designs like the Bazar Shopper Tote and Blanket Square selling well despite criticism. The tactic appears to be working, but the question remains if the French brand can continue to replicate cheap designs without alienating fashionistas.

site_title: eSports to be a medal event at 2022 Asian Games
summary: eSports will be an official medal sport at the 2022 Asian Games in China, following a partnership between the Olympic Council of Asia and Alisports, the sports arm of Alibaba. The decision reflects the rapid development and popularity of eSports among youth, with the OCA committing to its growth and improvement. The inclusion of eSports as a demonstration sport at the 2022 Asian Games will serve as a stepping stone for its potential inclusion in the Olympics.

site_title: Interpol issues red notice for Chinese tycoon Guo Wengui 'at Beijing's request'
summary: The Interpol has issued a red notice for Chinese tycoon Guo Wengui at Beijing's request, suspecting him of bribing former vice minister Ma Jian with 60 million yuan (S$12.1 million). Guo, a real estate magnate, has ties to Ma, who is facing corruption investigation. An Interpol red notice is a request to locate and arrest pending extradition, not an international arrest warrant. The move comes after Guo alleged misuse of power against Fu Zhenghua, China's executive deputy minister of public security, in recent interviews. China lacks extradition treaties with the US and Britain.

site_title: Rare row of six Peck Seah Street conservation shophouses up for sale
summary: A row of six conservation shophouses in Tanjong Pagar, Singapore, is up for sale via expression of interest for S$57.8 million. The shophouses, owned by a private equity fund, have a 33m wide frontage and are near the Tanjong Pagar MRT station. With a combined land area of 8,213 sq ft, they offer a guide price of S$2,900 per sq ft. The property has been refurbished at S$2 million and is being sold with existing tenancies. An expression of interest exercise closes on May 23, 2017.

site_title: China stocks are unnerving investors again as losses deepen
summary: China's Shanghai Composite Index has plummeted 3.3% in a four-day slump, the steepest decline since mid-December, breaching the 3,200 level for the first time in two months. The decline is attributed to the securities regulator's tougher stance on irregularities in the market, along with tensions on the Korean peninsula and fears of a tightening economy. The ChiNext gauge of small-cap shares is heading for its lowest close in two years, with some traders speculating that state-backed funds may step in to shore up the market.

site_title: Johor state official charged with graft
summary: Johor state executive councillor Abdul Latif Bandi has been charged with 33 counts of graft under Section 28(1)(c) of the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) Act, totaling RM30 million. He was charged along with Amir Sharifuddin Abdul Raub, both facing 33 charges each. Abdul Latif was arrested in February over a massive housing and land scandal, with his home seized and luxury items found, including 150 handbags and a luxury vehicle. Bail was set at RM2 million each with one surety, and the accused were ordered to surrender their passports.

site_title: V-P Mike Pence says US is working with allies to put pressure on North Korea
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence stated that the US will work with its allies, including China, to put economic and diplomatic pressure on North Korea. Pence reaffirmed the US commitment to reining in North Korea's nuclear and missile ambitions, saying the US will defeat any attack with an "overwhelming response." Pence's comments come amid controversy over the USS Carl Vinson aircraft carrier strike group's location, but he did not mention the issue. The US, South Korea, and Japan are calling on North Korea to abandon its nuclear and ballistic missile programs, and China expresses serious concern over North Korea's nuclear and missile development.

site_title: Golf: Still no timetable for Tiger Woods return from back injury
summary: Tiger Woods has no set timetable for his return to tournament golf due to ongoing back issues. After missing the cut at his first PGA Tour event since January and withdrawing from the Dubai Desert Classic, Woods acknowledged "good days and bad days" with his surgically repaired back. He expressed resignation to the uncertainty, having undergone three back operations. Woods briefly returned to competition in December and has been working on a new golf course design in Missouri, which is scheduled to open in 2019.

site_title: How Theresa May's decision to call an election could help Scotland's independence forces
summary: Theresa May's surprise call for a British general election on June 8 has unexpectedly boosted Scotland's independence forces. Despite the UK voting 52% to 48% to leave the EU, Scotland opted to remain by a larger majority, leaving May to claim Brexit is inevitable and Sturgeon to call it "democratically unacceptable." Polls suggest the Scottish National Party (SNP) will maintain its dominant position, potentially giving Sturgeon a reinforced mandate and forcing her to come up with answers to pressing questions about independence.

site_title: New Zealand tightens immigration rules in 'Kiwi-first' crackdown
summary: New Zealand is tightening its immigration rules, introducing a "Kiwis-first" approach to strike a balance between encouraging domestic hiring and attracting skilled workers. The changes, set to be implemented later this year, include a minimum income requirement of NZ$49,000 for "skilled" visas and restrictions on family members joining visa holders. The move aims to address concerns over low wages growth and soaring house prices, while also addressing labor shortages in sectors like technology and construction.

site_title: South Korea set to open lavish casino just as missile spat scares off Chinese gamblers
summary: South Korea's first casino resort, Paradise City, is set to open despite a diplomatic spat with China, which has scared off Chinese gamblers. The country's largest casino operator, Paradise Co Ltd, and Japanese slot machine maker Sega Sammy Holdings Inc, will open the resort near Seoul's Incheon International Airport, targeting Japanese and Southeast Asian consumers to offset revenue losses. Chinese travel agents were banned from selling tours to South Korea due to a planned anti-North Korea missile defence system outside Seoul, resulting in a 39% drop in Chinese visitors.

site_title: Japan's middle-aged 'parasite singles' fear uncertain future
summary: In Japan, approximately 4.5 million middle-aged individuals, aged 35-54, live with their parents, known as "parasite singles." This demographic trend, which emerged in the 1990s, is expected to worsen as the parents of these individuals pass away, placing a significant burden on Japan's already strained social welfare system. Many of these individuals rely on their parents' pensions, have limited savings, and face challenges finding stable employment, exacerbating the country's low birth rate and shrinking population.

site_title: Trump raised $149.6 million for inauguration, doubling Obama's record
summary: US President Donald Trump raised $149.6 million for his inauguration, more than doubling President Barack Obama's record of $53 million. The funds came from wealthy donors and corporations, with donor packages ranging from $25,000 to $1 million or more. Trump's inaugural committee is not required to report how it spent the money, fueling questions about his commitment to populist ideas. Trump's fundraising pace continued after Inauguration Day, with his re-election campaign raising $7.1 million in the first three months of this year.

site_title: Jakarta holds gubernatorial polls amid high tension
summary: President Joko Widodo urged unity among Indonesians as millions cast their votes in the tightly contested Jakarta gubernatorial election. Incumbent Basuki Tjahaja Purnama is running against conservative Muslim candidate Anies Baswedan, amidst sectarian strife and allegations of money politics. Quick counts of votes are expected to reveal the winner, with Basuki's underdog status despite being a double minority in Indonesia. The election is seen as a test of pluralism in Indonesia, with observers warning that a hardline Islamist victory could undermine democratic pluralism.

site_title: Police break up WhatsApp child porn image sharing network across Europe and Latin America
summary: Police have arrested 39 suspects across Europe and Latin America in a coordinated operation to dismantle a WhatsApp-based child pornography network. The network, dubbed "Operation Tantalio", was used to share images of child sex abuse in over a dozen countries, including Spain, Germany, Italy, and South and Central America. Hundreds of devices containing child exploitation material were seized, and 25 private groups are currently being investigated. The suspects are accused of sharing images of children as young as babies, with some dating back 20 years, and face charges of child abuse and exploitation.

site_title: Indonesians vote in Jakarta poll marred by religious divisions
summary: Indonesians voted in the Jakarta election on April 19, 2017, choosing between Muslim candidate Anies Baswedan and Christian incumbent Basuki "Ahok" Tjahaja Purnama. The election, marred by religious tensions, is seen as a test of Indonesia's democracy and tolerance. Basuki faces blasphemy charges, while Baswedan is backed by conservative retired general Prabowo Subianto. Over 7 million people voted, with unofficial results expected soon, and the loser can contest the results in the Constitutional Court.

site_title: Boxing: Anthony Joshua to Tyson Fury: shut up and get in the ring
summary: Anthony Joshua and Tyson Fury exchanged insults on Twitter, with Joshua challenging Fury to step into the ring and put up his money. The two British heavyweights engaged in a heated exchange after Fury called Joshua a "poor man's Frank Bruno." Joshua responded by offering Fury two ringside tickets to his upcoming fight against Wladimir Klitschko, which Fury refused. The two have a history of postponed fights, with Fury citing ankle and mental health issues. Joshua has established himself as a leading heavyweight, and the exchange has reignited speculation about a potential fight between the two.

site_title: Georgia congressional race seen as early Trump test heads to a runoff
summary: Jon Ossoff, a Democrat, narrowly won the US House of Representatives primary in Georgia's 6th district, but fell short of the 50% threshold, forcing a runoff. Ossoff, a 30-year-old documentary filmmaker and former congressional aide, secured 48.1% of the vote, while Republican candidate Karen Handel received 19.8%. The runoff, set for June 20, will be a challenging test for Ossoff, but Democrats see it as an opportunity to capitalize on President Trump's low popularity and potentially retake control of the House of Representatives in next year's midterm elections.

site_title: PayPal and Google get cozy with new digital wallet partnership
summary: PayPal and Google have partnered to enable payments through the tap of a phone at thousands of retail locations, including Walgreens Boots Alliance and Dunkin' Donuts restaurants. PayPal users can link their accounts to Android Pay, expanding their reach in stores. The deal aims to increase PayPal's frequency of use, with CEO Dan Schulman seeking to convert PayPal into a versatile financial tool. The partnership may boost Google's mobile payments efforts, but an acquisition of PayPal remains a possibility.

summary: I couldn't find any article content to summarize.

site_title: Athletics: Adidas sparks furore with Boston Marathon 'survivor' e-mail
summary: Adidas sparked outrage after sending an email to Boston Marathon participants congratulating them on "surviving" the event, referencing the 2013 bombing that killed three and injured 264. The email's insensitive tone sparked a social media backlash, prompting Adidas to apologize, saying "we are incredibly sorry" for the mistake. The company acknowledged that no thought was given to the email's impact, and the official Twitter account tweeted "we deeply apologize for our mistake." The incident has raised concerns about brand sensitivity and cultural awareness.

site_title: Trump's 'Buy American' edict may have little impact on US steel industry
summary: US President Donald Trump's "Buy American" executive order, aimed at boosting the domestic steel industry, has raised questions about its effectiveness due to existing loopholes and waivers granted to foreign companies. Steel executives and analysts argue that enforcing the order could cause supply problems and harm US companies, particularly those that use imported steel. The industry's skepticism is fueled by the Trump administration's lack of bold action on trade agreements and infrastructure. Despite some labor unions and industry groups welcoming the order, analysts warn that investors should temper their expectations for meaningful change.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust posts 9.6% rise in Q1 DPU to 2.40 cents
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 9.6% increase in Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.40 Singapore cents, driven by the acquisition of CapitaGreen and higher occupancy rates. Gross revenue surged 33.9% to S$89.5 million and net property income grew 34.3% to S$69.9 million. CCT expects downward pressure on office market rents in 2017 due to new developments and tenant relocations. Despite challenging market conditions, the trust maintained a high occupancy rate of 97.8% and 80% of its borrowings are fixed at lower interest rates.

site_title: Pound jumps to 6-month high on snap British election but Asian stock markets cautious
summary: The pound surged to a 6-month high against the US dollar following Britain's surprise snap election, with investors speculating it could lead to a more market-friendly outcome in its EU divorce. Asian markets, however, remained cautious, with Hong Kong, Sydney, Seoul, and Singapore falling. Analysts attributed the market volatility to increasing tensions in the Korean peninsula and the unpredictable French election. Safe-havens such as gold and bonds gained, while investors were advised to maintain a cautious stance and be prepared for potential investment opportunities.

site_title: Singapore ties with Germany for most powerful passport in the world
summary: Singapore and Germany have tied for the most powerful passport in the world, according to the Global Passport Power Rank 2017. The Singapore passport now has a score of 159, allowing holders visa-on-arrival in Ukraine for up to 15 days. While Germany still has the edge for visa-free travel, Singapore beats it with a visa-on-arrival score of 37. The Passport Index, which compares 193 UN member countries, ranks Singapore as the highest-ranked Asian country in both the Global Passport Power Rank and the Visa Restrictions Index.

site_title: 6.2 earthquake shakes Peru: Institute
summary: A 6.2-magnitude earthquake struck northern Peru's Loreto region on April 18, 2017, at 1:49am local time. The quake, at a depth of 142km, was felt in Peru, Ecuador, and Colombia, but no immediate damage was reported. Residents evacuated buildings and took precautionary measures, while emergency services reported no damage. The quake occurred in an earthquake-prone zone, the Ring of Fire, near the Pacific.

site_title: Death toll rises to 113 in Peru floods and mudslides
summary: Peru's death toll from flooding and mudslides has risen to 113, with five additional fatalities reported last weekend. Over 178,000 people are homeless, and 1 million homes have been partially damaged. The country needs approximately $9 billion to rebuild and modernize affected areas. Heavy rains, attributed to a coastal El Nino climate phenomenon, have also affected Colombia, where 323 people, including 100 children, were killed in a mudslide on March 31. Scientists blame the extreme weather on a localized warming of the Pacific Ocean along the South American coast.

site_title: Hat-trick hero Ronaldo first to 100 Champions League goals
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo became the first player to reach 100 Champions League goals, scoring a hat-trick in Real Madrid's 3-1 win over Bayern Munich. The Portuguese forward, who scored 85 goals in 85 appearances for Madrid, also extended his lead over Barcelona's Lionel Messi as the top scorer in Champions League history. Ronaldo's treble moved him to 100 goals, 15 of which he scored prior to joining Real in 2009.

site_title: Donald Trump orders review of visa programme to encourage hiring Americans
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order reviewing the H-1B visa program for high-skilled foreign workers, aiming to replace the current lottery system with a merit-based system. The move, part of Trump's "America First" agenda, could affect technology firms and outsourcing companies, potentially leading to changes in the visa allocation process. The review also includes a government procurement rule change to favor American companies, particularly the US steel industry. Critics argue the H-1B program allows outsourcing firms to flood the system with lower-paid workers, replacing American jobs.

site_title: Attack near Egypt's St Catherine's monastery kills one, injures four
summary: An attack near Egypt's St Catherine's Monastery in south Sinai killed at least one person and injured four, according to state television. Gunmen on a police checkpoint carried out the attack, with no group claiming responsibility. This incident comes just over a week after two bombings on Egyptian churches during Palm Sunday services, and follows years of an insurgency by Islamist militants in northern Sinai.

site_title: Family feuds over fortunes and business empires: 7 cases that have grabbed headlines
summary: Family feuds over fortunes and business empires have led to court battles in Singapore. A recent case involves Moh Tai Siang, who lost a court fight against his two brothers over their family home sold for $16 million in 2015. Other notable cases include a dispute over Malaysia tycoon Loong Yoke Phin's firms, a public fallout between the Jumabhoy clan over Scotts Holdings, and a fight to control Yeo Hiap Seng. These cases highlight the challenges of navigating family dynamics and wealth inheritance, with some families mired in factional fighting and others seeking to protect their interests.

site_title: Football: Real Madrid see off Bayern Munich in controversial thriller to reach semis
summary: Real Madrid advanced to the Champions League semi-finals with a 4-2 win over 10-man Bayern Munich in extra time, securing a 6-3 aggregate victory. Cristiano Ronaldo scored a hat-trick, including his 100th Champions League goal from an offside position, to seal the win. Bayern Munich's Arturo Vidal was sent off for two yellow cards, and Sergio Ramos scored an own goal to force the extra period. Real Madrid dominated the game after Vidal's dismissal, scoring four goals in the second half to secure the win.

site_title: Football: Leicester's Champions League dream over as Atletico power into semis
summary: Leicester City's Champions League dream ended with a 2-1 aggregate loss to Atletico Madrid. The Spanish side, led by manager Diego Simeone, reached the semi-finals for the third time in four seasons. Saul Niguez scored the opening goal in the 26th minute, which Atletico held onto despite Leicester's strong second-half comeback. Jamie Vardy equalized on 61 minutes, but it wasn't enough as Atletico advanced with a 2-1 aggregate win. Leicester, in their first Champions League campaign, fell short in their fairytale run.

site_title: 3 men on hash run triggered Woodleigh MRT flour scare: 6 things you didn't know about 'hashing'
summary: Three men involved in the Woodleigh MRT station flour scare on April 18 are part of a group participating in "hashing," a running practice where groups mark trails with flour, chalk, or toilet paper. The practice originated in Malaysia in 1938 and has since spread globally, with several active groups in Singapore. However, using flour in "NParks territory" is prohibited, and a 2016 guide advises runners to use only toilet paper. A man died during a Hash House Harriers run last year, and there have been instances of harassment and court cases against women participating in the activity.

site_title: Wall Street hit by weak Goldman, J&J results
summary: Wall Street stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Dow experiencing its largest drop due to disappointing earnings from Goldman Sachs and Johnson & Johnson. Goldman Sachs reported lower-than-expected quarterly profit, while Johnson & Johnson's first-quarter revenues fell short of analyst expectations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.6%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also declined. The weak earnings were attributed to a disappointing performance in Goldman's trading division and Johnson & Johnson's pharmaceutical segment.

site_title: Gunman 'motivated by hate' kills three people in California
summary: A 39-year-old homeless man, Kori Ali Muhammad, killed three white people in Fresno, California, on April 18, 2017, before surrendering to police. Muhammad, who identified as "Black Jesus," told police he was motivated by a hatred of white people and had previously made terroristic threats. He fired 16 bullets from a revolver, killing two people on sidewalks and one in a parking lot. The police are investigating possible links to terrorism, and Muhammad's family had cut off contact with him.

site_title: Call lift rescue experts when stuck in lift, not SCDF
summary: A Singaporean resident suggests that in case of a lift breakdown, people should call lift rescue experts instead of the Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) to minimize unnecessary use of emergency resources. The SCDF should only be called in emergency situations, such as fires and injuries. Lift mechanics should be trained to rescue people trapped in lifts and have the necessary equipment to do so. All lift cars should display the Essential Maintenance Service Unit (EMSU) telephone number, allowing people to contact experts directly.

site_title: Communities are shaped by one another in a multicultural society
summary: Singapore's multicultural society is shaped by its diverse communities, with various cultural customs, ceremonies, and rituals giving meaning to morality. The nation values family, social harmony, respect for authority, and a united family. Cultures are not solely the achievements of individual communities, but are also influenced by others, making them multiculturally constituted. Embracing other cultures and promoting community togetherness is crucial for integrating the nation, and this openness is what makes Singaporeans united. This approach fosters a sense of shared identity and national pride.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, April 19 edition
summary: A man identified as Stevie Steve, accused of killing a Cleveland man and live-streaming the murder on Facebook, took his own life after a brief car chase with Pennsylvania State Police. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced the company's efforts to prevent similar content. Meanwhile, a US aircraft carrier was not deployed to deter North Korea due to a navigation error, and a video of a violent United Airlines passenger removal went viral, prompting no employee firings. Cristiano Ronaldo led Real Madrid to the Champions League semi-finals with a hat-trick, and Kevin Spacey will host the Tony Awards.

site_title: Guns, explosives found at Marseille flat in foiled pre-election attack
summary: French police foiled a pre-election attack plot in Marseille, arresting two men on suspicion of planning an "imminent" attack just days before the first round of France's presidential vote. The suspects, identified as 23-year-old Clement Baur and 29-year-old Mahiedine Merabet, were found to have guns, explosives, and an ISIS flag in their apartment. The plot was deemed "violent" and authorities suspect the men were targeting French soil. The arrests raised fears of extremist attacks ahead of the election, which has seen the campaign narrowing with just days to go.

site_title: Stronger non-profits need stronger boards
summary: The Commissioner of Charities in Singapore has refined the code of governance for charities, recommending term limits for board members to ensure steady renewal. A study found 64% of non-profits lack defined term limits for chairpersons and 36% for treasurers, with many returning to these positions after term limits. The revised code requires disclosure of reasons for exceeding term limits of 10 consecutive years. The Centre for Non-Profit Leadership supports the change, emphasizing that well-governed non-profits will be able to adapt in a rapidly changing world.

site_title: Earthquake shakes Ecuador’s Amazon region, damage unclear
summary: An earthquake with a 6.0 magnitude hit Ecuador's Amazon region, approximately 260km north-west of Peru's Iquitos jungle town. The quake occurred about a year after a deadly 7.8-magnitude quake in April 2016, which killed around 600 people. Damage in Ecuador's Amazon region is unclear, with Petroecuador seeking information about possible damage.

site_title: Frog excretes mucus that fights flu: Study
summary: A study published in the journal Immunity found that a frog in south India excretes a mucus containing a peptide, called urumin, that appears to fight off the H1 strain of flu virus. Researchers collected the mucus using electric shocks and tested its effectiveness on lab mice, which showed protection against a lethal dose of H1 flu virus. Urumin is not toxic to mammals and appears to disrupt flu virus integrity. Further research is needed to determine if urumin could become a preventive treatment against the flu in humans.

site_title: Around 100 unarmed South Sudan refugees take 13 UN mission staff hostage
summary: Around 100 unarmed South Sudanese refugees took 13 UN mission staff hostage in eastern Congo, demanding to be moved to a third country. The refugees, mostly former fighters loyal to former vice president Riek Machar, have been living in a camp since August 2016. The UN is negotiating with them, with eight agreeing to be repatriated to South Sudan's capital Juba. The refugees are frustrated at being confined in the tiny camp and fear returning to South Sudan.

site_title: Donald Trump seeks headway on 'Buy American, Hire American' pledge
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order to tighten skilled-worker visa rules, aiming to "Buy American, Hire American" and curb "abuses" of the H-1B visa system. The decree instructs government agencies to address issues and propose reforms, but its impact is limited without congressional reform. The Trump administration seeks to award visas to highly skilled applicants, while the US Chamber of Commerce warns against eliminating the program. The move is part of Trump's efforts to regain momentum on domestic policy after court blocks his travel ban and health reform fails in Congress.

site_title: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg vows to help prevent repeat of Cleveland murder posting
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg pledged to prevent repeat of the Cleveland murder posting, where a fatal shooting was visible on the social media site for two hours. Zuckerberg expressed sympathy to the victim's family and announced a review of how objectionable material is reported and taken down. Facebook will also work with developers to create more augmented reality games and uses, aiming to leave a virtual note or find virtual street art. The company has made changes to its Messenger app, adding a "discover" tab.

site_title: Google Earth re-invented for new era
summary: Google has launched a revamped version of its Earth mapping service, featuring storytelling, artificial intelligence, and interactive experiences. The new "Voyager" feature guides users through interactive stories told by experts, while "knowledge cards" provide deeper information on places visited. A "Feeling Lucky?" feature suggests hidden gems, and users can capture and send digital postcards. The new version is available on Google Chrome, Android, and other internet browsing software, marking the first time Earth can be accessed directly through a web browser.

site_title: Football: Dortmund players 'fully focused' on Monaco - Tuchel
summary: Borussia Dortmund coach Thomas Tuchel expressed confidence ahead of the second leg of their Champions League quarter-final against Monaco, saying the team is "fully focused" and "stable" despite the traumatic events of last week's bus attack. Dortmund lost the first leg 3-2, but Tuchel believes the incident has brought the team together and strengthened their resolve. German international Marco Reus, who returned from injury to score in the weekend's Bundesliga win, is set to play against Monaco, with the team aiming to turn the tie around.

site_title: Aircraft carrier wasn't sailing to deter North Korea, as US suggested
summary: US President Donald Trump falsely claimed that an aircraft carrier was being sent to the Sea of Japan to deter North Korea, when in reality the USS Carl Vinson was sailing in the opposite direction, to participate in joint exercises with the Australian navy. The White House and Pentagon officials initially perpetuated the false narrative, with Defense Secretary Jim Mattis providing partially erroneous explanations. The miscues were corrected when the Navy posted a photo of the Carl Vinson on Monday, showing it was actually headed north to the Western Pacific. The incident raised questions about the administration's communication and decision-making during a period of heightened tensions.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines is first airline to track fleet with satellites
summary: Malaysia Airlines has become the first airline to track its fleet with satellites, signing an agreement with Aireon, SITAONAIR, and FlightAware. The move aims to monitor aircraft anywhere in the world, including remote areas, and is part of a broader effort to improve global aircraft tracking. The deal comes three years after Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 disappeared, with relatives of passengers still seeking answers about the disappearance. The new satellite network, set to be completed in 2018, will provide real-time tracking capabilities, but its effectiveness in previous cases, such as MH370, remains unclear.

site_title: Son of Swee Kee chicken rice founder sues 2 brothers for alleged share of $16m house
summary: A son of Swee Kee chicken rice founder Moh Tai Siang is suing his two brothers, Royston and Tai Tong, over a $16 million house in Katong. Moh Tai Siang claims his brothers held his one-quarter share on trust, but they deny this and argue he sold his stake for $200,000 in 1985. The dispute arises from a 1985 transfer of ownership, where Moh Tai Siang's mother allegedly told him he would get his share back when he is old or when the house is sold, but he disputes receiving any payment.

site_title: Kevin Spacey to host Broadway's Tony awards
summary: Kevin Spacey will host the 71st Tony Awards, marking his first time hosting the New York-based award show. The event, which will take place on June 11, comes after recent hosts Neil Patrick Harris, Hugh Jackman, and James Corden were unavailable. Spacey, a two-time Oscar winner and Tony winner, expressed humor about being the 15th choice for the job. Nominations will be announced on May 2, with last year's winner Hamilton taking 11 awards. The ceremony will be broadcast live on CBS from Radio City Music Hall.

site_title: United Airlines won't fire anyone over manhandled passenger
summary: United Airlines' violent removal of a passenger from a flight was a "system failure" and no employees will lose their jobs, according to the airline's chief Oscar Munoz. The incident, which sparked global outrage, has led to policy changes, including no longer having law enforcement remove customers from flights and requiring employees to sign in at least 60 minutes before the flight. Munoz apologized and said the airline will make the necessary changes to ensure the incident never happens again, despite potential financial and operational effects.

site_title: Space debris problem getting worse, say scientists
summary: Scientists warn of a worsening space debris problem, citing a significant increase in orbiting fragments large enough to destroy spacecraft since 2008. The estimated number of tiny objects, which can harm or degrade spacecraft, has risen to 150 million. The European Space Agency (ESA) and experts urge a global effort to tackle the issue, which poses a risk of catastrophic damage from hypervelocity impacts. Debris fields have been amplified by recent collisions, and satellites must often resort to fuel-consuming avoidance maneuvers to avoid collisions, with the ISS experiencing this issue four times in its history.

site_title: British PM Theresa May hopes to get strong mandate from early polls for Brexit talks
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is seeking a strong mandate from early polls to negotiate Britain's exit from the European Union. Holding general elections three years ahead of schedule, May aims to silence opposition and rebuff potential changes to her Brexit stance. The Conservative Party enjoys a double-digit lead over Labour, but May faces risks of her own party appearing divided and the Liberal Democrats potentially eating into their vote. The early elections will also test May's efforts to marginalize Scottish separatists and maintain control over the Brexit process.

site_title: Myanmar publisher who criticised establishment is found stabbed to death
summary: A Myanmar publisher, Wai Yan Heinn, 27, was found stabbed to death in his office, with 15 stab wounds to his chest and abdomen. He was the editor of the magazine Iron Rose, which criticized the military, business establishment, and former ruling generals. Journalists and activists face obstacles in Myanmar, with recent assassinations and threats targeting prominent figures. The investigation is ongoing, and the family is seeking answers, but fear of retribution is expected to silence them.

site_title: Basketball: Singapore Slingers falter in Hong Kong, levelling ABL Finals series at 1-1
summary: The Hong Kong Eastern Long Lions defeated the Singapore Slingers 92-84 in Game 2 of the ABL Finals, leveling the series at 1-1. The Lions started strongly, but the Slingers overcame a five-point deficit in the third quarter. However, the Lions regrouped in the final quarter, with Josh Boone playing through an ankle injury, to secure the win. The series now shifts to Singapore for Game 3 on April 21.

site_title: DPM Teo meets Leung Chun Ying, Carrie Lam on Hong Kong visit
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean met Hong Kong Chief Executive-elect Carrie Lam and Leung Chun Ying during a two-day visit to Hong Kong. Teo congratulated Lam on her electoral success, reaffirmed the strong bilateral relationship between Singapore and Hong Kong, and expressed confidence in Hong Kong's future development. He also extended an invitation for Lam to visit Singapore soon, emphasizing the benefits of the "One Country, Two Systems" framework for Hong Kong's stability and prosperity.

site_title: Woodleigh MRT incident: 3 men involved are part of running group using flour to mark out jogging trail
summary: A 69-year-old man was arrested for public nuisance after a flour substance was found at Woodleigh MRT Station in Singapore. Three men from a running group, Seletar Hash House Harriers, were assisting the police with the investigation. They were marking out a jogging trail before a run, a common practice in hashing, a running/drinking/social club activity. The station was closed for three hours due to the incident, which sparked a bioterrorism scare in the past.

site_title: Donald Trump praises China for helping on North Korea
summary: US President Donald Trump praised China for its role in pressuring North Korea, citing a stronger relationship with President Xi Jinping. Trump defended his softening stance on trade with China, saying he wouldn't start a trade war while addressing the North Korean issue. He credited China with sending back coal ships and fuel, and expressed hope for peace. Trump also downplayed the possibility of a military strike against North Korea, saying he didn't want to reveal his plans and acknowledging that previous administrations had been "outplayed" by the country.

site_title: Egypt discovers 3,000-year-old tomb of nobleman
summary: Egyptian archaeologists have discovered a 3,000-year-old tomb of a nobleman, Userhat, a judge from the New Kingdom, at the Draa Abul Nagaa necropolis in Luxor. The tomb features an open court, rectangular hall, corridor, and inner chamber, with artifacts including figurines, wooden masks, and a sarcophagus lid handle. This latest find, along with previous discoveries, is seen as a positive step for Egypt's struggling tourism industry, which has been impacted by political instability and militant attacks. Excavation is ongoing in a second chamber.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic through in Monte Carlo after Simon scare
summary: Novak Djokovic overcame a grueling two-and-a-half-hour match against Gilles Simon 6-3, 3-6, 7-5 in the second round of the Monte Carlo Masters. Djokovic, the world number two, struggled with poor form and injury, but managed to win the match after being broken at 4-4 in the final set. This victory marks the start of Djokovic's build-up for the Roland Garros tournament.

site_title: 'Facebook killer' kills himself after car chase
summary: A 47-year-old man, Stevie Steve, who posted a video on Facebook of a Cleveland man's fatal shooting, took his own life after a brief pursuit by Pennsylvania State Police officers. Steve Stephens, with no prior record, was accused of killing Robert Godwin Sr. on Sunday and claimed to have killed a dozen others. Facebook will review its content moderation policies after Stephens' post was visible on the site for two hours, and his employer, Beech Brook, stated he had cleared a background check. Stephens was found in Erie County, Pennsylvania, after a public tip.

site_title: Turkey minister rejects EU call for probe into vote
summary: Turkey's EU Affairs Minister Omer Celik rejected the EU's call for a probe into alleged irregularities in the referendum, labeling the appeal as "unacceptable" and "groundless." The EU had urged Ankara to investigate claims of irregularities in the vote, which resulted in a narrow win for the 'Yes' camp on the constitutional changes. Celik called on the EU to respect democratic processes and slammed a report by international observers as "far from maturity." The international observers had charged the referendum campaign was conducted on an "unlevel playing field."

site_title: Criminal Minds: Beyond Borders depiction of Singapore slammed as inaccurate, misleading
summary: The TV series Criminal Minds: Beyond Borders has faced backlash for its inaccurate and stereotypical portrayal of Singapore in an episode titled "Cinderella And The Dragon." The episode inaccurately depicts Geylang as a slum, incorrectly portrays the Singapore Police Force as "Singapore PD," and misrepresents the country's justice system. The show also fails to accurately depict Changi Airport and the presence of roadside hawkers. The episode's inaccuracies have sparked outrage among Singaporeans on social media, with many calling for the writers to get the facts right and visit the country to learn about its culture.

site_title: Singapore central bank moves to broaden protection of insurance policy owners
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is proposing to expand the Policy Owners' Protection (PPF) Scheme to cover private property and vehicles used for commercial gain. The scheme aims to protect policyholders in the event of an insurer's insolvency. The MAS also proposes to impose caps on property damage claims, setting a $50,000 limit for motor claims and a $300,000 limit for property claims. The move aims to keep levies and premiums affordable and aligns with practices in other jurisdictions. A consultation paper has been issued, with feedback due by May 19.

site_title: Owner of now defunct Cuddles Cat Cafe sentenced to 2 weeks' jail and fined $3,500
summary: A 33-year-old Singaporean, Jonathan Tan Wei-De, was sentenced to 2 weeks' jail and fined $3,500 for failing to comply with licensing conditions at his defunct cat cafe, Cuddles Cat Cafe. Tan had provided false information in his application for a temporary licence and breached conditions by not keeping cats in good health and testing negative for toxoplasmosis. The Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority (AVA) had initiated an investigation after receiving allegations of mismanagement of diseased cats in 2014. Tan was also required to cease operations and remove all cats from the cafe.

site_title: Emas Offshore unit slapped with US$195 million trade claim
summary: Emas Offshore's subsidiary Lewek Champion Shipping has received a US$195 million trade claim, with the option to be wound up if payment is not made within 21 days. The claim stems from a bareboat charter dispute after Emas terminated the agreement following a US bankruptcy court's rejection of a back-to-back charter on the vessel. Emas is seeking legal advice and assessing the impact on the group.

site_title: SEA Games 2017: President Tony Tan Keng Yam visits Team S'pore athletes training for KL event
summary: President Tony Tan Keng Yam visited Team Singapore athletes training for the 2017 SEA Games on April 18, 2017. He encouraged the athletes, who were preparing for the Aug 19-30 Games in Kuala Lumpur, and expressed confidence in their abilities. Tan praised the athletes' hard work, discipline, and determination, noting that their efforts reflect the values of the Singaporean people. He also highlighted the country's exceptional medal haul at previous games, saying he looked forward to a "very good result" for Team Singapore in the upcoming events.

site_title: PM Lee Hsien Loong to deliver eulogy at Othman Wok's memorial service, 600 guests expected
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is set to deliver a eulogy at the memorial service for late Mr. Othman Wok, one of Singapore's founding fathers, on April 19. Over 600 guests, including prominent figures, will attend the service at Victoria Concert Hall. Eulogies will be delivered by six individuals, including Lee Hsien Loong, Dr. Yaacob Ibrahim, and Minister of State Dr. Janil Puthucheary. The event aims to commemorate Mr. Wok's contributions to Singapore's peace and harmony, and a minute of silence and National Anthem will be observed at the end of the service.

site_title: The Straits Times' News In A Minute: April 18, 2017
summary: A 69-year-old man was arrested for causing public alarm after leaving a white substance, later identified as baking flour, at Woodleigh MRT station. Flash floods hit parts of Singapore. A man accused of setting fire to St Hilda's Church was charged with mischief.

site_title: Nearly 300 North Koreans surrender in Malaysia for overstaying
summary: Malaysia reported that nearly 300 North Koreans surrendered to authorities over the last week, following the revocation of visa-free entry for the country after the murder of Kim Jong Nam in February. The North Koreans, including 113 on work permits and 183 on social visit passes, had overstayed their visas and will leave Malaysia in stages. The country's Immigration Department stated that four remaining North Koreans with work permits will be handed over to authorities by their employers. The surrender comes as Malaysia seeks to enforce new visa requirements amid economic sanctions on North Korea.

site_title: Reactions to British PM Theresa May calling for early election
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has called for an early general election on June 8, citing the need for political unity in Brexit negotiations. The move is seen as a bid to strengthen her hand in negotiations, but critics argue it may shift attention away from the economy and EU intricacies. Market reactions are mixed, with sterling surging against the dollar but UK shares slipping to a 2% loss. The election outcome could impact Brexit negotiations and potentially lead to a U-turn on the UK's EU exit.

site_title: British PM Theresa May calls election: What next?
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May announced an early general election for June 8, 2017, after a motion was passed by two-thirds of the 650 seats in the House of Commons. The election will be held 25 working days before the scheduled date, May 3. May cited division in Westminster and economic strength as reasons for the move, despite previously ruling out a snap election. The outcome could strengthen her position on Brexit and give her more space to negotiate the UK's exit from the EU.

site_title: EU's Brexit plans unchanged by British vote, spokesman says
summary: The European Union will stick to its Brexit negotiation timeline despite British Prime Minister Theresa May's call for a snap general election. EU President Donald Tusk said the UK elections do not change EU plans, and a summit on April 29 will agree on negotiating guidelines. EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier expects full negotiations to start in early June, although the British position is unclear. The UK formally triggered a two-year Brexit countdown on March 29, with May stating there can be no turning back on Britain's decision to leave the EU.

site_title: Football: Michael Essien, Carlton Cole banned from playing in Indonesia without permits
summary: Indonesian authorities banned former English Premier League players Michael Essien and Carlton Cole from playing until they obtain work permits. The ban follows a failure by their new club, Persib Bandung, to obtain necessary documents. The players were set to debut in the country's top-flight Liga 1, but immigration authorities intervened after a warning was issued to the club. The football association and league organiser had previously granted permission for the players to play, but the ban remains in place as the club works to obtain the permits.

site_title: Russia metro bombing suspect says he was unwitting accomplice
summary: Russian suspect Abror Azimov claimed he was an unwitting accomplice in the April 3 St Petersburg metro bombing that killed 14 people. At a court hearing, Azimov stated he participated in the attack's preparation but did not realize his role. He claimed to have been given instructions without understanding the true nature of his actions. Azimov's confession to preparing the attack contradicts earlier statements, sparking uncertainty about the extent of his involvement.

site_title: Former Pioneer Secondary School to be repurposed for foreign system school use
summary: The former Pioneer Secondary School in Singapore will be repurposed for foreign system school use. The Singapore Land Authority and Economic Development Board have invited proposals for operators to provide affordable education for expatriate children. The conversion is expected to offer cost efficiencies compared to building a new school, and will strengthen Singapore's position as an attractive global city. The goal is to offer quality international education at a more affordable fee, catering to the growing demand for foreign system schools in the city. The tender process will be conducted by the SLA and EDB.

site_title: IMF raises global growth forecast, warns against protectionism
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has raised its 2017 global growth forecast to 3.5% due to manufacturing and trade gains in Europe, Japan, and China. However, the IMF warns that protectionist policies could halt a broad-based recovery, citing the potential for higher prices, lower productivity, and lower overall real income for households. The IMF lifted forecasts for Japan, the eurozone, and China, while holding steady its US growth forecast of 2.3%. The organization emphasizes the risks of trade protectionism, which could lead to a "self-inflicted wound" for the global economy.

site_title: Theresa May: Britain's 'no-nonsense' leader
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has forged a reputation as a no-nonsense pragmatist, seeking to lead the country through a tumultuous period following the UK's shock vote to leave the EU. After becoming PM without winning an election, May has insisted on "Brexit means Brexit" and appealed for national unity amidst divisions in Scotland. Born in 1956, May is a clergyman's daughter who has risen through the ranks, serving as home secretary for six years and earning respect for her hard work and pragmatism.

site_title: School sports: Singapore Sports School narrowly miss out on clean sweep of B & C Div badminton titles
summary: The Singapore Sports School (SSP) narrowly missed a clean sweep of all four B and C Division badminton titles at the National School Games. SSP won three out of four finals, including the B Div boys' and C Div girls' titles, but lost to ACS (I) in the C Div boys' event, 3-2. ACS (I) secured their first C Div boys' title since 2006 with a thrilling win in the final match.

site_title: 3 brilliant ways to enjoy brinjal
summary: This article showcases three simple and delicious ways to enjoy brinjal: Fried Brinjal with Salted Egg Yolk, Stir-Fried Brinjal with Spicy Soy Bean Paste, and Steamed Brinjal with Fragrant Sauce. Each recipe highlights the versatility of brinjal in various cooking methods, from deep-frying to steaming, and incorporates flavorful ingredients such as egg yolks, fermented soy bean paste, and five-spice beancurd. These recipes offer healthy and tasty options for those looking to incorporate brinjal into their meals.
