site_title: Othman Wok memorial service: Some Civic District roads closed, W!ld Rice musical cancelled
summary: A memorial service for late Cabinet minister Othman Wok is set to take place at Victoria Concert Hall on April 19, with roads in the Civic District closed from noon to 2am the next day. Eight bus services will be diverted, and drones are prohibited in the area. The W!ld Rice musical "La Cage Aux Folles" has been cancelled. Motorists and bus commuters are advised to expect delays and be aware of towed vehicles parked illegally or causing obstruction. The service will run from 6:30pm to 8pm.

site_title: Finally, pop star Aaron Kwok weds
summary: Hong Kong pop star Aaron Kwok has married model Moka Fang in a hush-hush ceremony at The Peninsula Hong Kong. The 51-year-old singer and 29-year-old model held a Chinese ceremony in the morning and a 10-table banquet in the evening. Kwok, the last of Hong Kong's Heavenly Kings to marry, kept the event low-key, asking guests not to take pictures or videos. The couple's wedding follows reports of Fang's suspected pregnancy, with some speculating about the low heels of her shoes in a pre-wedding Instagram post.

site_title: Pound rises as Theresa May calls snap election
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May announced a snap general election for June 8, causing the pound to rise and bonds to gain value. The news led to a decline in European stocks, particularly mining shares, and a drop in the Stoxx Europe 600 Index to its lowest level in about three weeks. The announcement also heightened investor uncertainty due to ongoing geopolitical events, including the North Korea standoff and the French presidential election.

site_title: An Islay whisky, from start to finish
summary: Bruichladdich distillery, based on Scotland's Islay island, has produced a range of whiskies using 100% Islay barley, a departure from the traditional use of mainland barley. The Islay Barley Exploration series began in 2004 with a single farm, and now includes 19 farms, with the 2009 expression being the latest release. The whisky is known for its unique flavor profile, with subtle peat and maritime influences, and is compared to the core Classic Laddie, which uses mainland barley, showing a distinct difference in complexity and saltiness.

site_title: 39-year-old man arrested for serial theft from vehicles in multi-storey carparks
summary: A 39-year-old man was arrested for his suspected involvement in a series of thefts from vehicles at multi-story carparks in Punggol, Singapore. The thefts occurred between April 15 and 17, and police used in-vehicle camera footage to identify the suspect. The man was arrested on Monday and recovered stolen items, including cash cards. He faces up to three years in jail if convicted of theft or up to a year if found guilty of mischief. The police highlighted the usefulness of in-vehicle camera footage in solving crimes and encouraged the public to join the Vehicles on Watch programme.

site_title: Fugitive Indian tycoon Vijay Mallya out on bail after London arrest
summary: Vijay Mallya, a fugitive Indian businessman, was arrested in London on Tuesday on a request from the Indian government. Mallya, 61, was declared a willful defaulter by local banks on loans taken for his defunct airline, Kingfisher Airlines. He was granted bail after appearing in a London court. The Indian government accuses Mallya of diverting funds to buy property abroad and owes over $1.4 billion in debt. Mallya maintains his airline's failure was due to macroeconomic factors and government policies, and claims he will prove his innocence in court.

site_title: Football: Winston Lee releases evidence to show Bill Ng was aware $500k donation was for Asean Football Federation
summary: FAS general secretary Winston Lee released evidence showing Tiong Bahru FC chairman Bill Ng was aware a $500,000 donation was meant for the Asean Football Federation. A letter and cheques, some bearing Ng's signature, revealed Ng agreed to the donation and instructed the full amount go to AFF. Lee claims Ng's statement was intended to damage FAS credibility and calls for an apology. Ng disputes Lee's version of events, stating Lee prepared the letter and directed him to use it. The controversy threatens to overshadow the April 29 FAS election.

site_title: Indian businessman Vijay Mallya arrested in London: Police
summary: Indian businessman Vijay Mallya, 61, was arrested in London on Tuesday for extradition on behalf of Indian authorities, accused of $1.4 billion fraud. Mallya fled to Britain in March after banks sued to recover debts from his company, Kingfisher. He will be presented in Westminster Magistrates Court later that day. Mallya has repeatedly denied the charges, and Indian authorities have requested Britain's cooperation in his extradition.

site_title: Weapons found as France arrests two men suspected of plotting 'imminent' attack ahead of polls
summary: French authorities have arrested two men suspected of plotting an "imminent" attack ahead of presidential polls. Guns and bomb-making materials were found during searches in Marseille after the suspects, aged 23 and 29, were taken into custody. The attack was reportedly planned to occur in the "next few days" and the suspects' identities were distributed to security teams of presidential candidates Marine Le Pen and Emmanuel Macron. The arrest comes as France gears up to vote on Sunday in the first round of a two-stage presidential election.

site_title: Indian billionaire plans to splash out US$150 million to make Mahabharata movie
summary: Indian billionaire B. R. Shetty plans to produce a two-part film adaptation of the Hindu epic Mahabharata with a budget of US$150 million, surpassing the cost of India's biggest budget film, Baahubali. Shooting is set to start late next year, with the first installment scheduled for release in early 2020. The film will be released in multiple Indian languages and dubbed for foreign audiences, aiming to reach over three billion people worldwide and reposition India's prowess in mythological storytelling.

site_title: Former monk shows true devotion, spending 50 years building cathedral from scratch in Spanish town
summary: Former monk Justo Gallego, 91, has spent over 50 years building a cathedral from scratch in Mejorada del Campo, Spain. Despite lacking local government funding or a building permit, he has used salvaged materials to construct the 20m by 50m structure, which features 28 domes and a 40m-wide dome. Gallego has relied on donations and family land sales to finance the project, which he believes is a demonstration of his faith. The cathedral remains unfinished, with a roof and cupola still under construction, but has become a tourist attraction and a symbol of the town, earning Gallego the respect of its inhabitants.

site_title: Investor conference highlights small cap firms with big promise
summary: The Singapore stock market has a range of promising small-cap firms, including TalkMed, a healthcare company, and Avi-Tech Electronics, a semiconductor burn-in services provider, that offer attractive dividend yields and growth potential. These companies, with market caps under S$2 billion, are expected to deliver steady growth and strong balance sheets, making them attractive investment choices. The local market has outperformed regional peers, with the FTSE ST Small Cap Index averaging an 8.5% year-to-date total return.

site_title: Apple readies iPhone overhaul for smartphone's 10th anniversary
summary: Apple is preparing its most extensive iPhone lineup to date, with three new iPhones set to launch this fall. The redesigned phone features a new curved glass and stainless steel design, an overhauled look, and advanced cameras. Supply constraints may delay the device's availability until one or two months after the typical fall introduction. The new iPhone will have a slightly larger display than the current models, but a similar overall size, and will use an organic light-emitting diode display for more accurate color representation. The exact release date remains uncertain due to ongoing design and testing.

site_title: Students showcase projects on defence science
summary: Over 70 students showcased projects at the Young Defence Scientists Programme (YDSP) Congress, ranging from data analytics to artificial intelligence and robotics. The annual event, started in 1992, aims to nurture young scientists and engineers. Senior Minister of State for Defence Dr Mohamad Maliki Osman presented 30 scholarships and 90 awards to students with outstanding achievements, highlighting the importance of nurturing talented individuals in defence science and technology.

site_title: Subcontractor fined $230k over Sentosa worksite accident which killed one and injured 10 others
summary: A Singapore court fined Genocean Construction $230,000 for failing to take adequate safety measures at a Sentosa worksite where one worker, Zhou Tonglin, was killed and 10 others injured in an accident on Jan 29, 2014. The subcontractor breached the Workplace Safety and Health Act by not conducting a risk assessment and safe work procedures, and failing to inspect the formwork structure before concreting works began. The company pleaded guilty and was allowed to pay the fine in instalments, with a maximum punishment of $500,000.

site_title: Keppel T&T posts 13% fall in Q1 earnings
summary: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (Keppel T&T) reported a 13.1% drop in Q1 earnings, with a net profit of S$11.6 million, down from S$13.3 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 15.6% to S$40.7 million due to weaker performance from the data centre and logistics divisions. Earnings per share decreased 12.5% to 2.1 cents. Shares closed 0.3% lower at S$1.755.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure inks agreement with EDB to develop a gasification facility
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Holdings has signed an agreement with the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) to develop, own, and operate a gasification facility on Jurong Island. The facility will produce hydrogen, carbon monoxide, and other industrial gases from various feedstocks, including coal and refinery by-products. The project aims to meet anticipated future demands of Singapore's refining and chemicals industries, particularly in response to the International Maritime Organisation's requirement for lower sulphur content in fuel by 2020. The project is in its project development phase, with a final investment decision to be made at a later date.

site_title: 25 killed as Philippine bus plunges into ravine
summary: At least 25 people were killed and 22 injured when a Philippine bus crashed into a deep ravine in the northern province of Nueva Ecija. The bus, carrying 60 passengers, plunged 24m down a windy road after its brakes failed. Authorities are investigating the cause, but officials say the road is "really risky" with many ravines. The incident highlights common road accidents in the Philippines, where old buses ply poorly lit roads and drivers work long hours.

site_title: DBS' Multi-Currency Account to allow 24/7 currency conversion by Q3
summary: DBS Bank plans to allow 24/7 currency conversion on its Multi-Currency Account (MCA) by the third quarter of this year. The new feature will enable customers to exchange currencies in 12 major currencies around the clock, eliminating the need to carry large amounts of cash overseas. This move is expected to increase customer take-up of the scheme, with DBS reporting a 43% increase in foreign currency spending in February. The 24/7 foreign currency exchange capability will provide customers with competitive rates and eliminate additional charges, making it a complete foreign currency payment solution.

site_title: Remembering Othman Wok: 5 ways he left his mark on Singapore
summary: Singapore's first Minister for Social Affairs, Othman Wok, has died at 92 due to a chest infection and stomach complications. He left his mark on the country through various initiatives, including signing the Separation Agreement, building the National Stadium, advancing social welfare services, supporting the Muslim community, and championing multiracialism. His legacy includes conferring the Order of Nila Utama in 1983 and forming the Singapore National Olympic Council. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong praised Wok for his unwavering belief in a multiracial, multi-religious Singapore, describing him as a "steadfast and unwavering" leader.

site_title: British PM Theresa May announces early election on June 8
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May announced an early general election for June 8, citing the need to strengthen her hand in divorce talks with the European Union and secure a strong and stable leadership for Britain during its exit from the EU. May, who has a strong lead in opinion polls, warned that division in Westminster could hinder Brexit progress. The early election was met with support from Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, who indicated his party would provide the necessary support under electoral law. The EU said the negotiations for Britain's exit would not be affected by the early election.

site_title: Wall damaged after flash floods along Dalvey Road, off Stevens Road
summary: Heavy flash floods hit the Dalvey Road area in Singapore, causing damage to a house wall. Debris and chunks of bricks were seen on the road near 64, 66, and 68 Dalvey Road. The incident occurred around 2:30 pm, but it was later clarified that the damage was not caused by lightning, but rather by the flash floods. No one was injured, and engineers from the Building and Construction Authority are currently on site to assess and repair the damage.

site_title: Swa Garden closure: 11 Teochew restaurants to go to for your orh nee fix
summary: Swa Garden, a well-known Teochew restaurant in MacPherson, Singapore, has closed its doors after serving its last meal on April 16, 2017. The restaurant's demise marks the end of an era for Teochew cuisine in the city-state, but there are still 11 other Teochew restaurants in Singapore that offer traditional fare. Some popular alternatives include Hung Kang Restaurant, Teochew Restaurant Huat Kee, Ah Orh Seafood Restaurant, and Imperial Treasure Fine Teochew Cuisine. These restaurants offer a range of Teochew classics, including braised duck, oyster omelette, and orh nee, and are worth visiting for those looking to try authentic Teochew cuisine.

site_title: Japan could rescue nationals in the event of a Korean crisis: Defence chief
summary: Japan's Defence Minister Tomomi Inada stated that the country will prepare to send troops to the Korean peninsula to protect its nationals in the event of a crisis, allowing for their evacuation. This move is allowed under Japanese law and requires the consent of the related country. The comments come amid heightened tensions over North Korea's potential sixth nuclear test and missile launches. Inada's remarks are likely to be controversial in South Korea, where memories of Japan's colonial occupation hinder relations. The move aligns with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's push to expand Japan's military role.

site_title: AVA received some 160 complaints on monkey attacks and nuisance in Segar area in Bukit Panjang
summary: The Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority (AVA) received 160 complaints about monkey attacks and nuisance in the Segar area of Bukit Panjang, deeming it a public safety risk. AVA has been conducting monkey control operations, while a wildlife rescue group notes that such encounters will become inevitable. An aggressive monkey has been attacking residents, entering homes through windows, and residents have taken precautions by shutting windows and securing garbage. AVA advises against feeding the monkeys and advises residents to keep food items out of sight to deter them.

site_title: Why It Matters (Ep 7): Disappearing Jobs
summary: Artificial intelligence is increasingly prevalent in the workplace, with robots helping tackle manpower shortages in labor-intensive industries. However, technology advancements also threaten jobs in other sectors. AI's ability to self-learn and re-design itself raises concerns that it could potentially surpass humans, leaving jobs at risk. This trend highlights the evolving role of technology in the workplace and the need to consider its impact on employment.

site_title: 4 people hurt in 2-bus collision near VivoCity
summary: Four people were injured in a bus collision in Singapore's Harbourfront area on April 18, 2017, when a single-decker bus hit a double-decker bus. The accident occurred at 12:20 pm, with over 10 passengers on the single-decker bus. The injured were treated at Singapore General Hospital, with reports of minor injuries. An investigation into the accident is ongoing, with SBS Transit staff visiting the hospital to check on the well-being of the passengers and provide assistance.

site_title: NBA: San Antonio Spurs, Cleveland Cavaliers build up commanding 2-0 leads
summary: The San Antonio Spurs defeated the Memphis Grizzlies 2-0 in their Western Conference first-round playoff series, with Kawhi Leonard scoring a career-high 37 points. The Spurs built a 26-point lead in the first half and held off a late Grizzlies comeback. Meanwhile, the Cleveland Cavaliers took a 2-0 lead in their Eastern Conference playoff series against the Indiana Pacers, led by Kyrie Irving's 37 points and LeBron James' 25 points, 10 rebounds, and 7 assists. The Cavs have never lost a playoff series when leading 2-0.

site_title: China Construction Bank launches three new units in Singapore
summary: China Construction Bank (CCB) launched three new units in Singapore, including an infrastructure financing services centre, a private banking centre, and a Singapore branch of CCB International, its investment services subsidiary. The move aims to enhance financial market collaborations between Singapore and China, particularly under China's Belt and Road initiative. CCB's expansion will allow Chinese companies to access Singapore as an infrastructure financing hub and provide local firms with access to CCB's network and Chinese partners or funds. The new centres are a result of a 2016 memorandum of understanding between CCB and IE Singapore.

site_title: Indonesian President Joko Widodo meets officials to discuss security measures for Jakarta election
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has met with top security officials to discuss extensive security measures for the April 19 Jakarta election, including the deployment of over 60,000 security personnel. The meeting comes amid sectarian tensions and amid reports of plans by some Islamic groups to mobilize supporters to guard polling stations. Widodo urged unity and promised to ensure voters' safety on election day, instructing the TNI and police to crack down on intimidation efforts. He also met with Islamic leaders, urging them to promote unity and discourage supporters from gathering around polling stations.

site_title: Aoxin Q&M Dental offers 57 million shares at 20 cents apiece in IPO
summary: Aoxin Q&M Dental Group is offering 57 million shares at 20 Singapore cents apiece in its initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board, aiming to raise S$9.1 million. The funds will be used for business expansion, mergers, and acquisitions, as well as infrastructure and working capital. The IPO is expected to begin trading on April 26, with applications closing on April 24. The company, a Chinese unit of the Singapore-listed Q&M Dental Group, posted a net loss of S$20,683 for the first nine months of 2016.

site_title: Errant macaque at Segar Road: Other monkey incidents and what to do when you encounter wildlife
summary: A resident in Bukit Panjang, Singapore, has been dealing with an errant long-tailed macaque that has been biting people in the area. The monkey, which is thought to have left its family to live alone, has become habituated to humans and has lost its fear. Residents are advised not to feed or taunt the monkey, and to contact wildlife rescue groups or government agencies for assistance. Similar incidents of human-monkey encounters have occurred in other areas, including Kent Ridge Park and MacRitchie Reservoir Park, highlighting the need for residents to be aware of their surroundings and take precautions to avoid conflicts with wildlife.

site_title: The Newsmaker: "Jackpot Aunty" says she is not a high profile person
summary: "Jackpot Aunty" Choo Hong Eng, known for her 2011 battle against Marina Bay Sands casino to claim $410,000 winnings, discusses the joys and woes of her high-profile charity work. Despite initial attention, some questioned her motives, labeling her an "attention seeker." However, Choo remains committed to charitable deeds, stating that the attention has not deterred her from continuing to support good causes. Her charitable endeavors have garnered attention, with her vegetarian chain of eateries also benefiting from the increased visibility.

site_title: China-made truck used in North Korea parade to show submarine-launched missile
summary: North Korea used Chinese-made trucks to display submarine-launched missiles and two new types of intercontinental ballistic missiles at a military parade, highlighting the difficulty in enforcing UN sanctions. The trucks, painted in North Korean navy camouflage, were identified as Sinotruk HOWO models, with one company stating it had no business with the North Korean market since last year. The use of dual-use equipment and vehicles with civilian applications makes it harder to track and enforce sanctions, allowing North Korea to continue displaying military hardware despite international restrictions.

site_title: World's largest number of people dressed as Charlie Chaplin's "The Tramp"
summary: Hundreds of people gathered in Corsier-Sur-Vevey, Switzerland, to break the world record for the largest gathering of people dressed as Charlie Chaplin's "The Tramp". On April 16, 662 people, including young and old, donned moustaches and walking canes for the attempt. The event was organized by Chaplin's World, the world's only museum dedicated to the famous director, coinciding with Chaplin's 128th birthday and the museum's first anniversary since opening.

site_title: Israel vows not to negotiate with Palestinian hunger strikers
summary: Israel's Public Security Minister Gilad Erdan has vowed not to negotiate with hundreds of Palestinian detainees on strike, calling them "terrorists and incarcerated murderers." The hunger strike, led by Marwan Barghouti, has seen over 1,100 prisoners refuse food, demanding better medical services and access to telephones. Barghouti, serving five life sentences, has been moved to solitary confinement. The strike, which could rise to 1,500 prisoners, has given Barghouti's call added credibility, highlighting Israel's treatment of Palestinian prisoners.

site_title: Carrie Lam to boost Hong Kong's competitiveness with Greater Bay Area initiative: China Daily Columnist
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive-elect Carrie Lam plans to boost the city's competitiveness with the Greater Bay Area initiative, a city cluster development project in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao region. Premier Li Keqiang has promised concrete measures to promote the project, which aims to foster economic cooperation and infrastructure development among major cities. The initiative addresses Hong Kong's internal development issues, such as land shortage and declining industries, and could enhance the city's competitiveness by leveraging its unique advantages in areas like law and professional services.

site_title: Air Canada apologises for bumping 10-year-old off oversold flight: Father
summary: Air Canada has apologized and offered compensation to a family after bumping a 10-year-old boy off an oversold flight. The boy's father, Brett Doyle, said his family was initially told there was no seat available for the boy on a flight from Charlottetown to Montreal, where they were connecting to a Costa Rica vacation. After a series of cancellations and miscommunications, the family was offered a C$2,500 trip voucher, sparking outrage over airline overbooking, following a similar incident on United Airlines.

site_title: Hackers exploit Japan's mobile gamers with fake fantasy cash
summary: Hackers in Japan are targeting mobile gamers with fake promotions, exploiting their desire for free virtual rewards. By installing remote access software, hackers gain access to corporate networks, compromising hundreds of businesses each month. FireEye Inc. warns that the gaming community's widespread appeal makes Japan a prime target, and hackers are learning to mimic game-industry promotions. Japanese companies, including GungHo Online Entertainment, have become skilled at creating engaging games that encourage players to spend money, making them vulnerable to such scams.

site_title: Flash floods hit parts of Singapore on Tuesday afternoon
summary: Flash floods hit parts of Singapore on Tuesday afternoon, with water submerging vehicles up to mid-tyre level in areas such as Exeter Road, Somerset Road, and Stevens Road. The National Environment Agency (NEA) warned of high flood risks from 1.35pm to 2.33pm, with heavy rain expected over southern and western parts of the city-state from 1.35pm to 2.25pm. A taxi successfully navigated through flooded roads, while a car became stuck in water outside the Mount Elizabeth Medical Centre.

site_title: More measures needed to curb Japan's population plunge: The Yomiuri Shimbun
summary: Japan's population is projected to decline from 127.09 million in 2015 to 88.08 million in 2065, with a 40% drop in the working-age population and 38.4% elderly population by 2065. The birthrate remains below the necessary 2.07 level to maintain the population, with 1.44 births per woman. The government is urged to implement measures to promote work-life balance, increase childcare facilities, and stabilize young people's economic base to curb the population decline and super-aging of society.

site_title: Thai government campaign sees drop in road deaths during Songkran festival
summary: Thailand's road deaths during the Songkran festival decreased by over 10% compared to the previous year, with 390 fatalities reported during the previous seven days. The government's campaign, which includes harsher penalties, vehicle seizures, and mortuary visits, has shown results. Despite improvements, drink-driving remains a significant issue, accounting for nearly a third of accidents, and speeding and helmet-wearing among motorcyclists also contribute to the high death rate. Thailand's traffic cops face criticism for bribe-taking, allowing wealthy drivers to evade punishment.

site_title: Football: All members of Team LKT and Team Game Changers cleared for April 29 FAS election
summary: The Football Association of Singapore (FAS) has cleared both Team LKT and Team Game Changers to contest the April 29 election, with Team LKT led by Lim Kia Tong and Team Game Changers led by Bill Ng. The clearance comes amid a donation saga surrounding a $500,000 donation made by Ng to the FAS in 2014, which was given to the Asean Football Federation. Ng claims the donation was to benefit Singapore football, while the FAS disputes his claim, stating they will present the details in due course. The election will be held at the Singapore Sports Hub.

site_title: Airbus and Singpost testing last-mile drone package delivery
summary: Airbus and Singapore Post have partnered to test last-mile drone package delivery through the Skyways parcel delivery project. The trial aims to develop safe use of drones for urban environments, with a focus on autonomous delivery in pre-defined routes. Airbus will develop drone hardware, while SingPost will provide logistical support. The trial is set to begin at the National University of Singapore in early 2018, with the goal of addressing safety and accurate flight challenges in high-rise cities. This is the second drone delivery test by SingPost, following a 2015 trial.

site_title: Singapore top in Asia, 2nd-best globally at attracting talent: Insead
summary: Singapore ranks highest in Asia and second globally in attracting and developing talent, according to the Global Talent Competitiveness Index by Insead. The city-state's strong education system, technological competence, and flexible employment policies contribute to its success. Other top-ranked countries include Switzerland, Australia, and Malaysia, which scores high for vocational and technical skills and openness to foreign talent. Japan, China, and India lag behind, facing challenges in attracting and retaining talent due to limited opportunities and high emigration rates.

site_title: Australia cracks down on visa scheme used by foreign workers including Singaporeans
summary: Australia has abolished its 457 visa scheme, used by about 170,000 foreign workers, including over 500 Singaporeans. The new two- and four-year temporary skilled visas will impose stricter English language tests, labor market testing, and higher fees. The program aims to ensure foreign workers fill skill gaps, not replace Australian workers. The new scheme starts immediately, with full implementation by March 2018, and will not lead to permanent residency. The move signals a tougher stance on immigration, following other developed nations.

site_title: US Marines arrive in Darwin for exercises with Australia and China
summary: US Marines have arrived in Darwin, Australia, for a six-month deployment as part of the annual 25-year program, which began under former President Barack Obama. The deployment, with 1,250 troops, will conduct exercises with Australian and Chinese forces, including a significant US aircraft contingent. The move aims to strengthen the partnership between the US and Australia, while also navigating tensions between the two countries and China. The exercises come as the US and China engage in a show of force over North Korea, with the USS Carl Vinson carrier strike group sailing to the Korean peninsula.

site_title: Most major Western leaders skipping China's New Silk Road summit in May
summary: China's New Silk Road summit in May will feature only one major Western leader, Italian Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni, amid a snub of most Western countries. China's foreign minister denied the absence was a snub, calling it a "positive, cooperative agreement". Despite concerns about the project's lack of detail and transparency, China sees an opportunity to become a global leader. The summit aims to promote economic cooperation and will feature representatives from 110 countries, including leaders from countries with dubious human rights records.

site_title: Woodleigh MRT incident: Man, 69, arrested for leaving substance, which turns out to be flour, at station
summary: A 69-year-old man was arrested at Woodleigh MRT station for leaving a suspicious white substance, later identified as flour, which caused a temporary closure of the station for about three hours. The incident occurred after a cleaner spotted the substance, prompting a HazMat response. Two other men, aged 53 and 70, were assisting with police investigations. The station reopened at 4:20pm, with free buses provided for commuters during the closure. The incident highlights the authorities' preparedness to handle security threats and the importance of public vigilance.

site_title: Final journey for late pioneer Cabinet minister Othman Wok
summary: Pioneer Cabinet minister Othman Wok, 92, died after a long battle with cancer. A state-assisted funeral was held, with a state flag draped over his casket. The casket was carried on a ceremonial gun carriage through Singapore to Choa Chu Kang Muslim Cemetery, where he was buried after a prayer session and reading of the talqin. More than 100 family members, politicians, and unionists attended the burial service, paying respects to the late minister who leaves behind a wife, four daughters, and multiple grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

site_title: Manufacturing and retail recovery drove China's solid Q1 growth
summary: China's economy grew 6.9% in the first quarter, beating expectations, driven by a recovery in the industrial sector. Manufacturing expanded 7.0% and retail sales rose 7.4%, while the construction industry slowed to 5.3%. The property sector grew 7.8% and the finance industry saw a 4.4% increase. Analysts attribute the growth to a rebound in exports, particularly in electronics, and a pick-up in housing starts. However, some warn that the construction sector may be overheating due to peak housing demand.

site_title: Prayers held at Sultan Mosque for the late pioneer leader Othman Wok
summary: Late pioneer leader Othman Wok was brought to Sultan Mosque in Singapore for prayers after his death on April 17 at 92. The prayers, led by Mufti Fatris Bakaram, were attended by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, government leaders, and many who remembered him as a jovial and humorous man. Friends and family paid their respects at his home and later at the mosque, with some traveling from afar to honor his legacy. Wok will be laid to rest at the Choa Chu Kang Muslim Cemetery in the afternoon.

site_title: Laos 'drug kingpin' denies Thai smuggling charges
summary: Laos' alleged "drug kingpin" Xaysana Keopimpha denied being a major player in the regional narcotics trade when he appeared in a Bangkok court. Facing charges of drug smuggling and possession, Keopimpha claimed he didn't understand Thai laws and signed a confession under duress. His arrest drew widespread attention in Thailand, linking him to celebrities and wealthy individuals, but experts question his seniority in the criminal chain, citing Laos' weak anti-trafficking efforts and Thai police's frequent arrests without catching top figures.

site_title: Smart technology, 2-in-1 hospital and gardens galore: 6 interesting facts about Woodlands Health Campus
summary: Singapore's Woodlands Health Campus, set to open from 2022, is a 1,800-bed hospital complex featuring a general hospital, community hospital, specialist clinics, and daycare facilities. The campus will be "future ready" with smart technology, including telehealth, online services, artificial intelligence, and robotics. It will also include dedicated blocks for specialist clinics and a dementia-friendly facility with inter-generational programs. The campus spans 7.66 hectares with green spaces, including a Forest Healing Garden and Therapeutic Gardens, designed to promote relaxation and healing.

site_title: Street vendors to be banned across Bangkok, except in Yaowarat and Khao San, by year-end
summary: The Bangkok Metropolitan Administration (BMA) plans to ban street vendors across Bangkok, except in Yaowarat and Khao San, by the end of the year. The exception is due to the districts' popularity with tourists and street food culture. Vendors in these areas will be allowed to stay but must follow zoning and sanitation regulations. In contrast, other districts will be cleared of street vendors as part of the BMA's efforts to improve cleanliness. The decision aims to promote night activities and maintain the city's reputation as a top street food destination.

site_title: Football: Asean Football Federation issues conflicting statements over $500,000 donation from S'pore on the same day
summary: The Asean Football Federation (AFF) issued conflicting statements regarding a $500,000 donation from the Football Association of Singapore (FAS), initially stating it was the FAS that made the donation, then later saying it was National Football League (NFL) club Tiong Bahru FC that made the donation through the FAS. The AFF apologized for the confusion, stating that the donation was made to support the AFF Football Management System, not FAS or Singapore football activities.

site_title: CK Tang appoints Sean Tang, son of Tang Wee Kit, as CEO
summary: CK Tang appoints Sean Tang, 32, son of CEO Tang Wee Kit, as CEO with immediate effect. Sean Tang, who sits on the board of Tang Holdings, succeeds Kevin Dyson, who left the firm in August 2016. This marks a new generation taking over the reins at the 98.3% owned retail icon, which was previously delisted in 2009. The appointment is part of a "family succession plan" initiated in 2006.

site_title: US will work with Japan, South Korea, China to resolve North Korea issue peacefully: Mike Pence
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence met with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, assuring Japan of the US commitment to reining in North Korea's nuclear and missile ambitions. Pence stated that the US will work with Japan, South Korea, and China to achieve a peaceful resolution and denuclearization of the Korean peninsula. Pence also emphasized the need for China to play a larger role in addressing North Korea's belligerence, with US officials considering tougher economic sanctions, including an oil embargo, as a key strategy.

site_title: Singapore's first festival for artistes with disabilities to be held next March
summary: Singapore is set to host its first festival for artistes with disabilities, the True Colours Festival, from March 22-25, 2024. The festival, presented by the Nippon Foundation and UNESCO, will feature performers with various disabilities, including visual impairment and hearing loss. The event aims to inspire and empower individuals with disabilities, showcasing their talents and challenging societal perceptions. Local and international artistes, including beatbox performer Danial Bawthan, will participate in the festival, which also includes interactive activities, concerts, and a professional conference on arts and disabilities.

site_title: Remembering Othman Wok: Neighbours and friends remember a warm, smiling 'man on the ground'
summary: Singaporean former Cabinet minister Othman Wok, 87, died on April 17. Neighbours and friends paid their respects to him the next day, with many recalling his warm personality and community spirit. Wok, a retired education officer, was known for his encouragement and advice, and was remembered by colleagues and acquaintances for his kindness and dedication to promoting equal rights. He was laid to rest at the Choa Chu Kang Muslim Cemetery on Tuesday afternoon, with a memorial service to be held on Wednesday.

site_title: Two-year-old boy in China run over by car while driver talks on mobile phone
summary: A two-year-old boy in China was nearly run over by a car while the driver was on his mobile phone. The boy had wandered in front of a parked car, and the driver, who was still on the phone after getting in, drove off without noticing the child. Miraculously, the boy suffered only minor scratches and bruises. Surveillance footage was released to warn motorists to stay focused on the road and not be distracted by mobile phones. The driver may face charges for dangerous driving.

site_title: Man accused of setting fire to St Hilda's Church charged with mischief
summary: A 60-year-old man, Yeo Liang Chai, was charged in court with committing mischief by fire after allegedly setting ablaze a room inside St Hilda's Church in Singapore. The incident occurred on April 16 between 6:45am and 6:50am. No one was injured, but the fire was extinguished by the Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) using a compressed air foam system. Yeo will be remanded and may be taken out to assist officers with their investigations; he will be back in court next Tuesday.

site_title: US Vice-President Mike Pence says new US-Japan talks could lead to trade deal
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence launched economic talks with Japan, focusing on trade and investment, with the possibility of a bilateral trade deal. Pence stated that the talks could lead to a free trade agreement, although no formal negotiations have been announced. The talks aim to salvage elements of the scrapped Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal, with Japan potentially agreeing to open its agricultural markets. A second round of talks is set to take place by the end of the year, with Pence and Japanese Deputy Prime Minister Taro Aso aiming to deepen economic relations and achieve a "win-win" agreement.

site_title: Malaysia foils large-scale kidnapping plans following death of Abu Sayyaf leader
summary: Malaysian security forces foiled a large-scale kidnapping plan by Abu Sayyaf, a militant group led by Muamar Askali, who was killed in a gun battle on April 10. The plan aimed to kidnap dozens of Caucasian tourists from tourist islands in Sabah and the central Philippines. However, after Askali's death, 11 sub-leaders surrendered, and security forces remain on alert to prevent further threats. The foiled plan was part of a larger operation by Abu Sayyaf to use human shields to stop military operations in their strongholds.

site_title: Pay feud threatens terror fight in Africa near key shipping lane
summary: Security forces in Somalia's semi-autonomous region of Puntland are on the brink of mutiny due to unpaid salaries, which have been delayed since a 2016 budget crisis. The situation has led to brief seizures of government buildings and resignations from the Puntland Intelligence Agency. If security and intelligence organizations become non-functional, Islamist militants could attack civilian vessels and warships in the Bab-el-Mandeb strait, a key shipping lane. The region is already experiencing increased lawlessness, with a faction of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) seizing a port and fueling a potential threat to global maritime trade routes.

site_title: Learn to cook and eat insects with new cookbook
summary: A new cookbook, "On Eating Insects," has been released, offering tips on cooking and eating insects at home. The book, written by the Nordic Food Lab, aims to challenge Western palates to adopt a more sustainable and healthy protein-rich diet featuring insects like beetles, caterpillars, and wasps. The book includes essays, stories, and recipes, with detailed tasting notes on the unique flavors and textures of various insects. The publication is set to retail for $59.95 and aims to popularize the concept of entomophagy, or insect-eating, in the Western world.

site_title: Get ready to say 'awww': 5 animal births that became an Internet sensation
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Animal births captured the internet's attention, with five notable cases making headlines. April, a 15-year-old giraffe, gave birth to a male calf at the Animal Adventure Park in New York, with over 1 million viewers watching live. Other notable births include Fiona, a premature hippo, who received support from fans; red panda triplets, a rare occurrence; quintuplet hedgehogs, whose videos went viral; Nora, a polar bear born in 2015, who was named after her parents; and Amani, a gorilla born in 2016, who was named after an orphaned eastern lowland gorilla.

site_title: askST: As a divorcee with no income, should I opt for a Build To Order or a resale flat?
summary: A divorcee with no income, Jacqueline Goh, is considering buying a Build To Order (BTO) or a resale flat. The quickest option is to buy a resale flat, which can be occupied immediately, but Goh must sell her private property within six months. Alternatively, she can wait 30 months from selling her private property to apply for a BTO. The HDB offers an Assistance Scheme for Second-Timers, which provides two-room flexi and three-room flats in non-mature estates for eligible divorced or widowed parents with children below 16 years old.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.98% lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares began trading 0.98% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,138.30, down 30.94 points. Around 41.5 million shares were exchanged, with gainers beating losers 120 to 23.

site_title: French presidential election: Emmanuel Macron's key policy proposals
summary: Emmanuel Macron, a 39-year-old former investment banker, is a frontrunner in France's presidential election, with his closest rival Marine Le Pen. Macron's key policy proposals include incentives for low-income earners, tax breaks for employers, and mergers of public- and private-sector retirement pension systems. He aims to lower the budget deficit, cut corporate tax, and increase investment in public sectors such as education and healthcare. His proposals also include measures to reduce unemployment, increase public spending, and improve security and law enforcement.

site_title: White House meeting on Paris climate deal postponed: Official
summary: The White House meeting to discuss withdrawing the US from the Paris climate accord has been postponed due to scheduling conflicts among top advisers, including Energy Secretary Rick Perry and Environmental Protection Agency head Scott Pruitt. The meeting was initially set for April 18 but was cancelled because some principals were traveling. A rescheduled meeting has been announced, but no date has been set. The US committed to reducing emissions by 26-28% by 2025 under the 2015 climate deal, which Trump has previously called for cancellation.

site_title: French presidential election: Francois Fillon's key policy proposals
summary: French presidential candidate Francois Fillon is holding on to third place in opinion polls despite a scandal surrounding public funds to his family. Fillon proposes a supply-side economic strategy with cuts in public spending, a 39-hour workweek, and raising the retirement age. He also supports social conservatism, including limiting gay couples' adoption rights, and warmer ties with Russia. Fillon's policy proposals include slashing public spending by 100 billion euros, cutting taxes and welfare charges by 50 billion euros, and raising the pensionable retirement age to 65.

site_title: French presidential election: Marine Le Pen's key policy proposals
summary: Marine Le Pen, the leader of France's far-right National Front, has outlined her policy proposals ahead of the country's presidential election on April 23 and May 7. Her manifesto includes plans to leave the euro currency, hold a referendum on EU membership, and suspend France's membership in the Schengen border-free area. Le Pen also proposes stricter immigration policies, increased defense spending, and lower taxes. Key targets include GDP growth of 2% in 2018, a reduced public deficit, and a decrease in the national debt to 89% of GDP by 2022.

site_title: Procter & Gamble to invest US$100m in Singapore digital innovation centre, its first outside US
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) is investing US$100 million in its first digital innovation centre outside the US, in partnership with the Economic Development Board in Singapore. The centre, called the P&G Singapore E-Center, aims to enhance supply chain management, e-business, and e-analytics across three core areas. The centre will train 40 employees and partner with local SMEs and start-ups to co-develop digital solutions, further solidifying Singapore's position as a leading digital hub. The move reaffirms P&G's commitment to Singapore and its Asia-Pacific operations.

site_title: UOB, KrisFlyer launch savings account that rewards with air miles
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) and KrisFlyer have launched a savings account that rewards customers with air miles when they save or spend. The KrisFlyer UOB Account offers 5.4 KrisFlyer miles per dollar spent for balances above S$350,000, 3.4 miles per dollar spent for balances between S$100,000 and S$350,000, and 1.4 miles per dollar spent for balances between S$3,000 and S$100,000. The account also provides cardmembers with special privileges on Scoot and Tigerair flights.

site_title: Woodlands Health Campus will add 1,800 beds and use technology for better patient care
summary: Singapore's 1,800-bed Woodlands Health Campus, set to open in 2022, will rely heavily on smart technology to improve patient care amidst a shrinking workforce. The campus will integrate acute and community hospitals, specialist clinics, and online services, utilizing artificial intelligence and telehealth to streamline patient care. The facility aims to provide seamless care transitions, dementia-friendly housing, and therapeutic gardens, and will be built as a single integrated campus serving patients with varying care needs. The project is designed to meet the growing demand from Singapore's ageing population and support the area's growth as a regional centre.

site_title: PAS chief urges Muslims to forgive newspaper over monkey cartoon
summary: PAS president Datuk Seri Hadi Awang urged Muslims to forgive Chinese daily Nanyang Siang Pau after it published a cartoon deemed insulting to Islam. The cartoon, published on April 8, depicted PAS president Abdul Hadi Awang and Dewan Rakyat Speaker Tan Sri Pandikar Amin Mulia as monkeys. PAS received an apology from the daily on April 12, which was also published publicly. The Home Ministry accepted the apology and will not take action, stressing that the same mistake should not be repeated. Hadi called for forgiveness to promote harmony and understanding.

site_title: South Koreans are dealing with a new wild card: Donald Trump
summary: South Koreans are navigating a complex situation with the US under President Donald Trump, who has introduced a new wild card to their decades-long technical state of war with North Korea. Despite North Korea's increasing threats, South Koreans are more concerned about Trump's actions, citing his tendency to act quickly and impulsively. While some worry about the potential consequences of Trump's decisions, others believe he would not start a war that would put South Korea in danger. The situation remains business as usual in Seoul, with daily life continuing unaffected by the tensions, as South Koreans express varying opinions on Trump's role in the escalating tensions.

site_title: China has world's hottest property stocks as curbs are ignored
summary: China's property stocks are the world's hottest, driven by soaring sales and improving profits, with top performers including Country Garden, Sunac China Holdings, and China Evergrande Group. Despite tougher measures to cool real estate prices, investors continue to flock to these companies, with Country Garden and Sunac seeing gains of over 70% and Evergrande's debt-to-equity ratio at its lowest since the 2008 global financial crisis. Analysts predict further growth, with sales forecast to soar 39% and earnings to grow 9.2% this year, but warn of profit taking and a potential slowdown in sales momentum.

site_title: Bar in London hotel serves virtual reality whiskey cocktail that takes you to Scotland
summary: A new whiskey cocktail, the Origin, is served at The Lobby Bar in London's One Aldwych hotel, featuring a 12-year-old Dalmore whiskey and a virtual reality (VR) headset. The headset transports customers to the Scottish Highlands, where Dalmore's distillery is located, while the drink is being served. The £18 price tag comes with a high-tech gimmick, and the whiskey is a blend of various ingredients, including cherry liqueur, grapefruit juice, and chocolate bitters. The drink was available on the menu until early 2018, with reviewers praising its unique flavors and scents.

site_title: Punchlines: April 18, 2017
summary: No article content provided.

site_title: Super passes 90% threshold, to stop trading at close of buyout offer on April 25
summary: Super Group, a Singapore-based food and beverage maker, will suspend trading on April 25, 2017, after acceptances for a Dutch buyout offer by Jacobs Douwe Egberts (JDE) reached 90%. JDE owns 91.73% of Super and intends to take the firm private. The offer, valued at S$1.45 billion, was made last November. Super shares closed at S$1.30, the same as the offer price, on Monday.

site_title: French presidential election: Jean-Luc Melenchon's key policy proposals
summary: French presidential candidate Jean-Luc Melenchon has surged in the final stages of the campaign, becoming a serious contender for the top spots in the first round. Melenchon's key policy proposals include a 100-billion-euro economic stimulus plan, a rewrite of the Constitution to boost parliamentary power, and plans to close ageing nuclear power stations and invest in offshore wind power. He also proposes raising public spending by 275 billion euros, increasing taxes on the wealthy, and implementing a 35-hour workweek with higher wages and job creation.

site_title: Shinhwa star Eric Mun to wed in July
summary: K-pop star Eric Mun, leader of boy band Shinhwa, is set to marry model and actress Na Hye Mi on July 1. The two, who have been in a three-year relationship, made the announcement on April 17 through a letter to fans. Mun, 38, debuted in 1998 and has since pursued acting, while Na, 26, made her acting debut in 2001. This marks Mun's first marriage, following previous rumors of a relationship in 2014 that were denied by his agency.

site_title: Melania Trump nudges President to put hand over heart during national anthem
summary: US President Donald Trump was reminded by First Lady Melania Trump to put his hand over his heart during the national anthem at the White House Easter Egg Roll on April 17, 2017. The tradition, which Melania and their son Barron followed, is outlined in the US Flag Code. Trump was the last to adopt the patriotic posture, prompting social media buzz. The event, which began in 1878, features various activities for kids, including a roll of colored eggs. Melania's subtle reminder helped Trump adhere to the national anthem protocol.

site_title: Family see shark kill teenage daughter in Western Australia
summary: A 17-year-old girl, Laeticia Brouwer, was attacked and killed by a shark while surfing with her father in Western Australia's southwest coast on April 17. She lost a leg and was bleeding heavily before being rushed to hospital. Her mother and younger sisters witnessed the attack and alerted emergency services. Authorities believe a great white shark was responsible, as it is the species responsible for all fatal shark attacks in Western Australia since 2000. The beach was closed until further notice, and experts attribute the increase in shark attacks to the growing popularity of water sports.

site_title: US man sues dating app Grindr after 1,100 strangers turn up at his home, workplace demanding sex
summary: A US man, Matthew Herrick, is suing dating app Grindr after 1,100 strangers showed up at his home and workplace, demanding sex. Herrick claims a former boyfriend created fake profiles using his photos and info, inviting men to his apartment and workplace. Herrick's lawyers say Grindr shares blame for offering a "dangerous product" and failing to act on Herrick's reports of fake profiles. The app allegedly allowed the fake profiles to continue, putting Herrick at risk of sexual assault, and Grindr's inaction is likened to a car manufacturer's duty to warn users of a product's risks.

site_title: Track circuit faults cause delays on NSL, EWL on Tuesday morning; SMRT says new signalling system will eliminate problem
summary: Delays occurred on the North-South Line (NSL) and East-West Line (EWL) in Singapore on Tuesday morning due to track circuit faults. The faults, caused by ageing track circuits, resulted in trains traveling at slower speeds for commuter safety. SMRT, the operator, apologized for the inconvenience and stated that a new signalling system will eliminate the problem. The new system, currently being tested, will replace ageing track circuits with more reliable ones, reducing the likelihood of similar delays in the future. Trials of the new system are set to begin on Sundays starting from April 16.

site_title: Asian stocks climb while yen slips as geopolitical tensions ease
summary: Asian stocks rose on Tuesday as US stocks surged, while the yen weakened due to easing geopolitical tensions and improved US economic data. The Bloomberg dollar index strengthened, and 10-year Treasury yields edged higher. Investors became less cautious, with readings on American housing and New York manufacturing lowering interest rate expectations. The yen declined 0.3% to 109.21 per dollar, while Japan's Topix and South Korea's Kospi advanced 1% and 0.1% respectively.

site_title: Donald Trump to sign executive order on 'Buy American, Hire American' policy during Wisconsin trip
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to sign an executive order in Wisconsin on April 18, 2017, aimed at making it harder for tech companies to replace American workers with cheaper foreign labor and strengthening rules barring foreign contractors from bidding on government projects. The order will crack down on fraud and abuse in guest worker programs, review federal procurement rules and trade agreements to favor American firms, and direct the Department of Commerce to review existing procurement policies. The move is seen as a step towards Trump's "America First" ideology, but its effectiveness depends on Congressional cooperation.

site_title: NBA: LeBron James pays tribute to grieving Isaiah Thomas
summary: NBA star LeBron James paid tribute to Boston Celtics' Isaiah Thomas, offering condolences after Thomas's sister Chyna died in a car crash. James expressed sympathy for Thomas's situation, calling it a "tough situation" and saying Thomas's performance in the team's Game 1 defeat was "unbelievable." Celtics coach Brad Stevens confirmed Thomas plans to play in Game 2, but will return to be with his family in Seattle after the game. James praised Thomas's strength and resilience, saying "who cares about basketball when something like that happens."

site_title: Tennis: Petra Kvitova targets French Open comeback
summary: Czech tennis star Petra Kvitova plans a surprise return at the French Open, six months after a knife attack left her with severe injuries to her playing hand. Despite doctors estimating she wouldn't be ready until the second half of the year, Kvitova made progress in her recovery and aims to compete at the May 28-June 11 tournament. She expressed gratitude for continued support and hopes to play in Paris, although acknowledges a long road ahead in her recovery.

site_title: Formula One: Max Verstappen apologises to Brazil for Massa remark
summary: Max Verstappen, a Red Bull Formula One driver, apologized to Brazilian fans after making a comment about Felipe Massa that was perceived as insulting. Verstappen initially stated that Massa was a Brazilian, implying that there was nothing to discuss, but later clarified that he meant to express his disappointment with Massa's qualifying performance. Verstappen expressed respect for the Brazilian people and apologized for any offense caused, referencing Brazilian racing legends. The incident occurred after Verstappen crashed out of the Bahrain Grand Prix.

site_title: China's Korea policy 'in tatters' as both North and South defy sanctions
summary: China's efforts to impose sanctions on North and South Korea have failed, with both countries continuing to defy China's demands. Despite China's deployment of unofficial sanctions against South Korea, South Korea has announced plans to proceed with the deployment of an American missile defense system, known as Thaad. North Korea has also ignored China's pleas not to raise regional tensions by conducting another missile test. China's approach has been deemed ineffective, and experts say Beijing is increasingly frustrated with Pyongyang's actions, with some suggesting China may shift its focus from suppressing North Korea to opposing the US.

site_title: Beleagured United Airlines posts earnings that top forecasts
summary: United Airlines' parent company, United Continental, reported a 69.3% decline in first-quarter net income to $96 million, but still topped analyst expectations. Revenues rose 2.7% to $8.4 billion. The airline vowed to remake its customer service after a passenger was forcibly removed from an overbooked flight, sparking global outrage. United projected passenger revenue growth in the second quarter and acknowledged much work remains to be done to regain customer trust, with the company planning to stop using police to remove passengers and undergo further changes.

site_title: Latest North Korean missile test may have involved new system: Analysts
summary: North Korea's latest missile launch may have involved a new, untested system, according to analysts. The launch near Sinpo on the east coast failed "almost immediately" and was described as a medium-range device. Experts believe the test was likely of a new missile, possibly the KN-17 Scud, which could be used to target ships. The US has not confirmed the details of the launch, but some speculate that hacking efforts may have played a role in the failure. The incident raises concerns about the capabilities of North Korea's military and its nuclear deterrent.

site_title: US will review and reform free trade agreement with South Korea: Vice-President Mike Pence
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence announced on April 18, 2017, that the Trump administration will review and reform the five-year-old free trade agreement between the US and South Korea due to the significant trade deficit. The US trade deficit with South Korea has more than doubled since the agreement took effect in 2012, with a surplus of $23.2 billion in 2016. Pence stated that the administration will work with businesses to identify and eliminate barriers for US companies in the country, aiming to boost US manufacturing jobs and narrow trade deficits with nations like China and Japan.

site_title: Endangered species are being poached in protected areas: WWF
summary: WWF warns that nearly half of the world's most protected natural sites, including UNESCO-listed sites, are threatened by illegal poaching, logging, and fishing, putting critically endangered species like the vaquita and tigers at risk of extinction. The vaquita, the world's smallest porpoise, is particularly vulnerable, with fewer than 30 individuals remaining due to bycatch in fishing nets. WWF calls for increased efforts to combat the illegal wildlife trade, which rakes in $15-20 billion annually, and notes that protecting these sites can also safeguard livelihoods and tourist industries.

site_title: Litmus test looms for President Trump in Georgia congressional race
summary: In a special election for Georgia's 6th Congressional District, Democratic candidate Jon Ossoff is seeking to upset the Republican stronghold, potentially marking a shock victory for the party and a significant blow to President Trump. Ossoff, a 30-year-old documentary filmmaker and former congressional aide, leads in the polls with 42.5%, while Trump's approval rating lags at 40%. A Republican win would be in doubt, making this election a key test of Trump's first 100 days in office and a potential litmus test for the 2018 mid-term elections.

site_title: Football: Promoted Brighton in full Bloom after gaining promotion to EPL
summary: Brighton & Hove Albion Football Club has been promoted to the English Premier League after a £200 million investment by owner Tony Bloom. The club, which was once on the brink of bankruptcy, has transformed from a lower league mediocrity to a top-tier team under Bloom's leadership. With a state-of-the-art stadium and significant financial backing, Brighton is poised to compete at the highest level. The team's promotion is a testament to Bloom's business acumen and his commitment to the club, which has a rich history dating back to the 1970s.

site_title: Coachella festival cellphone thief nabbed by phone app
summary: A 36-year-old New York man, Reinaldo De Jesus Henao, was arrested at the Coachella music festival in California after stealing cellphones from over 100 people. He was caught after festival-goers used the "Find My Phone" app to track him down. Henao was found with over 100 stolen phones in his backpack and charged with grand theft and possession of stolen property. He was released on $10,000 bail. The incident highlights the effectiveness of modern technology in combating theft.

site_title: Cleveland killing leads Facebook to review handling of videos
summary: Facebook launches review of handling violent videos after a Cleveland killing video remained on its platform for two hours. The company, in response to the incident, is reviewing its process for reporting and reviewing objectionable material. Facebook will look for ways to speed up the review process and make it easier for users to report violent videos. The company also released a timeline of events related to the suspect, Steve Stephens, who posted three videos, including a video of the killing. Facebook disabled Stephens' account within 23 minutes of receiving the first report about the murder video.

site_title: Prince's doc prescribed meds under friend's name: Warrants
summary: Police investigating Prince's 2016 death found opioids scattered around his home, but no evidence on who supplied the fatal dose of fentanyl. Documents reveal Prince was prescribed painkillers, including some under a friend's name, and had a history of withdrawal symptoms. The investigation is ongoing, with no one charged. A doctor admitted issuing a prescription under a friend's name to protect Prince's privacy, but no evidence of the fentanyl source has been found.

site_title: Football: Chelsea stalwart John Terry to leave at end of season
summary: Chelsea defender John Terry will leave the club at the end of the season, according to a statement from the Premier League club. Terry, 36, has played over 700 games for Chelsea, serving as the team's most successful captain, and has captained the team a record 578 times. He will depart after more than two decades of dedicated service, with the club praising his "utmost pride" in wearing the Chelsea shirt.

site_title: H-1B visa applications drop as US employers anticipate reforms
summary: US employers submitted 199,000 H-1B visa applications for 2018, a 16% decrease from last year's 236,000. The drop may reflect concern over the Trump administration's restrictive approach to the program, which is designed to fill technical job vacancies. The number of applications far exceeded the 85,000 visas available, with no significant changes made this year. Some officials, including lobbyists, believe the drop is a shift in strategy rather than a decrease in demand, as companies often apply for more visas than they plan to use.

site_title: Boy crushed to death at Atlanta revolving restaurant: 4 other freak accidents
summary: A 5-year-old boy died after his head became lodged between the revolving floor and a stationary wall at the Sun Dial restaurant in Atlanta. The incident is the latest in a series of freak accidents involving revolving structures, including a teenager's death in China, a girl's foot mangled in Houston, a Yale undergraduate's asphyxiation from hair caught in a lathe, and a Japanese boy's fatal crush between an automatic revolving door in Tokyo. Authorities have highlighted inadequate safety measures and design flaws in these incidents.

site_title: Football: Alexis Sanchez, Mesut Ozil strike to end Arsenal away woes
summary: Arsenal ended their four-game away losing streak with a 2-1 victory over Middlesbrough in the Premier League. Goals from Alexis Sanchez and Mesut Ozil, in the 42nd and 71st minutes, respectively, secured the win. Despite a strong Middlesbrough performance, Arsenal's attacking difficulties were addressed, and the Gunners now sit seven points behind fourth-placed Manchester City with a game in hand. The win brings relief to manager Arsene Wenger, but Arsenal still face a tough fight to avoid relegation.

site_title: Athletics: Kenyans sweep titles at Boston Marathon
summary: Kenyan athletes dominated the 121st Boston Marathon, sweeping the top spots in both the men's and women's divisions. Geoffrey Kirui won the men's race with a time of 2:09:37, while Edna Kiplagat claimed the women's title in 2:21:52. The Kenyan clean sweep comes as a welcome boost after recent doping scandals, including a failed test by 2016 Olympic women's marathon champion Jemima Sumgong.

site_title: China says no political motive as North Korea flights suspended
summary: China denies any political motive behind suspending flights to North Korea, attributing the decision to low demand. State broadcaster CCTV reported Air China cancelled its Beijing-Pyongyang route, but the foreign ministry said it was a "market-based" decision. The US has urged China to rein in North Korea's missile and nuclear programs, while China has halted coal imports and seen a decline in tourism interest. Despite this, foreign tour companies report no decrease in demand for tours to North Korea, with some citing poor sales as the reason for their decision to stop offering trips.

site_title: Football: Christian Fuchs lauds Griezmann as Atletico prepare for Foxes' cauldron
summary: Leicester City's Christian Fuchs praises teammate Antoine Griezmann as the team prepares to face Atletico Madrid in the Champions League quarter-final. Despite Griezmann scoring the only goal in the first leg, Fuchs believes Leicester's defenders adjusted well to his movement and will be prepared for him in the return leg. Fuchs credits the King Power Stadium's electric atmosphere for giving Leicester an edge, citing the fans as the 12th man. The team's historic quarter-final appearance is seen as a rare opportunity, with Fuchs acknowledging that Tuesday's game could be their last chance to reach the semi-finals for a while.

site_title: Football: Neymar ready to lead from the front as Barca plot Champions League comeback
summary: Barcelona striker Neymar is confident the team can overcome a 3-0 deficit against Juventus in the Champions League quarterfinals. Neymar has a point to prove after missing several games due to suspension, and will look to replicate his magical performance against Paris Saint-Germain, where he scored and assisted in a 6-1 win. Barcelona will need to give their "absolute maximum" to achieve a comeback, and will be without midfielder Javier Mascherano due to a calf injury, while Juventus forward Paulo Dybala is expected to be fit despite an ankle injury.

site_title: US police, FBI widen nationwide search for Facebook killer, as Cleveland residents remain rattled
summary: US police and the FBI have widened their search for Steve Stephens, 37, who is accused of shooting 74-year-old Robert Godwin in Cleveland, Ohio, and posting the killing on Facebook. A $50,000 reward has been offered for information leading to his arrest. Stephens had no prior criminal record, but had worked as a vocational specialist and youth mentor before the shooting. He was last seen in the Cleveland area, but police believe he may be in neighboring states, including Pennsylvania, Indiana, Michigan, and New York. The suspect's face has been plastered on billboards and alerts, and police are urging residents to remain vigilant and report any sightings.

site_title: Donald Trump congratulates  President Erdogan on disputed Turkey referendum
summary: US President Donald Trump congratulated Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on winning a referendum granting him sweeping new powers, despite criticism from international observers who deemed the vote as "uneven" and "unfair." The referendum saw the "Yes" camp win 51.41% of the vote, but the opposition claimed it was marred by procedural changes and allegations of fraud. Erdogan vowed to hold further referendums, including one on Turkey's EU bid, and to reintroduce the death penalty, which would automatically end the country's EU membership bid.

site_title: North Korea warns of 'all out war', vows to continue testing missiles
summary: North Korea has warned of an "all-out war" if the US takes military action against it, amid escalating tensions over the country's missile tests. Vice Foreign Minister Han Song-Ryol said North Korea would continue to test missiles on a weekly, monthly, and yearly basis, and vowed to respond to any US military action "in kind." US Vice-President Mike Pence warned North Korea that the US would not tolerate its nuclear ambitions and would take military action if necessary, while visiting South Korea and reaffirming the US's commitment to defending its ally.

site_title: Football: Sky's the limit for prodigious Marcus Rashford, says Matteo Darmian
summary: Manchester United's Marcus Rashford has been backed by teammate Matteo Darmian to become one of the world's top forwards. Rashford scored in a 2-0 win over Chelsea, his ninth goal of the season. Darmian praised Rashford's quality, shot, movement, and speed, saying he is "very good in every part of the game." The 19-year-old is still young, but Darmian believes he has the potential to be one of the most important players in the world, citing a "not as good period" in scoring goals as a normal part of a striker's career.

site_title: Delta Air Lines to pay up to US$10,000 to bumped customers
summary: Delta Air Lines has increased its payout for bumped passengers to nearly $10,000, with customers eligible for up to $2,000 and supervisors able to grant up to $9,950. The move comes after a violent incident on a United Airlines flight last week, where a passenger was forcibly removed from an overbooked flight. The airline industry's response aims to address global outrage sparked by the incident. United Airlines has already amended some policies, including requiring employees to be booked at least 60 minutes prior to departure, as part of an audit of its practices.

site_title: Russian investigators question new suspect over St Petersburg metro bombing
summary: Russian investigators are questioning Abror Azimov, the ninth suspect detained on suspicion of colluding with St Petersburg metro bombing bomber Akbarzhon Jalilov, who was killed in the explosion. Azimov, born in 1990 from Central Asia, is described as one of the organisers of the attack and had allegedly trained Jalilov. He was detained in the Moscow region, marking the latest development in the investigation into the April 3 attack that killed 14 people.

site_title: North Korea said to snub Chinese diplomats as tensions mounted
summary: North Korea snubbed Chinese diplomats, including Foreign Minister Wang Yi and special envoy Wu Dawei, as tensions with the US escalated. This move raises questions about Beijing's influence over Kim Jong Un. The snub came after Chinese President Xi Jinping met with US President Donald Trump, who is seeking stronger action from China to stop North Korea's nuclear development. The lack of response from North Korea has sparked concerns about the effectiveness of China's efforts to pressure Kim's regime.

site_title: Wall Street edges higher as tech, financials gain
summary: US stocks opened higher on April 17, 2017, rising for the first time in four days, driven by gains in technology and financial stocks. The S&P 500 technology sector rose 0.44%, followed by a 0.3% gain in financials. Geopolitical tensions and weak US retail sales data were factors holding gains in check. Gold prices hit five-month highs, and the dollar fell to a five-month low. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 67 points, or 0.33%, to 20,520.25.

site_title: Twenty-six students shortlisted for OCBC Bank internship on 'bank of the future'
summary: Twenty-six students have been selected for the OCBC Bank's six-month FRANKpreneurship programme, designed to create innovative ideas for a bank of the future. The programme, starting next month, will equip students with cloud-based applications and training from experts, and have them work on a problem statement to develop their entrepreneurial skills and banking sector experience. At the end of the six months, students will pitch their ideas to a panel of judges, and those deemed suitable will be considered for the bank's management trainee programme.

site_title: Malaysia police query social activist Peter Chong's abduction claim
summary: Malaysian social activist Peter Chong claimed he was abducted while investigating the disappearance of Pastor Raymond Koh in southern Thailand. However, Inspector-General of Police Khalid Abu Bakar questioned Chong's credibility, asking why he didn't share information with authorities. Chong returned to Malaysia on Sunday, claiming he was abducted, but police will not open an investigation. Police will instead record a statement from Chong to verify his claims. The disappearance of Pastor Koh remains the only one classified as an abduction by the police, with CCTV footage showing a professionally executed operation.

site_title: 21,000 people and 18,000 eggs: the Trump White House presides over its first Easter Egg Roll
summary: US President Donald Trump kicked off his first White House Easter Egg Roll on April 17, 2017, amidst overcast skies and occasional showers. The event drew approximately 21,000 attendees, a significant decrease from the 35,000 in 2016. Trump praised the competitive spirit of the children and thanked his wife Melania for her efforts in planning the event, which has faced organizational challenges. The event featured a few musical acts, military bands, and fewer characters than previous years, but the mood remained cheerful, with the Trumps playing warm hosts.

site_title: Turkey referendum was 'unlevel playing field': Monitors
summary: Turkey's referendum on granting President Erdogan extra powers was marred by allegations of an "unlevel playing field" and procedural changes that removed key safeguards. International observers from the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe and the Council of Europe stated that the campaign was not conducted fairly, with unequal media coverage and allegations of intimidation. The monitors also noted that late changes in counting procedures and the state of emergency imposed after a failed coup infringed upon fundamental freedoms. The referendum was won by the "Yes" camp, but its legitimacy remains disputed.

site_title: 3 roads, lanes in Kampong Glam closed for Othman Wok's State-assisted funeral on Tuesday
summary: Three roads and lanes in Kampong Glam, Singapore will be closed from 7am to 3pm on April 18 for the State-assisted funeral of late Mr. Othman Wok. The prayer service will be held at Sultan Mosque from 1pm to 2pm. The roads to be closed include Kandahar Street, Muscat Street, and Sultan Gate. Heavy traffic is expected along the funeral procession route from 2pm to 3pm, with LTA advising against flying drones in the area. Police officers will direct traffic, and parking restrictions will be enforced.

site_title: Arconic CEO exits after 'poor judgment' in fight with Elliott Management
summary: Arconic CEO Klaus Kleinfeld stepped down after showing "poor judgment" in sending a letter to Elliott Management during a proxy fight. He was appointed interim CEO by David Hess, a board member, and Patricia Russo will take over as interim board chair. Kleinfeld's departure disrupts a proxy battle between Elliott Management, which sought to oust him and replace four directors, and Arconic. The company cited Kleinfeld's actions as the reason for his departure, not the proxy fight or Elliott's criticisms of the company's strategy or performance.
