site_title: Suspected acid attack in London club injures 12; incident not terror-related
summary: Twelve people were injured in an acid attack at a London nightclub, Mangle, on April 17. The incident, not believed to be terror-related, occurred after a dispute between two groups of people. Two men in their twenties suffered serious but stable injuries, while 10 others had minor injuries. An unknown corrosive substance was sprayed inside the club, with around 600 people present. Police are investigating and have appealed for witnesses, with no arrests made yet. The incident is part of a sharp rise in acid attacks in London, with over 1,800 reported incidents since 2010.

site_title: Family remembers Othman Wok as kind, loving father who was also devoted to his constituents
summary: Former Singapore Cabinet minister Othman Wok, 92, died on April 17 at Singapore General Hospital after a prolonged illness. He was remembered by his family as a kind and loving father who was also devoted to his constituents. Wok served as Minister for Social Affairs from 1963 to 1977 and Singapore's ambassador to Indonesia from 1977 to 1981. His daughter, Lily, described him as a devoted family man who emphasized the importance of humility and racial harmony. Wok's death was met with respect and condolences from the public, with a wake held at his home in Bedok.

site_title: Indonesia police thwart plan by hardline Muslims to guard poll stations for Jakarta governor election
summary: Indonesian police thwarted a plan by hardline Muslim groups to guard polling booths during the Jakarta governor election, citing the potential for clashes and intimidation. The groups, which include the Islamic Defenders Front, had planned to deploy 100 monitors at each polling station, but police said such mobilization was prohibited. The election has been marred by religious tensions, with incumbent Governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama facing blasphemy charges stemming from the campaign. Around 66,000 police and military personnel will be deployed on voting day, aiming to ensure a neutral and safe election process.

site_title: Small airplane crashes in Portugal near supermarket, killing five
summary: A small airplane crashed near a supermarket in Tires, Portugal, killing five people, including three French nationals and one Swiss citizen. The plane, headed for Marseilles, France, crashed into a truck, causing a fire. One person on the ground died in the incident. The cause of the accident was not yet known. President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa visited the crash site, with over 50 rescue workers present.

site_title: Prudent fiscal policy can also benefit economy
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is unlikely to change its exchange rate policy, maintaining a stable Singapore dollar to support economic growth and control inflation. As a small, open economy, adjusting the exchange rate is more effective than changing interest rates. A stable exchange rate enables the government to adopt prudent fiscal policy, allowing for slow increases in expenditure on research and development. This can lead to moderate inflation, encouraging businesses to invest and promoting economic growth. By combining a stable exchange rate and fiscal policy, Singapore can maintain a positive economic outlook while keeping inflation under control.

site_title: After death of Othman Wok, only two members of independent Singapore's first Cabinet remain
summary: Singapore's first independent cabinet has lost its last remaining members with the death of Othman Wok. Only two members, Ong Pang Boon, 88, and Jek Yeun Thong, 86, remain. Both men were part of the People's Action Party's (PAP) Old Guard and held key ministerial posts, including Home Affairs and Labour Minister. They were the only remaining signatories to the Independence of Singapore Agreement signed in 1965.

site_title: Football: Defiant David Moyes claims he's still a match winner
summary: Sunderland manager David Moyes defended his Premier League win record, stating he believes it's the third- or fourth-best in the league. Despite a 2-2 draw with West Ham, Moyes acknowledged the jeers from the crowd, accepting that his team isn't performing well. He offered playing time to midfielder Wahbi Khazri, who scored against West Ham, if he continues to deliver. Sunderland remains rooted at the bottom of the league with 21 points from 32 games, and will visit Middlesbrough on April 26.

site_title: NKF to open 7 new dialysis centres by 2020, to benefit about 1,300 patients
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) plans to open seven new dialysis centres in Singapore by 2020, benefiting approximately 1,300 patients. Currently, NKF runs 31 dialysis centres, serving over 4,000 patients with kidney failure. The new centres will help alleviate the shortage of space, which has left existing facilities running at full capacity. The mega dialysis centre in Jurong West and the Toa Payoh West Community Centre centre are expected to open in September and December, respectively, with opening dates for the remaining centres yet to be confirmed.

site_title: State-assisted funeral for Othman Wok, gun carriage to carry casket through town, heartland areas
summary: State-assisted funeral services will be held for former Singapore cabinet minister Othman Wok, who died at 92. The funeral will feature a gun carriage carrying a State Flag-draped casket through heartland areas, followed by a burial at Pusara Aman in the Choa Chu Kang Muslim Cemetery. A Memorial Service will also be held on Wednesday at the Victoria Concert Hall. The funeral is a rare honor, as the State Flag is draped over the casket, the highest State honor given to someone who dies.

site_title: Second half of April to be wet, with short thundery showers in the afternoon: MSS
summary: The Meteorological Service Singapore predicts six to eight days of short thundery showers in the second half of April, mostly in the afternoon, with temperatures ranging from 24-34°C. Despite the wet weather, warm days are expected, with daily maximum temperatures reaching 35°C. Widespread thundery showers accompanied by gusty winds are also forecast for two or three days, due to Sumatra squalls. The month is expected to see slightly above normal rainfall, with the highest daily rainfall total recorded on April 13 at 61.7mm.

site_title: Remembering Othman Wok: A unifying icon in multi-racial Singapore: Ministers
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam eulogized late founding father Othman Wok, saying he would be a vastly different country without him. Wok, a pioneer Cabinet minister, united people of different racial and religious backgrounds during Singapore's early days. He fought against extremist forces and laid the foundation for a modern and progressive Malay-Muslim community. Wok's legacy includes developing the Administration of Muslim Law Act and launching the Mosque Building Fund, which helped construct 26 modern mosques. His death at 92 was mourned by ministers and leaders who praised his courage and commitment to multi-racialism.

site_title: Kids mark World Haemophilia Day with visit to biotech firm
summary: Five children, including three with haemophilia, visited a biotechnology firm in Singapore to learn about blood clotting factors and how they manage their bleeding disorders. The visit, organized to mark World Haemophilia Day, featured a lab tour and games stations. The children learned about the treatment options and the challenges faced by people with haemophilia, including the cost of medicine and the need for regular injections. The event aimed to raise awareness and promote understanding of the disease, and to provide a positive experience for the children, who can now participate in activities with their peers and lead more productive lives.

site_title: Football: Game Changers demand explanation from FAS general secretary Winston Lee over $500,000 donation
summary: The Game Changers team in the upcoming FAS election has accused FAS general secretary Winston Lee of not explaining the $500,000 donation made by Tiong Bahru FC to the AFF in 2014. The team claims that the donation was made to benefit Singapore football, but questions how the funds were used and why the FAS didn't obtain Board approval. The FAS has denied the allegations, stating that they will provide details in due course. The revelation has raised eyebrows over the handling of funds and the implementation of the AFF Football Management System.

site_title: The Straits Times' News In A Minute: April 17, 2017
summary: Former Singapore Cabinet minister Othman Wok died at 92. The Singapore Maritime Gallery reopened after a $2-million renovation. An otter was found injured by a fishing hook at Marina Bay.

site_title: Othman Wok channelled 'courage and passion' into creating better life for fellow citizens: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed his condolences to the late Mr Othman Wok's wife, calling him a steadfast believer in a multiracial, multi-religious Singapore. Mr Wok, one of Singapore's founding fathers, channelled his courage and passion into creating a better life for fellow citizens. Despite facing threats and pressure, Mr Wok stood resolutely by his convictions, helping keep the dream of a united Singapore alive. Mr Lee remembered Mr Wok's numerous contributions, including his work as Minister for Social Affairs and Director of the Malay Affairs Bureau, and conferred him the Order of Nila Utama in 1983.

site_title: Cycling infrastructure won't help if mindsets don't change
summary: Singaporean cyclists face barriers in adopting cycling as a primary mode of transport due to misconceptions about its benefits and challenges. Despite its comparable time to public transport and health benefits, many view cycling as requiring great effort, taking longer times, and being weather-dependent. To overcome this, the government can implement public campaigns and school education to highlight cycling's convenience and speed, especially for short distances. Changing mindsets is crucial for increasing cycling adoption and effectiveness of infrastructure improvements, ultimately benefiting public health and reducing reliance on cars.

site_title: Former delivery driver jailed, disqualified from driving for five years after accident
summary: A 26-year-old former delivery driver, Vijayanand Arumugam, was jailed for 11 months and banned from driving for five years after pleading guilty to riding a motorcycle while disqualified, causing grievous hurt to an elderly woman. He had forged an official document to obtain a job as a delivery driver, despite being disqualified from driving, and also stole from his employer and committed other thefts. The elderly woman suffered multiple fractures and was hospitalized for six days.

site_title: Revamped Kidney Discovery Centre to promote kidney health to working adults and the elderly
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has revamped its Kidney Discovery Centre with new interactive exhibits to educate working adults and elderly on kidney health. The $1 million renovation features technology such as motion detectors and touch screens, allowing visitors to simulate exercises and calculate meal calories. The centre aims to double its 6,000 yearly visitorship to 12,000, targeting a broader audience due to the rising incidence of kidney failure in Singapore. With one new case of kidney failure reported every five hours, the NKF hopes to increase awareness and prevention through early education.

site_title: Turkey to extend state of emergency after referendum win: Reports
summary: Turkey is set to extend its nearly nine-month state of emergency, following President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's referendum win that boosted his powers. The decision will be made at a security council meeting at the presidential palace. Erdogan's referendum victory allows him to increase his authority, following the July 15 failed coup. The state of emergency, first imposed in July, will be extended, with the exact duration to be determined at the meeting.

site_title: Russia warns US against unilateral strike on North Korea
summary: Russia's Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov warned the US against a unilateral strike on North Korea, calling it a "risky path" that breaches international law. Lavrov stated Russia is ready to restore relations with Washington. Vice President Mike Pence declared the era of "strategic patience" with North Korea over, stating all options are on the table to curb its missile and nuclear programs. The US and North Korea engage in heightened tensions amid failed missile tests and warnings of potential military action.

site_title: Formula One: Toro Rosso's Carlos Sainz given three-place grid penalty for Russian GP
summary: Formula One driver Carlos Sainz of Toro Rosso received a three-place grid penalty for the Russian Grand Prix after being deemed mostly responsible for a collision with Williams driver Lance Stroll during the Bahrain Grand Prix. The incident occurred on lap 13 when Sainz collided with Stroll while attempting to pass, bringing out the safety car. The stewards ruled that Stroll had taken the normal racing line, while Sainz's passing attempt was deemed optimistic. The penalty will impact Sainz's starting position for the Russian Grand Prix on April 30.

site_title: Tennis: Marketa Vondrousova clinches first title at Biel Bienne Open
summary: Marketa Vondrousova, a 17-year-old Czech tennis player, won her first title at the Biel Bienne Open in Biel, Switzerland, defeating Anett Kontaveit 6-4, 7-6 (8-6) on April 16, 2017. Vondrousova, ranked 233, came from qualifying and knocked out top-seeded Barbora Strycova in the semi-finals. This was her biggest win and her second main draw on the WTA Tour, following a year of recovery from a left elbow injury.

site_title: NBA: Wizards cast their spell on Hawks, 4th-quarter surge lifts Warriors over Portland
summary: The Washington Wizards defeated the Atlanta Hawks 114-107 in Game 1 of the 2017 NBA Playoffs, taking a 1-0 lead in the series. John Wall scored 32 points and 14 assists, while Bradley Beal and Markieff Morris added 22 and 21 points respectively. The Hawks committed 21 turnovers and shot 43.6% from the field. Meanwhile, the Golden State Warriors won Game 1 of their series against the Portland Trail Blazers 121-109, with Draymond Green leading a defensive surge in the fourth quarter.

site_title: First Reit posts 1.4% rise in first quarter DPU
summary: First Reit, a healthcare-based investment trust, reported a 1.4% rise in first quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.14 cents, driven by rental income from Siloam Hospitals Labuan Bajo acquired in December 2016. This marks the Reit's 11th consecutive quarter of DPU growth since 2014. The trust's gearing ratio stands at 31% with an interest cover of 5.7 times, and it remains optimistic about the Indonesian healthcare market, citing a growing pipeline of hospitals and government reforms.

site_title: Golf: Edoardo Molinari takes his first European title in seven years at Trophee Hassan II
summary: Italy's Edoardo Molinari won his third European Tour title, and first in seven years, by defeating Ireland's Paul Dunne in a sudden-death play-off at the Trophee Hassan II in Morocco. Both players finished tied on nine-under par after four rounds. Molinari, 36, triumphed over Dunne, 24, who led by two shots overnight and had a disappointing final round. Molinari's victory comes after a long drought, and he hopes it will be the start of a successful comeback.

site_title: European leaders respond cautiously to Turkey vote
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel have responded cautiously to Turkey's narrow referendum victory, calling on Turkish authorities to address concerns about the referendum's content and procedure. The result shows a divided Turkish society, with Merkel stating it's a "big responsibility" for President Erdogan to bear. The European Commission has also expressed reservations, and Merkel and Gabriel have urged Turkey to quickly address these concerns and engage in respectful dialogue with all parts of Turkish society.

site_title: Formula One: McLaren's woes get worse after Bahrain GP meltdown
summary: McLaren's Formula One woes worsened after a disastrous Bahrain Grand Prix, where Belgian rookie Stoffel Vandoorne failed to start due to a Honda power unit problem. Two-time world champion Fernando Alonso also suffered engine failures in qualifying and a first-lap retirement, finishing 11th. McLaren remains last in the standings, without a point from three races, due to reliability issues and poor performance. Alonso criticized Honda, stating he's never raced with less power, while Vandoorne joked about exercising on a treadmill after his disappointing debut.

site_title: Billionaire Taizo Son ditches Japan to start afresh in Singapore
summary: Singapore has lured billionaire Taizo Son, president and CEO of Mistletoe Inc, to relocate from Japan with a $100 million investment plan over the next five years. Son cited frustration with Japan's regulatory environment and education system, which he believes failed to create entrepreneurs. He plans to invest in the region, expand his existing Garena stake, and open a school in Singapore. Son aims to redesign cities with a human-centric model, reducing reliance on cars, and expects permanent residency within three months.

site_title: Turkey opposition disputes Erdogan referendum win, monitors concerned
summary: Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan declared victory in a referendum granting him sweeping powers, with the 'Yes' camp winning 51.41% of the vote. However, opposition parties disputed the results, claiming irregularities and alleging a "dirty" campaign. International monitors expressed concern over the vote count and campaign process, citing an "unlevel playing field." The opposition plans to challenge the results, while Erdogan's government is set to introduce the new system, which could give him direct power to appoint ministers and potentially extend his rule until 2029.

site_title: M1 net profit down 14.6% in Q1
summary: M1's net profit fell 14.6% to S$36.3 million in Q1, primarily due to higher operating expenses. Operating revenue rose 1.2% to S$260.7 million, while service revenue decreased slightly to S$201.5 million. The company added 24,000 postpaid customers and 3,000 prepaid customers during the quarter. M1 maintained its 80% payout ratio and expects to pay S$208 million for spectrum lots. Net asset value per share increased to 47.2 cents.

site_title: Tennis: Borna Coric wins first ATP title at Grand Prix Hassan II
summary: Croatian tennis player Borna Coric won his first ATP title at the Grand Prix Hassan II in Marrakech, Morocco, defeating Philipp Kohlschreiber in the final. Coric, 20, overcame a set and 3-0 deficit to win 5-7, 7-6 (7-3), 7-5 in two hours 38 minutes. This victory marked a significant turnaround for Coric, who had lost form and slipped to 79 in the rankings. His win came after he saved four match points and secured a comeback from a 2-4 deficit in the third set.

site_title: Football: Valencia stalemate leaves Sevilla stuck in a rut
summary: Sevilla secured a 0-0 draw against Valencia, ending their slump in form and moving closer to automatic Champions League qualification. The draw leaves Sevilla three points behind third-placed Atletico Madrid, but they maintain an eight-point lead over fifth-placed Villarreal. Valencia's four-game winning streak was halted due to a disputed handball call against Italian striker Simone Zaza, who had a goal disallowed 17 minutes from the end. The draw is Sevilla's first in their last eight games in all competitions.

site_title: Reboot of US-Sino ties good for Asean: The Nation Columnist
summary: US President Donald Trump's informal summit with Chinese President Xi Jinping exceeded Asean leaders' expectations, setting a positive tone for the region's engagement with the US and China. The meeting highlighted the need for Asean to promote further dialogue between North Korea and its antagonists, as well as address trade challenges with the US. Asean leaders will meet later this month to review external relations with dialogue partners, including the US and China, and explore ways to reduce tension on the Korean Peninsula. The region's diplomatic approach, led by China, may provide a useful deterrent, and Asean is expected to be more assertive in settling trade issues with the US and engaging in efforts to reduce tension on the Korean Peninsula.

site_title: Athletics: Singapore Athletics management torn apart by in-fighting, set to elect new leaders
summary: Singapore Athletics is set for a leadership reshuffle after current president Ho Mun Cheong's team faces internal conflicts and disagreements over various issues. A snap election is expected, with several management committee members calling for an extraordinary general meeting. The issues include the appointment of Jaime Cheong as general manager and unilateral actions by the president. The association has also been withholding funding from Sport Singapore, leading to a dispute over documents. The leadership turmoil may impact Singapore's preparations for the upcoming SEA Games in Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: Football: Arsene Wenger implores critics to ease up on out-of-form Hector Bellerin
summary: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger has urged his team to respond to their 0-3 loss at Crystal Palace, calling for unity between fans and the club. Wenger believes Hector Bellerin, who has struggled to return to form due to ankle problems, did not deserve the criticism he received after the loss. Wenger praised Bellerin for trying to focus on defending well and hopes he can contribute to the team's success in the future. The team will look to bounce back from the defeat at Middlesbrough on Monday, aiming to improve their record at the Riverside Stadium.

site_title: Football: Ki Sung Yueng believes Swansea can avoid the dreaded drop
summary: Swansea City midfielder Ki Sung Yueng believes the team can avoid relegation from the Premier League with positive results in their remaining five matches. After dropping into the relegation zone, Ki expressed confidence in the team's ability to win games, particularly at home. He sees Saturday's match against Stoke City as an opportunity to gain momentum and boost confidence, which will be crucial in the challenging fixtures that follow, including matches against Manchester United and Sunderland.

site_title: Tennis: Steve Johnson digs deep to grind out Houston clay court victory
summary: American tennis player Steve Johnson won the US Men's Clay Court Championship in Houston, defeating Brazilian Thomaz Bellucci 6-4, 4-6, 7-5. Johnson, struggling with a cramp in his left leg, nearly lost the match but prevailed in the final set tiebreak with a crucial forehand groundstroke. Johnson attributed his victory to being worn down after a long week of competing in a Davis Cup tie in Australia. His second ATP victory came after a physically draining match, with Johnson crediting his "body running out of gas" for his eventual win.

site_title: Football: Harry Kane aiming for Chelsea scalp in FA Cup semi-final
summary: Tottenham Hotspur striker Harry Kane says beating Chelsea in the FA Cup semi-final could psychologically impact the Premier League leaders, who have lost two of their last four league games. Tottenham, 71 points behind Chelsea with six games left, are aiming to inflict another blow. Kane urges his team-mates not to take their foot off the pedal, saying their strong season isn't over yet. The last FA Cup win over Chelsea came in 1982, with Tottenham seeking to extend their lead.

site_title: Body found in Singapore River; second such incident in four days
summary: A body of a Chinese woman in her 50s was found in the Singapore River early Monday morning, marking the second unnatural death in the river in four days. The woman was discovered motionless in the water by a group of friends in Clarke Quay and pronounced dead by paramedics. Police are investigating the unnatural death, which occurred without identification documents. The discovery is the second such incident in four days, following the discovery of a man in his 60s near Esplanade Park last Thursday.

site_title: Football: Everton looking at a top-six finish, says Ashley Williams
summary: Everton defender Ashley Williams has stated that the team must focus on their own performances to achieve a top-six finish in the Premier League. Currently sixth with 57 points after 33 games, Everton has played three more games than Arsenal, who are three points behind. Williams emphasized the importance of maintaining their current form and confidence, acknowledging that pushing into the elite group is a difficult task. Everton is set to face West Ham United on Saturday, with a strong home league record, including an eight-game winning streak.

site_title: Football: Southampton's Jack Stephens satisfied with burgeoning Maya Yoshida partnership
summary: Southampton's Jack Stephens expressed satisfaction with his defensive partnership with Maya Yoshida, which has helped the team keep two clean sheets in their last four Premier League games. With the departure of Jose Fonte and Virgil van Dijk, Stephens and Yoshida have become the recognized central defenders, and Stephens believes their partnership has become stronger with regular playing time. The duo faces a challenging trip to league leaders Chelsea on April 25, but Stephens is focused on getting a result.

site_title: From scorpion to broken guitar: 5 passenger incidents aboard United Airlines
summary: United Airlines has faced a series of passenger incidents, including a scorpion on a flight, two teenage girls denied entry for wearing leggings, an autistic child's emergency landing, a 90-year-old WWII veteran bumped off a flight, and a broken guitar thrown by baggage handlers. The incidents have sparked public outcry and criticism, with some calling for boycotts. In response, the airline has apologized and offered compensation in some cases, but the incidents have damaged the airline's reputation and led to increased scrutiny of its policies and procedures.

site_title: Swa Garden Teochew Restaurant closes, 300 customers flock there to say goodbye
summary: A well-known Teochew restaurant, Swa Garden Teochew Restaurant, closed on April 16 after 18 years of operation. The 300 customers who visited the restaurant in its last days were met with a farewell dinner, where the two bosses personally cooked dishes for them. The owners cited poor health and a lack of successors as reasons for the closure. Customers expressed sadness, with many leaving messages on the restaurant's Facebook page, sharing fond memories of their dining experiences. The restaurant's closure marks the end of an era for the Teochew community in Singapore.

site_title: Anwar sues Malaysian government over sodomy conviction
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim has filed a new lawsuit against the government, claiming his sodomy conviction was obtained through fraud. Anwar, who was convicted in 2014, is suing the government, citing the testimony of his accuser as false and perjured. He is seeking a civil court to invalidate his conviction and claim his immediate release. Anwar's lawyers argue that the government knew his accuser was untruthful and used false evidence to secure his conviction. The case marks another challenge by Anwar to his conviction, which has been upheld by Malaysia's highest courts.

site_title: Hundreds evacuated after deadly Sri Lanka garbage dump collapse
summary: Hundreds of people were evacuated in Sri Lanka after a 300-foot garbage dump collapsed, killing 26 and injuring many more. The disaster occurred in a slum in Colombo, where police found 145 homes destroyed and many more buildings damaged. At least six people were reported missing, and hundreds of soldiers were searching for survivors. The collapse came as the country celebrated its traditional new year, and the government had planned to relocate the garbage dump. Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe offered assistance and a Japanese team will be sent to evaluate the situation and provide aid.

site_title: 4 home cooks set up private dining kitchens
summary: Four home cooks, Lynnette Seah, Rose Sivam, Annette Tan, and Felicia Tan, have opened their own private dining kitchens, offering customizable menus to groups of 8-17 people. Each has a unique background and cooking style, with Lynnette specializing in Peranakan cuisine, Rose focusing on Western options with a Peranakan twist, Annette blending Eurasian and Peranakan flavors, and Felicia offering Asian-inspired dishes. The dinners range in price from S$38 to S$120 per person and are often themed, with entertainment and decorations adding to the experience. While some may view private dining as a money-losing venture, the cooks say it's a passion project that allows them to share their love of food and cooking with others.

site_title: Remembering Othman Wok: Tributes to a firm believer of multi-racial Singapore
summary: Former Singapore minister Othman Wok, 92, died on Monday, leaving behind a legacy as a champion of multiracialism and patron of sports and social services. Tributes poured in from leaders, including President Tony Tan and Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, who remembered him as a firm believer in a harmonious Singapore. Wok's contributions included promoting racial and religious reconciliation, developing the local sports scene, and establishing the National Stadium. His passing has been hailed as a loss for the nation, but his legacy will continue to inspire Singaporeans to build on the foundations he laid.

site_title: Turkish electoral board head says ballots, envelopes in referendum are valid
summary: Turkish electoral board head Sadi Guven confirmed that ballots and envelopes used in Sunday's referendum are valid. The decision to allow unstamped ballots was made before results were entered into the system, and was previously permitted by the government. Guven's statement comes after the "No" campaign raised concerns about the vote's validity. The ruling AK Party and main opposition were present at polling stations, where they signed off on reports, further validating the process.

site_title: Social media tributes: Othman Wok 'an independence fighter, a fearless leader and a true gentleman'
summary: Minister Othman Wok, a founding cabinet member of independent Singapore, died at 92 on April 17, 2017. Tributes poured in from ministers, family, and ex-colleagues, praising his role in promoting multiracial harmony and social welfare. Leaders including Dr Vivian Balakrishnan and K Shanmugam hailed him as an "independence fighter, a fearless leader and a true gentleman." His contributions to Singapore's development were recognized, with many expressing condolences on social media, including New Zealand's High Commissioner Jonathan Austin.

site_title: Football: Crowd trouble forces Bastia v Lyon game to be called off
summary: Olympique Lyonnais' game against SC Bastia was abandoned on April 16, 2017, due to crowd trouble. Bastia fans attacked Lyon goalkeeper Anthony Lopes as he left the pitch at half-time, prompting the LFP to call off the match. The LFP condemned the incidents and announced plans to re-examine SC Bastia's security arrangements. This incident is the second in a week, following a Europa League clash with Besiktas, which also involved crowd trouble.

site_title: Actress Julie Tan to leave Mediacorp's stable
summary: Actress Julie Tan, 24, announced she will leave Mediacorp after her contract ends in June, citing a desire to pursue her passion in acting. This comes after she failed to make the Top 10 Most Popular Female Artistes list. Tan, who won Best Supporting Actress last year, revealed she has been taking acting classes in New York and feels a change in her thinking and approach to the industry. She expressed gratitude to Mediacorp but plans to "walk a different path."

site_title: No 'special treatment' as Special Functions Minister, says Hishammuddin
summary: Datuk Seri Hishammuddin, Malaysia's Defence Minister, has denied receiving "special treatment" as the newly appointed Special Functions Minister. His main task is to help the Prime Minister safeguard security in Sabah, alongside the Eastern Sabah Security Zone (Esszone) committee. Hishammuddin will work closely with the Esszone advisory board and plans to involve local fishermen in the security efforts. He also emphasized his commitment to his duties and dismissed criticism from certain parties, stating he will focus on his tasks rather than engaging in petty politics.

site_title: China reiterates opposition to South Korea's Thaad anti-missile system
summary: China reiterated its opposition to South Korea's deployment of the Terminal High Altitude Area Defence (Thaad) anti-missile system, citing concerns over its powerful radar posing a threat to its security. China urged all parties to maintain peace and stability in the region. Despite China's objections, South Korean acting President Hwang Kyo Ahn and US Vice-President Mike Pence reaffirmed plans to proceed with the system's deployment, citing its defensive purpose against North Korean missiles. The dispute remains unresolved, with tensions in the region continuing to escalate.

site_title: South Korea prosecutors charge ousted leader Park Geun Hye and Lotte chief Shin Dong Bin with bribery
summary: South Korean prosecutors have charged ousted President Park Geun Hye and Lotte Group chairman Shin Dong Bin with bribery, as well as abuse of power and coercion. Park was also accused of receiving 7 billion won from Lotte for favors and taking bribes worth 29.8 billion won from Samsung scion Lee in exchange for supporting his succession. Shin was charged without detention, while Lee and Park are being held at detention centers. The charges mark the latest twist in a corruption scandal that has rocked the country for months.

site_title: Ahn & Moon should hold one-on-one debate as race to Blue House begins: The Korea Herald
summary: South Korea's presidential campaign is underway, with 22 days left until the election on May 9. The two leading candidates, Moon Jae-in and Ahn Cheol-soo, are currently ahead in the polls with 40% and 37% respectively. A one-on-one debate between the two is being proposed to help voters compare their traits and abilities, as the shortened campaign period raises concerns about voters electing an undeserving leader. The debate would also allow for a more in-depth discussion on policies, addressing the lack of detail in previous debates.

site_title: Lavish lifestyle of 21-year-old Datuk becomes Malaysia's social media hit
summary: A 21-year-old Datuk in Malaysia has gained widespread attention on social media for his lavish lifestyle. Posts on Facebook and Instagram show him attending luxury events, including a private jet ride and a birthday party with a live performance. The young Datuk, Muhammad Saiful Muhamad Ali, has also received the Darjah Indera Mahkota Pahang award in 2015. His business ventures include various industries such as scrap metal, convenience stores, and a recording studio. His posts have garnered over 300,000 views, making him a social media sensation in Malaysia.

site_title: From the archives: Remembering Othman Wok, one of Singapore's founding fathers, 1924-2017
summary: Former Singapore cabinet minister Othman Wok, a key figure in the country's founding, has died at 92. A People's Action Party (PAP) Old Guard, he served as the first minister for social affairs and was an MP for Pasir Panjang constituency from 1963 to 1981. Wok is remembered for his role in championing multi-racialism in Singapore, particularly during the 1964 riots, where his quick thinking may have saved lives. His legacy is seen as crucial to building on Singapore's early progress.

site_title: South Korea says it still plans to deploy US Thaad anti-missile system
summary: South Korea reaffirmed its plans to deploy the US Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (Thaad) anti-missile system, despite concerns over its potential impact on regional stability. The decision, made by Park's conservative government, has been met with opposition from China, which has launched an economic boycott. US Vice-President Mike Pence's visit to South Korea aims to address the issue, with the US seeking China's cooperation to counter North Korea's nuclear and missile threats.

site_title: President Tony Tan visits family of late pioneer leader Othman Wok
summary: President Tony Tan Keng Yam visited the family of late pioneer leader Othman Wok at his house in Kew Avenue on April 17. Othman Wok, Singapore's first Minister for Social Affairs from 1963 to 1977, died at 92 after being in poor health for some time. The public can pay their respects at the house from 6pm on Monday. Notable visitors included Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen, and former mufti Syed Isa Semait, who described Othman Wok as a "multiracial icon" and a "local and national leader".

site_title: March new private home sales jump 82% from February, more than double from year ago
summary: Singapore's new private home sales surged 82% in March, more than doubling from the same period last year, with 1,780 units sold. This represents a near four-year high and a 75.7% jump in executive condominium sales. The strong numbers are attributed to the recent tweaks in property cooling measures, which reduced the holding period for selling properties to three years, and the launch of several successful projects. Developers are expected to capitalize on this momentum, with plans to launch more projects in the coming months.

site_title: Othman Wok, member of independent Singapore's first Cabinet, dies aged 92
summary: Singaporean politician Othman Wok, a founding cabinet minister and champion of multi-racialism, has died at the age of 92. Wok was a key member of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew's Cabinet during Singapore's separation from Malaysia and played a crucial role in shaping the country's social welfare and sports development. He is remembered for his tireless efforts in promoting social progress and equality, and his legacy continues to be celebrated by his colleagues and the Singaporean people.

site_title: Remembering Othman Wok: A champion of multi-culturalism
summary: Minister Othman Wok, a pioneer of multi-culturalism in Singapore, died on April 17 at 92. Born into an Orang Laut family, he rose to become the only Malay in Cabinet in 1963, standing up for a multi-racial Singapore despite facing death threats. Wok defused tensions after Singapore's worst racial riots in 1964 and helped establish policies to support the Malay community. He was instrumental in the creation of the 1965 Independence of Singapore Agreement, and his dedication to a multi-racial Singapore earned him a place in history, with Lee Kuan Yew praising his courage and leadership.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore's export engine roars on for now but risks remain
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports rose 16.5% year-on-year in March, the fifth consecutive month of growth, exceeding analyst expectations. This follows a 21.1% year-on-year rise in February, the fastest in five years. Electronic sales increased 5.2% and non-electronic exports grew 20.8% year-on-year. Economists predict sustained growth in electronics exports, but note risks from anti-globalization rhetoric and potential trade protectionism, particularly from the US.

site_title: US, South Korea agree on early deployment of Thaad as Pence warns North of US resolve
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence warned North Korea of the US resolve during a meeting with South Korean President Hwang Kyo Ahn, amid rising tensions on the Korean peninsula. Pence stated that recent US strikes in Syria and Afghanistan showed the strength of President Trump's resolve, and that North Korea should not test it. The two nations also agreed to strengthen anti-North Korea defenses by deploying the Thaad missile-defence system earlier than planned, in response to North Korea's recent failed missile test and display of missiles in Pyongyang.

site_title: 3-month-old British baby summoned for questioning after grandfather wrongly listed him as terrorist in US travel form
summary: A 3-month-old British baby was summoned to the US embassy in London for questioning after his grandfather mistakenly listed him as a terrorist on a travel form. The grandfather, 62, incorrectly ticked "yes" to potential terrorist activities while filing the Electronic System for Travel Authorisation (Esta) form for the baby's trip to Orlando, Florida. The baby was questioned by officials, but the visa was ultimately not issued in time, causing the grandparents to fly to Orlando without their infant son. The mistake cost the family an extra £3,000.

site_title: US police issue arrest warrant for man who broadcast deadly shooting on Facebook
summary: US police have issued an arrest warrant for Steve Stephens, 37, who broadcast a deadly shooting on Facebook live, killing 74-year-old Robert Godwin Sr. Stephens, a former employee of a behavioral health agency, shot his victim at random on Easter Sunday. Authorities urge Stephens to turn himself in, describing him as armed and dangerous. Stephens has claimed to have committed multiple other homicides, but these have not been verified. Police are searching for Stephens, who fled in a white Ford Fusion with temporary license plates, and are working with the FBI and regional law enforcement.

site_title: Ex-A*Star research assistant jailed for using spy camera to insult modesty of women
summary: A former A*Star research assistant, Raymond Loh Wai Mung, was jailed for six months and two weeks for using a spy camera to take upskirt videos of his female colleagues. Loh, 31, admitted to eight charges, including four for criminal trespass, and was terminated from the company in 2016. He had purchased the camera in 2015 and transferred the videos to his desktop computer. The court heard that Loh had followed one of his colleagues into a female toilet six times, and that he had used the camera to film upskirt videos of three women.

site_title: Prince Harry suffered 'total chaos', sought help to deal with Diana's death
summary: Prince Harry revealed he suffered "total chaos" after his mother Diana's death in 1997, ignoring his emotions for 20 years before seeking help from mental health professionals at 28. With encouragement from brother Prince William, he finally opened up about his struggles with grief and mental health. Harry credited boxing as a helpful outlet for his aggression and now advocates for normalizing conversations about mental health, stating he's "part of a big club" who can share their feelings without stigma.

site_title: China's Q1 property investment accelerates, defying curbs
summary: China's real estate investment grew 9.1% in Q1, accelerating from 8.9% in the first two months of 2017, defying government efforts to cool the market. New construction starts also quickened to 11.6% in the first three months, despite a slowdown in sales. Analysts warn of an overheating market, but policymakers expect moderation, citing the delayed impact of recent cooling measures. The government has implemented tougher curbs, including higher downpayment ratios and restrictions on short-term speculation, to stabilize the market and prevent a crash.

site_title: China's economy grows 6.9% in Q1, slightly faster than expected
summary: China's economy grew 6.9% in Q1, slightly faster than expected, driven by government infrastructure spending and a frenzied housing market. This is the fastest growth since the third quarter of 2015. Analysts expect the economy to lose steam later in the year due to fading stimulus measures and rising debt risks. Despite this, the government aims for 6.5% growth in 2017, and has taken steps to contain financial risks through targeted measures, including raising short-term interest rates.

site_title: askST: What should I do if I suspect poaching activity is going on?
summary: Singapore is a hub for wildlife, with some animals being poached for pets, sale, or consumption. Suspected poaching activity can be reported to the Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority (AVA) via their online feedback form or phone number 6805-2992. If the activity occurs within parks and nature reserves, contact NParks at 1800-471 7300. Photographs, car plate numbers, or videos can aid in investigations, and reports will be kept confidential. Despite official figures indicating low numbers of poaching cases, authorities encourage the public to report any suspicious activity to help combat wildlife poaching.

site_title: New Razer Blade is sleek and capable
summary: The new Razer Blade is a sleek gaming laptop with an upgraded Intel seventh-generation Kaby Lake processor, but retains the Nvidia GeForce GTX 1060 graphics chip. It produces 101fps in Doom and 62fps in Crysis 3, comparable to other GTX 1060-powered laptops. The Blade features a 14-inch 1080p screen, customizable Chroma keyboard, and loud, clear speakers. However, its design is somewhat cramped, and the touchpad buttons are a drawback. Priced at $2,899, it competes with other slim gaming laptops like the Aorus X3 Plus and Gigabyte Aero 14.

site_title: A guide to teas steeped in tradition
summary: Tea enthusiasts worldwide are experiencing a resurgence, with the US and globally seeing a renewed interest in the traditional drink. Key to understanding tea lies in knowing its origins, with all tea derived from the Camellia sinensis plant. Experts advise sampling teas in person or purchasing small quantities online to discover preferences. Types of tea include black, green, white, oolong, pu-erh, and tisane, each with unique characteristics and steeping requirements. As the industry grows, high-end and unusual teas are gaining popularity, with many businesses focusing on sustainable and locally sourced ingredients.

site_title: InstaScram: The key to your next great photo is by the #doors
summary: A social media trend of showcasing beautiful doors in Singapore has led InstaScram to highlight the unique and historic doors in the city-state. The trend, seen in hashtags like #doorsofSingapore, has led to the discovery of stunning doors in conservation estates such as Bukit Pasoh and Joo Chiat. These estates, once home to settlers, migrants, and vice, have been restored and now showcase pre-war architectural styles, including Malay, Chinese, Portuguese, and Art Deco influences. The doors, with their vibrant hues and intricate designs, are not only visually appealing but also tell stories of Singapore's past, highlighting the importance of conservation and preserving the city-state's unique heritage.

site_title: Turkey referendum: 5 ways the outcome could shape the country
summary: Turkey voted narrowly on April 16, 2017, to expand President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's powers, giving him enhanced authority and potentially leading to one-man rule. The outcome could shape the country's future in various ways, including EU integration, peace with Kurdish rebels, societal polarization, and economic stability. The referendum result could also impact Turkey's relations with the West and its strategic alliances. Erdogan's new powers could lead to a more authoritarian system, while the country's diverse society remains sharply divided.

site_title: Free musical to kick off Singapore Maritime Week
summary: A free musical, "Sea Dreams," will kick off Singapore Maritime Week, a week-long event featuring community outreach programs, exhibitions, and business forums. The musical, about a young girl's maritime career aspirations, will be held at VivoCity Amphitheatre on April 22 and 23. The week, organized by the Maritime Port Authority, will also include a maritime exhibition, games and challenges, and a Singapore Maritime Lecture. The event aims to provide insights into the dynamic maritime industry and equip participants with knowledge to navigate its challenges.

site_title: Jail, fine for man involved in Geylang fight
summary: A 54-year-old unemployed man, Seah Hock Teck, was sentenced to one week's jail and a $2,000 fine for his role in a fight in Geylang Road in 2014. Seah pleaded guilty to one count of assault after a confrontation with a 65-year-old stall assistant, Chen De Ming, over a borrowed motorized bicycle. Seah, who had been drinking, joined the fight along with another friend, Henry Lim Kim Leng, and was later injured. Seah will begin his sentence on July 17 and was initially eligible for up to two years' jail and $5,000 fine.

site_title: Almost edible deodorant? Katfood advocates the power of natural skincare
summary: Kendra Liew, a 29-year-old, launched Katfood, a natural skincare line, driven by her passion for organic ingredients. After a positive response to her products, she left her law career to pursue the niche, now Singapore's most awarded independent beauty brand. Katfood advocates for the transformative powers of organic skincare using premium natural ingredients, aiming to educate the public on the benefits of a chemical-free skincare routine.

site_title: In South Korea, world's biggest shipbuilder gets bond rescue by pension fund
summary: South Korea's National Pension Service has agreed to a bond restructuring with Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering, the world's largest shipbuilder, helping the company avoid a financial crisis. The pension service will convert 80% of loans to shares and extend maturities for the remaining loans, giving Daewoo more time to repay debts. The move comes after banks agreed to provide additional loans and swap debt for equity. Daewoo faces significant debt and cash shortages, with up to 50,000 jobs and $34 billion at risk if it fails to meet its obligations.

site_title: China home sales surged 18% in March ahead of stepped-up curbs
summary: China's home sales surged 18% in March, driven by buyers rushing into the market before tightened curbs on home-buying. The value of new homes sold reached 1 trillion yuan (S$202.54 billion), exceeding a 23% year-over-year increase in the first two months. Policymakers aim to clear a glut of unsold homes while enforcing stricter curbs in major cities to prevent a housing bubble. Despite new restrictions in 64 cities, investors continued to pour into the market, boosting fixed-asset investment 9.2% in the first quarter.

site_title: Is coffee getting too fancy?
summary: A revolutionary fast-food chain, Locol, is challenging the notion that high-quality coffee must be expensive. By offering a 355ml cup of coffee for just $1 or $1.50 with milk and sugar, Locol's coffee is obtained and roasted according to the same standards as high-end companies, yet at a significantly lower price. The chain's mission is to bring wholesome, affordable food to underserved neighborhoods, and its coffee is deemed "clean and flavorful" by critics. Locol's CEO, Tony Konecny, aims to democratize coffee by making it accessible to a broad audience, not just a select group of coffee connoisseurs.

site_title: Bistro November - Flavour of the month
summary: Chef John-Paul Fiechtner's Bistro November in Singapore offers experimental flavors and progressive thinking in its dishes, reflecting the chef's wild imagination and foraging instincts. The menu is dictated by fresh ingredients, including unusual items like frog livers and squid. While some dishes, such as "Parfait, egg yolk and longan," showcase Fiechtner's creativity, others, like the aged flounder, feel conventional. The restaurant's transient nature and focus on new ideas have garnered mixed reviews, with diners praising the chef's innovative approach but sometimes struggling to enjoy the creations.

site_title: Raffles Education wins case against India's Educomp, awarded $3.52m in damages
summary: An Indian arbitration tribunal has ruled that Educomp breached a share purchase agreement with Raffles Education Corporation Ltd, awarding the Singapore-listed company $3.52 million in damages. The tribunal found Educomp failed to complete the sale and purchase transaction as agreed. Raffles Education was awarded damages from August 19, 2015, and will also receive interest and a portion of Educomp's legal costs. The decision will see Raffles subsidiaries enforcing the terms of the award in Singapore and India, and the companies will not proceed with the original sale and purchase transaction.

site_title: Golf: Wesley Bryan edges out Luke Donald for first PGA Tour win at Heritage
summary: Rookie Wesley Bryan secured his first PGA Tour win at the Heritage, edging out Luke Donald by one stroke with a 13-under 271 total. Bryan's dominant season on the Web.com Tour last year paid off, as he became the first South Carolina-born player to win the event since 1969. He also earned a Masters invitation, fulfilling his goal of winning on the main tour before the year's first major.

site_title: Japan PM Shinzo Abe strongly urges North Korea to refrain from further provocation
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe urged North Korea to refrain from further provocative actions and comply with UN resolutions, including abandoning nuclear missile development. This comes amid escalating tensions on the Korean peninsula, following North Korea's failed ballistic missile test and US President Donald Trump's hardline stance against North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Abe plans to discuss the issue with Russian President Vladimir Putin at a summit meeting later this month, as the US, its allies, and China work together to respond to North Korea's actions.

site_title: 'I love you Mommy': US mum shares heartbreaking story of cancer-stricken son's last days
summary: A US mother, Ruth Scully, shared a heartbreaking story of her son Nolan's last days after he died from rhabdomyosarcoma, a rare soft tissue cancer. Nolan, 4, was diagnosed in 2015 and underwent treatment, but the cancer spread to his lungs. In a poignant Facebook post, Scully shared a photo of her son curled up in the toilet before he left for chemotherapy, and another photo of the empty shower rug after his death. The post has been shared over 630,000 times, with over 150,000 comments expressing support for Scully, who described her son's final moments as a miracle.

site_title: Punchlines: April 17, 2017
summary: There is no article provided.

site_title: Gold hits 5-month peak on rising geopolitical worries
summary: Gold prices surged to a five-month high on April 17, reaching $1,295.42 per ounce, amid rising geopolitical tensions over North Korea and a weakening US dollar. Investors sought safe-haven assets as the US and its allies, along with China, discussed responses to North Korea's failed ballistic missile test. The US dollar hit a five-month low against the yen, while hedge funds increased their gold holdings for the fourth straight week. This marked the metal's largest weekly gain since June last year.

site_title: Mother and daughter die in sauna in Czech Republic after door handle comes off
summary: A 65-year-old mother and her 45-year-old daughter died in a sauna in the Czech Republic after the door handle came off, trapping them inside. The women had been taking a sauna for around 90 minutes at a friend's home in a garden colony near Jicin, northeast of Prague. Emergency services declared them dead at the scene, and an investigation found that the women tried to break the window but failed. Post-mortem examinations are scheduled to take place.

site_title: Unattended bag at airport arrival hall: Police reply
summary: A suspicious unattended bag was found at Changi Airport's arrival hall on April 12. The incident prompted the Airport Police to respond and reinforce the need for staff and officers to be vigilant in today's security climate. The police acknowledged that they should have handled the situation immediately, and will work with airport agencies to improve security measures.

site_title: Otter hurt by fishing hook at Marina Bay
summary: A Singaporean otter, part of the "Bishan 13" family, was injured by a fishing hook in Marina Bay on April 16. The otter had the hook caught in its right front paw and was limping badly. The incident highlights the dangers of fishing hooks to wildlife, with experts warning that such incidents can lead to infection and even death. Authorities have urged anglers to be responsible and dispose of hooks after use, and have increased surveillance patrols in the area to prevent illegal fishing.

site_title: United Airlines says staff will no longer take seats of boarded passengers
summary: United Airlines has implemented a new policy to ensure that crew members are booked on flights at least 60 minutes prior to departure, preventing them from taking the place of civilian passengers who have already boarded overbooked flights. This change comes after the violent removal of passenger Dr. David Dao, which sparked international backlash and criticism of the airline industry. The company is reviewing the incident and plans to share its findings and proposed reforms by the end of the month, with CEO Oscar Munoz promising that such incidents will "never happen again" on a United Airlines flight.

site_title: Recep Tayyip Erdogan: Turkey’s pugnacious ‘sultan’
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan declared victory in a referendum granting him sweeping powers, but opponents claim irregularities marred the vote. Erdogan has taken part in 11 elections since his ruling party came to power in 2002, winning all of them. The new system is seen as a historic change, but critics say it's a step towards one-man rule. Erdogan's popularity has been bolstered by his public speaking skills, but the result is seen as a tight win, with major cities voting against him. The new constitution could keep Erdogan in power until 2029.

site_title: South Korean prosecutors to indict Park Geun Hye on bribery and other charges
summary: South Korean prosecutors plan to indict ousted President Park Geun Hye on April 17 on bribery and other charges related to 13 allegations. Park, who was arrested on March 31, is accused of colluding with friend Choi Soon Sil to coerce large conglomerates into donating to non-profit foundations in exchange for bribes from Samsung. Park denied all charges during five rounds of questioning at a detention centre. The indictment marks the conclusion of a probe into the influence-peddling scandal that led to her ouster.

site_title: At least 36 people hurt after grenade detonates in Colombia nightclub
summary: At least 36 people were injured in a grenade detonation at a nightclub in San Pedro, Colombia. The attack occurred late Saturday and may have targeted the owners of the establishment. Two victims were hospitalized in intensive care. Authorities are investigating possible connections to a rivalry between warring drug traffickers in the area, with no known threat against the owners.

site_title: Don't underestimate US resolve, Vice-President Mike Pence warns North Korea
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence warned North Korea on Monday that the US will not underestimate its resolve, stating that military action is still a possibility to stop the regime's nuclear and missile programs. Pence's visit comes after North Korea launched a ballistic missile, which exploded shortly after launch, and amid a weekend of fanfare in North Korea. Pence reiterated that the US wants to deal with North Korea "through peaceable means, through negotiations," but made it clear that military force would be used if necessary.

site_title: North Korea's nuclear threat: What options does President Donald Trump have?
summary: US President Donald Trump has limited options in dealing with North Korea's nuclear threat, including economic sanctions, covert action, diplomatic negotiations, and military force. Trump's strategy focuses on tougher sanctions, but China's reluctance to pressure its ally limits the effectiveness of these measures. Covert action, such as cyber attacks, is also considered, but the secrecy surrounding North Korea's government hinders US intelligence. Diplomatic negotiations have been suspended for seven years, and military force is seen as a last resort, with risks for US ally South Korea.

site_title: Changi Airport, SIA and STB jointly invest $33.75m to promote Singapore as a travel destination
summary: Singapore's Changi Airport, Singapore Airlines (SIA), and the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) have jointly invested $33.75 million to promote the country as a travel destination. The three-year partnership aims to attract more stopover and twinning tourists, targeting long-haul markets and business travelers. The joint marketing efforts will focus on refreshing the Free Singapore Tour, which has seen an 8% increase in passengers last year. The partnership is expected to drive sustainable traffic growth and further develop Changi Airport as a major tourist hub.

site_title: I was trying to defend my pet, says Malaysian man who kicked dog during pet show
summary: A 51-year-old Malaysian man, Mr Lee Kong Hoong, was disqualified from a dog obedience trial event after a video showed him kicking another trainer's dog during a pet show. Lee claimed he was defending his dog from the other dog's attacks, stating that if a dog is about to attack his own pet, he would react similarly. The incident sparked outrage on social media, with many calling him a dog abuser, but Lee maintained he has been involved in animal welfare and training dogs for over 10 years, and abused dogs cannot participate in dog sports.

site_title: Singapore's non-oil exports expand 16.5% in March, beating forecasts and rising for 5th straight month
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports expanded 16.5% in March, beating forecasts and marking the fifth consecutive month of growth. This surge was driven by strong performances in non-electronic shipments, particularly in petrochemicals, specialized machinery, and structural parts. Exports to China, the top market, rose 45.5% year-on-year, while shipments to Taiwan and Hong Kong also saw significant gains. The growth is seen as a positive sign for the economy, but private-sector economists predict the double-digit growth will slow to single-digit by mid-year.

site_title: United Airlines removes from flight engaged couple travelling to wedding
summary: An engaged couple, Michael Hohl and Amber Maxwell, were removed from a United Airlines flight to Costa Rica on April 15 after repeatedly attempting to sit in upgraded seating they didn't purchase. United claimed the couple refused to return to their assigned seats despite being asked by crew. However, the couple disputed this, stating they were denied the upgrade and told to move back to their original seats. The airline offered them a discounted hotel rate and rebooked them on a Sunday morning flight.

site_title: Cleveland police seek man who broadcast killing of elderly man live on Facebook
summary: Cleveland police are searching for Steve Stephens, a man who allegedly killed an elderly man and streamed the murder live on Facebook. The incident occurred on April 16, with Stephens claiming to have murdered 13 people, including the victim, who was identified as 78-year-old "Mr. Goodwin". The video, which has been taken down, shows Stephens shooting the victim after asking him for a favor. Police have confirmed only one homicide and urge residents to be on alert for Stephens, who is considered armed and dangerous.

site_title: Make space for unobstructed views of mural
summary: The Singapore Hokkien Huay Kuan has commissioned a mural display at the Thian Hock Keng temple depicting early immigrant lives, sparking public interest. The clan association's efforts promote art and cultural heritage, but weekday viewings are obstructed by parked motor vehicles. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is advised to consider relocating or barricading the obstructing car spaces to allow unobstructed viewing of the mural.

site_title: Witnesses describe horror of Syria bus bombing that killed nearly 70 children
summary: A suicide car bombing in Syria's Aleppo province killed nearly 70 children, including at least 68, when a bus carrying evacuees from besieged government-held towns was targeted. The blast, which occurred on Saturday, also killed at least 109 evacuees, aid workers, and rebels. The attack, which was carried out without a clear claim of responsibility, was condemned by the UN aid chief and Pope Francis, who urged an end to the war in Syria.

site_title: Asian stocks, US dollar under pressure after soft US data, worries over North Korea
summary: Asian stocks fell on Monday, with the US dollar and US bond yields also declining, amid soft US economic data and concerns over North Korea and the French presidential election. The US Treasury department did not name China as a currency manipulator, avoiding a confrontation between the US and China. US retail sales dropped in March, while annual core inflation slowed, driving down the 10-year US Treasuries yield to its lowest level since mid-November. The dollar slipped to a five-month low, and gold gained 0.7% to a five-month high, amid continued concerns over North Korea.

site_title: From The Straits Times archives: The unquiet South China Sea
summary: The South China Sea has been a point of contention among nations, with disputes over territorial claims and resource extraction. The Straits Times published a series of articles on the issue from March 2016 to July 2017, highlighting concerns over China's increasing assertiveness in the region. The articles featured unique Singaporean perspectives on the topic, sparking discussion and inquiry from readers. The South China Sea disputes have significant implications for regional stability and global security, with China's actions drawing criticism from the international community.

site_title: Man arrested in connection with fire set at St Hilda's Church
summary: A 60-year-old man has been arrested in connection with a fire set at St Hilda's Church in Singapore. The fire, which involved some books on the second floor, was extinguished quickly by the Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) without reported injuries. The man will be charged on Tuesday for mischief by fire, a serious offence that carries a life imprisonment or up to 10 years in prison, and a fine. Investigations are ongoing.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, April 17 edition
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan declared victory in a referendum to increase his powers, with 98% of ballots counted showing 51.3% approval. Opposition parties contested the result, alleging foul play. Meanwhile, US Vice President Mike Pence described North Korea's failed missile test as a provocation, and nearly 70 children were killed in a Syria bus bombing. Manchester United secured a 2-0 win over Chelsea, narrowing the Premier League title gap, and Sebastian Vettel won the Bahrain Grand Prix, moving clear in the Formula One world championship.

site_title: Football: Manchester United offer hope to Spurs with 2-0 win over Chelsea
summary: Manchester United secured a 2-0 win over Chelsea, moving into contention for the Premier League title. The victory, led by a tactical masterclass by manager Jose Mourinho, leaves second-placed Tottenham Hotspur four points behind. The win comes after Tottenham lost to Chelsea earlier in the season, and United's performance has reinvigorated their title hopes. Manchester United are now in a strong position to challenge for the title, with Tottenham still in second place.

site_title: British MPs call for wife of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to lose citizenship
summary: British MPs are calling for Asma Al-Assad, wife of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, to lose her British citizenship due to her support for his regime during the ongoing war. The Liberal Democrats' Tom Brake and Conservative MP Nadhim Zahawi argue that her international profile allows her to defend "barbaric acts" and that she should be stripped of her citizenship if she continues to do so. The government has not commented on taking action, but the Home Secretary can deprive individuals of citizenship where it is conducive to the public good.

site_title: Formula One: Sebastian Vettel triumphs in Bahrain as Lewis Hamilton pays penalty
summary: Sebastian Vettel won the Bahrain Formula One Grand Prix, moving clear at the top of the world championship with 68 points. He defeated Lewis Hamilton, who finished second after collecting a five-second penalty for a pit-lane incident. Vettel's Ferrari team employed an aggressive strategy, which paid off as he controlled the race. Hamilton now trails Vettel by seven points, with Valtteri Bottas finishing third. The victory marked Vettel's 44th win and third in Bahrain.

site_title: Latest 'Furious' film opens strongly, especially outside of the US
summary: The Fate of the Furious, the latest installment in the Fast and Furious series, opened strongly worldwide, grossing an estimated $532.5 million globally in its debut weekend. The film took in $100.2 million in the US and $432.3 million in China, breaking the record for the highest global debut held by Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Despite a slightly weaker opening in the US, the film's global performance was robust, with nearly two-thirds of North American revenues.

site_title: Football: Roberto Firmino on target as Liverpool strengthen their push for a top-four place
summary: Liverpool reclaimed third spot in the Premier League with a 1-0 victory over West Bromwich Albion, as Roberto Firmino scored his 11th league goal of the season with a header in the first half. The match was largely uneventful, with Liverpool's James Milner missing a clear chance and West Brom's Alberto Moreno squandering an open goal late on. The win lifts Liverpool to 66 points from 33 games, two points ahead of Manchester City in fourth place.

site_title: Lady Gaga debuts song The Cure at Coachella
summary: Lady Gaga debuted her new R&B-tinged love song "The Cure" at Coachella, showcasing a sensual performance with acrobatic choreography and confetti, fireballs, and fireworks. The pop star headlined the festival, marking her first new music release since her album "Joanne" in October. Gaga emphasized her music over fashion, giving a glowing vocal performance of her hit song "The Edge Of Glory." The festival also featured surprise performances by Future, Drake, Lauryn Hill, and Bon Iver, following Beyonce's cancellation due to pregnancy.

site_title: French voters disappointed, undecided days before vote
summary: French voters are disappointed and undecided just a week before the presidential election, with nearly 40% of voters remaining undecided. The election is marred by scandals, including fake jobs claims against Marine Le Pen and Francois Fillon, and voters are struggling to make up their minds. Centrist Emmanuel Macron and far-right Marine Le Pen are neck-and-neck in polls, with the top two candidates set to advance to a second-round run-off on May 7. Voters are concerned about the candidates' trustworthiness, with many citing scandals and a lack of clear policy positions.

site_title: British PM Theresa May says country uniting around Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May stated that the country is uniting behind Brexit, 10 months after the divisive referendum. In her Easter message, she emphasized the shared values and interests of the nation, calling Britain "one great union of people and nations." A recent poll by Orb International found that support for Brexit has reached a five-month high, with 55% backing the country's exit from the EU. May's message also highlighted the importance of Christianity in British society and the need to protect the rights of religious minorities.

site_title: 'Weird', 'voyeuristic', 'decadent': Banksy hotel in the West Bank proves popular
summary: The Walled Off Hotel in the West Bank, opened by street artist Banksy, has proven popular since its opening over a month ago, with 700 visitors per day, including 200 Palestinians. The hotel features a gallery, museum, bookstore, and spray paint shop, offering rooms from $30 to $965 per night. While some locals are unhappy with the hotel, many visitors, including tourists from Berlin, have praised it for raising awareness about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and its "worst view in the world." The hotel's owner, Wissam Salsaa, aims to return all profits to the local community, and Banksy's work is meant to be a form of creative activism.

site_title: North Korea's behaviour cannot continue: US national security adviser
summary: US National Security Adviser General H.R. McMaster stated that there is an international consensus, including China, that North Korea's "threatening behavior" cannot continue. China, a key ally of North Korea, is now concerned about the reclusive communist state's actions. McMaster emphasized that the US, under President Donald Trump, will take all necessary actions to resolve the situation peacefully, short of a military option. China's involvement in addressing the North Korean issue was acknowledged by Trump, who defended his reversal on calling China a currency manipulator.

site_title: Badminton: Tai Tzu-ying wins fifth title in a row
summary: Tai Tzu-ying of Chinese Taipei won her fifth consecutive Superseries title, defeating Carolina Marin 21-15, 21-15 in the women's singles final of the Singapore Open. The victory solidifies Tai's position as the world No.1. India's B. Sai Praneeth claimed his first Superseries title by beating K. Srikanth in the men's singles final. China's Lu Kai and Huang Yaqiong also secured their third Superseries title in the mixed doubles.

site_title: Vietnamese police 'held hostage' by residents in land dispute
summary: At least a dozen Vietnamese police officers have been held hostage by residents in a land dispute near Hanoi, according to activists and state media. The incident began on Saturday when authorities clashed with villagers who claimed their land was seized by a military-owned telecoms firm. The residents have refused to release the hostages unless the central government intervenes, with the situation remaining tense. This is a rare show of defiance against communist authorities, highlighting ongoing land disputes in Vietnam where powerful individuals and companies often make claims on property.

site_title: Rugby: Against all odds, Canada claim first Sevens Series title with 26-19 win over USA in S'pore
summary: Canada claimed their first Sevens Series title by defeating the USA 26-19 in the HSBC Singapore Rugby Sevens Series final. This marks Canada's first championship since 2014. The victory follows a tough loss to Fiji in the previous leg. Canada captain John Moonlight credited the team's resilience and determination for their win, saying they "showed the world we can beat anyone." South Africa remains the series leader, followed by Fiji and England, as the series moves to Paris and London.

site_title: Football: New FAS council must provide report on donations, says Sport Singapore
summary: The Football Association of Singapore (FAS) is under scrutiny after Hougang United chairman Bill Ng claimed a $850,000 donation to the FAS, but the association clarified that only $715,000 could be linked to Ng. Sport Singapore has urged the new FAS council to provide a complete report on the management of the donations. An ongoing investigation into the management of Woodlands Wellington's jackpot revenue and a proposed merger between Hougang and Woodlands have also raised questions about the FAS's transparency and accountability.

site_title: Football: Champions League tie not yet dead and buried, says Barca manager Luis Enrique
summary: Barcelona coach Luis Enrique believes his team can still overcome a 3-0 deficit in their Champions League tie against Juventus, despite the Italian team's strong defensive record. Enrique, who will step down at the end of the season, praises his team as "a group of winners and champions capable of anything" and predicts they will be in the tie at some point during the match. Barcelona has a history of remarkable comebacks, having overcome a 4-0 first leg deficit against Paris Saint-Germain last season.

site_title: Top US official visits Afghanistan after huge bomb attack
summary: US National Security Advisor General H.R. McMaster visited Kabul, Afghanistan, following the US military's largest non-nuclear bomb drop in the country, killing nearly 100 Islamic State group militants. The attack, which occurred in eastern Afghanistan, sparked global shock and criticism. McMaster discussed security and counter-terrorism efforts, as well as reforms to tackle corruption, with Afghan President Ashraf Ghani. The visit came days after the US military's massive bomb drop and amid rising tensions with North Korea.

site_title: Turkish President Erdogan claims vast new powers after narrow referendum victory
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan declared victory in a referendum, granting him sweeping powers in a constitutional overhaul. The "yes" vote had 51.3% of the total, while opponents had 48.7%, with the main opposition party demanding a recount of around 2.5 million votes. The changes will give the president full control of the government, end the parliamentary system, and allow for a state of emergency to last six months. Erdogan's victory tightens his grip on the country, which is a key player in the Middle East and a major partner of the US and Russia.

site_title: Fugitive Mexican ex-governor held in Guatemala
summary: Former Mexican governor Javier Duarte, suspected of embezzling hundreds of millions of dollars, has been arrested in Guatemala after six months on the run. Duarte, 43, was detained at a luxury hotel in Panajachel, Guatemala, and will be placed at the disposal of a counternarcotics court. His extradition to Mexico is pending, following a request from Mexican authorities. Duarte had fled Mexico in 2016 and was previously expelled from his own party, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, for his alleged involvement in organized crime and embezzlement.
