site_title: Star Awards: Zoe Tay wins Best Actress after 21 years; Chen Han Wei wins fifth Best Actor award
summary: Veteran actress Zoe Tay won her second Best Actress award at the Star Awards, 21 years after her first win, for her role in "You Can Be An Angel 2." Chen Hanwei took home his fifth Best Actor award for his role in "The Gentleman." Other winners included Aileen Tan for Best Supporting Actress and Romeo Tan for Best Supporting Actor. The drama series "Hero" won Best Drama, while actress Joanne Peh, host Quan Yi Fong, and actor Elvin Ng received the All-Time Favourite Artiste Award for their 10th consecutive Top 10 Most Popular Artiste nominations.

site_title: Philippines, US to hold military drills
summary: The Philippine military will hold annual military exercises with US troops in May, marking the first time under President Rodrigo Duterte, who has softened his stance on working with the US military after previously calling for the withdrawal of American troops. The 10-day Balikatan exercises will focus on counter-terrorism and disaster response, with no live-fire exercises, and will be scenario-based, simulating a big storm or terrorist attack. The drills come as the Philippines battles Islamic militants in its southern strongholds and amid improved relations with China.

site_title: NBA: Giannis Antetokounmpo runs the show as Bucks beat Raptors 97-83 in play-offs opener
summary: The Milwaukee Bucks defeated the Toronto Raptors 97-83 in the NBA playoffs opener, led by Giannis Antetokounmpo's 28 points and 8 rebounds. The Raptors fell to 0-9 in first-round series openers and 1-10 overall. Malcolm Brogdon added 16 points, Greg Monroe had 14 points and 15 rebounds, and Khris Middleton contributed 10 points and 9 assists. The Bucks took the first game of their best-of-seven series.

site_title: US Vice President Mike Pence calls North Korea missile launch 'a provocation'
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence on April 16 called North Korea's failed missile test a "provocation" that highlights the risks in the region and the US. Pence, on a 10-day Asia tour, expressed the US resolve and commitment to its alliance with South Korea, with 28,500 troops stationed there. The US has a naval strike group, led by the USS Carl Vinson aircraft carrier, in the region, and President Trump has ordered it to the area. Pence also met with a White House foreign policy adviser who hinted at the US having intelligence to potentially take covert action.

site_title: Pope Francis condemns Syria bus convoy attack, denounces “oppressive regimes” but urges restraint
summary: Pope Francis condemned the attack on a Syrian bus convoy that killed at least 112 people, calling it an "ignoble" attack. In his Easter message, he denounced "oppressive regimes" but urged world leaders to prevent the spread of conflicts, while also calling for peace in several war-torn countries. The Pope also expressed concern over rising tensions in North Korea, where the US has deployed a military aircraft carrier group.

site_title: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan says referendum is vote for Turkey's future
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan cast his vote in a referendum that would grant him sweeping new powers, potentially leading to the most radical change in Turkey's political system in its modern history. The "Yes" vote, which would replace Turkey's parliamentary democracy with an all-powerful presidency, has a narrow lead in opinion polls. The outcome will shape Turkey's strained relations with the European Union and may lead to a one-man rule, prompting criticism from Western allies and rights groups.

site_title: Golf: Two eagles help Jason Dufner soar to Heritage third-round lead
summary: Jason Dufner took a one-stroke lead at the RBC Heritage tournament with a round of six-under 65, thanks to two eagles and three consecutive birdies. Dufner's lead over Canadian Graham DeLaet, who bogeyed the final hole, now stands at one stroke. The American golfer, a 2013 PGA Championship winner, is looking forward to the challenge of playing with DeLaet on Sunday.

site_title: Golf: Former British Open sensation in third-round lead at Trophee Hassan II
summary: Ireland's Paul Dunne is in the lead at the Trophee Hassan II golf tournament after a strong third-round performance, two shots ahead of Italy's Renato Paratore. Dunne, a former British Open contender, is seeking his first career title and showed glimpses of his past form with a 69. The final round will determine the champion, with Dunne's lead potentially secure if he maintains his current pace.

site_title: Football: Gonzalo Higuain brace takes Juventus closer to sixth Scudetto in a row as Roma falter
summary: Juventus secured a 2-0 win over Pescara, moving eight points clear at the top of Serie A with 80 points. Gonzalo Higuain scored two goals, including one just before halftime, to help Juventus close in on a sixth consecutive Scudetto. Roma faltered with a 1-1 draw against Atalanta, while Napoli edged to within two points of Roma with a 3-0 win over Udinese.

site_title: Peace along the Chinese border despite North Korean threats
summary: North Korean soldiers appear relaxed along the Yalu River border with China, despite North Korea's bellicose language and recent missile test. Chinese tourists can take river cruises and see North Korean soldiers from a distance, while North Korea enforces UN sanctions to curb its nuclear and missile programmes. The sanctions have had limited effect, and tensions persist with the US sending a naval strike group to the region. North Korea has reiterated its readiness for war with the US, but the soldiers' relaxed demeanor suggests a lack of urgency.

site_title: Tennis: Francesca Schiavone eyes spot in French Open draw after Bogota title
summary: Italy's Francesca Schiavone won her 8th career title at the Bogota Open, defeating Lara Arruabarrena 6-4, 7-5. The 36-year-old Schiavone, now ranked 168, is close to a main draw place at the French Open in her final year on tour. Her victory marked her 600th career win, taking her ranking back within striking distance of the top 100 and solidifying her chances for the French Open draw.

site_title: North Korea missile launch 'no surprise, no need to expend resources': US foreign policy adviser
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence stated that North Korea's latest missile launch, described as a medium-range missile that failed four to five seconds into the launch, was not a surprise and didn't require US resources to counter. Pence, accompanying Pence on his Asia trip, emphasized the US was anticipating the launch and didn't need to expend resources against it.

site_title: NBA: Utah Jazz eke out 97-95 play-off win over LA Clippers despite losing centre Rudy Gobert
summary: The Utah Jazz won Game 1 of their Western Conference playoff series against the Los Angeles Clippers 97-95. Despite losing center Rudy Gobert in the first minute with a sprained left knee, Joe Johnson scored a team-high 21 points, including a game-winning runner at the buzzer. Gordon Hayward added 19 points and 10 rebounds, while George Hill and Derrick Favors contributed 16 and 15 points, respectively. The Jazz will proceed to Game 2, but Gobert's availability for the remainder of the series is uncertain.

site_title: Tennis: Steve Johnson to play Thomaz Bellucci in ATP Houston final
summary: Steve Johnson advanced to the ATP Houston final after defeating top-seeded Jack Sock 4-6, 6-4, 6-3. Johnson, the fourth seed, came back from a break down in the third set to claim his second career win. Thomaz Bellucci, the eighth-seeded Brazilian, will face Johnson in the title match. Bellucci defeated Ernesto Escobedo 5-7, 6-4, 6-2, winning his fourth straight three-set match and advancing to his first final of 2017.

site_title: Easter address by Pope Francis marked by heightened security
summary: Pope Francis delivered his Easter mass in Rome on April 16, 2017, with heightened security measures in place due to recent attacks on Coptic churches in Egypt. The mass, attended by thousands, followed a Good Friday prayer condemning the suffering of migrants and persecuted Christians worldwide. The area around St Peter's Basilica was blocked, and security checks were conducted before mass, with hundreds of police and security forces present. Pope Francis also condemned the Aleppo bus convoy attack and urged restraint, marking the start of a week of Easter events.

site_title: School sports: St Andrew's dethrone ACS(I) to win Schools Sevens Under-14 title
summary: St Andrew's Secondary School defeated Anglo-Chinese School (Independent) 12-10 in the Schools Sevens Under-14 final at the National Stadium on April 16. St Andrew's took an early lead with tries by Jabez Lim and Lucky Anthony Castillo, and held off ACS(I)'s comeback attempts, with Lucius Yau's successful conversion securing the win. The Saints won the final, while ACS(I) won the first leg of the Schools 7s series.

site_title: Death toll from Syria bus convoy attack kills at least 126: Monitoring group
summary: A bomb attack on a crowded bus convoy outside Aleppo, Syria, has killed at least 126 people, with 68 of them being children. The convoy, carrying Shi'ite residents and pro-government fighters, was targeted while waiting to cross from rebel to government territory. The attack, carried out by a suspected suicide car bomber, is the deadliest such incident in Syria in almost a year. The death toll is expected to rise, with rescue workers already collecting at least 100 bodies from the scene.

site_title: Football: Monaco come from behind to beat Dijon, Nice seal Champions League berth
summary: Monaco overcame a 1-0 deficit to beat Dijon 2-1 at home, thanks to Radamel Falcao's late winner and a goal from Nabil Dirar. The match was Monaco's 77th point, three ahead of Paris Saint-Germain and four ahead of Nice, which sealed a top-three finish with a 3-1 win over Nancy. Monaco's win came after a challenging week, following a Champions League quarter-final win against Borussia Dortmund.

site_title: Video of trainer kicking dog at obedience test angers Malaysians
summary: A video circulating on social media in Malaysia shows a dog trainer kicking another participant's dog during an obedience test. The incident occurred when two dogs got into a fight, prompting the trainer to kick the other dog. The video has been viewed over 30,000 times and received 253 comments. This incident follows a similar case of a Singaporean man kicking a dog two weeks prior, which also sparked widespread outrage and led to the man's company losing several international outdoor gear brands as a distributor.

site_title: Mobile phone number with 10 eights auctioned for $24 million in China
summary: A mobile phone number consisting of 10 consecutive eights, considered auspicious in Mandarin, was auctioned for a record-breaking 120 million yuan ($24 million) in China. The number, 18888888888, is believed to symbolize prosperity and was sold through a Chinese company based in Shantou. The buyer, who remains anonymous, plans to donate the funds to charity. This sale sets a new record for the most expensive phone number ever auctioned in China, where auspicious numbers can fetch thousands or tens of thousands of dollars.

site_title: 'Missing' Malaysian activist Peter Chong arrives home after Thai trip
summary: Former Petaling Jaya councillor Peter Chong, who was reported missing after posting a Facebook update about a strange encounter, has returned home after crossing into Thailand on April 7. Police found evidence of his crossing into Thailand at the Bukit Kayu Hitam immigration checkpoint. Chong was spotted at KLIA International Airport wearing shorts and a blue T-shirt, and will be questioned by authorities upon his return. He had been missing for over a week before his safe return.

site_title: Golf: Cristie Kerr wins the Lotte Championship
summary: American golfer Cristie Kerr won the Lotte Championship with a 72-hole total score of 20-under par 268. Kerr, 39, overcame a three-shot deficit to fire a bogey-free 66 in the final round, her first LPGA Tour win since 2015. Kerr's victory came after Jang Su Yeong's back-nine stumble, with Kerr vaulting into the lead with three straight birdies on the back nine. Kerr tied for second were Lydia Ko, Chun In Gee, and Alena Sharp, with Ko finishing a stroke back in fifth.

site_title: Tears and cheers greet China's new Xiongan economic zone
summary: China has announced the transformation of a rural spot outside Beijing into a modern metropolis, the Xiongan New Area, which spans 2,000 square kilometers. The move is expected to boost the regional economy, but has sparked concerns for local businesses, including a family-run clothing factory that may be forced to close. Housing prices have doubled in a single day, attracting speculators, and authorities have imposed strict bans on home sales. Analysts predict the project's economic impact will be limited, but for some, it promises to be "life-changing".

site_title: Donald Trump's supporters, opponents clash in California park
summary: A melee broke out in a Berkeley, California park where supporters and opponents of President Donald Trump were holding competing rallies, resulting in at least 20 arrests and numerous injuries. The clashes, which included fist fights, bottle-throwing, and explosions, occurred as police struggled to keep the two camps apart. Authorities reported that at least 11 people were injured, with several others observed with bloodied faces. The incident was sparked by a counter-rally against Trump's "Patriots Day" free-speech rally and picnic, which drew hundreds of protesters.

site_title: Indian metro probes porn screened at busy station
summary: Hardcore pornography flashed onto a giant screen at Delhi's Connaught Place metro station, prompting an investigation by the Delhi Metro Rail Corporation. The incident was caught on camera and shared widely online, with authorities identifying three suspects. The screen, operated by a private company, had an unsecure WiFi network, allowing others to access it. The contractor will be required to have password protection from now on, in a country where public displays of affection are seen as taboo. The incident has sparked concern over the need for better security measures in public spaces.

site_title: Papua New Guinea to investigate 'drunk rampage' at Australia refugee camp
summary: Papua New Guinea police launched an investigation into a "drunk rampage" at an Australian refugee camp on Manus Island, where soldiers allegedly fired shots into the air and assaulted detainees after a football game altercation. The incident occurred in response to an alleged assault on a military colleague, and one senior immigration officer and an asylum-seeker were treated at a medical centre. The violence marks the latest in a series of incidents at the camp, prompting renewed calls for detainees to be removed, with the camp set to close by October due to a PNG Supreme Court ruling.

site_title: Senior Chinese banking regulator under investigation: Caixin
summary: A senior official at China's Banking Regulatory Commission, Yang Jiacai, is under investigation for suspected links to a loan scandal in Hubei province. Yang, assistant chairman of CBRC, was relieved of his duties and placed under investigation along with his wife and son. The investigation follows a government fight against graft, with President Xi Jinping pledging to "wage war" on corruption. This is the latest in a series of official probes, including into the chief risk officer of China's Bank of Communications, who was expelled from the party in February.

site_title: Fallen tree outside Singapore Discovery Centre damages walkway, blocks Upper Jurong Road
summary: A 17m tall Khaya tree fell at Upper Jurong Road in Singapore on April 15, 2017, damaging a walkway near the Singapore Discovery Centre. The tree, estimated to be over 25 years old, uprooted and toppled, blocking the road and a bus bay. No one was injured, but traffic was blocked for several hours before the tree was removed. The incident occurred despite regular pruning and monitoring of the tree's health by the Singapore Discovery Centre.

site_title: Time to ease quota for hiring foreign workers
summary: The Singapore Government is considering easing hiring quotas for foreign workers, despite a high demand for this group of workers. This decision comes as companies face challenges in filling labor gaps for jobs that require manual labor, which Singaporeans are reluctant to undertake. The Government has previously encouraged companies to adopt technology to address manpower issues, but some jobs remain dependent on foreign workers. Easing quotas selectively in areas with no alternative to manpower could help alleviate labor shortages.

site_title: Police raid 9 public entertainment outlets, arrest 17 suspects
summary: Police raided 9 public entertainment outlets in Singapore, arresting 17 suspects in an 8-hour operation. The 14 female suspects faced employment-related offenses, including appearing nude in public, while two male suspects were suspected of being part of an unlawful society. The raids resulted in charges for breaches of public entertainment licensing conditions and fire safety regulations. Many of the suspects held student passes, tourist visas, or were permanent residents. An investigation is ongoing, and one man was arrested for drink driving during a separate enforcement operation.

site_title: Hope fades for Sri Lanka missing, garbage toll hits 23
summary: Rescue teams in Sri Lanka's capital, Colombo, have abandoned hope of finding anyone alive under a collapsed garbage mountain, with the death toll rising to 23 and six more reported missing. The disaster, triggered by heavy rain and a fire, destroyed 145 homes, mostly shacks, and left over 600 people without shelter. Authorities have stepped up security and arrested 18 suspects accused of looting victim belongings, with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe offering help in the recovery effort. The garbage dump, which was 300 feet high, was a serious health hazard, with 23 million tonnes of rotting waste.

site_title: Turkey referendum: What are the changes under Turkey's new constitution plan
summary: Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's proposed new constitution would grant him expanded powers, including direct appointment of top officials and the ability to assign vice presidents. The proposed 18-article constitution would also overhaul the judiciary, allowing the president and parliament to choose key judicial council members. A longer state of emergency could be imposed, and the number of parliament members would increase to 600. The changes would allow Erdogan to potentially stay in power until 2029, despite opponents claiming it's a move towards one-man rule.

site_title: Badminton: Singapore Open a Level 4 event for now, but an upgrade in future not ruled out
summary: The Singapore Open badminton tournament will be classified as a Level 4 event for the next four editions, with a total prize money of US$350,000. The Singapore Badminton Association (SBA) is not ruling out an upgrade to a Level 3 event if it secures title sponsors early. The tournament will need to start groundwork one to two years before the next tender cycle, and the SBA is in talks with title sponsor OUE about a possible extension, which would ensure the event's financial stability.

site_title: 'Grandpa' lures mum and daughter in Malaysia to send him their nude photos
summary: A 13-year-old girl in Malaysia, Ann, was manipulated by a man she believed was her "grandfather" into sending him nude photos. He then coerced her mother, May, into sending nude photos of herself and even threatening to expose their images to others. May paid the man RM2,590 to stop the threats, but the situation escalated with strangers sending lewd messages and blackmailing her. May and Ann sought help from local officials, filing a police report as a suspected case of child sexual grooming. The incident has raised concerns over child protection and safety.

site_title: Swimming: US Olympic champion Dana Vollmer competes in 50m freestyle race while 6 months pregnant
summary: US Olympic swim champion Dana Vollmer competed in a 50m freestyle race while six months pregnant, participating in the USA Swimming Pro Series on April 14. Vollmer, 29, posted on Instagram about her decision to swim while pregnant, stating she didn't want to sit on the couch and do nothing. She finished 55th overall with a time of 2:57.59 seconds, below her personal best. Vollmer, a five-time Olympic gold medallist, is due to give birth to her second child in July.

site_title: North Korean missile 'blows up' on test launch as US Vice-President Mike Pence arrives in South
summary: A North Korean missile "blew up almost immediately" during a test launch on Sunday, hours before US Vice President Mike Pence arrived in South Korea for talks on the North's defiant arms program. The failed launch occurred despite warnings from China, a key ally, and comes a day after North Korea held a military parade showcasing new long-range ballistic missiles. Pence's visit aims to demonstrate US commitment to its ally in the face of rising tension, with the US Pacific Command stating the type of missile being analyzed.

site_title: Feel the pain of the poor and immigrants, pope says at Easter Vigil
summary: Pope Francis urged Roman Catholics on Easter Sunday to feel the pain of the poor, immigrants, and vulnerable people. During the Easter Vigil Mass, he recounted the grief of Jesus' mother Mary and Mary Magdalene, comparing their faces to those of many women today who suffer from poverty, exploitation, and loneliness. He also baptized 11 adult converts, emphasizing his vision of service to the neediest. The Pope's message comes as security remains tight following recent attacks in London and Stockholm.

site_title: Woodlands to transform into 'star destination of the North' with new housing, recreational and business facilities
summary: Singapore's Woodlands estate is set to undergo a major transformation, dubbed the "Star Destination of the North", with the goal of becoming a vibrant hub of residential, recreational, and business facilities. The Remaking Our Heartland (ROH) programme, led by Minister Lawrence Wong, aims to introduce 10,000 new dwelling units, a business park, and various attractions, including a new healthcare complex, community hub, and upgraded parks. The project is expected to be completed within 5-10 years, with a focus on enhancing the area's connectivity and environmental impact.

site_title: About 50 job scam victims from China stranded at Johor airport
summary: About 50 Chinese farmers are stranded at Senai International Airport in Johor after being promised fake jobs at a construction site. The farmers, who spent between RM12,000 to RM38,000 each to secure the jobs, were told they would work for four to five years and earn a monthly salary of 13,000 yuan. However, the jobs never existed, and the farmers were left with limited money and no work visas. The group has been surviving on bread and biscuits at the airport, with some falling ill due to poor living conditions.

site_title: Child crushed to death in accident at Atlanta revolving restaurant
summary: A 5-year-old boy, Charles Holt, died after becoming stuck between a rotating floor and a stationary wall at the Sun Dial restaurant in Atlanta. The incident occurred on Friday when the child wandered into the tight space, which was approximately 13cm in width. Automatic systems and employees dislodged him, but he suffered fatal crushing injuries to his head and brain, leading to his accidental death. The incident is under investigation, with the Fulton County Medical Examiner's Office ruling the death as accidental.

site_title: Britain 'concerned' by North Korea missile test
summary: Britain expressed concern over North Korea's reported missile test on April 16, 2017, which the US Defence Department described as a failed launch. The test came a day after Pyongyang showcased its ballistic arsenal at a military parade. British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson urged North Korea to abide by UN resolutions and stop pursuing nuclear weapons. Tensions over North Korea's nuclear ambitions remain high, with the US deploying an aircraft carrier battle group to the region, and North Korea threatening to use nuclear force.

site_title: Turkey votes in historic referendum on expanding President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's powers
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's referendum on expanding his powers to an all-powerful presidency has begun, with 55 million eligible voters casting ballots at 167,140 polling stations. The outcome could see Erdogan in office until 2029, shaping Turkey's relations with the European Union. The referendum has divided the nation, with supporters arguing it's needed for Turkey's security and opponents claiming it's a step towards authoritarianism. Erdogan's ruling AK Party has dominated media coverage, while the opposition has accused him of seeking a "one-man regime."

site_title: Football: Spurs hot on Chelsea's heels, City up to third
summary: Tottenham moved within four points of Premier League leaders Chelsea after a 4-0 win over Bournemouth, with Mousa Dembele, Son Heung-Min, Harry Kane, and Vincent Janssen scoring. Manchester City climbed to third with a 3-0 win at Southampton, while Everton rose to fifth with a 3-1 win over Burnley. Meanwhile, Leicester squandered a two-goal lead in a 2-2 draw at Crystal Palace, and Hull lost 3-1 at Stoke, leaving them on the brink of relegation.

site_title: Mandai Columbarium needs more linkways
summary: The Mandai Columbarium, a vast complex with multiple blocks, requires improved infrastructure to link the various sections. The need for covered walkways, sheltered ramps, and additional lifts is emphasized, particularly for those with physical mobility issues. The complex, situated on undulating ground, could benefit from elevated walkways and lifts to enhance accessibility. Improving the linkages between blocks, such as connecting Block B to Block D and Block C to Block I, is also recommended to facilitate easier navigation within the complex.

site_title: New train with LCD displays begins running on North-South Line
summary: Singapore's North-South Line began running a new train with LCD display boards, featuring upcoming stops, exit locations, attractions, and safety messages. The 57 new trains will be fitted with a new signalling system, clearer wheelchair markings, and energy-saving LED lights. All-day trials for the new system started on April 16, with tests lasting two months. The system allows trains to run 100 seconds apart, replacing the existing 120-second fixed-block signalling system, and is expected to improve passenger experience and efficiency.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, April 16 edition
summary: Thousands of protesters marched in US cities to pressure President Donald Trump to release his tax returns. Italian Emma Morano, believed to be the last survivor of the 19th century, died at 117. A 5-year-old boy was fatally injured in an accident at an Atlanta revolving restaurant. Tottenham moved within four points of Premier League leaders Chelsea after a 4-0 win, while Valtteri Bottas secured his first Formula One pole position at the Bahrain Grand Prix, ending Lewis Hamilton's bid for a seventh consecutive pole.

site_title: US Vice President Mike Pence lands in South Korea after North defies Donald Trump with missile
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence landed in South Korea on April 16, 2017, amid heightened tensions after North Korea fired an unidentified ballistic missile. Pence's visit coincided with warnings from the Trump administration to avoid further provocations. He will discuss security guarantees and protectionist rhetoric with South Korean officials, while also addressing concerns over the deployment of the Thaad missile defense system. Pence aims to reassure allies that the US is a reliable partner, particularly after President Trump's comments on trade deficits and his call for a review of bilateral trade agreements.

site_title: Football: Barca keep pressure on Madrid with thrilling 3-2 Real Sociedad win
summary: Barcelona secured a 3-2 win over Real Sociedad, thanks to Lionel Messi's double strike and assist. The victory keeps pressure on La Liga leaders Real Madrid, who lost to Sporting Gijon earlier in the day. Barcelona now trails Madrid by three points, with the teams set to face off in the Clasico match next Sunday. Messi's performance saw him score twice and set up a third goal for Paco Alcacer, securing a thrilling win for the Catalans.

site_title: Kompany scores as Manchester City climb to third with 3-0 Southampton victory
summary: Manchester City defeated Southampton 3-0 at St Mary's, moving to third in the Premier League. Vincent Kompany scored his first goal since August 2015 in the 55th minute, with Leroy Sane and Sergio Aguero adding further goals in the 77th and 80th minutes, respectively. The win was City's second league victory in six matches and helped them move one point above Liverpool. The result was a cathartic moment for Kompany, who made only his fourth league start of the season due to injuries.

site_title: Football: Relief for Man City goalscorer Kompany after injury nightmare
summary: Vincent Kompany scored his first Premier League goal in 20 months, sparking relief and frustration after two injury-ravaged seasons. The 31-year-old's 55th-minute header in Manchester City's 3-0 win at Southampton was a rare moment of success for the defender, who has started just 21 of City's last 102 games. Manager Pep Guardiola praised Kompany's "calming, imperious and faultless defensive display," and expressed hope that he can stay fit to play every week, finally alleviating City's struggles in building a consistent central defensive partnership.

site_title: Mexican navy guns down top bodyguard to eldest son of 'El Chapo' drug lord
summary: The Mexican navy killed Francisco Zazueta, top bodyguard to Ivan Archivaldo Guzman, eldest son of jailed 'El Chapo' drug lord Joaquin Guzman, in a shootout in the town of Badiraguato, Sinaloa. Zazueta was suspected of helping launch an ambush of soldiers last year, resulting in the deaths of five soldiers. He had escaped from a Sinaloa jail in February but was recaptured before the shootout. Several assault rifles and a rocket launcher were recovered from the scene, marking a significant blow to the Sinaloa Cartel's operations.

site_title: Football: Isco winner takes Ronaldo-less Real six points clear
summary: Real Madrid secured a 3-2 win over Sporting Gijon, moving six points clear of Barcelona at the top of La Liga. Midfielder Isco scored in stoppage time to seal the comeback, following earlier goals from Isco and Alvaro Morata. The victory, which came despite nine changes from the starting lineup, has all but secured Real's first La Liga title in five years. A win for Barcelona against Real Sociedad next weekend will determine the league's final standings.

site_title: Protesters across US press Donald Trump to release tax returns
summary: Thousands of protesters gathered across the US on April 15 to pressure President Donald Trump to release his tax returns. The "Tax March" demonstrations coincided with the traditional tax filing deadline, with protesters demanding transparency and criticizing Trump's refusal to disclose his tax returns. Organizers claim Trump is hiding something, with some speculating about potential connections to Russia. The protests, which took place in cities nationwide, were met with violent clashes in Berkeley, California, resulting in at least 14 arrests.

site_title: Explosives used in Dortmund attack may have come from German military: Newspaper
summary: German police suspect explosives used in the April 2017 attack on Borussia Dortmund's team bus may have originated from German military supplies, citing a source involved in the investigation. Specialist knowledge was required to use military detonators, and the attack's perpetrators are still unclear. Investigators believe right-wing extremists were likely responsible, with some suspecting an anonymous far-right email was an attempt to exploit the situation. The incident highlighted concerns about security at soccer games and led to increased calls for more video surveillance and body scanners at stadiums.

site_title: Formula One: Bottas ends Hamilton's pole run in Bahrain
summary: Finland's Valtteri Bottas secured his first Formula One pole position at the Bahrain Grand Prix, beating Mercedes teammate Lewis Hamilton by 0.023 seconds. The pole was Bottas' first in his career, marking a significant milestone for the driver. Hamilton, the reigning champion, was delighted for Bottas and acknowledged that the close qualifying session pushed him to improve. The front row lockout marked the first for the reigning champions, with Sebastian Vettel starting third and Daniel Ricciardo fourth.

site_title: Football: Sunderland in dire straits despite Borini leveller against West Ham
summary: Sunderland drew 2-2 against West Ham, but remain in dire straits with nine points from safety and just six games left. Fabio Borini scored a late equalizer to salvage a point, but the team needs wins, not draws, to avoid relegation. The Black Cats have not won a match in eight games and are now without a win since January 14. West Ham, nine points clear of the bottom three, are likely to avoid the drop despite their troubled season.

site_title: Formula One: Hamilton relishes three-way battle after Bottas pole
summary: Lewis Hamilton's hopes of a seventh successive Formula One pole position were dashed in Bahrain, but he relished the prospect of a three-way title battle with Valtteri Bottas and Sebastian Vettel. Bottas secured pole, with Hamilton just 0.023 seconds behind. Hamilton praised Bottas for his performance, saying he deserved the pole and was happy for him. The result leaves Vettel and Hamilton jointly leading the championship with 43 points each, setting up an exciting title battle.

summary: Valtteri Bottas secured pole position at the Bahrain Grand Prix, beating teammate Lewis Hamilton by 0.023 seconds. Despite his achievement, Bottas downplayed the possibility of a maiden victory, focusing on the team's strategy and performance. Bottas praised the car's setup and his own driving, while Hamilton expressed admiration for his teammate's skill and congratulated him on the pole. The win marked a strong start for Bottas, who aims to help Mercedes secure a one-two finish and potentially lead the drivers' title race.

site_title: Football: Capoue deepens Swansea gloom
summary: Watford beat Swansea 1-0 in their Premier League match, with Etienne Capoue scoring the winning goal in the first half. This victory lifts Watford to 40 points and ensures their spot in the Premier League for another season. Swansea, on the other hand, remains in the bottom three with a losing streak of six games, two points shy of fourth-from-bottom Hull. The loss deepens the team's struggles under manager Paul Clement, who had hoped to turn things around after a bright start to his tenure.

site_title: Football: Toothless Bayern held to 0-0 draw by 10-man Leverkusen
summary: Bayern Munich was held to a 0-0 draw by 10-man Bayer Leverkusen in a Bundesliga match, despite having several gilt-edged chances. The draw left Bayern Munich top of the league with 69 points from 29 games, while Leverkusen moved to 11th place with 36 points. Bayern's Robert Lewandowski missed the match due to a shoulder injury, and the team's lack of cutting edge was evident in the draw, which came just a day after their 2-1 defeat by Real Madrid in the Champions League quarter-final first leg.

site_title: Football: Stoke win to increase relegation pressure on Hull
summary: Stoke City beat Hull City 3-1 in the Premier League, ending a four-game losing streak and increasing the pressure on relegation-threatened Hull. Xherdan Shaqiri scored a stunning goal, and Marko Arnautovic also found the net. The win boosts Stoke's 11th place and 39 points from 33 games, while Hull remains two points above the relegation zone with 30 points. Manager Mark Hughes praised the team's performance, saying it was a "big three points" that will allow them to express themselves in the remaining games.

site_title: Italian Emma Morano, last known survivor of 19th century, dies at 117
summary: Italian woman Emma Morano, believed to be the last survivor of the 19th century, died at 117 years old on April 15, 2017. Born in 1899, Morano outlived all her siblings and held the Guinness World Record for the oldest person alive. She credited her longevity to a simple diet of two eggs and cookies per day, and refused hospital visits except for a cataract operation. With her death, there is no one known to have been born before 1900, making her the fifth longest-lived person ever verified.

site_title: Football: ‘Incredible’ Dortmund players fight back tears
summary: Borussia Dortmund's players showed "incredible character" in a 3-1 win over Eintracht Frankfurt, their first Bundesliga match since a traumatic bus attack on their team. The team celebrated with emotional moments, including holding up Spanish defender Marc Bartra's jersey, who was injured in the attack and released from hospital. Coach Thomas Tuchel praised the players' resilience, saying they were "learning to deal with fluctuating emotions." The win boosts Dortmund's chances of a top-four finish and morale ahead of their Champions League quarter-final return leg against Monaco.

site_title: Football: Kane matches Greaves after hitting 20-goal mark again
summary: Tottenham Hotspur's Harry Kane has become the first player since Jimmy Greaves to hit 20 goals in three successive top-flight seasons. Kane achieved this feat after scoring his 20th goal of the season in a 4-0 Premier League win over Bournemouth. With 71 points, Tottenham are just one point off their best-ever Premier League points total, and a win over Manchester United could secure their spot in the top four. Kane played down his achievement, focusing on maintaining Tottenham's form as they continue to chase the English title.

site_title: Berlin Christmas market attacker got order directly from ISIS: Report
summary: A German magazine reported that Anis Amri, the Berlin Christmas market attacker, received his orders directly from ISIS. Surveillance footage shows Amri, a Tunisian failed asylum seeker, transited through Lyon by train before the attack on Dec 19, killing 12 people. The information was provided to German security authorities by the UAE on Jan 8, citing a squad within ISIS. Amri was shot dead by Italian police four days after the attack, with ISIS claiming responsibility and stating the attack was in response to calls to target nationals of coalition countries.

site_title: Rugby: England pull off stunning comeback to reach Singapore quarters
summary: England, with a patched-up team, made a stunning comeback to reach the Singapore Sevens quarters. After losing their opening match to France, England won two crucial matches, including a 40-10 victory over Japan and a 19-12 win over South Africa. The team, led by Dan Norton and coach Simon Amor, overcame injuries and a tough start to secure their spot in the quarterfinals, where they will face Kenya on Sunday.

site_title: ISIS militant linked to Charlie Hebdo attack could still be alive: Iraq
summary: An ISIS militant linked to the 2015 Charlie Hebdo attack could still be alive, despite being reported killed in a US drone strike in November. Iraqi intelligence shared information with the Syrian airforce, which targeted ISIS headquarters and hideouts, including one believed to belong to the militant, Boubaker el-Hakim. El-Hakim was involved in planning the Charlie Hebdo attack that killed 17 people. The Iraqi military confirms that el-Hakim's headquarters were destroyed, but it's unclear if he was killed. The militant's status remains uncertain.

site_title: Rouhani says Iran needs 'no one's permission' to build missiles
summary: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani stated on Saturday that his country will not require anyone's permission to build up its missile capability, amid US efforts to hamper the Iranian military. Rouhani's comments came as he faces an election in May, where he hopes to secure a second term. The US has criticized Iran's nuclear deal and threatened to stop its missile program, with President Donald Trump tweeting that Iran's recent ballistic missile test was "playing with fire." Rouhani emphasized that Iran's military strength is for defense purposes only, and that the country will remain vigilant.

site_title: Dozens dead as car bomb hits Syria evacuees
summary: A suicide car bomb attack on buses carrying Syrians evacuated from two besieged government-held towns in Syria killed 43 people, mostly evacuees. The blast occurred in rebel-held Rashidin, west of Aleppo, as thousands waited to continue their journey to regime-controlled areas. The attack targeted buses carrying residents of Fuaa and Kafraya under a deal reached between the regime and rebels. The bombing has raised concerns about the safety of evacuation processes in Syria's ongoing civil war.

site_title: As the world watches on live YouTube stream, April the giraffe finally gives birth
summary: April, a 15-year-old reticulated giraffe, gave birth to a baby boy at the Animal Adventure Park in Harpursville, New York, after 15 months of anticipation. A live YouTube stream, initially banned due to complaints, attracted over 1 million viewers worldwide as April gave birth shortly before 10am. The calf will be raised naturally for 6-10 months before being moved to a breeding facility. A contest will be held to name the newborn, with subscribers receiving updates on the calf's progress.

site_title: AHTC has resolved one lapse flagged in past audits: KPMG
summary: The Aljunied-Hougang Town Council (AHTC) has addressed nine out of 17 audit points flagged in past audits, with the help of independent auditor KPMG. The council has also completed its self-review of Goods and Services Tax returns and is working on its migration to a new accounting system. KPMG has made suggestions for AHTC's business continuity plan and management policy, which the council will consider in future reviews. AHTC has also confirmed the amount of GST received from the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore that will be transferred to its Sinking Fund.

site_title: Egypt sentences ex-interior minister Habib al-Adly to 7 years' jail
summary: Egyptian former interior minister Habib al-Adly was sentenced to 7 years in prison for embezzlement, with the court finding him guilty of stealing over $3.5 million while in office. The verdict came less than a month after the acquittal of Hosni Mubarak on charges related to protester deaths, and Adly can appeal the sentence.

site_title: Football: Palace fight back to force 2-2 draw with Leicester
summary: Crystal Palace fought back from two goals down to secure a 2-2 draw with Leicester City at home. The match saw a pulsating clash, with Leicester taking a 2-0 lead through Robert Huth and Jamie Vardy. However, Palace scored twice, with Yohan Cabaye and Christian Benteke denying the champions. The result left Palace above the relegation zone with 35 points, two behind Leicester. The draw was described by Palace manager Sam Allardyce as a "tremendous fight back" and a "fantastic run of results," while Leicester's Jamie Vardy expressed disappointment at the result ahead of their Champions League quarter-final.

site_title: Football: AC Milan snatch dramatic last-gasp draw with Inter in first all-Chinese derby
summary: AC Milan drew 2-2 with Inter Milan in the first all-Chinese-owned derby between the two teams. Cristian Zapata scored the equalizing goal in the 7th minute of stoppage time, heading the ball over the line after a corner kick. The match, played at lunchtime for the first time, was part of a historic day for the teams, both of which are now owned by Chinese interests. The result kept Milan sixth in Serie A and Inter seventh, two points behind their rivals. The match drew criticism from local fans for the unusual kick-off time.

site_title: Philippine army plans all-Muslim units amid insurgency
summary: The Philippine military announced plans to create all-Muslim fighting units, allocating 5% of new applications for Muslims, in an effort to bolster efforts against Islamic insurgents. The move aims to address local concerns about Christian soldiers being perceived as occupying forces in Muslim communities. The plan is part of a broader strategy to tackle separatist insurgency in the southern region of Mindanao, which has claimed over 120,000 lives since the 1970s. The move is seen as a step towards building trust with the Muslim minority and bolstering security efforts against militant groups, including those allied with ISIS.

site_title: Roadside bomb kills 11 Afghan civilians: Officials
summary: At least 11 Afghan civilians were killed in a roadside bomb explosion in the restive southern province of Helmand on Friday. The blast targeted a senior local police vehicle, and officials suspect the Taleban were behind the attack. The victims were traveling from Nawa district to the provincial capital Lashkar Gah. The incident is part of a growing trend of roadside bombs used by the Taleban to target Afghan security forces and civilians, highlighting the ongoing conflict in the country.

site_title: Actor Edmund Chen files police report, after giving $10,000 to woman who 'abused his trust'
summary: Actor Edmund Chen, 56, has filed a police report alleging he lost $10,000 to a woman he hired part-time, claiming she abused his trust. The 30-year-old woman denies his allegations, stating she has not done anything wrong. Chen, who also fired her in February, claims she continued to represent him in business circles after being let go. Chen made public his accusations after considering it to prevent future victims, and the woman is discussing options with lawyers.

site_title: Rugby: Singapore capture men's SEA 7s crown but succumb to Thais in women's final
summary: The Singapore men's rugby sevens team won the South-east Asian (SEA) 7s tournament, defeating Malaysia 19-7 in the final. The hosts took an early lead but Malaysia equalised before half-time, only to be dominated by Singapore in the second half. In the women's competition, Singapore lost to defending champions Thailand 34-0, with Thailand overpowering the opposition with six tries. The victory for the men's team marked Singapore's first SEA 7s title.

site_title: Football: Spurs keep up their relentless chase of Chelsea with a 4-0 spanking of Bournemouth
summary: Tottenham Hotspur secured a 4-0 win over Bournemouth, extending their Premier League home win streak to 12 games. Moussa Dembele and Son Heung-min scored two goals in three minutes, while Harry Kane added his 20th league goal of the season. The victory narrowed Chelsea's lead to four points, putting pressure on the leaders ahead of their match against Manchester United. Tottenham's win also marked the third season in a row Kane has reached the 20-goal mark.

site_title: Big names star as top-flight football returns to Indonesia
summary: Top-flight football returned to Indonesia on April 15, 2017, after a two-year absence due to a major crisis between the government and the local FA, resulting in a one-year ban by FIFA. The new Liga 1 league features high-profile signings, including former Chelsea stars Michael Essien and Carlton Cole, and ex-West Bromwich Albion forward Peter Odemwingie. The season runs until November, with 18 teams competing, and aims to revitalize the sport in the country after last year's suspension.

site_title: Team from Hwa Chong Institution wins NTU's first inter-school medical competition
summary: A team from Hwa Chong Institution won NTU's first inter-school medical competition, the Anatomy Challenge, held on April 15. The team, named after its school motto, took home a trophy and $400 cash, with each member receiving a medal. The competition, which drew over 150 students from 20 schools, aimed to inspire aspiring doctors with knowledge of human anatomy and its applications in modern clinical practice. The event was organized by NTU's Lee Kong Chian School of Medicine, with career advice also provided to participants.

site_title: Hands off the animals: Tunis zoo where croc stoned to death reopens
summary: The Belvedere Zoo in Tunis, Tunisia, has reopened after a 2-month closure following the stoning of a crocodile to death. The zoo underwent an extensive makeover, including cleaning, restoring pathways, and installing new signs instructing visitors not to disturb or throw things at animals. Extra guards were deployed after a public outcry over the animal's death and other complaints about litter and delinquent behavior. Authorities report an improvement in behavior, with visitor numbers increasing to 8,000 per day, and plans to spend an additional $6.5 million to develop the surrounding park.

site_title: Football: Barkley inspires Everton to eighth straight home win
summary: Everton midfielder Ross Barkley inspired his team to an eighth straight home win with a 3-1 victory over Burnley in the Premier League on April 15. Barkley's shot, deflected off Ben Mee, put Everton 2-1 up in the 71st minute and Romelu Lukaku sealed the win three minutes later with his 24th goal of the season. Barkley had a tumultuous week after being the victim of an assault and was at the center of controversy, but he played a key role in the win, clearing off the line twice and scoring the decisive goal.

site_title: Football: Dortmund boss considered Champions League pull out
summary: Borussia Dortmund CEO Hans-Joachim Watzke revealed that he briefly considered pulling the club out of the Champions League after a team bus attack on April 11, 2017. However, he ultimately decided not to give in to the bombers, saying it would have been a victory for those responsible. The team played the quarter-final first leg against Monaco 24 hours later, despite several players criticizing the decision. Watzke left each player with the option to play or not, with none refusing. The team suffered a 3-2 loss and will face an uphill struggle to qualify for the semi-finals.

site_title: Syrians stuck in and near Aleppo as evacuation deal halts
summary: Thousands of Syrians are stuck in and around Aleppo as a deal to evacuate people from two Shi'ite villages in exchange for Sunni rebels and their families leaving two besieged towns near Damascus has stalled. The agreement, which included rebels and their families from Madaya, halted due to rebels not being granted safe passage. Those from Madaya are waiting in a bus garage in Aleppo, while residents from the Shi'ite villages are still waiting to cross into the city. The deal is seen as a forced displacement of Assad's opponents, causing demographic changes and further solidifying Assad's military advantage.

site_title: 8 charged over Pakistani liberal student's murder
summary: Eight Pakistanis have been charged with murder and terrorism over the brutal killing of journalism student Mashal Khan, who was brutally beaten, shot, and thrown from a second-floor hostel in 2017. Khan's classmates, who were angry over his liberal views, stripped and attacked him, and he was later killed. The incident has sparked widespread condemnation, with the Human Rights Commission of Pakistan urging justice for those involved. The case has highlighted the country's sensitive blasphemy laws, which can lead to mob violence and the death penalty.

site_title: President Tayyip Erdogan makes final push before vote on presidential powers
summary: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan is set to vote on a constitutional referendum on April 16, 2017, that could tighten his grip on power and replace Turkey's parliamentary democracy with an all-powerful presidency. Opinion polls suggest a narrow lead for a "Yes" vote, with Erdogan's support at around 51%. Opponents argue the move is a step towards authoritarianism, while proponents say it would end a "two-headed system" and bring stability. Erdogan has urged supporters to vote, saying the outcome will be a "turning point in the fight against terrorist organisations."

site_title: Najib urges pro-govt social media activists to go on offensive as Malaysia election looms
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak urges pro-government social media activists to go on the offensive to defend the government and maintain power. He urges unity and expansion of their cyber network to effectively reach the public. Najib criticizes the opposition for using "lies" to mislead voters, referencing allegations of phantom voters and manipulated votes. The statement comes as Malaysia's 14th general election is expected to be held this year, potentially challenging the ruling Barisan Nasional coalition's hold on power.

site_title: Germany probes new letter claiming Borussia Dortmund bus attack
summary: German prosecutors are investigating a third claim of responsibility for the 2017 explosion that injured Borussia Dortmund players, including Spanish international Marc Bartra. A new letter, reportedly from far-right circles, was received by a newspaper, claiming the attack was carried out and threatening another. The letter's authenticity remains unclear, and no new suspects have emerged. Previous claims, initially linked to Islamists, have been discredited, and a sole suspect has been cleared. The team will play their next match under heightened security, with police pursuing leads on the attack.

site_title: South Korean actor Lee Dong Wook would teleport to Singapore every week if he had that superpower
summary: South Korean actor Lee Dong Wook expressed his desire to have the superpower of teleportation if he could choose one. The 35-year-old actor, known for his roles in K-dramas like "Goblin" and "Hotel King," would use this power to save time and travel easily between Korea and Singapore, where he is currently on a fan-meet tour. Lee's fan meet in Singapore sold out its tickets quickly, and he will hold another event in the city tonight.

site_title: Singapore Rugby Sevens: Defending champions Kenya recover to reach Cup quarter-finals
summary: Kenya, the defending HSBC Singapore Rugby Sevens Series champions, have reached the Cup quarter-finals after beating Samoa 17-7 on April 15. They previously won their opener against Argentina but lost to Australia. Kenya's captain, Andrew Amonde, aims to win the trophy again, citing the team's strong potential. The Cup quarter-finals feature teams such as Fiji, Canada, South Africa, England, New Zealand, and the USA, with the winner of the tournament set to claim the world series title.

site_title: China seeks Russia's help to 'cool' North Korea situation
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi has sought Russia's help to calm tensions over North Korea's nuclear ambitions, warning that war could break out "at any moment." China, North Korea's sole major ally, and Russia are working together to encourage parties to resume dialogue, with a common goal of preventing war and chaos on the peninsula. This comes amid heightened tensions, with a US naval strike force deployed near the Korean peninsula and President Trump warning of a "merciless" response to any provocation. Beijing and Moscow aim to coordinate efforts to cool down the situation and promote dialogue.

site_title: Football: Arsenal not going to break the wage structure for Alexis Sanchez, says Wenger
summary: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger stated that the club should not change its wage policy for star striker Alexis Sanchez, despite fans' opinions that he should sign a new contract. Wenger emphasized the importance of respecting the club's wage structure, which would put the club in trouble if altered. Wenger cited the changing landscape of modern life, where players earn significantly more, but also highlighted the need to prioritize the club's interests. Wenger's comments may further divide fans, who are divided on whether Sanchez should extend his contract.

site_title: Golf: Gregory Havret targets Trophee Hassan II to end nine-year drought
summary: France's Gregory Havret leads the Trophee Hassan II golf tournament after a 70 on Friday, opening a one-shot lead at six-under par. Havret, seeking his first European Tour title in nine years, eagled the 14th and birdied four holes. He finished with a disappointing two-bogey finish, but remains optimistic about his chances. Havret trails Dane Lucas Bjerregaard and South African Trevor Fisher, who are tied on five under, one stroke behind the leader.

site_title: Fight between 2 men at Eunos leaves 59-year-old slashed, 46-year-old arrested
summary: A 59-year-old man was slashed with a knife by a 46-year-old in Eunos, Singapore. The incident occurred at around 2am on April 14 at Block 1, Eunos Crescent, after a dispute arose when the 59-year-old let the 46-year-old into his home. The 59-year-old was taken to hospital and the 46-year-old was arrested. Police investigations are ongoing.

site_title: NBA: Golden State Warriors seek redemption after last year's Finals collapse
summary: The Golden State Warriors enter the NBA playoffs seeking redemption after last year's Finals collapse, where they blew a 3-1 lead to the Cleveland Cavaliers. Despite this, they remain favorites to win the title, with Kevin Durant's addition in the off-season and his successful return from a knee injury boosting their odds. Analysts, including Jeff Van Gundy and Reggie Miller, predict a championship win, with some stating it won't be close. The team's high expectations are fueled by their NBA-record 73 wins during the season and Durant's ability to close games, making a championship "obviously championship or bust" for the Warriors.

site_title: NBA: Giannis Antetokounmpo will be key to Milwaukee Bucks' play-off hopes
summary: Milwaukee Bucks forward Giannis Antetokounmpo is crucial to the team's playoff hopes, having led the franchise in multiple categories during the regular season. The 22-year-old Greek dominated with 1,832 points, 700 rebounds, 434 assists, 151 blocks, and 131 steals, earning an All-Star nod. Coach Jason Kidd believes Antetokounmpo would be in the MVP discussion if not for Russell Westbrook and James Harden's impressive seasons. Antetokounmpo's impressive skillset and athleticism make him a force to be reckoned with, particularly against the Toronto Raptors in the first round of the NBA playoffs.

site_title: Security tight as Egypt Copts hold Easter mass
summary: Egyptian Coptic Christians held Easter Mass under tight security on April 15, 2017, following twin church bombings that killed 45 people, the worst attack on Copts in recent memory. The bombings were claimed by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) group, which has threatened more attacks. The government declared a state of emergency and called in the army to protect vital installations. The Coptic Church, which makes up around 10% of Egypt's population, observed the mass with metal detectors and police guards, with the Pope calling for peace and an end to the "brokenness of humanity."

site_title: Golf: Luke Donald and Graham DeLaet in joint-second round lead at RBC Heritage
summary: Luke Donald and Graham DeLaet are tied for the lead at 10-under par after two rounds of the RBC Heritage golf tournament in South Carolina. Donald, a former world No. 1, shot a 4-under 67 with clutch short game shots, while DeLaet eagled the 9th hole with a 109-yard wedge shot. Ian Poulter and Webb Simpson are two shots back at 8-under par. The tournament will continue on Sunday, with Donald seeking to prove himself after struggling in recent years.

site_title: Football: Jorge Sampaoli unhappy at Sevilla's Argentina rebuke
summary: Sevilla's coach Jorge Sampaoli expressed anger over the Argentine Football Association's (AFA) threat to take legal action against him for interest in hiring him to manage Argentina's World Cup qualifying campaign. The AFA's president, Claudio Tapia, had previously threatened to sue Sampaoli, but later clarified that he would meet with Barcelona star Lionel Messi instead. Sampaoli, currently under contract at Sevilla, stated that he had not given a commitment to AFA and criticized the AFA's statement as speculative and lacking respect.

site_title: Football: Chelsea's Marcos Alonso not taking Manchester United lightly
summary: Chelsea defender Marcos Alonso has warned Manchester United to be cautious ahead of their upcoming match, citing United's revenge mission following two losses to Chelsea. With seven games remaining, Chelsea leads the Premier League by seven points, but a Tottenham win against Bournemouth could temporarily close the gap. Alonso acknowledges that a Chelsea win at Old Trafford would be challenging, especially after United's humiliating 4-0 loss in October and 0-1 loss in the FA Cup. Alonso expects a tough game and emphasized the need for Chelsea to perform at their best to secure a win.

site_title: At least 25 killed in Iran floods
summary: At least 25 people were killed and 16 declared missing in Iran due to flash floods in north-western provinces, according to state media. Torrential rains began on Friday, causing rivers to burst their banks and flooding homes and cars. The districts of Ajabshir and Azarshahr were the worst hit. Iran's emergency response organisation reported the casualties, with more missing.

site_title: Tennis: Top seed Jack Sock avoids upset to reach Houston semi-finals
summary: Top seed Jack Sock avoided an upset to reach the Houston semi-finals, defeating Feliciano Lopez 7-6 (8-6), 1-6, 6-4. Second seed John Isner was ousted by Ernesto Escobedo 7-6 (8-6), 6-7 (6-8), 7-6 (7-5), while third seed Sam Querrey lost to Thomaz Bellucci 6-4, 3-6, 6-3. Escobedo, ranked 91st in the world, faces Bellucci in the semi-finals, while Sock advances to the final four.

site_title: Plaque commemorating Thailand's 1932 revolution removed, prompting outcry
summary: A plaque commemorating Thailand's 1932 revolution, which led to the establishment of democracy, has been removed and replaced with a new one highlighting the importance of the monarchy. The removal sparked outcry from pro-democracy activists, who claim it's an attempt to rewrite history. The new plaque was embedded in the same location, but its text is seen as promoting ultra-royalist rhetoric. The government has stepped up prosecution of monarchy critics under a harsh royal insult law, and a military-backed constitution was signed into law this month, which critics say will give the military sway over politics.

site_title: Magnitude 6.2 quake hits northern Chile
summary: A 6.2-magnitude earthquake struck northern Chile on April 15, 2017, with an epicenter about 67 kilometers southeast of the San Pedro de Atacama tourist zone. The quake, at a depth of 135 kilometers, caused a medium-intensity shaking in the northern regions of Tarapaca, Antofagasta, and Atacama. No tsunami alert was issued, and there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries. The quake occurred in an area prone to frequent earthquakes and volcanic eruptions, but Chile's emergency office did not declare an emergency.

site_title: NBA: New York Knicks, Carmelo Anthony split best for both parties
summary: New York Knicks president Phil Jackson stated that forward Carmelo Anthony "would be better off somewhere else" due to the team's inability to win with him on the court. The Knicks completed their fourth consecutive losing season, falling short of expectations. Anthony, a 10-time All-Star, has been at odds with Jackson over trade speculation. Jackson expressed his desire for players who can play every single play, defensively and offensively, and Anthony has expressed openness to being traded this summer.

site_title: Artbox Singapore draws big crowds, organiser tells visitors busiest period between 5 and 8pm
summary: Artbox Singapore, the first overseas installation of Bangkok's popular creative market, has drawn massive crowds, exceeding expectations of 400,000 visitors over two weekends. However, the event has faced criticism on social media for overcrowding and poor layout, with visitors complaining of difficulty finding parking, navigating the market, and accessing stalls. Organiser Mr Lee Haoming advises visitors to avoid the busiest period between 5-8pm and to take public transport to the nearest MRT Station. Despite the challenges, the event has been deemed a success, with many visitors praising the warm welcome and strong turnout.

site_title: Football: Angel Di Maria brace keeps PSG on Monaco's tail
summary: Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) secured a 2-0 win over Angers in the French L1 football match, thanks to Angel Di Maria's brace. The victory kept PSG level with leaders Monaco at 74 points, as they bid for a fifth successive French title. Di Maria scored in the 28th and 84th minutes, with goalkeeper Kevin Trapp making crucial saves to secure the win, moving PSG's unbeaten league run to 14 games.

site_title: Sri Lanka garbage dump toll death rises to 19
summary: A garbage dump in Colombo, Sri Lanka, collapsed on April 14, 2017, destroying 145 homes and killing at least 19 people, with four children among the dead. The 91m-high dump came crashing down due to heavy rain and a fire, and rescue efforts are ongoing. Authorities have promised compensation for those affected and plan to remove the garbage dump, but concerns remain about the risks of further collapse and health hazards. The incident has sparked anger among residents, who had previously protested against the daily dumping of hundreds of tonnes of garbage at the site.

site_title: Badminton: Carolina Marin, Tai Tzu-ying to meet again in S'pore Open final
summary: Reigning Olympic champion Carolina Marin will face world No. 1 Tai Tzu-ying in the final of the OUE Singapore Open, seeking her first title since the Olympics. Marin defeated South Korean Sung Ji Hyun 21-9, 21-12, while Tai outlasted Zhang Beiwen 21-19, 21-15. The two met just a week ago in Malaysia, with Tai winning the Superseries Premier title. Marin is confident and determined to win her first title since the Olympics, while Tai hopes to win her fifth straight title and lift the title at the Singapore Indoor Stadium for the first time.

site_title: Punchlines: April 15, 2017
summary: I couldn't find any article content to summarize.

site_title: I held up umbrella for King Salman, yet China gets the investment: Jokowi
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo expressed disappointment over Saudi Arabia's $65 billion investment in China, which is nearly ten times the $9.4 billion pledged to Indonesia. Despite receiving special treatment during King Salman's visit, including holding up an umbrella, Indonesia received a smaller investment. Widodo promised to make phone calls to the king and deputy crown prince to discuss investment further, after the king's visit was considered historic, marking the first Saudi king to visit Indonesia in 47 years.

site_title: Pay just $10k for a Caribbean resort with more than 24% returns yearly? Anti-scam ad aims to educate investors
summary: A Singapore-based anti-scam campaign, in partnership with the Securities Investors Association, has created a fake Caribbean resort website to educate investors about potential scams. The website, SantaQuay Resorts, was promoted on social media and newspapers, offering beachfront resorts for as little as $10,000 with 24% yearly returns. However, upon clicking through, the site revealed its true intentions, highlighting common signs of investment scams and providing advice on how to protect oneself. The campaign aims to raise awareness and educate investors about the dangers of fake investment opportunities.

site_title: Wintry wolverine has cub in Belgium, beating climate-change odds
summary: A wolverine cub was born in February at the Domain of the Caves of Han park in Belgium, marking a rare occurrence of the species in a southern European location. Wolverines, confined to colder climates since the last Ice Age, have re-established a foothold further south. The cub, born to a female, emerged from its den this week. Conservationists have expressed concern over the species' shrinking habitats due to rising global temperatures. The park plans to transfer the cub to a zoo in two years, joining around 116 wolverines in European zoos and wildlife parks.

site_title: What would hardline presidential frontrunner Ebrahim Raisi mean for Iran and the world?
summary: Ebrahim Raisi, a hardline cleric, has registered for Iran's May 19 presidential election, sparking concerns about the country's fragile opening to the West. Raisi is seen as loyal to Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, suggesting he will maintain a cautious foreign policy stance while preserving the 2015 nuclear deal. Analysts predict he will prioritize domestic economic issues, particularly addressing high unemployment and slow economic growth, and may not ease social restrictions or release opposition leaders. Raisi's candidacy poses a risk to the nuclear deal and threatens Iran's engagement with the West.

site_title: People's Association wants senior citizens to try pedal boating in move to get them involved in water sports
summary: The People's Association in Singapore has launched the Silver WaVe initiative, aiming to get 1,000 senior citizens (55+) involved in water sports each year. The program offers a two-hour pedal boat orientation for $5 and teaches participants how to operate the vessels. The goal is to promote a healthy lifestyle among active agers, utilizing the elderly as a valuable resource for the country's economy. The program is part of a larger national drive and will be conducted on weekends, with costs ranging from $2 to $10 for boat rentals.

site_title: Pope presides at Colosseum's Good Friday service, speaks of shame for Church and humanity
summary: Pope Francis presided over a Good Friday service at Rome's Colosseum, asking God for forgiveness for scandals within the Catholic Church and humanity's inuredness to violence and suffering. He spoke of shame for Church scandals, daily innocent bloodshed, and persecution, while expressing hope that good will triumph despite apparent defeat. The service, attended by 20,000, came after recent attacks in European cities and amid a migrant crisis in the Mediterranean.

site_title: United Airlines changes crew booking policy after passenger dragged off plane
summary: United Airlines has changed its policy on booking flight crews onto its planes, ensuring crews are booked into seats at least 60 minutes before departure. The move comes after a passenger was dragged off an overbooked flight in April, sparking global criticism and ridicule. The airline apologized to the passenger, David Dao, who suffered significant injuries, and will review policies to deliver the best customer experience. The change is an initial step, with CEO Oscar Munoz standing behind his leadership amid pressure from activist investors to improve customer relations.

site_title: Violence flares at Australian refugee facility in Papua New Guinea
summary: Violence broke out at an Australian refugee facility on Manus Island in Papua New Guinea, with shots fired and up to 100 rounds fired into the facility. The incident occurred after a local resident tried to break into the centre, prompting a response from PNG military personnel. One inmate was reportedly hit by a rock and received treatment, while two guards were allegedly injured. The incident has reignited calls for the closure of the centre, which has been criticized for poor conditions. The Australian government has faced pressure from rights groups and the UN to address the situation.

site_title: Number of ISIS fighters killed by US 'Mother of All Bombs' jumps to 90: Afghan officials
summary: US forces dropped the GBU-43 Massive Ordnance Air Blast (MOAB) on an ISIS militant cave complex in Afghanistan's Nangarhar province, killing at least 90 fighters. The bomb, dubbed the "Mother of All Bombs," was used in combat for the first time and destroyed ISIS's remote mountain hideouts. Afghan officials initially reported 36 deaths, but later confirmed 90. The US-led forces conducted clean-up operations, with no reported military or civilian casualties. The use of the bomb was met with mixed reactions, with some condemning it as a "testing ground" for the weapon, while others saw it as a strategic move against a non-top threat.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, April 15 edition
summary: The US National Security Agency (NSA) allegedly monitored global bank transfers through the Swift interbank messaging system, according to leaked files. Hackers, The Shadow Brokers, released the documents and computer code, which could be used by criminals to break into Swift servers. Meanwhile, a Palestinian man stabbed a 23-year-old British tourist to death near Jerusalem's Old City. In Sri Lanka, a massive rubbish dump buried 40 homes, killing at least six people. The US dropped a massive bomb in Afghanistan's Nangarhar province, and Disney released the first trailer for Star Wars: The Last Jedi.

site_title: Students spotted climbing to roof of 5-storey carpark, AMK Town Council 'exploring preventive measures'
summary: Students in Singapore were spotted climbing to the roof of a 5-storey carpark in Hougang, where they took selfies and played. A resident reported the incident, citing safety concerns due to lack of railings. The Ang Mo Kio Town Council has launched an investigation and is exploring preventive measures, including informing the school and increasing surveillance. A police report has been filed, and the students had climbed up to retrieve a fallen wallet. The incident highlights concerns about student safety and irresponsible behavior in public spaces.

site_title: Troublemakers spark panic at Seville's Good Friday event
summary: Troublemakers disrupted Seville's Good Friday processions, causing panic among spectators, resulting in the serious injury of one person. Eight people were detained, including one later released, for shouting, making loud noises, and creating chaos. Authorities denied any link to extremism, describing the incidents as isolated cases of vandalism and hooliganism. The situation was eventually brought under control, and the processions continued, with 17 people taken to hospital for injuries and panic attacks, one in intensive care with a head injury.

site_title: Golf: Jang grabs solo lead at LPGA Lotte Championship
summary: South Korea's Jang Su-Yeon secured a one-stroke lead at the LPGA Lotte Championship in Oahu, Hawaii, after a second-round 67. With a 36-hole total of 134, Jang edged out South Korea's Kim In-Kyung and Thailand's Ariya Jutanugarn, who were tied for second. Jang credited her putts for the key to her score, despite feeling that her shots weren't particularly solid. The third round is scheduled to start later on Friday.

site_title: Football: Guardiola accepts City 'far away' from Champions League
summary: Pep Guardiola has stated that Manchester City are "far away" from challenging for the Champions League, despite reaching the quarter-finals in the previous season. Guardiola, who watched the quarter-finals from a distance, believes the team needs more experience to compete at the top level. He acknowledged City's recent performances and praised the form of striker Sergio Aguero, who has been involved in the game despite being injured. Guardiola's comments come after City's elimination in the last 16, and he expects the team to qualify for next season's competition.

site_title: Hacked files suggest US National Security Agency penetrated Swift, Mideast banks
summary: The US National Security Agency (NSA) allegedly infiltrated two Swift service bureaus, including EastNets, which provide technology services for the Belgium-based Swift and individual financial institutions in the Middle East. The NSA exploited numerous vulnerabilities in Microsoft Windows products, targeting banks in Kuwait, Dubai, Bahrain, Jordan, Yemen, and Qatar. EastNets denied the allegations, stating no customer data was compromised. Swift confirmed the NSA had accessed communications between its service bureaus and customers, but no unauthorized access to its network or messaging services was found.
