site_title: US unleashes ‘mother of all bombs’ in Afghanistan, kills 36 ISIS fighters
summary: The US dropped the largest non-nuclear device, the GBU-43 "mother of all bombs," on a network of ISIS caves and tunnels in eastern Afghanistan, killing 36 militants. The 9,797kg bomb was dropped from a MC-130 aircraft in the Achin district of Nangarhar province, near the border with Pakistan. President Donald Trump described the mission as "very successful" and touted it as evidence of a more muscular US foreign policy. The strike was the first time the US has used this size of conventional bomb in a conflict, and it comes amid ongoing efforts to combat ISIS in Afghanistan.

site_title: Misdirected coalition strike kills 18 partner forces in Syria: Officials
summary: A coalition air strike in northern Syria accidentally killed 18 members of the US-backed Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) near the town of Tabqa, south of Raqa, the ISIS stronghold. The strike was intended to target an ISIS position but mistakenly hit an SDF fighting position. The coalition offered condolences to the SDF and expressed its desire for the group to remain focused on the fight against ISIS. An investigation is underway to determine the cause of the strike and implement safeguards to prevent similar incidents.

site_title: Football: AC Milan sold to Chinese-backed consortium
summary: Italian former prime minister Silvio Berlusconi sold soccer club AC Milan to a Chinese-led consortium, Rossoneri Sport Investment Lux, for €740 million, ending an era for the 80-year-old businessman. The deal includes €220 million in debt and is the biggest Chinese investment in a European club. Berlusconi, who owned the club since the 1980s, will step down as president and sell his stake, citing the need for investments and resources to compete with top clubs.

site_title: British PM Theresa May says highly likely Syrian government behind poison gas attack
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May stated that it is highly likely the Syrian government, led by President Bashar al-Assad, was behind a suspected poison gas attack in Syria's Idlib province. The attack, which the US and allies blamed on the Syrian military, was described as a "100 per cent fabrication" by Assad. However, May believes the Assad regime has the capability to carry out such an attack, citing positive test results for the nerve agent sarin at the alleged attack site.

site_title: Beyond Ooho edible blob: 4 other unusual containers that can be consumed
summary: London-based startup Skipping Rocks Lab has released Ooho, edible water blobs encased in a seaweed-based membrane, aiming to replace plastic bottles. Other eco-friendly edible containers include a milk-based packaging film developed by the USDA, edible candy wrappers made from gelatin and glycerin, edible cutlery made from millet flour, and heat-resistant chocolate cups. These innovations aim to reduce food waste and promote sustainability in packaging.

site_title: Donald Trump says on Twitter 'things will work out fine' with Russia
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed confidence in US-Russian relations, stating "things will work out fine" after talks in Moscow, despite tensions over Syria and North Korea. Trump looked to China to "deal properly" with North Korea, while warning that the US would take action if China failed to do so. The US Secretary of State had previously warned Russian President Vladimir Putin that relations were at a "low point."

site_title: Syria's Assad says chemical attack '100 per cent fabrication'
summary: Syrian President Bashar al-Assad denied a suspected chemical attack in the rebel-held town of Khan Sheikhoun, calling it a "fabrication" to justify a US strike. Assad insisted his forces handed over all chemical weapons stockpiles in 2013 and would never use them. He blamed the West, particularly the US, for fabricating the story to have a pretext for the attack. The OPCW has begun an investigation, but Assad demands an impartial probe, stating his forces' firepower has not been affected by the US strike.

site_title: United Airlines faces pressure to settle quickly with passenger - lawyers
summary: United Airlines is under pressure to settle a lawsuit with passenger David Dao, who was forcibly removed from a flight at Chicago O'Hare International Airport in April 2017. Dao, a doctor, was hospitalized after being dragged off the plane, and his lawyers have filed an emergency request to preserve video recordings and evidence. Lawyers predict a strong public relations and business case for United to settle the claim, but experts also note potential legal roadblocks. The airline's CEO, Oscar Munoz, has apologized and announced changes to its policy on removing passengers from overbooked flights.

site_title: 'Gangsta gardener' brings fresh produce to Los Angeles' inner city
summary: Ron Finley, a self-proclaimed "Gangsta Gardener", has been providing fresh produce to Los Angeles' inner city for seven years through his "Ron Finley project". Frustrated with the lack of healthy food options in his neighborhood, Finley transformed a plot of land into a lush garden, offering fruits and vegetables to the local community. His initiative aims to improve access to healthy food in underserved areas, making a positive impact on the lives of those in need.

site_title: No request for documents from lawyers of Kim Jong Nam murder accused, Malaysian police chief says
summary: Malaysian police chief Inspector-General of Police Tan Sri Khalid Abu Bakar stated that defence lawyers for the Kim Jong Nam murder accused, Siti Aishah and Doan Thi Huong, have not made an official request for documents. The police chief emphasized that such requests must be made through the court and assured that they will cooperate with the lawyers. The Attorney-General will ultimately decide which documents to release to the lawyers, following complaints from the defence lawyers about not being given access to important material, including CCTV recordings, in the trial.

site_title: Be on alert against scam callers posing as immigration officers: ICA
summary: The Immigration and Checkpoint Authority (ICA) in Singapore is warning citizens to be on alert against scam callers posing as ICA officers. Scammers have been making calls from a specific phone number, claiming to rectify discrepancies in personal information, and demanding money transfers ranging from $900 to $20,000. The ICA clarified that these calls are not made by real officers and urged the public to ignore the calls and not transfer any money. Those with information can report it to the police hotline or submit online.

site_title: Air France expands Asia links with Singapore Airlines tie-up
summary: Air France-KLM has signed a code share deal with Singapore Airlines to boost its network to Asia, following a similar move by Lufthansa with Cathay Pacific. The deal allows Air France to add its AF code to Singapore Airlines flights to Melbourne and Sydney, while Singapore Airlines will add its SQ code to 10 Air France flights from Paris. The partnership aims to expand Air France's market position and increase its range of destinations globally, as European carriers respond to weaker demand caused by Gulf carriers.

site_title: Uber resumes ride-hailing service in Taiwan after talks with authorities
summary: Uber has resumed its ride-hailing service in Taiwan after a two-month suspension, following "constructive talks" with the island's authorities. The US-based ride-hailing service had halted operations on February 10 after facing fines of up to T$25 million per infraction. Uber will partner with licensed rental car companies to resume service in Taipei, with plans to expand to other cities in the near future. The resumption comes after Taiwanese authorities had maintained Uber's business was illegal and had considered ordering it to leave the domestic market.

site_title: Founder of beauty treatment chain PPP Laser Clinic allowed to join competing firm
summary: The founder of PPP Laser Clinic, Dr Goh Seng Heng, has been allowed to work for his competitor Quikglow after a Court of Appeal lifted an injunction restraining him from joining the firm. The decision came after the court lifted a Mareva injunction that froze his assets up to $40 million. Dr Goh had sued Quikglow and his daughter, also a co-founder, for allegedly breaching fiduciary and contractual obligations. The court ruled that Dr Goh was unlikely to dissipate his assets and that the injunction to stop him from joining Quikglow was granted wrongly.

site_title: The Straits Times' News In A Minute: April 13, 2017
summary: Singapore is exploring plans to fully pedestrianise Orchard Road, with government agencies collaborating with the private sector. Starting July 1, private-hire drivers will be required to display a permanent decal on their car's windscreens. Meanwhile, a dead body of a 60-year-old Chinese man was discovered in the Singapore River on April 13.

site_title: Thai police arrest woman over alleged travel scam that left thousands stranded at airport
summary: Thai police arrested Pasist Arinchayalapis, head of a company selling food supplements, over an alleged travel scam that left over 1,000 people stranded at Suvarnabhumi airport in Bangkok. The victims paid for cheap holidays to Japan but found no chartered plane when they arrived on Tuesday night. Arinchayalapis was brought to Bangkok for questioning and denied any wrongdoing, stating she never sold cheap tours or offered free tours. Police continue to gather evidence from the stranded passengers.

site_title: 65% of 2G users have migrated to 3G; network to shut down for good on April 18
summary: About 65% of 2G users in Singapore have migrated to 3G, with 60,000-80,000 individuals still using the older network, primarily due to having dual-SIM phones. The 2G network will shut down on April 18, but users with 3G-enabled phones will not be affected. The Migrant Workers' Centre (MWC) will engage with migrant workers to remind them to migrate to 3G phones, and telco partners will offer attractive migration packages. The shutdown is part of the transition to faster mobile data rates.

site_title: Football: Jurgen Klopp feared for Borussia Dortmund stars after bomb blast
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp expressed concerns for his former Borussia Dortmund players after a bomb attack on their team bus before the Champions League quarter-final match against Monaco. Three explosions occurred as the team made their way to the stadium, and Klopp feared the worst upon hearing the news. Thankfully, no fatalities were reported, but Dortmund defender Marc Bartra required surgery for a wrist injury. Klopp and Dortmund manager Thomas Tuchel criticized Uefa for rescheduling the match just 24 hours after the incident, which they believe will cause long-lasting mental scars for the players.

site_title: Football: Bill Ng's Game Changers to focus on seven key areas to revive S'pore football, want to expand S-League
summary: Bill Ng's Game Changers, a team of 9 candidates, unveiled a manifesto for the Football Association of Singapore (FAS) election, focusing on 7 key areas to revive S'pore football. The areas include administration, technical, facilities, talent scouting, commercial activities, player care, and competitions. The team aims to expand the S-League from 9 to 12-14 teams, making it self-sustaining, and increase funding for the National Football League to promote teams to the S-League. Key candidates include Annabel Pennefather, who advocates for women's football, and Hougang United chairman Bill Ng.

site_title: Where pedestrians are kings of the road: 5 scramble crossings from around the world
summary: Singapore is planning to make Orchard Road more pedestrian-friendly with a scramble crossing, joining other cities like Tokyo, New York, Oxford Circus in London, Brisbane, Australia, and Ontario, Canada, which have successfully implemented scramble crossings to reduce congestion and improve safety. These cities have seen significant increases in pedestrian traffic and sales, with some even banning cars from certain areas to enhance pedestrian experience. The scramble crossing in Singapore aims to make it easier for pedestrians to navigate the busy thoroughfare and is part of a broader effort to transform Orchard Road into a distinctive shopping and lifestyle destination.

site_title: Badminton: Olympic champion and silver medallist set up clash at OUE S'pore Open
summary: Olympic champion Carolina Marin and silver medallist P.V. Sindhu will face off in the quarter-finals of the OUE Singapore Open. Marin, the world No. 2, defeated Lee Chia-hsin 21-7, 21-11, while Sindhu came from behind to beat Fitriani Fitriani 19-21, 21-17, 21-8. The two met in the India Open final last week, with Sindhu winning 21-19, 21-16. Marin is confident, saying she's feeling good on court and looking forward to the tough match against Sindhu on Friday.

site_title: Tiny cameras attached to whales offer new insights into their world: 4 other ways conservation and tech mixed in harmony
summary: Scientists attached tiny cameras to humpback whales in Antarctica, gaining unprecedented insights into their behavior without invasive methods. This project is part of a growing trend of using technology to aid environmental conservation, alongside other initiatives such as using drones to pollinate flowers, harnessing computing power for climate prediction, and tracking global forest changes. These projects demonstrate how technology can be used to promote conservation efforts while minimizing human impact.

site_title: DBS seeks to tap US$289 billion opportunity in Indonesian wealth
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Southeast Asia's largest lender, is expanding its wealth business in Indonesia, where a tax amnesty has prompted rich citizens to declare billions of dollars. The acquisition of Australia & New Zealand Banking Group businesses will boost DBS' Indonesian retail and wealth customer base by about six times. DBS plans to offer mobile-banking services and invest in onshore wealth platforms, capitalizing on the market's growth potential. The bank's head of consumer banking and wealth management, Tan Su Shan, expects Indonesia to introduce more products for onshore wealth platforms, making it an attractive investment opportunity.

site_title: North Korea may be preparing its 6th nuclear test
summary: North Korea may be preparing its 6th nuclear test, with satellite images suggesting increased activity at Mount Mantap, a mile-high peak where the country conducts its nuclear tests. The site's debris pile has grown to a football field size, and water is being pumped out of the tunnel system, indicating readiness for a detonation. Experts believe the blast could be as powerful as 282 kilotons, roughly 20 times stronger than the Hiroshima blast. The test could be a celebration of the nation's founder's birthday or a show of military force, with analysts speculating that the country may be focusing on increasing the power and range of its nuclear weapons.

site_title: Jailed former Hong Kong chief executive Donald Tsang sent to hospital over breathing problem
summary: Former Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tsang, serving a 20-month prison term for misconduct, was sent to hospital for treatment on April 13 after experiencing breathing difficulties due to asthma. He was initially treated at the prison's health clinic before being transferred to the Queen Mary Hospital for further examination. Tsang, 72, was convicted of failing to disclose a conflict of interest during rent negotiations for a luxury apartment. He has appealed his conviction and sentence, as well as applied for bail. A hearing is set for April 24.

site_title: Why It Matters (Ep 6): Disappearing Traditions
summary: Over 40 cultural practices and expressions are at risk of disappearing due to industrialization and popular culture. These include traditional local delights like ang ku kueh and Teochew pastries. To address this, UNESCO's intangible cultural heritage list has over 40 items in need of urgent safeguarding. Governments worldwide are taking steps to preserve local traditions, but the rate of disappearance remains a concern. The "Why It Matters" series aims to raise awareness about the importance of preserving cultural heritage and encourage action to prevent further loss.

site_title: European Court of Human Rights finds 'serious failings' by Russia in Beslan school siege
summary: The European Court of Human Rights ruled that Russia's handling of the 2004 Beslan school siege was marred by "serious failings," including failing to disrupt the plot and protect hostages. The court found that Russia's security forces used lethal force unnecessarily, violating the right to life, and that the investigation into the attack was inadequate. The ruling criticized Russia's response to the tragedy, with the Russian justice ministry planning to challenge the decision to a higher chamber. The court's conclusions were met with outrage from Russia, with the Kremlin labeling the ruling "absolutely unacceptable."

site_title: Manager jailed two weeks for driving Nissan GTR in illegal race against Lamborghini
summary: A 37-year-old food and beverage manager, Koo Kwok En, was sentenced to two weeks' jail and fined $2,500 for participating in an illegal high-speed race on Seletar Link in May 2015. Koo drove a Nissan GTR at 219 km/h, surpassing the 60 km/h speed limit, while a Lamborghini driven by Kevin Pratama Chandra reached speeds of over 200 km/h. Koo admitted to the charges and was banned from driving for 18 months, while Kevin is currently claiming trial.

site_title: Football: Juventus lock in striker Paulo Dybala until 2022
summary: Juventus has extended striker Paulo Dybala's contract until June 30, 2022. The Argentine player, 23, has signed a new deal with the Italian football team after a standout performance in the Champions League quarter-final first-leg against Barcelona, where he scored twice to help Juventus win 3-0. As part of the deal, Juventus will pay Palermo an €8 million performance bonus.

site_title: McDonald's Sichuan sauce from 1998 sells for S$20,500 on eBay, China netizens amused
summary: A limited-edition McDonald's "SzeChuan" sauce from 1998 has sold for $20,500 (S$20,500) on eBay after being referenced in the animated sitcom Rick And Morty. The sauce was part of a promotional tie-up with Disney's Mulan film in 1998. The sale sparked amusement among Chinese netizens, with some questioning its authenticity as a representation of Sichuan cuisine. A petition on Change.org has garnered 34,390 supporters, and the news has led to a surge in sales of similar spicy Chinese sauces.

site_title: Football: Chelsea stars Eden Hazard, N'Golo Kante make six-man shortlist for PFA award
summary: Chelsea's Eden Hazard and N'Golo Kante have been shortlisted for the PFA Players' Player of the Year award, along with Tottenham's Harry Kane, Manchester United's Zlatan Ibrahimovic, Everton's Romelu Lukaku, and Arsenal's Alexis Sanchez. Chelsea's title success has been led by Hazard's 14 goals and Kante's contributions as a defensive midfielder. The award winner will be announced on April 23.

site_title: Joseph Schooling on Forbes 30 Under 30 Asia: Entertainment and Sports list
summary: Singapore swimmer Joseph Schooling, 21, has made it to Forbes 30 Under 30 Asia's Entertainment and Sports list for winning Singapore's first Olympic gold medal in Rio last year. He beat Michael Phelps and others in the 100m butterfly final, setting an Olympic record time of 50.39 seconds. Schooling, a junior at the University of Texas, is set to aim for a world record in the 100m butterfly at the Fina World Championships in Budapest, Hungary, this summer.

site_title: 20 places to dine at this long Easter weekend
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several restaurants in Singapore are offering lavish Easter brunches with activities for children, including egg hunts, face painting, and balloon sculpting. The list includes 20 establishments, such as Raffles Hotel, Marina Mandarin, and Shangri-La's Rasa Sentosa Resort & Spa, offering various cuisines and price points. Prices range from $35 to $218 per person, with some restaurants offering free-flowing drinks and champagne. Many restaurants are also offering special deals for children, including kids' meals and Easter-themed activities. These events are available from April 13 to 23, making it a great opportunity for families to celebrate the long weekend.

site_title: Philippines' President Rodrigo Duterte cancels visit to disputed South China Sea island
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte cancelled a planned visit to the disputed South China Sea island of Thitu after Beijing warned him against it. Duterte stated that he will not raise the Philippine flag due to the country's friendship with China, saying "there will likely be trouble" if other heads of state visit the island. The visit was seen as a challenge to China's claims in the South China Sea, through which $5 trillion in trade passes annually. Duterte is on a Middle East state visit to facilitate trade and investments.

site_title: Animal lovers in Malaysia get 2 more outdoor gear brands to drop Singaporean's firm over dog abuse
summary: Malaysia's outdoor gear distributor, Tearproof, has faced backlash from animal lovers after its owner, Terry Yee, was caught on CCTV beating a dog. Three international brands, Osprey Packs, Nalgene, and Craghoppers, have since dropped Tearproof as their distributor due to consumer demands. Yee had apologized for his actions in an interview, but animal lovers continued to protest, citing a lack of honesty and integrity. The Department of Veterinary Services is investigating the case under the Animal Act 1953 for animal cruelty.

site_title: Syria says US strike hit ISIS poison gas depot, killed hundreds; US denies claims
summary: The Syrian army claims a US-led coalition air strike hit an ISIS poison gas depot, killing hundreds, but the US denies the allegations. The Syrian statement, which could not be independently verified, accuses ISIS of possessing chemical weapons. US Air Force Colonel John Dorrian stated that the coalition had no air strikes in the area at the time, calling the Syrian claim "incorrect and likely intentional misinformation." This incident comes after the US launched cruise missiles at a Syrian air base in response to a deadly poison gas attack blamed on President Bashar al-Assad's government.

site_title: North Korea may be capable of sarin-loaded missile attack, says Japan PM Shinzo Abe
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that North Korea may have the capability to launch a sarin-loaded missile attack, citing concerns over the country's missile and nuclear programs. This comes amid rising tensions on the Korean peninsula, with the US deploying a strike group to the region. Sarin, a nerve agent used in deadly attacks in Japan in 1995, has been used in other conflicts, including the 1988 Halabja gas attack by Saddam Hussein's regime and a suspected Syrian government attack last week.

site_title: Hong Kong, Singapore wealth managers may have to disclose fund fees
summary: Hong Kong and Singapore are set to launch new disclosure rules for wealth managers, requiring them to reveal fees they receive from funds to sell their products. The move aims to reveal conflicts of interest and increase transparency, potentially disrupting the $billions-dollar industry. Clients may scrutinize products more closely, leading to lower fees and increased competition among wealth managers, with smaller ones most vulnerable. The rules follow similar initiatives in Western nations and come amid scrutiny of wealth managers' role in promoting high-yielding bonds.

site_title: Three dentists and manager charged with submitting fraudulent Medisave claims
summary: Three Singapore dentists, Steven Ang Kiam Hau, Daniel Liew Yaoxiang, and Cecil Goh Chin Chye, along with manager Yeo Meow Koon, have been charged with submitting fraudulent Medisave claims. The alleged offences took place between 2011 and 2014 and involved 29 patients, totaling $1.2 million in claims. The dentists face up to 10 years in prison and fines for cheating and forgery, with some already having their bail set at $300,000 to $500,000. The case will proceed to a pre-trial conference on May 11.

site_title: Micro:bit launch: What you need to know about the coding gadget Singapore plans to introduce
summary: Singapore to introduce a pocket-sized, codeable computer called the micro:bit to school-going children to instill passion for technology and coding skills. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) and Ministry of Education (MOE) will roll out the device over the next two years as part of the Digital Maker Programme. The micro:bit is a small computer that can be used for various purposes, including communication, gaming, and automation, and is already in use in British schools to teach coding and inspire interest in STEM subjects.

site_title: Badminton: National shuttlers Hee and Tan come close to shock win at S'pore Open
summary: Singaporean badminton players Terry Hee and Tan Wei Han reached the second round of the OUE Singapore Open, the only Singaporean pair to do so. They defeated Singapore's Lok Jian Wen and partner Loh Kean Hean in the first round but lost to China's Lu Kai and Huang Yaqiong in the round of 16, coming within a whisker of a stunning upset. Hee and Tan showed strong form, winning the first set 21-17, but ultimately fell short in the deciding set.

site_title: Thailand kicks off watered down Songkran new year festival amid govt warning
summary: Thailand launched its watered-down Songkran festival amid a government warning to rein in the celebration's usual exuberance, following the country's year of mourning for late King Bhumibol Adulyadej. The military government, led by Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha, cautioned against excessive drinking and advised against wearing skimpy clothing. Despite these warnings, tourists and locals alike are expected to participate in the festival, with the tourism authority anticipating a 10% increase in international visitors to 470,000. The event has become a significant tourist attraction, with its water fights and purification rituals.

site_title: First peeks at latest Galaxy S8 phones at Samsung Galaxy Studio
summary: Samsung has opened its Galaxy Studio in Singapore, allowing visitors to try its latest Galaxy S8 and S8+ smartphones two weeks before its official launch on April 29. The studio features a range of Samsung products, including a 360-degree camera, DeX station, and virtual reality (VR) rides. Visitors can also pre-order the new smartphones and experience VR games with the Gear VR controller. The studio will run until June 29, offering an early look at Samsung's latest offerings and a chance to pre-order the devices.

site_title: Football: Paul Pogba defends Manchester United displays, bemoans high expectations
summary: Manchester United midfielder Paul Pogba defended his performances, stating he's doing a fine job as a midfielder despite high expectations due to his world record transfer fee. Pogba, who has scored just seven goals in 43 appearances, feels critics focus on him scoring goals rather than his overall contribution. He emphasized his role as a midfielder and not being judged as a striker or defender. Pogba's comments come as Manchester United prepares to host Chelsea in the league and face Anderlecht in the Europa League quarter-final.

site_title: The Newsmaker: Kallang slashing victim says 'I bear no grudges, only regret'
summary: Jairus Ang, a 26-year-old Singaporean, shares his story of survival after being brutally assaulted by four construction workers in 2010, resulting in the amputation of his left hand. Seven years on, Ang bears no grudges against his attackers, choosing to focus on his life and career. He has completed his National Service, graduated from the University of Virginia, and started work in the US. Ang's parents also share their journey through the ordeal, and he advises others not to "wallow in self-pity, life is full of opportunities."

site_title: Ringgit is back on investors' radar
summary: Malaysia's ringgit currency is gaining favor among investors after a slump in November, with some analysts predicting it may be one of the region's better performers in coming months. The ringgit has improved due to a stronger economy, increased foreign direct investment, and improved balance of payments. Despite still expecting the currency to weaken against the dollar, analysts now see it falling to 4.46 by mid-year, a smaller decline than earlier predictions. The Malaysian central bank has introduced new measures to revive interest in the country's financial markets, including revising rules to encourage investors to hedge their currency exposure.

site_title: Chemical weapons experts in Turkey to investigate; Britain confirms sarin use
summary: Global chemical weapons investigators have arrived in Turkey to collect samples and interview survivors of an alleged chemical attack in Syria, which killed 87 people. Samples from the site tested positive for sarin, a nerve agent, confirming the first large-scale use of sarin in Syria's civil war since 2013. The OPCW mission will determine if chemical weapons were used, but not assign blame, with findings expected in 3-4 weeks. The attack prompted a US cruise missile strike on a Syrian air base and widened tensions between the US and Russia.

site_title: 10,000 cartons of contraband cigarettes worth $830k in evaded duty, GST seized at Tuas Checkpoint
summary: Singapore authorities seized 10,000 cartons of contraband cigarettes worth $830,000 at Tuas Checkpoint. The cigarettes were hidden among a consignment of "ceramic fibers" declared by a 33-year-old Malaysian driver. The driver and the lorry were handed over to Singapore Customs for investigation. The lorry is liable for forfeiture. The seizure is part of ICA's efforts to prevent smuggling and security threats, with the agency warning that similar concealment methods could be used by terrorists to smuggle arms and explosives. Total evaded duty and GST amount to $776,000 and $57,510 respectively.

site_title: At least 11 dead in two Indonesian boat accidents
summary: At least 11 people were killed in two separate boat accidents in Indonesia, with 9 dying in a river accident and 2 in a sea accident. Five others are missing. The incidents occurred on Java, where boat accidents are common due to poor safety records. Authorities are investigating the causes of the accidents, which occurred when a wooden boat flipped over and a passenger vessel ran into rough waters.

site_title: NBA: Celtics claim Eastern Conference top seed, to face Bulls in first round of playoffs
summary: The Boston Celtics clinched their first Eastern Conference title in nine years with a 112-94 win over the Milwaukee Bucks on the final night of the NBA regular season. The Celtics finished with a 53-29 record, claiming the top seed in the East since 2007-08. The win secured home court advantage through the first three rounds of the playoffs, where they will face the Chicago Bulls. The Cavaliers, without LeBron James, lost to the Toronto Raptors, and the Indiana Pacers defeated the Atlanta Hawks to advance to the playoffs.

site_title: Woman arrested for trying to bribe 3 police officers along Stamford Road
summary: A 29-year-old woman was arrested in Singapore for attempting to bribe three police officers along Stamford Road on April 11. The officers, conducting anti-vice operations, were approached by the woman who offered them money to let her go despite being warned about the seriousness of bribery. The officers rejected the bribe and arrested her. The case has been referred to the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau for investigation, and the woman is also being probed for suspected involvement in prostitution activities under the Women's Charter.

site_title: School Sports: RI boys on target at A Division shooting championships, winning two golds
summary: Raffles Institution (RI) dominated the Schools National A Division shooting championships in Singapore, winning two gold medals. Milford Oh of RI won the boys' 10m air pistol title with a score of 228.2, while Sean Ang also of RI secured the boys' 10m air rifle gold with a score of 242.0. In the girls' categories, Victoria Junior College's Amanda Mak won the 10m air pistol title with 235.3, and Singapore Sports School's Ho Xiu Yi took the 10m air rifle gold with 251.4.

site_title: SMU names new deans for students and international affairs
summary: Singapore Management University (SMU) has appointed Professor Paulin Straughan as the new dean of students, effective July 1. She will take over from Professor Ong Siow Heng, who will become dean of international affairs. Straughan brings over 20 years of experience working with students and has previously served as a faculty member at the National University of Singapore. Ong, who has held the role of dean of students since 2011, will focus on promoting SMU's international profile and reputation. Both appointments are set to take effect in July.

site_title: Athletics: Van Niekerk set for 200m showdown with Bolt and a shot at world c'ship double
summary: South African athlete Wayde van Niekerk will compete in the 200m and 400m events at the 2017 World Championships in London, potentially emulating Michael Johnson's feat of winning both races at the same championships. The 200m heats have been moved to August 7, allowing van Niekerk to face Usain Bolt in what is set to be the Jamaican's final major competition. IAAF president Sebastian Coe expressed excitement over the change, which creates a double header for both athletes and fans. The championships will take place at London's Olympic Stadium from August 4-13.

site_title: Make your own blanket bag for under $40
summary: A fashion journalist, Alyssa Woo, attempts to create a replica of Balenciaga's $2,980 Blanket Square tote using affordable materials from Chinatown in Singapore. Woo's DIY project costs under $40, but she encounters several challenges. The result is a rough approximation of the original bag, with some notable differences. The project offers an affordable alternative for fashion enthusiasts who want to emulate the iconic design without breaking the bank.

site_title: New $21m e-commerce facility at Changi promises faster deliveries to online shoppers
summary: A new $21-million e-commerce facility at Changi Airport is set to reduce delivery times for online shoppers. The facility, operated by Sats, uses automation and technology to process over 1,800 parcels an hour, cutting the turnaround time by half from six hours to three. The development is part of efforts to transform Singapore's aviation sector and enhance its e-commerce capabilities, with the goal of supporting the region's growing e-commerce business. The facility is expected to strengthen Changi Airport's attractiveness and create new job opportunities for Singaporeans.

site_title: All must work to diffuse the Korean Peninsula crisis: China Daily
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping called for a peaceful resolution to the Korean Peninsula crisis, urging all parties to stop fueling the fire and seek a non-military solution. Tensions have escalated with North Korea threatening nuclear attacks and the US dispatching a carrier strike group to the region. However, South Korean officials suggest that no party wants war, and Pyongyang has reinstated its foreign affairs committee, indicating an interest in diplomacy. The international community should work together to stop adding fuel to the fire and focus on a peaceful resolution to the crisis, which would benefit all stakeholders.

site_title: Singapore to use micro:bit to teach coding, nurture its own Steve Jobs
summary: Singapore plans to distribute micro:bit devices to up to 100,000 school-goers and adults to teach coding and inspire interest in STEM subjects. The devices, which contain programmable components and sensors, will be used in a Digital Maker Programme to be rolled out over the next two years. The initiative aims to nurture a passion for technology and prepare Singaporeans for a digital future, with Minister Yaacob Ibrahim citing the potential to produce a future Steve Jobs.

site_title: Singapore container throughput rose 6.9% year on year in March
summary: Container throughput at the Port of Singapore rose 6.9% year-over-year in March, reaching 2.69 million TEUs. This brings the total for the first quarter to 7.61 million TEUs, a 3% increase from the same period last year. March's figure also outpaced February's 2.3 million TEUs by 17.2%, and exceeded March 2016's 2.52 million TEUs by 6.9%. Overall, cargo throughput in March increased 8.8% from February and 6.3% from the same period last year.

site_title: Japan scrambles jet fighters at record pace as Chinese military activity rises
summary: Japan's Air Self Defense Force scrambled fighter jets 1,168 times in the year to March 31, a record pace, as Chinese military activity escalated in the East China Sea. This is 280 more instances than in the previous year, with 851 jets chased away by Chinese planes. The uptick in Chinese activity is part of a push to extend military influence in the region, where Japan controls an island chain. Japan's top military commander warned that Chinese planes are now closer to the main Okinawa island and other parts of the island chain, raising tensions in East Asia.

site_title: Investigators clear detained ‘Islamist’ over Dortmund blasts
summary: German federal prosecutors have cleared the sole suspect in custody, Abdul Beset A., of involvement in the bomb attack against Borussia Dortmund's football team bus in 2017. Investigators had initially called the attack a "terrorist" incident and were focusing on suspects in the "Islamist spectrum." However, no evidence was found to link A. to the attack, and an arrest warrant is still being sought for alleged ties to the Islamic State. The incident left one player, Marc Bartra, and a policeman injured, and Dortmund officials criticized the decision to play the postponed Champions League match just 24 hours after the attack.

site_title: New Zealand battens down as big storm approaches, extreme weather alerts in place for North Island
summary: New Zealand is bracing for a potentially catastrophic storm, Cyclone Cook, which is expected to make landfall on Thursday night, bringing extreme weather conditions. The storm, which has generated offshore winds of over 170 kmh, is predicted to produce five-meter swells, torrential rain, and gale-force winds, potentially causing widespread flooding, landslides, and wind damage. The storm is considered the worst in nearly 50 years, with emergency services pre-emptively evacuating small coastal communities and the military assisting relief efforts.

site_title: SGH chief executive to step down after nine years at the helm
summary: Professor Ang Chong Lye, Singapore General Hospital's (SGH) chief executive for nearly a decade, will step down next month. He will be succeeded by Professor Kenneth Kwek, his current deputy at SGH. Kwek, who has also served as chief executive of KK Women's and Children's Hospital, will relinquish the KKH post upon taking over. Group chief executive Ivy Ng praised Ang's leadership, citing his strong sense of duty and engagement with staff, which contributed to SGH's success.

site_title: People with disabilities to get more help in using assistive technology
summary: Singapore's government has announced initiatives to provide more support for people with disabilities to use assistive technology. The Enable IT Scheme will double grants to $100,000 per project, helping 3,000 more beneficiaries over four years. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) is partnering with tech companies to train "assistive technology ambassadors" to spread awareness of built-in accessibility features, starting with Apple and Microsoft. Workshops, such as the recent one for visually-impaired participants, are also being conducted to educate users on using built-in assistive technology features on devices like the iPad.

site_title: US takes sharper tone on Russia's role in Syria
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and President Donald Trump criticized Russia for backing Syrian President Bashar Assad, calling him an "animal." Trump said Russia likely knew about the chemical attack and denounced Putin, but Tillerson and other officials avoided blaming Moscow for foreknowledge. Russia vetoed a UN resolution condemning the attack, and China abstained for the first time. The US and Russia are at an "all-time low" in their relationship, with no visible warming of ties. Trump praised NATO as a vital force for peace and security, reversing his previous criticism of the alliance.

site_title: No facts suggest Russia meddling in US election: Lavrov
summary: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov stated that there is no evidence or fact to suggest Russia interfered in the US election, contrary to US intelligence agency accusations. Lavrov emphasized that Russia has requested evidence to support the allegations, but none has been provided. The US Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson, was present at the news conference, but no joint statement or agreement was reached on the matter.

site_title: Bike-sharing start-up oBike officially launches, to offer Tampines residents free one-month usage
summary: Singapore's bike-sharing start-up oBike officially launched, partnering with Tampines Town Council to promote bike-sharing in the estate. Residents will receive a month of free usage, while new demarcated zones will provide more parking areas. The company aims to deploy "tens of thousands" bicycles, with rentals starting at 50 cents for 15 minutes. To encourage responsible use, oBike will work with cycling ambassadors and introduce a points system, deducting 20 points for non-designated parking or unlocked bikes, potentially increasing rental rates for users with negative scores.

site_title: Malaysian Red Shirts leader, 9 supporters charged with rioting and disrupting peace
summary: Datuk Seri Jamal Md Yunos, leader of the Malaysian Red Shirts, and nine supporters were charged with rioting and disrupting peace in a Sessions Court in Ampang. They were charged under Section 147 of the Penal Code and Section 14 of the Minor Offences Act 1955. The charges stem from an incident on November 13 last year, where the Red Shirts clashed with police and Bersih supporters, resulting in two arrests and Jamal suffering a bloodied nose. The trial began on April 13, with bail set at RM3,000 in one surety each.

site_title: Inaugural Home Team gala show taking place in May to mark NS50 and pay tribute to officers
summary: The inaugural Home Team Show and Festival (HTSF) is set to take place from May 3 to 7 to mark the 50th anniversary of National Service and the 20th anniversary of the Home Team. The biennial festival will feature a multimedia extravaganza, a parade, and a live telecast on Channel 5. The event will showcase the stories of Home Team officers, their challenges, and their commitment, with a simulated terrorist attack scenario. President Tony Tan Keng Yam is the guest of honour, and performances by Dick Lee and Taufik Batisah will be part of the show.

site_title: Making a life in workaholic S. Korea: The Korea Herald Columnist
summary: A South Korean man, Lee Joo-hee, reminisces about the country's work culture in the 1970s, where employees were expected to work seven days a week. He recalls feeling rushed and anxious, sacrificing his personal life for his job. In contrast, his son Lee Joon-seong describes a similar work culture, with long hours and low pay. The country's labor market efficiency ranks 77th globally, and irregular workers are common. Joon-seong considers relocating for a better work-life balance and a healthier environment for his child. His story highlights the struggles of working in a country with an intense work culture.

site_title: French presidential race tightens, markets nervous over popularity of far-left Jean-Luc Melenchon
summary: French presidential candidate Jean-Luc Melenchon's surge in the polls has tightened the campaign, with financial markets growing nervous about his far-left popularity. Melenchon's 18.5% support has surpassed that of centrist Emmanuel Macron, while Marine Le Pen's 23.5% remains one point ahead. The top two candidates will proceed to a runoff on May 7, with polls indicating Macron would easily beat Le Pen. Investors are concerned about the potential for a Le Pen victory, which could pressure the EU, and Melenchon's rising popularity has led to speculation about potential endorsements from outgoing Socialist President Francois Hollande.

site_title: China's foreign minister says force cannot resolve North Korea issue, expects opportunity for talks
summary: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi stated that military force cannot resolve the North Korea issue, expecting an opportunity for talks to arise amid current tensions. He also said whoever provoked the situation would have to assume historical responsibility for it. A Chinese state-backed newspaper suggested North Korea give up its nuclear program, with China promising to protect a denuclearized North Korea if it complies. The US has diverted a US aircraft carrier group towards the Korean peninsula, raising concerns of a potential military response to North Korea's nuclear tests or missile launches.

site_title: Rex Tillerson: Assad may face war crimes charge in future
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson stated that Syrian President Bashar al-Assad may face war crimes charges in the future. This comment came during a press conference with Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov in Moscow. Tillerson emphasized that the charges were not imminent but acknowledged the Trump administration's pursuit of such charges. Russia, however, disputes the US claim that Assad's military was responsible for a suspected gas poisoning in Syria's Idlib province, and claims to have evidence that Syrian rebels possess chemical weapons, calling for an independent investigation.

site_title: Britney Spears announces Asian dates, could play in Singapore
summary: American pop star Britney Spears has announced several Asian dates in June, including Hong Kong on June 27, and is likely to include a stop in Singapore. The tour also includes dates in Japan and the Philippines. Spears could perform at either the Singapore Indoor Stadium or National Stadium in June, which have available schedules. This would be her first full concert in Singapore, following her massive pop hits and her recent album, Glory, which reached the top three on the US and British charts.

site_title: Dead body found in Singapore River; police investigating unnatural death
summary: A dead body of a Chinese man in his 60s was found in the Singapore River on April 13 morning by a cleaner. The victim was pronounced dead at the scene, and a cordon was set up at Esplanade Park. Police were alerted at 8am, and two boatmen were seen being questioned by policemen. The cause of death is being investigated as unnatural, and forensic work is underway.

site_title: Bigger BCA Gallery launched after revamp
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) Gallery in Singapore has launched a revamped, two-storey exhibition featuring six zones with distinct themes and interactive exhibits. The gallery, which opened on April 13, aims to educate the public on the importance of the building and construction industry in shaping Singapore's development. The upgraded gallery showcases the industry's progress, achievements, and future trends, with features such as a sensory garden and a "swipe wall" with iconic building photos. The gallery is free to visit and open from 10am to 5pm on weekdays, except for public holidays.

site_title: New video shows United Airlines passenger David Dao telling police officer: 'I'm staying... you'll have to drag me'
summary: A new video shows Dr. David Dao, a Vietnamese-American passenger, arguing with security officers before being forcibly removed from a United Airlines flight at Chicago O'Hare International Airport. Dao, a physician, refused to leave his seat despite being told he would have to be dragged off. He was heard saying "I'm staying... you'll have to drag me" as he was dragged down the aisle. The incident has led to widespread outrage, with calls to boycott the airline and charges of racism. United has apologized and is reviewing its policy on bumping passengers off flights.

site_title: Amos Yee prosecuted for hate speech, not political dissent: Singapore to The Economist
summary: Singapore's High Commissioner for London, Ms Foo Chi Hsia, disputes The Economist's claim that blogger Amos Yee was prosecuted for political dissent, stating that he was charged for hate speech against Christians and Muslims. In contrast, a US immigration judge granted Yee asylum, citing persecution for his political opinions. Yee had made vicious statements about Christians and Muslims, including calling Jesus Christ "power hungry and malicious." Singapore's laws on contempt do not prevent fair criticisms of court judgments, and Ms Foo defends the country's stance on hate speech, citing the fragility of racial and religious harmony.

site_title: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un oversees special forces operation
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un supervised a special forces operation, according to state media. The operation involved commando troops dropping from planes and destroying enemy targets, with Kim praising their precision. The move comes amid heightened tensions with the US over Pyongyang's nuclear program, with US President Donald Trump deploying a naval armada to the Korean peninsula. North Korea has threatened war with the US, and China is urging a peaceful resolution. The situation remains volatile, with speculation of a potential nuclear or missile test by North Korea.

site_title: Technology initiatives unveiled as part of 'prison without guards' transformation
summary: Singapore's Prison Service is transforming into a "prison without guards" through technology initiatives. By 2018, officers will use wrist tags with embedded chips to remotely track inmates' attendance and activities. Mobile devices will provide access to inmates' data and enable officers to capture information into the prison management system. The Digital Rehabilitation Records Management System will track inmate activities through near field communications technology, and a body scanner will be introduced to screen for hidden objects. The goal is to free up officers' time for higher-order jobs, such as rehabilitation and data analysis.

site_title: Prada earnings slide to lowest since IPO on slump in Asian luxury demand
summary: Prada reported its lowest full-year profit since its 2011 IPO, with net income falling 16% to €278.3 million ($295 million) in the year through January. The company attributed the decline to a slump in Asian luxury demand, particularly in Asia, where it generates about half its revenue. However, recent indicators suggest a turnaround, with sales returning to growth in January and double-digit growth in mainland China and Europe. Prada raised its dividend and plans to boost e-commerce and social media engagement to speed up recovery.

site_title: President Donald Trump u-turns on 6 issues
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a series of U-turns on key issues, including NATO, China, Russia, Syria, Janet Yellen, and the Export-Import Bank. Trump declared NATO is "no longer obsolete" after criticizing its outdatedness, and stated China is not a currency manipulator, reversing his campaign promise. He also expressed concerns about Russia's actions in Syria and questioned the US-Russia relationship, but praised China's President Xi Jinping for his efforts on North Korea. Additionally, Trump expressed support for Janet Yellen's Federal Reserve chair position and the Export-Import Bank, reversing his previous opposition.

site_title: China March exports jump 16.4%, trade surplus with US rises to US$17.7b
summary: China's March exports rose 16.4% year-over-year, exceeding market expectations, while imports increased 20.3%. The country's trade surplus with the US rose to $17.74 billion, a significant jump from February. China's overall trade surplus was $23.93 billion, driven by strong demand for commodities. The US has been pressing China to reduce its trade surplus, which stood at $347 billion last year, and the two countries agreed on a 100-day plan for trade talks.

site_title: Jay Chou back for another show here on Jan 6 at National Stadium
summary: Taiwanese singer Jay Chou is set to return to Singapore on January 6, 2018, for "The Invincible" Part 2 concert at the National Stadium. The event follows the success of his previous concert in the same venue last year, which was marred by poor sound quality. The show has sold out in every leg, including a performance in London's SSE Arena, Wembley. Ticketing details for the Singapore concert will be released later, with the same promoter, Multimedia Entertainment, handling the event.

site_title: Samsung says Galaxy S8 pre-orders exceed S7
summary: Pre-orders for Samsung's Galaxy S8 smartphone have exceeded those of its predecessor S7, according to mobile business chief Koh Dong-jin. The S8, set to launch on April 21, has been well-received and is expected to help Samsung recover from the Note7 recall. Analysts predict the company will record its best-ever quarterly profit in April-June, driven by strong S8 sales and a booming memory chip market. The S8 features larger curved screens and safety measures to address previous battery issues, and will be marketed in China to regain market share.

site_title: China warns against force as North Korea prepares celebration
summary: China has warned against the use of military force to resolve tensions with North Korea, stating that it cannot resolve the issue. Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi said that military force would only lead to more problems, and that talks leading to a peaceful resolution and denuclearization of the peninsula are the best option. Meanwhile, the US has diverted an aircraft carrier group towards the Korean peninsula, with US officials focusing on tougher economic sanctions. North Korea has threatened to conduct a nuclear test or more missile launches, despite warnings from the US and UN. China has urged North Korea to suspend its nuclear activities, promising to protect it if it complies.

site_title: World Bank maintains 2017 East Asia growth outlook, sees central bank policy risks
summary: The World Bank has maintained its 2017 economic growth forecast for developing East Asia and the Pacific at 6.2%, with growth expected to slow to 6.1% in 2018. The region is vulnerable to global trade slowdowns and tightening financial conditions, which could pose risks to growth. The World Bank advises countries to adjust monetary policies, particularly in Indonesia and the Philippines, to address rising inflationary pressures. A sharp slowdown in global trade, especially in China, could also impact the region's growth outlook.

site_title: MMA: Holly Holm to star at UFC Singapore Fight Night on June 17
summary: Former UFC bantamweight champion Holly Holm will headline the UFC Singapore Fight Night on June 17, facing Bethe Correia in a bantamweight bout. This will be Holm's first fight since her last loss in 2017, and she looks to end her three-fight losing streak. The event also features other notable matchups, including Rafael dos Anjos vs. Tarec Saffiedine and Andrei Arlovski vs. Marcin Tybura.

site_title: Meet S.H.E singer Ella Chen's newborn baby boy
summary: Singer Ella Chen has given birth to a baby boy, her first child, weighing 3.088kg and measuring 48cm. The newborn, nicknamed "Strong Baby," was put on a respirator due to choking on amniotic fluid and meconium, but is otherwise fine. Chen had a natural birth without an epidural, after initially trying for a water birth. Her husband, Alvin Lai, and S.H.E bandmates were present at the hospital.

site_title: Toshiba's plans for chip sale hit snag as Western Digital objects
summary: Toshiba's chip sale plans hit a snag as joint-venture partner Western Digital Corp objects to the sale, citing a potential contract violation. Western Digital CEO Steve Milligan advised Toshiba's board to negotiate exclusively with his company before any sale. Analysts warn that Western Digital has legal rights to veto or approve a winning bid, potentially blocking the sale. Toshiba disagrees with Western Digital's assertion and shares have dropped 3.1% in Tokyo trading. The chip business sale is crucial for Toshiba to raise much-needed cash and avoid financial collapse.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.35% higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.35% higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,186.01 points, up 11.26 points. Around 129.1 million shares were traded, with 98 losers compared to 57 gainers.

site_title: Permanent decal to be displayed by private-hire cars from July 1
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore will require private-hire drivers to display a permanent decal on their car's windscreen starting July 1. The 14cm by 10cm tamper-evident decal helps identify registered private-hire cars and facilitates enforcement against unregistered cars providing chauffeured services or picking up passengers by street-hail. Owners of registered vehicles before Feb 28, 2017, will receive decals at no cost, while those registered after will have to pay $20. Failure to affix the decal will be an offence under the Road Traffic Act.

site_title: Chinese woman's face to be re-built with nose and lips grown on chest
summary: A 27-year-old Chinese woman, Jin Qi, underwent a 10-hour surgery in Shanghai to rebuild her lower face, which was severely damaged at the age of one due to a rare illness. The surgery involved transplanting her nose and lips from her chest, cultivated using tissue grown on her body. The procedure, which will be repeated over six months, aims to correct maxillary deformities and is a first for a patient who lost facial organs at such a young age. The surgery uses 3D printing technology to fashion implants.

site_title: MAS policy decision, GDP data: Analyst reactions
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) maintained its monetary policy unchanged, with the Singapore dollar expected to appreciate at zero percent. The decision follows a slightly less-than-expected 2.5% year-on-year economic growth in the first quarter of 2017. Analysts, including ANZ Research's Ng Wei Wen and OCBC's Selena Ling, expressed cautious views on growth and inflation, citing structural headwinds such as a tight labor market and declining housing rents. The MAS will continue its neutral stance until at least October 2017, according to Westpac senior currency strategist Sean Callow.

site_title: Angela Merkel says China, US can sway North Korea with political pressure
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel urged the US and China to apply political pressure on North Korea to resolve its nuclear program peacefully. She stated that trust should be placed in diplomatic efforts rather than military means. Merkel expressed confidence that joint pressure from China and the US would have consequences for North Korea. This comes as US President Donald Trump's aircraft carrier strike group approaches the region, following a call from Chinese President Xi Jinping for a peaceful resolution of tensions on the Korean peninsula.

site_title: United Airlines to reimburse all passengers on flight that caused uproar
summary: United Airlines will reimburse all 70 passengers on the overbooked flight where a doctor was forcibly removed from his seat, following a public relations backlash. The refund comes after a series of botched responses from the airline, including CEO Oscar Munoz's initial comments that sparked global condemnation. The move is seen as a step to regain consumer goodwill, with travel industry experts saying it may not fully repair the damage, but will help. The airline's efforts to apologize and make amends have been welcomed, with Munoz expressing remorse and the Chicago Department of Aviation placing two officers on leave amid its review of the incident.

site_title: Australia's central bank intensifies alert on rising household debt, escalating property prices
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia has intensified its warning on rising household debt and escalating property prices in Sydney and Melbourne. The central bank noted that interest-only loans now account for almost a quarter of owner-occupier mortgages and that about one-third of mortgage holders have no buffer or less than one month's repayments. Lending restrictions have been tightened, with lenders restricted to 30% interest-only loans and stricter scrutiny of loans over 90% of a property's value. The RBA also warned of elevated financial stability risks in China, citing shadow banking and a potential for "financial distress" that could impact Australia and other economies.

site_title: North Korea's 'big and important event' turns out to be showpiece housing project
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un opened a prestigious housing project in Pyongyang, dubbed Ryomyong Street, on April 13, 2017. The 70-storey tower complex, featuring nearly 5,000 apartments, was touted as a symbol of the country's prosperity and modernity. The event aimed to burnish North Korea's image amidst mounting tensions over its nuclear ambitions, with US President Donald Trump dispatching an aircraft carrier group to the Korean peninsula. The project's unveiling was seen as a demonstration of the "do or die" spirit of the North Korean people and army, and Kim's efforts to counter international sanctions.

site_title: Fully pedestrianised Orchard Road being explored in long term to refresh premier shopping belt: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's premier shopping belt, Orchard Road, is being explored for full pedestrianization as part of plans to refresh the precinct. The Urban Redevelopment Authority and Land Transport Authority are working with the private sector to make the area more pedestrian-friendly, with options including a road reduction program and expanding the pedestrian mall. The Singapore Tourism Board aims to introduce a scramble crossing and minimize visual barriers, encouraging experiential concepts and street-level pop-up activations. The government also plans to allocate $10 million for the Kickstart Fund, which supports innovative lifestyle concepts, and invest in digital platforms to harness technology and data for future growth.

site_title: Donald Trump says prepared to take on North Korea without China if needed
summary: US President Donald Trump stated on April 12 that the US is prepared to tackle the North Korea crisis without China's support if necessary. Trump made the comments during a joint news conference with Nato Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg, following a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping the previous week. Trump expressed confidence in Xi's willingness to help with North Korea, but also emphasized that the US is capable of handling the situation alone.

site_title: Asian stocks slide as US dollar slumps on Trump talk
summary: Asian stocks slid on Thursday as the US dollar weakened against major currencies following President Donald Trump's comments that the greenback was getting too strong. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index fell 0.4% and US Treasury bond yields dropped to their lowest level this year, reducing the risk of China dumping its Treasury holdings. Global markets are entering a key period with earnings season and mounting geopolitical tensions, while Trump's struggle to push through his fiscal agenda clouds the picture.

site_title: North Korea is ready to launch nuclear test at Punggye-ri site: Report
summary: North Korea is reportedly ready to launch a nuclear test at its Punggye-ri site, according to a 38 North monitoring group report. The test site is described as "primed and ready" with increased activity, and the US fears that Pyongyang may soon develop an intercontinental ballistic missile. The US has warned Pyongyang that military options remain on the table, with President Trump stating that a strike group, including the USS Carl Vinson supercarrier, is heading to the Korean peninsula as a show of force. A potential nuclear test is speculated to coincide with Kim Il Sung's 105th birthday.

site_title: Graphene-oxide 'sieve' could lower cost of desalination
summary: Scientists at the University of Manchester have developed graphene-oxide membranes that can efficiently filter salt from seawater, potentially lowering the cost of desalination. The membranes, which are the world's thinnest material, can separate salt from water molecules at an unprecedented level, allowing water to flow anomalously fast through the membrane. This technology could provide millions with clean drinking water, making it an ideal solution for desalination, a currently expensive process.

summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has kept its exchange rate policy unchanged, citing modest improvements in economic growth and inflation. The central bank attributes Singapore's uneven growth to trade-related sectors, while higher oil prices have pushed up inflation. The MAS maintains its policy stance, a "neutral" policy, with the Singdollar policy band on a path of zero appreciation against key trading partners. Economic growth is forecast at 1-3% this year, similar to the 2% expansion in 2016.

The win left the tie in balance ahead of the second leg in England on April 18, as Leicester seeks to maintain their fairytale run in their first season in the elite club competition.

site_title: Ooho! You can eat this water bottle and save the earth
summary: A biodegradable water bottle called Ooho, made from seaweed and calcium chloride, has won a European Union competition for sustainable products. The edible bottle can be consumed and is hygienic, costing just one penny to make. It features a double membrane that contains water, similar to an orange, and can be produced in large quantities with a sustainability grant. The innovative design aims to reduce plastic waste, with over 800,000 tonnes generated in Singapore in 2015. Ooho's potential to replace plastic water bottles is being explored by its manufacturer, Skipping Rocks Lab.

summary: President Donald Trump distanced himself from chief strategist Steve Bannon, downplaying his role in the White House during an interview with the New York Post. Trump's comments also appear to target Bannon's close relationship with the media, with Kellyanne Conway making similar remarks, further indicating a rift between the two.

site_title: Football: Ronaldo hits 100th Euro goal as Real down Bayern 2-1 in Champions League
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo scored his 100th European goal as Real Madrid came from behind to defeat 10-man Bayern Munich 2-1 in the Champions League quarter-final first leg. Arturo Vidal gave Bayern the lead in the first half, but Ronaldo equalized before Bayern's Javi Martinez was sent off. Ronaldo then scored the winner 13 minutes from time, giving Real a crucial advantage heading into the second leg.

site_title: Singapore's GDP growth eases to 2.5% in Q1: Flash data
summary: Singapore's economy grew 2.5% in Q1, slightly lower than expected, according to advance estimates from the Ministry of Trade and Industry. This eased from the 2.9% growth in the previous quarter. Despite a 1.9% contraction in the quarter, the pace remains at the higher end of the government's 1-3% forecast for the year. The manufacturing sector expanded 6.6% year-over-year, while the construction sector contracted 1.1% and the services sector grew 1.5%. Private economists now forecast 2.3% growth for 2017, up from 1.5% previously.

site_title: Trump sends US dollar sliding after saying it's 'too strong'
summary: US President Donald Trump's comments that the US dollar is "too strong" led to a significant drop in the dollar's value, with the US dollar index falling 0.5% to its lowest level since late March. Treasury bond yields also dropped to a near five-month low, with benchmark 10-year yields falling 3 basis points to 2.268%. The dollar's decline was accompanied by a decline in global equity markets, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.29% and the S&P 500 losing 0.38%. The comments also reduced the risk of China retaliating against the US by labeling it a currency manipulator.

site_title: Donald Trump says China is not a currency manipulator
summary: US President Donald Trump reversed his stance on China, stating they are not manipulating their currency to gain a trade advantage. This comes after his meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Florida. Trump said China has not been manipulating its currency for months, contradicting economists who have been making this point. He also left open the possibility of renominating Janet Yellen as head of the Federal Reserve, reversing his previous criticism of her. Trump's comments may deflate anticipation for the Treasury Department's report on foreign exchange policies.

site_title: Jeff Koons unveils new project - painting handbags for LV
summary: US artist Jeff Koons has unveiled a new project, a series of luxury handbags in collaboration with French fashion house Louis Vuitton. The collection, titled "Masters," features 51 pieces, including handbags, scarves, and small leather goods, inspired by five famous paintings, including the Mona Lisa. Koons' designs feature gold or silver lettering and his signature reflective gold or silver accents. The collection will be sold in select Vuitton stores and a pop-up store in New York, with no online sales. Koons' collaboration with Vuitton has sparked debate about the commercialization of art, but both parties argue that it aims to make great art more accessible to a wider audience.

site_title: Nato 'no longer obsolete', says Donald Trump in reversal of campaign rhetoric
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that NATO is "no longer obsolete" during a news conference with Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg, reversing campaign rhetoric. Trump emphasized the importance of meeting financial obligations and paying 2% of GDP to military expenditure. He also acknowledged NATO's role in combating terrorism, but expressed concerns about strained ties with Russia. Trump expressed a desire for improved relations with Russia, despite being at an "all-time low" in their relationship. The US reaffirmed its commitment to NATO's security, with Stoltenberg welcoming the strong commitment to Europe's security.

site_title: Philippine's Duterte pulls back from Spratlys flag vow
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has pulled back from a vow to place the country's flag on a disputed island in the Spratlys chain, citing a desire to improve relations with China. He initially stated that he would occupy the islands and raise the flag on June 12, but later clarified that he meant to upgrade existing facilities on occupied islands. The move was seen as a concession to China, which Duterte has been wooing since taking office, and is expected to lead to improved trade and investment.

site_title: US stocks fall on uncertainty on Syria, Trump agenda
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday, April 12, amid concerns over Syria and President Trump's economic agenda. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.3%, the S&P 500 fell 0.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index tumbled 0.5%. Analysts cited geopolitical worries and doubts over tax cuts, with industrial shares, such as Caterpillar and Boeing, taking a hit. Tesla also plummeted 3.9% after a group of investors lobbied for new board members. The decline follows a rally in stocks earlier in the year, with investors anxious about the Trump administration's ability to pass a tax plan.

site_title: Football: Mbappe strikes twice as Monaco stun Dortmund 3-2 day after bus attack
summary: Kylian Mbappe scored twice as Monaco stunned Borussia Dortmund 3-2 in the Champions League quarter-final first leg, despite the team bus attack on Tuesday. Dortmund coach Thomas Tuchel criticized the game's rescheduling, but Monaco took advantage of the early goals, with Mbappe also scoring in the second half. The win puts Monaco in a strong position to advance to the semi-finals, despite being without midfielder Fabinho due to suspension. The match came just one day after three explosions rocked Dortmund's team bus, leaving Spain international Marc Bartra with a broken wrist.

site_title: Is it too late now to say sorry: A guide to bad apologies in 3 acts
summary: A series of public relations blunders sparked widespread outrage, with Pepsi, Faves Asia, and United Airlines drawing criticism for insensitive and tone-deaf responses to backlash. Pepsi's ad co-opting Black Lives Matter, Faves Asia's materialistic portrayal of social media influencers, and United Airlines' violent removal of a passenger from a plane led to failed apologies. The examples highlight common mistakes in apologizing, including apologizing to the wrong person, suspending reality, and being "sorry, not sorry." Ultimately, these incidents demonstrate how apologies can backfire, leading to further outrage and damage to reputation.

site_title: Putin says trust erodes under Trump, Moscow icily receives Tillerson
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that trust has eroded between the US and Russia under President Donald Trump, citing the recent missile strike on Syria. During Secretary of State Rex Tillerson's visit to Moscow, Putin reiterated Russia's support for Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, denying blame for the suspected chemical attack. Despite some progress on Syria, tensions remained high, with Moscow delivering an icy reception to Tillerson. The visit dashed hopes for improved relations between the two countries, which had been on the rise following Trump's election.

site_title: Jude Law cast as young Dumbledore in next Fantastic Beasts movie
summary: British actor Jude Law will play a young version of Albus Dumbledore in the second Fantastic Beasts movie, set 70 years before the events of the Harry Potter series. The film, written by J.K. Rowling, follows Dumbledore's character decades before he became Hogwarts' headmaster. Law joins the cast of the franchise, which has already grossed over $813 million at the global box office. The sequel, titled but not yet released, is set to debut in November 2018.

site_title: Trump broke news of Syria air strikes to China's Xi over 'most beautiful piece of chocolate cake you have ever seen'
summary: US President Donald Trump revealed that he broke the news of air strikes on Syria to Chinese President Xi Jinping over dessert, saying Xi paused for 10 seconds before asking for clarification. Trump described Xi as being "OK" with the Syrian regime's brutal actions, sparking criticism from China experts who say Xi would have preferred a more discreet briefing. Despite this, China's leaders have spun Xi as "Trump's equal" in domestic media, capitalizing on the summit to drive a wedge between the US and Russia.

site_title: United Airlines passenger launches legal action over forceful removal
summary: A United Airlines passenger, Dr. David Dao, was forcibly removed from a flight in Chicago on April 9, sparking widespread outrage and calls for a boycott. Dao's lawyers filed an emergency request to preserve video recordings and evidence related to the incident, citing "serious prejudice" to their client. United CEO Oscar Munoz apologized and announced the airline would no longer use law enforcement officers to remove passengers from overbooked flights. The incident has led to increased scrutiny of the airline's practices and calls for new rules to regulate overbooking.

site_title: Football: British police to impose vehicle restrictions for Champions League final
summary: British authorities plan to restrict vehicle access to certain areas in Cardiff during the Champions League final on June 3, following the attack on Borussia Dortmund's team bus in April. The measure aims to enhance sports security after three blasts targeted the Bundesliga side's coach. Authorities, including police and security forces, have been preparing for months and are working together to ensure a safe and secure environment for the final.

site_title: Football: Dortmund's Bartra doing 'much better' after wrist surgery
summary: Borussia Dortmund defender Marc Bartra reported doing "much better" after undergoing surgery for a broken wrist and shrapnel in his arm, sustained in the team bus attack with explosives on April 11. Bartra joined Dortmund from Barcelona in August 2016 and was giving a thumbs-up in a photo posted on Instagram after his surgery. The match against AS Monaco, initially scheduled for April 11, has been rescheduled for Wednesday at Signa Iduna Park.

site_title: Malala Yousafzai becomes honorary Canadian citizen
summary: Nobel Peace laureate Malala Yousafzai has been awarded honorary Canadian citizenship, becoming the youngest person to receive the honor at 19 years old. Yousafzai, a Pakistani activist, condemned violence and called on Canada to lead in advocating for girls' education, saying "If Canada leads, I know the world will follow." She also urged world leaders to prioritize education for all children, particularly refugees. The honorary citizenship was granted during a ceremony at the Canadian parliament, where Yousafzai was welcomed by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and received a standing ovation.
