site_title: Lack of clarity on Toshiba earnings audit is a problem: Japan finance minister
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso expressed concern over Toshiba's delayed business results, citing a lack of clarity on why auditors did not sign off. The filing, without an auditor's endorsement, increases the likelihood of Toshiba's delisting from the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Aso warned that this could fuel speculation about Japan's auditing standards, potentially eroding investor confidence. The crisis stems from Westinghouse Electric Co.'s nuclear unit problems, with estimated annual losses of $9 billion. Authorities must weigh the pros and cons of delisting, which could complicate Toshiba's crisis and expose it to further lawsuits.

site_title: Remember Tamagotchi? The 1990s' cult toys are back
summary: Tamagotchi, the 1990s virtual pet toy, has made a comeback in its original form to celebrate its 20th anniversary. The new version features monochrome, retro graphics and six characters, available on Amazon Japan for approximately $18. This release marks a return to the toy's iconic egg-shaped design and care requirements, including feeding, playing, and administering medicine. The original Tamagotchi launched in Japan in 1996 and sparked a worldwide craze, with a shortage in 1997 leading to lotteries and a thriving black market.

site_title: United Airlines CEO says sorry over rough handling of passenger, family appreciates outpouring of support
summary: United Airlines CEO Oscar Munoz apologized for the rough handling of a passenger, David Dao, who was dragged off a plane after refusing to give up his seat. Dao, a 69-year-old Vietnamese-American doctor, had been bumped from the flight due to overbooking. Munoz promised a thorough review of the airline's practices and acknowledged the company's initial response was inadequate. The incident sparked widespread outrage and calls for boycotts, with the US Department of Transportation promising a review of the airline's actions. The airline's stock plummeted 2.9% in afternoon trading.

site_title: Important to know contributions of other ethnic groups
summary: Singapore's Eurasian community has made significant contributions to the country, despite being one of the smallest ethnic groups. Notable figures include swimmer Joseph Schooling, musician Jeremy Monteiro, and lawyer Annabel Pennefather. Prominent past figures include late PM founding member K.M. Byrne, first Commissioner of Police John Le Cain, and sports legends Lloyd Valberg, Frederick de Souza, Wilfred Skinner, and Mary Klass. The article highlights the importance of appreciating and learning from each other's heritage in a multiracial society, with PM Lee Beng emphasizing the value of the Eurasian community's contributions to Singapore's success.

site_title: Trailblazing idol drama Meteor Garden getting S$33-million reboot
summary: Meteor Garden, a 2001 Taiwanese idol drama, is getting a S$33-million reboot 16 years after its initial release. Creator Angie Chai announced the project on Weibo, with a new 48-episode adaptation of the Japanese comic series Boys Over Flowers. The reboot will be made by Chinese companies and will feature a new cast, with Chai leaving the door open for potential cameos by the original F4 members. The project is expected to start filming in the second half of the year and will premiere in 2018.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, April 12 edition
summary: Borussia Dortmund's soccer team bus was targeted with explosives, injuring one player, Marc Bartra, during a Champions League game against AS Monaco. White House spokesman Sean Spicer sparked outrage by downplaying Adolf Hitler's use of chemical weapons, while United Airlines CEO Oscar Munoz apologized for a passenger being dragged off a plane. Caitlyn Jenner revealed she underwent genital surgery, stating she did it to "stop staring." Juventus defeated Barcelona 3-0 in a Champions League quarter-final match, with Paulo Dybala scoring two goals.

site_title: Magnitude 6.0 quake hits the Philippines: USGS
summary: A 5.6-magnitude earthquake struck the center of Mindanao island in the Philippines on April 12, initially reported as a magnitude 6.0. The quake was very shallow, at a depth of 6km, amplifying its effect. Its epicentre was 5.5km north-east of Cotabato on the southern island of Mindanao, causing considerable damage.

site_title: US-Russia tensions over Syria will not 'spiral out of control' - Jim Mattis
summary: US Defence Secretary Jim Mattis stated that tensions between the US and Russia will not "spiral out of control" following the US cruise missile strike on a Syrian air base. Mattis described the strike as a one-off measure to deter Syria's use of chemical weapons. He expressed confidence that Russia will act in its own best interest and avoid escalating the situation, citing no incentive for Russia to want the situation to worsen. The strike occurred in response to a chemical attack in Syria, and Mattis aimed to reassure that the US action was not a sign of escalating conflict.

site_title: White House spokesman Sean Spicer apologises for 'insensitive' remarks comparing Assad to Hitler
summary: White House spokesman Sean Spicer apologized for "insensitive" remarks comparing Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to Adolf Hitler, saying Hitler didn't use chemical weapons on his own people. Spicer made the comments during a press briefing, sparking outrage on social media and from Holocaust memorial groups. Spicer clarified that he was trying to draw a distinction between tactics, but his remarks were criticized for minimizing Hitler's crimes. Spicer apologized and said he was "insensitive" and "lacked integrity."

site_title: 'Stop staring,' says Caitlyn Jenner, announcing genital surgery
summary: Caitlyn Jenner, 67, has undergone genital surgery, two years after transitioning, to feel "not only wonderful but liberated." In her upcoming memoir, she wrote that the surgery was successful and relieved her of the need to constantly "tuck" her genital area. Jenner, a prominent American transgender woman, made the announcement in a leaked excerpt from her book "The Secrets Of My Life," stating she decided to go public to "stop staring."

site_title: NBA: LeBron to miss Cavaliers' season finale
summary: LeBron James will miss Cleveland's season finale against Toronto due to a calf strain, a decision made by coach Tyronn Lue to ensure the team's key players get rest before the playoffs. The Cavaliers are battling to regain the Eastern Conference's number one ranking, currently one game behind Boston, and Lue prioritized their health over securing the top spot. James' absence comes after he played 47 minutes in an overtime loss to Atlanta before missing Monday's game.

site_title: Wall St ends down; geopolitical risks weigh ahead of earnings
summary: US stocks ended down on Tuesday, closing near their day's lows due to geopolitical risks and investor concerns. Rising tensions between the US and Russia, Syria, and North Korea drove investors into safe-haven assets, while US corporate earnings reports begin this week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.03%, the S&P 500 lost 0.14%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.24%. Analysts expect strong corporate earnings to justify pricey valuations, but geopolitical risks may weigh on sentiment.

summary: Spanish international Marc Bartra underwent wrist surgery after being injured in a bus attack on April 11, 2017. The Borussia Dortmund team bus was rocked by three explosions, forcing the postponement of their Champions League match against Monaco. Bartra broke his right wrist and had foreign bodies in his arm, with his status upgraded from "lightly" to "badly injured". The team bus had strengthened glass in its windows, but the blasts still shattered several panes. The match was rescheduled for the return leg next Wednesday.

site_title: Centrist Macron, far-right Le Pen hold French election lead, but investors eye Melenchon surge
summary: French centrist Emmanuel Macron and far-right leader Marine Le Pen are leading in the presidential election, but the unpredictable outcome is pushing investors to consider a runoff between the two far-left and far-right candidates, Jean-Luc Melenchon and Le Pen. Melenchon has surged into the top four, threatening Macron's lead, and some pollsters are calculating extreme runoff scenarios. Macron leads in polls, but one in three voters remains undecided, making the outcome uncertain.

site_title: Football: Two-goal Dybala upstages Messi as Juventus thump Barcelona 3-0 in Champions League
summary: Juventus thrashed Barcelona 3-0 in the Champions League quarter-final first leg, with Argentine forward Paulo Dybala scoring two goals to outshine teammate Lionel Messi. Dybala's goals set the tone for Juventus' dominant performance, which saw Barcelona leak possession and struggle to cope with the pace of Mario Mandzukic and Juan Cuadrado. Giorgio Chiellini sealed the win with a third goal from a corner in the 55th minute, as Juventus took a significant step towards advancing to the semi-finals.

site_title: Gold jumps on geopolitical worries, bringing 2017 gains to 10%
summary: Gold prices surged 2% to a fresh five-month high on April 11, driven by geopolitical concerns over North Korea, the Middle East, and the looming French election. This brings the year-to-date gain to over 10%. Investors sought safe-haven assets, boosting demand for gold, while US Treasuries and the Japanese yen also gained. Despite some analysts warning that the rally may be unsustainable, gold prices remain high, with the spot gold price reaching US$1,275.16 per ounce.

site_title: Donald Trump approves Montenegro's membership in Nato - White House
summary: US President Donald Trump signed off on Montenegro's accession to Nato on April 11, removing a potential hurdle for the Balkan nation to become the alliance's 29th member. The decision further strains US relations with Russia, which has described Montenegro's accession as a "provocation." The move comes ahead of Trump's meeting with Nato Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg at the White House and ahead of the Nato summit in Brussels on May 25.

site_title: No charges expected for One Direction star Louis Tomlinson in LA airport scuffle
summary: One Direction singer Louis Tomlinson is not expected to be charged after a scuffle with a photographer at Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) on March 3. Tomlinson, 25, was booked for misdemeanor battery but will instead be summoned to the Los Angeles City Attorney's office for an interview and advice on avoiding similar incidents. The City Attorney's office reserves the right to file charges within a year, but typically does not take further action after a hearing. Tomlinson's lawyer previously claimed the singer was not at fault and that the paparazzi caused the altercation.

site_title: US investigating possible Russia collusion in Syria chemical attack
summary: The US is investigating possible Russia collusion in a suspected chemical attack by Syrian forces on civilians, with no determination yet made. A senior administration official questioned how Russian forces could be co-located with Syrian forces without knowing about the attack, suggesting it's a question worth asking the Russians. The US has seen the two militaries operate closely, but there's no consensus on the extent or interpretation of the information gathered.

site_title: Asian stocks mixed as flight to safety lifts yen, gold and bonds
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on April 12 as investors sought safety in the yen, gold, and bonds amid rising geopolitical tensions. Japan's Nikkei slid 1% and Asia-Pacific shares were near flat, while gold reached a five-month high of $1,275.66. North Korea warned of a nuclear attack on the US, and tensions escalated with US Navy ships in the western Pacific. The euro sank to its lowest in five months, and bonds saw their lowest yields of the year. Despite this, US stocks were relatively stable, with the Dow easing 0.03%.

summary: President Donald Trump announced plans to reduce and revamp Wall Street reform rules under Dodd-Frank, potentially eliminating and replacing them with "something else." Trump stated that his administration will streamline regulations and eliminate "wasteful" rules, with some remaining. The decision follows earlier reviews of major banking rules and a "major haircut" for regulations. Business leaders, including CEOs from major companies, attended a meeting with Trump, where he also reiterated criticism of the North Atlantic Free Trade Agreement.

site_title: Formula One: Sauber's Wehrlein fit for Bahrain
summary: Pascal Wehrlein, Sauber's German driver, is set to make his first appearance of the 2017 Formula One season at the Bahrain Grand Prix after missing the opening two races due to injury. Wehrlein had been struggling with fitness after a crash in January and had been linked with the vacant seat at Mercedes. He will replace Italian rookie Antonio Giovinazzi, who stood in for Wehrlein in the Australian and Shanghai Grands Prix. Practice for the Bahrain Grand Prix begins on Friday.

The measure frees up resources to fight the fires and aid affected residents. Weather forecasters predict a hotter and drier summer, which may worsen the situation. The state has already seen a 2.5 times increase in wildfires in the first three months of 2017 compared to last year.

site_title: Barcelona star Neymar banned for Clasico after sarcastic applause
summary: Barcelona star Neymar has been banned for three matches, including the highly anticipated Clasico against Real Madrid, after receiving a red card for two yellow cards and sarcastically applauding the fourth official. The Brazilian forward was dismissed for obstructing a Malaga free kick and committing a foul on Roberto Rosales. The three-match suspension will keep him out of the game against Real Sociedad on April 15, the Clasico on April 23, and Barcelona's home game against Osasuna on April 26.

site_title: New York raises to 18 criminal age of responsibility
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo signed a law raising the age of criminal responsibility to 18, making the state the last in the US to do so. The law, which will be phased in over two years, aims to end the automatic transfer of 16 and 17-year-olds to adult courts, reducing the disproportionate incarceration of minority youth. The move is expected to prevent 1,500 to 2,400 crimes annually and prioritize rehabilitation over punishment. Cuomo cited the need to treat young offenders as juveniles, rather than adults, to prevent lifelong consequences.

summary: Three blasts hit Borussia Dortmund's team bus, injuring Spanish player Marc Bartra, as it headed to a Champions League game against AS Monaco. The attack, which damaged the bus and shattered its rear window, was described by police as a "targeted attack." A letter claiming responsibility was found near the scene, but its authenticity is unclear. The match has been postponed, and the player is undergoing surgery on his right wrist. Police say there is currently no evidence of a threat to the visitors at the stadium, and the team is in a state of shock.

site_title: Football: Lewandowski in fitness race to face Real - Ancelotti
summary: Bayern Munich coach Carlo Ancelotti has expressed doubt about star striker Robert Lewandowski's fitness for the Champions League match against Real Madrid due to a bruised shoulder. Lewandowski only trained for 20 minutes on Tuesday after injuring his right shoulder during the team's 4-1 win over Borussia Dortmund. Ancelotti stated that Lewandowski will only play if he has no pain, and the team will prepare for both scenarios. If Lewandowski is out, Thomas Mueller is likely to replace him, and Bayern will be without injured defender Mats Hummels.

site_title: Sweden's girl with dragon tattoo returns in new thriller
summary: Sweden's Lisbeth Salander, created by Stieg Larsson, returns in "The Girl Who Takes An Eye For An Eye", a fifth thriller published globally on September 12. Written by David Lagercrantz, the book features the return of Salander and investigative journalist Mikael Blomkvist. The novel marks the fifth installment in the series, following the death of Larsson in 2004. With over 85 million copies sold worldwide, Larsson's books have popularized the Nordic noir genre, which also includes works by Henning Mankell and TV shows like The Killing and The Bridge.

site_title: Badminton: Olympic champs Tontowi Ahmad, Liliyana Natsir crash out of S'pore Open
summary: Olympic mixed doubles champions Tontowi Ahmad and Liliyana Natsir of Indonesia lost in the first round of the OUE Singapore Open to Thailand's Dechapol Puavaranukroh and Sapsiree Taerattanachai, 21-14, 21-16. Liliyana struggled with a knee injury, and the pair's communication was poor, leading to their early exit.

The airline has faced widespread criticism, and the incident has reignited discussions about airline policies and passenger treatment. The video has garnered millions of views and has become a symbol of the tension between airlines and passengers.

site_title: Alleged ISIS supporter attacks police station in Central Java
summary: A 22-year-old man, Mohammad Ibnu Dar, allegedly attacked police personnel at Banyumas Police headquarters in Central Java, injuring three officers. Dar broke through the front yard on a motorbike, wielding a short machete, and was subdued by police. He was identified through fingerprints and later revealed to have "ISIS attributes." Police are investigating the motive and possible terror network connections, with Dar's lack of identification and identity documents raising concerns. He has been taken into custody and questioned.

site_title: Man on United Airlines flight identified as Vietnamese-American doctor with troubled past: Reports
summary: A 69-year-old Vietnamese-American doctor, Dr. David Dao, was dragged off a United Airlines flight on April 9 due to an overbooking issue. Dao, a father of five and grandfather, has a troubled past with convictions for trading prescription drugs and obtaining drugs by fraud. Despite this, netizens have defended him, saying his past should not dictate his treatment. The incident sparked outrage and protests, with US Representative Jan Schakowsky calling for congressional hearings and legislation to bar headlines from removing seated passengers.

site_title: Rugby: World Cup winner Jason Robinson conducts clinic for S'pore youths
summary: Former Rugby World Cup winner Jason Robinson conducted a clinic for over 190 Singaporean youths at Yio Chu Kang Stadium, ahead of the HSBC Singapore Rugby Sevens. Robinson, a 2003 England team member, shared his expertise on skill-based drills and provided advice to the youngsters. Emphasizing the growth potential of Rugby Sevens, Robinson expressed his support for grassroots rugby. The HSBC Sevens Series Singapore will be held at the National Stadium this weekend, offering more information at www.singapore7s.sg.

site_title: Putin warns of chemical weapons 'provocations' to frame Syria's Assad
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin warned of future chemical weapons "provocations" in Syria to frame President Bashar al-Assad, amid heightened tensions with the US. Putin said Russia would appeal to the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons to investigate such incidents, amid reports of rebel fighters bringing poisonous substances to areas in Syria. The claims come as US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson visited Russia to discuss its support for Assad. Putin accused the US and its allies of portraying Russia and Syria as a "common enemy" to bring about cooperation.

site_title: Shellfish, seriously: Aussie runs into sea to avoid paying $650 seafood restaurant bill
summary: An Australian man, Terry Peck, ran into the sea to avoid paying a $650 bill at a seafood restaurant on Gold Coast. He ordered two lobsters, 21 oyster cocktails, and a baby octopus, totaling $621.30. Peck claimed he ran to help a friend in labor, but the restaurant manager denied this. Peck was charged with stealing and assaulting a police officer after being pursued on jet skis. He was granted bail and will return to court on May 4.

site_title: Researchers give voice to historic sounds of Stonehenge with new app
summary: Researchers at the University of Huddersfield developed an app that recreates the historic sounds of Stonehenge, allowing users to hear the prehistoric acoustics that swirled around the ancient monument over the last 5,000 years. The app, released this week, features an interactive soundscape of birds and wind moving through the stones, and provides insight into the surprisingly sonorous properties of the stones. The findings suggest that Stonehenge was not only a temple but also a unique acoustic environment, unlike any other human-made structure of its time.

site_title: The North Korea problem: Some key Q&A
summary: Tension on the Korean peninsula has escalated with North Korea's nuclear tests and ballistic missile launches. The country is thought to have 20 nuclear warheads and missiles capable of reaching South Korea and Japan. Despite economic sanctions and six-party talks, North Korea continues to develop nuclear weapons. The US and China are considering military action and sanctions, but a pre-emptive attack could be costly and lead to devastating conventional retaliation. Some analysts suggest accepting North Korea's nuclear weapons as a viable option, but others warn it could lead to a proliferation of nuclear arms in the region.

site_title: Football: Three out of four candidates win appeal to contest in FAS election
summary: Three out of four candidates who appealed to contest in the FAS election were successful, including former Fifa referee Lai Boon Teck, Hougang treasurer Jeffrey Sim, and independent candidate Kumar Appavoo. Suresh Nair, a refereeing instructor, was barred from contesting due to failing eligibility and integrity checks, specifically regarding past betting on local football. The final official list of candidates will be released 10 days prior to the April 29 polls, where 14 candidates will vie for six seats on the FAS council.

site_title: Two cases of locally transmitted Zika virus confirmed at Poh Huat Terrace/Terrasse Lane
summary: Two cases of locally transmitted Zika virus infection have been confirmed in Singapore at Poh Huat Terrace/Terrasse Lane, near Hougang. Both cases are residents in the area and the National Environment Agency (NEA) is conducting vector control operations and outreach efforts to raise awareness and prevent further transmission. Residents are urged to eliminate mosquito breeding habitats and take precautions, with inspections and indoor spraying of homes also being carried out. The situation highlights the risk of asymptomatic cases and the need for continued vigilance, with members of the public advised to seek medical attention if they experience symptoms.

site_title: Bicycle sharing in Singapore: Which is a ride above the rest?
summary: Singapore's bicycle-sharing scheme, operated by private companies oBike, oFo, and Mobike, continues despite scrapped national plans. The Straits Times tested the services, finding that oBike was the priciest at $1/half hour, while oFo and Mobike started at 50 cents. The size of the bike played a significant factor, with oBike's larger bicycles being more convenient. After testing all three, oBike emerged as the clear winner, offering a convenient and user-friendly experience. The scheme remains available to thousands of users, despite the scrapped national plans.

site_title: Thai junta lifts control on influential Dhammakaya temple
summary: Thailand's junta lifted restrictions on the Dhammakaya temple, ending a three-week standoff with police after the temple's former abbot, Phra Dhammachayo, was accused of money laundering. The temple, which claims millions of followers and is nearly 10 times the size of the Vatican City, had been declared a restricted area under Article 44 emergency law. The decision was made after police failed to find Phra Dhammachayo, who is also accused of taking over land without permission. The temple's senior monk expressed relief and gratitude for the improved situation, stating they would meet conditions set by the state and the Sangha council.

site_title: Thai political restrictions will not end quickly: PM Prayut
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha has stated that restrictions on political parties will remain in place until after the cremation of late King Bhumibol Adulyadej and the coronation of King Maha Vajiralongkorn, likely in October and later this year. The restrictions, imposed since the 2014 coup, will not be lifted until after these royal ceremonies, with no set date for a general election under the new military-backed constitution.

site_title: Record number of bids at Toh Tuck government land sale site
summary: A record 24 bids were submitted for a 99-year leasehold government land sale site at Toh Tuck Road, exceeding expectations. The top bid of $265 million came from Malaysian developer S P Setia International, translating to $939 per square foot per plot ratio. This price far surpasses estimates of $600 to $700 per square foot per plot ratio. The site is expected to yield 324 private homes.

site_title: GIC led wealth funds in sovereign investor deals in first quarter
summary: GIC led sovereign investor deals in the first quarter of 2017, totaling US$9 billion, with the Singaporean fund participating in 12 deals. Notable transactions include a US$1.9 billion deal for a stake in Spain's Allfunds Bank and a US$1.04 billion acquisition of 60 Wall Street in Manhattan. GIC also invested in student housing portfolios worth over US$1 billion, with the fund's chief investment officer citing opportunities in private equity, real estate, and infrastructure during market volatility.

site_title: Football: Manchester United must improve home form to finish in top four, says Juan Mata
summary: Manchester United midfielder Juan Mata emphasizes the need for improvement at home to secure a top-four finish in the Premier League. The team has won just six times at Old Trafford this season and trails fourth-place Manchester City by four points. Mata hopes to return from groin surgery soon and is optimistic about their chances, particularly in their upcoming match against Chelsea. A top-four finish will secure Champions League participation, while a Europa League win could also secure qualification. Mata believes converting draws into victories at home is crucial to achieving this goal.

site_title: United Continental tumbles, US stocks fall on uncertainty over Syria
summary: United Continental's stock tumbled 3.2% amid public outrage over the forcible removal of a passenger from a flight. The airline reported flat first-quarter revenue per seat mile, threatening to impact revenue in China. The controversy overshadowed US stocks, which fell early Tuesday due to uncertainty over Syria. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.3%, the S&P 500 fell 0.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.5%. Other stocks, including Qualcomm, also fell due to a countersuit against Apple.

site_title: China will get better US trade deal if it solves North Korea problem: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump told China's President Xi Jinping that Beijing would receive a better trade deal if it helps solve the US problem with North Korea. Trump stated this during a summit in Florida last week. China had previously agreed to end a 13-year ban on US beef, but purchases have yet to resume. Trump linked a trade deal to China's help in pressuring North Korea to halt its nuclear development, drawing criticism from Senator Charles Schumer. The two sides agreed to negotiate a 100-day plan to reduce China's massive trade surplus with the US.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust completes purchase of IT property in Hyderabad
summary: Ascendas India Trust completed the purchase of aVance 4, a 390,000 sq ft IT building in Hyderabad, India, for approximately $42.2 million. The building has a 80.4% leasing commitment with anchor tenants including IBM India and Sears IT & Management Services India. This is the fourth building acquired from Phoenix Infocity, increasing a-iTrust's total floor area to 11.5 million sq ft, with robust rental growth expected in Hyderabad due to demand from global IT companies.

site_title: Turkey health minister says tests confirm sarin used in attack on Syrian town
summary: Turkey's Health Minister Recep Akdag confirmed sarin gas was used in a suspected chemical attack in Syria's Idlib province, killing nearly 100 people, including children. Tests on victims identified isopropyl methylphosphonic acid, a byproduct of sarin, in their blood and urine. The US blames the Syrian government for the attack, while Damascus denies responsibility. The US launched missile strikes against a Syrian air base last week in response.

site_title: In Indonesia, pious 'punks' promote Islam
summary: Indonesia's first Islamic punk movement has gained popularity, with hundreds of members in Jakarta, Surabaya, and Bandung. The "Punk Muslim" group, founded by Ahmad Zaki, combines punk rock's anti-establishment ideology with Islamic values and social issues. Members, often with mohawks and leather jackets, sing about freedom for Palestine and Islamic values, seeking to redefine the punk genre as a positive force. The movement aims to redirect its fans towards a more pious path, with concerts ending in prayer and sermons. This phenomenon reflects Indonesia's moderate Muslim majority.

site_title: Crowdfunding platform MoolahSense launches invoice financing service
summary: MoolahSense, a Singapore-based crowdfunding platform, has launched an invoice financing service to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) raise short-term financing of over $15,000. The service allows SMEs to submit tax invoices to MoolahSense, which verifies them and provides up to 80% of the invoice amount as a loan. The tenure of the loan ranges from 15 to 90 days, with investors receiving returns in a relatively shorter period. The service aims to make business financing more inclusive for underserved SMEs, with plans to expand its operations and introduce new financing products in Southeast Asia.

site_title: US outdoor gear maker Osprey Packs axes Singaporean’s firm over dog abuse: Report
summary: Osprey Packs, a US outdoor gear maker, has dropped Terry Yee, a 30-year-old Singaporean, as its Malaysia distributor after he was caught on video abusing a dog. Yee had apologized for the incident, claiming he "snapped" after being attacked by the dog multiple times. Osprey vice-president Rob BonDurant stated the company opposes inhumane animal violence and has terminated its relationship with Yee's distributor, Tearproof Sdn Bhd. The case is under investigation by the Serdang police and the Department of Veterinary Services, with a new distributor to be appointed soon.

site_title: The Straits Times' News In A Minute: April 11, 2017
summary: DBS Singapore will roll out "soft" tokens to replace physical tokens by June 2018. Contraband cigarettes worth 322 cartons and 879 packets were seized at Woodlands Checkpoint. The Urban Redevelopment Authority seeks public feedback on improving connectivity along the Kallang River at seven areas.

site_title: ISIS now controls less than 7% of Iraq: Army
summary: ISIS controls less than 7% of Iraq, down from nearly 40% in 2014, according to a military spokesman. As of March 31, the group holds 6.8% of Iraqi territory, a significant decline in its territory. The decrease is attributed to the efforts of Iraqi forces battling Islamic State militants, particularly in western Mosul. This marks a major shift in the group's control, with less than 7% of the country under its influence.

site_title: $39m offer for Catalist-listed Imperium Crown's two Japanese properties
summary: Imperium Crown, a Catalist-listed property firm, has received letters of intent for its remaining two Japanese properties, valued at approximately $38.6 million, bringing the total sale price to $80.4 million. The sale will strengthen the company's cash and financial position, enabling it to pursue new projects in Australia and China. The company plans to use the funds to acquire stakes in projects in these markets, including a proposed acquisition in Western Australia and a stake in a Chinese historical park.

site_title: Burst water pipe in Aljunied affects 75 households, floods carpark
summary: A burst water pipe between two Housing Board blocks in Aljunied, Singapore, flooded a carpark and affected 75 households on April 10. The pipe burst at around 3am, causing muddy water to flood the area. Water agency PUB and the Marine Parade Town Council temporarily supplied alternative water to the affected households, with repairs completed and the water supply fully restored by 3:30pm.

site_title: US sees no place for Assad in Syria future: Tillerson
summary: The US sees no place for Syrian President Bashar al-Assad in any future peace resolution for Syria, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said during the G7 meeting in Italy. The US hopes Russia will abandon its support for Assad, citing last week's chemical attack as stripping him of legitimacy. The G7 agreed that no future in Syria is possible with Assad, with French Foreign Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault stating that Russia must return to the political process. The US remains focused on defeating ISIS and will continue to evaluate its strategic options to de-escalate violence in Syria.

site_title: Singapore Red Cross sends aid to East African drought victims
summary: The Singapore Red Cross has contributed $85,000 in relief to Kenya, Ethiopia, and Somalia in response to severe drought affecting millions of people in the Horn of Africa. The funds will support food security and livelihood initiatives, procuring food and hygiene supplies, and aid an estimated 1.45 million people. The relief efforts aim to address health, water, sanitation, and hygiene, nutrition, and food security issues, exacerbated by desertification, land degradation, and climate change, which have been worsening for three consecutive years, according to the United Nations.

site_title: Start of works for North-South Corridor delayed to 2018
summary: The construction of the 21.5km North-South Corridor in Singapore has been delayed to 2018, with works starting slightly later than initially planned. The corridor, which will connect northern towns to the city, was reconfigured to include dedicated bus lanes and cycling trunk routes. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has called a tender for the first civil contract and aims to maintain its 2026 completion date. The completed corridor is expected to shorten bus journeys to the city by up to 30 minutes, improving travel times for passengers from northern towns.

site_title: Russia, before envoy Tillerson's visit, says worried US may attack North Korea
summary: Russia expressed concern that the US may unilaterally attack North Korea during US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson's visit to Moscow. Russia is worried about the implications of such an action, particularly given North Korea's nuclear capabilities and the country's role in the UN. The US Navy is reportedly steaming towards the western Pacific as a show of force, further escalating tensions. Russia hopes for productive talks with the US, but is also concerned about US foreign policy on Libya, Yemen, and Syria, and is calling for an international investigation into the nerve gas attack in Syria.

site_title: An asparagus pesto pasta that sings of spring
summary: A seasonal pasta recipe from Alice Hart's book "Good Veg" celebrates the arrival of asparagus in spring. The dish combines blanched asparagus with a vibrant pesto made from basil, garlic, and lemon, served atop whole-wheat penne pasta and white beans. The recipe, which yields 6 servings, is a fine way to welcome asparagus to the table throughout the spring season.

site_title: Poly lecturer admits to inciting violence online
summary: A Singapore Polytechnic lecturer, Tang Koon Huat, 63, pleaded guilty to inciting violence online after creating a Facebook page calling for a vigilante group to "beat up" Caucasians in drinking joints. Tang, who retired in 2016, used the page "Act for Singapore" to post racially offensive terms and advocated for violence against foreigners. He was given a fine for punching a teen driver in a road rage incident, which sparked his online call for violence. Tang faces a non-custodial sentence and up to three months' jail for the offence.

site_title: Growing risk of 'mass' starvation deaths in Africa: UN
summary: The UN warned that the risk of "mass" starvation deaths is growing in conflict and drought-hit areas of Africa, Yemen, and Nigeria. A severe funding shortfall has led to an avoidable humanitarian crisis, with the potential to be worse than the 2011 Horn of Africa drought that killed 260,000 people. The Horn of Africa, Yemen, and Nigeria are particularly at risk due to drought and conflict.

site_title: 82-year-old DJ thrills crowds on Tokyo's club scene
summary: An 82-year-old Japanese woman, Sumiko Iwamuro, is making waves on Tokyo's club scene under the moniker DJ Sumirock. By day, she runs a Chinese restaurant, and by night, she spins techno and jazz records at clubs in the Shinjuku district. Despite being 60 years younger than her audience, Iwamuro's energy and passion for music have won over club-goers. A self-taught DJ who learned in her 70s, Iwamuro hopes to debut on the New York club scene one day, saying her goal is for her audience to enjoy themselves.

site_title: Samsung launches new 4K TVs
summary: Samsung has announced the pricing and availability of its new 4K TVs, starting from May 1. The flagship Q9F Qled 65-inch TV will be priced at $8,999, while the next tier of Qled TVs, Q8C series, starts from $5,199. The Qled TVs use quantum-dot technology to produce bright and vibrant images, meeting the Ultra HD Premium standard for 4K HDR performance. Samsung also offers two new stands and a soundbar with an embedded subwoofer, with prices starting at $3,099 for the MU8000 series of premium UHD TVs.

site_title: Tennis: Age no object as German veteran Haas downs teenager Opelka in Houston
summary: German tennis veteran Tommy Haas, 39, defeated 19-year-old Reilly Opelka in the first round of the Houston ATP clay-court tournament, 7-6 (7-5), 4-6, 6-3. Haas, a former world No. 2, credited his experience for the win, saying nerves can't be practiced. He'll face top-seeded American Jack Sock in the second round, looking to upset him. Haas, semi-retired from the tour, aims to recover well and be ready for the next match, saying he plays to win and doesn't see the point of anything less.

site_title: Thai junta rejects conditional peace talks with Muslim insurgents
summary: Thailand's military junta rejected a conditional offer from the main Muslim separatist group, Barisan Revolusi Nasional (BRN), to enter into formal peace talks. The BRN proposed mediation by a neutral third party and international observers, but Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha deemed it unnecessary. The insurgency in southern Thailand, which has claimed over 6,500 lives since 2004, is expected to continue. Experts say the junta's decision may hinder lasting peace in the region, emphasizing the need for BRN's inclusion in negotiations.

site_title: Cheat jailed 16 months after pocketing money from sale of 'discounted' Apple products
summary: Theresa Tan, 47, was sentenced to 16 months' jail for cheating four victims of $13,075. She deceived them into believing she had discounted Apple products for sale, collecting over $13,000 in deposits. Tan admitted to four of 10 charges and has made partial restitution of $1,950 to two victims. Her lawyer cited financial stress as a motivation, but Tan has prior property-related convictions, including cheating in 2015. The sentence was backdated to November 21, 2016.

site_title: Hong Kong's MTR may face HK$3m fine after breakdown that affected 10,000 commuters
summary: Hong Kong's Mass Transit Railway (MTR) may face a fine of up to HK$3 million after a two-and-a-half-hour breakdown on Monday evening affected 10,000 commuters. The power fault occurred near Kowloon Bay Station, trapping an estimated 2,000 commuters and causing eight people to faint. MTR provided over 90 bridging bus services, ferrying 5,000 commuters. The fine could be imposed if the operator fails to modify its service recovery measures, according to Legislative Council Chairman Michael Tien Puk Sun.

site_title: No Internet, phone calls for some in Jurong West area due to cut cable
summary: A cut cable in the Jurong West area of Singapore affected internet, phone, and TV services for over 3,500 users, with disruptions starting at 4:30pm on April 11, 2017. NetLink Trust, the fibre network operator, identified the affected cables and deployed recovery teams to rectify the issue, with services expected to be restored by 4am the next morning. The outage was caused by a third-party contractor carrying out sheet piling works, and the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) monitored the situation closely to minimize inconvenience to affected customers.

site_title: Figure skating: Japan's Mao Asada retiring as she has lost will to compete and is unable to regain top form
summary: Japanese figure skater Mao Asada is retiring due to a loss of will to compete, citing knee pain and disappointment with her performance. The 26-year-old, a three-time world champion and silver medalist from the 2010 Winter Olympics, announced her retirement on her blog after a disappointing season, including a 12th-place finish at the national championships. Asada, known for her triple Axel jump, expressed no regrets over her skating career and plans to find new goals and dreams.

site_title: Huge fire destroys French migrant camp housing 1,500 people
summary: A massive fire destroyed the Grande-Synthe migrant camp in northern France, home to 1,500 people, on April 10, 2017. The blaze, sparked by a brawl involving hundreds of Afghans and Kurds, left only 70 out of 300 huts and communal buildings intact. At least 10 people were injured, and six had knife wounds. The camp, built by MSF, was a magnet for refugees and migrants trying to reach Britain, causing tension with the UK. The incident is the latest in a spate of violent incidents at the camp, which the French government had planned to close in March due to public order problems.

site_title: Painted Thai elephants spray tourists with water to banish bad luck
summary: Colourfully painted Thai elephants in Ayutthaya sprayed tourists with water on April 11, 2017, as part of the country's traditional New Year festivities, known as the Songkran festival. The water fight is meant to banish bad luck and usher in prosperity. The event, which marks the start of the three-day water festival, has become a popular tourist attraction, with foreigners and locals alike participating in the fun. site_title: Toshiba warns over its ability to survive as it releases delayed earnings
summary: Toshiba, Japan's 142-year-old conglomerate, warned it may not be able to continue as a going concern due to billions of dollars in losses from its Westinghouse Electric nuclear business. The company reported a 576.3 billion yen operating loss for the third quarter and negative shareholders equity of 225.6 billion yen. Toshiba's inability to report earnings has raised speculation of a possible delisting from the Tokyo Stock Exchange, with shares already 20% lower this year. The company faces a deadline to improve internal controls and faces delisting if deemed insufficient, with a potential demotion to the second section of the exchange if the situation persists.
